Headline Text: LETTERS - Gun debate back in our sights
Article Text:
Where fault lies
Regarding the "Collateral damage" editorial (Page B8, Thursday), of the nine paragraphs devoted to the anti-gun piece, one single sentence stands out to expose your hypocrisy and answer the opening question, "Why did Chris die?" Buried in the middle of the piece, probably hoping no one would notice, is this: "And yes, he killed with knives as well as guns." There you have it, right in front of you, but the choice to politicize tragedy in order to promote an agenda seems to trump the truth these days.
Chris died, not because of " craven, irresponsible politicians and the NRA." He died because a deranged criminal chose to violate the most sacrosanct tenet of civil society by committing murder. To be brutally frank, this tragedy has nothing to do with either the NRA or craven politicians. If you choose not to believe me, then ask the families of the three souls stabbed to death.
Lionel J. Rotelli Jr., Conroe Solutions?
Reading the headline about needing to change America's gun culture, I was intrigued. Much of the gun violence occurs where the gun laws are the most strict, as in Chicago. Some of the recent dead were killed with a knife and there have been some mass stabbings as well. So, I assumed that the editorial was going to discuss solutions to reduce the exposure to guns such as eliminating all movies, TV shows, video games, newspapers and books that include guns. While we are at it, we should do the same with knives.
Unfortunately, such a solution would violate our beloved First Amendment. We should never allow that, but it is politically correct to consider the same for the hated Second Amendment.
Pat Wetuski, Kingwood More study
Your editorial, once again, made me proud to be a subscriber. Please do not stop. Your point about the law change in Australia was extremely valid but please elaborate in more detail. If necessary, go country by country, to drive the point home. Please analyze every aspect of this American phenomenon: Cultural leanings, NRA's self-interest, mentally imbalanced individuals, type of heavy machines, etc.
After a lengthy and detailed study, you would know that you have accomplished something for the city of Houston and perhaps, if copied by others, the country.
Kamran Nasr, Houston ...
Care about victims
Regarding "Tax-collection vendors tied to lawmakers, officials (Page B1, Monday), I am concerned when large law firms involved in the collection of delinquent taxes can influence the process by hiring attorneys who also serve as state legislators. I am just as concerned when these same law firms can influence the news coverage by hiring media people to serve as spokespersons. Overall, the names listed in this article were a who's-who of local government, with everyone using their connections to get in on lucrative government contracts. In this case, it was mostly Democrats, but that's only because the Republicans have a different group of backers - homebuilders, oil and gas - making sure their financial needs are met.
As a citizen, you're left to wonder if there's anyone left who could be considered clean. Matthew Bradley, Spring
Rights of all
Regarding "Council approves extension of rights protection to gays" (Page A1, Thursday), David Welch of the Houston Area Pastors Council believes the Houston City Council catered to a "tiny interest group ... instead of serving the people" of Houston by passing the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance.
I'm amazed he thinks the only ones concerned for the civil liberties of the LGBT community are members of that community alone. If we are not concerned about the civil liberties of everyone, everyone's liberties are at risk.
To deny housing, employment or equal protection under the law because of sexual orientation defies logic, ethics and the U.S. Constitution.
The Houston City Council did serve the people when they chose to protect the rights of all.
Martha Nelson, Houston
Explaining the VA
Regarding "VA staff alleged to have altered records" (Page A1, Sunday), I am a vet in the system and this is an attempt to explain the current system.
Imagine Houston with only one hospital and only six primary-care doctors, and their offices are in the hospital. All imaging and testing is in the hospital, as well.
Try to get an appointment in that system, or a parking space. Try to fight the traffic.
The medical staff is not the problem. I have always been treated with the utmost respect and caring. Increased capacity is the expensive answer, and that can only be solved by Congress.
David Koger, Rosenberg Tell the stories
Regarding Joe Holley's column "WWII veterans silent but not forgotten" (Page B1, Sunday), the article really struck a chord with me. I'm a 55-year-old white female and, though no one in my immediate family served during World War II, it is one of my favorite periods of history.
My deceased husband had three uncles in the war, two who died in the D-Day invasion. The third uncle did make it home from the Pacific theatre, but with a permanent injury. My current husband's parents both served during WWII, which is how they met. Hubby's maternal uncle also served in WWII as a pilot.
So, please tell Cousin Bob that he must tell his story. Not only for himself but for all the young American men and women who died preserving the freedom we as U.S. citizens enjoy.
If those courageous young people had not stepped up to the line, where would the world be? I hope and pray you hear from many more readers saying the same thing: that Cousin Bob is wrong, people do care and want to hear the stories.

Headline Text: Council approves extension of rights protection to gays - Mayor hails vote, but opponents vow to force recalls, referendum
Article Text:
After nearly nine hours of discussion, punctuated by opponents chanting outside City Hall and by emotional supporters' personal stories of discrimination, the Houston City Council on Wednesday passed an ordinance extending equal rights protections to gay and transgender residents.
Public dissension has persisted for weeks, but the final vote was 11-6, a count that matched guesses made months ago when Mayor Annise Parker - the first openly gay mayor of a major U.S. city - said she planned to bring the measure forward.
The approval was greeted with applause from the audience, largely full of supporters by the time of the vote, and chants of "HERO," for the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance.
Opponents vow to gather the signatures needed to trigger a referendum to repeal the law this November, and others say they plan to seek recall elections against some council members who supported the measure.
Reflecting after the vote, Parker mentioned her son, who is gay and black, and her daughters, who are biracial.
"This is not the most important thing I have done or will do as mayor, but it is the most personally satisfying and most personally meaningful thing I will do as mayor - not just for myself, but for my children and for all the other mothers' children out there who have an opportunity to have redress if they are discriminated against here in the city of Houston," the mayor said.
The measure bans discrimination based not just on sexual orientation and gender identity but also, as federal laws do, sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information, as well as family, marital or military status.
The ordinance applies to businesses that serve the public, private employers, housing, city employment and city contracting. Religious institutions are exempt. Violators could be fined up to $5,000.
Council members Brenda Stardig, Dwight Boykins, Dave Martin, Oliver Pennington, Michael Kubosh and Jack Christie voted no, saying either that they must represent their constituents or that they had been left out of the drafting process.
"I want to represent all the city of Houston," Kubosh said, "but I have a problem voting against what I feel like the majority of the city of Houston voters are asking me to do."
Marathon testimony
In the marathon testimony - the speakers list was the longest City Secretary Anna Russell could recall, and she has worked for the city for six decades - supporters stressed that the eyes of the world and of companies deciding whether to relocate to Houston were watching the vote, just as opponents invoked the gaze of God and of vengeful voters in next year's municipal elections - or at the ballot box this fall.
Opponent Dave Welch, of the Houston Area Pastors Council, said his group will begin gathering signatures against the ordinance to trigger a referendum seeking its repeal this November. The group would need to gather roughly 17,000 signatures - or 10 percent of turnout in last fall's mayoral race - in the next 30 days.
"Once we correct this grievous act through the ballot this fall," Welch said in a statement, "we will then remind those members that patronizing a tiny interest group and outgoing mayor instead of serving the people leads to a short political career." Parker said she would encourage those desiring repeal to respect the will of the City Council.
"The idea that we might possibly have a vote in November on whether or not the city of Houston should discriminate, I think, would be unfortunate," Parker said, "but they have the right to do that."
Houston voters twice have rejected protections or benefits for gays, in 1985 and in 2001.
The most recent vote was spearheaded by Houston Community College trustee and longtime anti-gay advocate Dave Wilson, who said he plans to gather signatures to seek a recall election against "three or four" council members who voted yes.
Only the number of signatures equivalent to one-quarter of the votes cast for mayor in a given council district are required, which Wilson said makes some districts with poor turnout particularly ripe targets.
The signatures must be gathered within a 30-day period and a recall petition must list grounds related to "incompetence, misconduct, malfeasance or unfitness for office." The target of such a petition could then object, triggering a vote of the City Council on whether the grounds are sufficient. City Attorney David Feldman said the city's 100-year-old recall process has never been used, and added a single ordinance vote would not be valid grounds.
"Some people say it's intimidation, et cetera, but I look at it as accountability," Wilson said, adding he views Feldman as a biased source. "People are elected to represent their district. They're not up there to propagate their own personal views."
Wilson said he also is gathering the signatures needed to seek a charter amendment banning a biological man from using a women's restroom. The ordinance passed Wednesday offers such a protection for transgender residents citywide, as does an executive order Parker signed in 2010 applying to city facilities.
Charter vote
The earliest a charter vote could appear would be May 2015, but Feldman said such an effort may be too relevant to the ordinance passed Wednesday, meaning the signatures gathered would need to fall within the 30-day window.
Councilman Jerry Davis referenced public backlash in explaining his support for the ordinance, invoking his daughters and his 9- year-old son.
"He probably will go through some of the same discriminatory practices that have been acted out on me, and I want a better city for him," said Davis, who is black and has shared his own experiences of discrimination. "For those out there going around threatening me as it relates to, 'We won't vote for you,' that's fine, if that's the way you choose to feel. I won't be bothered by idle threats."
#HERO New Houston equal rights ordinance gives local protection, for the first time, against discrimination on race/gender/religion/etc.-A
#HERO Petition may force repeal election, but Houston won't vote for discrimination. This protects vets/seniors/disabled/etc. Right thing.-A
#HERO Opponents will ignore that this ordinance protects on > a dozen different characteristics and pretend it is only about GLBTs.-A
#HERO New Houston equal rights ordinance gives local protection, for the first time, against discrimination on race/gender/religion/etc.-A
Signing Houston's first comprehensive equal rights ordinance! It protects us all.-A
Thanks to my exec team (pictured), CM Cohen and CM Laster for the heavy lifting on #HERO.-A http://houstontx.gov/mayor/images/mayorstaff-2014april-large.jpg
Proud of Houston for passing an inclusive equal rights ordinance to ensure the #LGBT community and all Texans are treated fairly. #HERO
Proud of Houston for passing an inclusive equal rights ordinance to ensure the #LGBT community and all Texans are treated fairly. #HERO

Headline Text: CITY HALL - Equal rights, unequal reactions - Compromise suggested for city ordinance not enough for some GOP, faith leaders
Article Text:
Mayor Annise Parker and supporters of her proposed nondiscrimination ordinance announced a compromise Tuesday in hopes of quelling a chorus of opposition from religious and conservative leaders who are against the city offering equal rights protections to gay, lesbian and transgender individuals.
It did not work, as more than 300 protesters gathered with clergy members and conservative activists outside City Hall an hour later to denounce the proposed ordinance as providing "an opportunity for sexual predators to have access to our families."
Most of the heated opposition stemmed from one paragraph in the 35-page proposal specifying that no business open to the public could deny a transgender person entry to a restroom consistent with his or her gender identity.
Council member Jerry Davis said he simply will ask his colleagues to remove it at Wednesday's council meeting. He said the compromise now makes him comfortable supporting the ordinance, adding to the tally of council members Parker can rely on when the item reaches a vote.
"We believe this will end some of the confusion," Davis said.
Republican political leaders and some clergy members have used the provision to dub the measure "Parker's Sexual Predator Protection Act," suggesting it would allow people to lie about their gender to enter bathrooms where they could attack women and children.
Members of the gay, lesbian and transgender community were equally outraged that the provision would give businesses an out if they had a "good faith belief" that the person's claim of being transgender was disingenuous.
Maverick Welsh, president of the GLBT Political Caucus, stood with the mayor, Davis and religious and Democratic leaders to welcome the compromise.
"The ordinance will still protect transgender people," Welsh said. "Discrimination is discrimination - whether it's a restroom, at a job, or somewhere else."
Transgender people barred access to a restroom still would be able to file a discrimination complaint with the city's Office of Inspector General under the process outlined for all protected characteristics, such as race and veteran status.
Coalition of support
A coalition of 70 faith leaders wrote a letter supporting the ordinance and proposed compromise. Houston civil rights leader and Baptist minister Bill Lawson joined some of them at Tuesday's announcement, as did state Rep. Sylvester Turner and state Sen. Rodney Ellis, both Democrats of Houston.
"The base ordinance is still the same," Parker said. "It says you can't discriminate." The proposed measure would ban discrimination based on sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, family status, marital status, military status, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information, as federal laws do, and also would cover sexual orientation and gender identity.
Labeled 'smokescreen'
As drafted, it would extend to businesses with 50 or more workers, businesses that serve the public, housing, city employment and city contracting; religious institutions would be exempt. Violations would be civil misdemeanors, with fines capped at $5,000.
Council members offered a dozen amendments last week.
Some would tweak the provision Davis and the mayor now want to remove. Others want to expand the ordinance's reach by including businesses with more than 15 employees rather than 50.
Oliver Pennington, among other suggestions, is seeking to exempt all private businesses and some single-family home rentals or sales.
Most of the clergy members and GOP political leaders who rallied protesters Tuesday outside City Hall condemned the compromise as a "smokescreen."
"The real persons that are being discriminated against are standing here!" shouted the Rev. Max Miller, president of the Baptist Ministers Association of Houston and Vicinity.
Children's safety cited
People cheered and waved Bibles as Miller and others argued the ordinance would restrict religious liberty, harm businesses and, even with the compromise, put children using public bathrooms at risk from sexual predators.
The Rev. F.M. Williams Sr. said the ordinance "is not about civil rights. It's about immoral rights." He held up a Bible and said, "My contract says homosexuality is an abomination to God."
State Rep. Dwayne Bohac, D-Houston, said he "profoundly disagrees" with the proposal, in part, because the religious exemption does not extend to business owners who would deny service because of personal beliefs, such as a florist refusing to provide flowers for a same-sex wedding. Bohac signed a letter of opposition with Houston-area Republican Reps. Bill Callegari, Allen Fletcher and Debbie Riddle.
Pledge to repeal
The Rev. Willie Davis lamented that the ordinance had divided Houston.
"We're here to unite the city," he said, gesturing to the crowd behind him.
The debate continued into the early evening at the City Council's public comment session, with more than 200 people signed up to speak.
Opponents said that if the council approves the ordinance, they will seek a ballot initiative to repeal it and remember it come election time.
Anna Eastman, a Houston Independent School District board member, said HISD already has an anti-discrimination policy that covers the same characteristics and includes ensuring bathroom access for transgender people.
"We have not seen the problems people fear," she said.

Magnet benefits
Regarding "HISD looks at boosting pay of new teachers" (Page B2, April 25), as a firm believer in the effectiveness of learning by doing and place-based education, I was disappointed to learn of HISD's proposal to terminate their fifth-grade Outdoor Education Center (OEC) magnet program.
Every week during the school year the four-decade-old OEC program takes fifth-grade students from elementary schools across HISD to camp facilities two hours north of Houston and teaches them about science, nature, report writing and other outdoor educational activities for four days and three nights.
The OEC program gets students excited about learning. By literally getting their hands dirty, maybe in the lake or in the garden, and doing things themselves, the students discover that learning can be more than just a classroom exercise. For many of the students the OEC program may be the first time that they have been outside of Houston, and it also may be the first time they have been away from their parents or guardians for an extended period. They gain valuable self- confidence from this.
HISD has been at the leading edge of public education with its magnet programs, and the OEC has provided generations of Houston students with a unique, memorable and horizon-expanding educational experience. I urge HISD not to shut down the OEC.
David Wood, Houston Life learning
Regarding "HISD teacher suit could impact nation" (Page A1, Friday), I strongly believe that the evaluation of teachers should not be based primarily on the student's test scores, especially if society itself has pushed and allowed students to get away with misbehavior and disrespectful attitude toward them.
For as much passion that a teacher has toward his or her profession, if the students do not wish to learn and do their best in school, it is not the fault of the educators.
It is also unfortunate that some students don't want to attend school because that attitude affects those who genuinely want to learn. A classroom should be a place to continue learning for students and school faculty; it should not feel like a battle between those who behave and those who disrupt education. If the overall evaluation depends on the ambition and success of the students, there is just so much a teacher can achieve.
Instead of looking at the scores and evaluating school professionals through this, we should look at our children and determine why they get the grades they get, then promote education as a way of life.
Ana K. Kiaz, Hitchcock Teacher pay
Rather than issue a memo or press release full of platitudes for Teacher Appreciation Week (May 5-9), HISD should demonstrate its commitment to teachers by developing a teacher evaluation and compensation system that recognizes and supports them as the professionals they are. This would include a salary scale and structure that encourages the best and brightest new teachers to apply to HISD and our experienced teachers to stay in HISD rather than flee to suburban districts with higher and more stable salaries and less challenging students.
It would also include an evaluation system based on administrator observation and feedback on actual teaching throughout the year rather than the test scores of students on a single day, a practice that has been shown to be inaccurate, inconsistent and especially unfair to the teachers of our most challenging students.
We need practices that build professional learning communities in our schools, not practices that promote constant turnover, competition, fear and flight.
Debora Banner, Houston
...
Needed measure
Regarding "Houston Partnership backs equal-rights measure" (Page B1, Wednesday), I know people who have been fired because they are gay. In fact, one of my students just got fired about a month ago because she advocated for the gay community.
While other identities are protected, many of which are protected at the federal level, sexual orientation, gender identity and expression are not protected at the federal, state or local level. That is why we need the Houston equal-rights ordinance.
Maria Gonzalez, posted on HoustonChronicle.com Don't blame the GOP
Regarding "Surge of Latino voters stagnates under state GOP's policies" (Page B13, April 27), Latinos should look beyond the Democratic Party and stop blaming Republican Party policies for lower voter turnouts.
Rep. Trey Martinez Fischer, D-San Antonio, makes a lot of statements about what troubles the Latino Texan, but fails to provide one single solution, other than more government involvement in our lives.
The absurdity that the GOP wants to keep Latinos uneducated, in bad health and poor is laughable. Nothing is farther from the truth. By making that statement he endorses the Democratic Party as the panacea for what troubles Latinos.
He cites that Texas government has been controlled by the GOP since 1994 and that that is the root cause for all our problems. That is pure nonsense.
For the record, the Democratic Party had a majority in both houses of the Legislature, the Supreme Court and the governor's mansion for 88 years of the 100 years of the 20th century. The same injustices Martinez Fischer is now laying at the feet of the GOP could have been easily addressed and corrected by the Democrats during that long period.
Martinez Fischer is a member of the Texas Legislature. He does not mention his party's failure of Latinos but now conveniently singles out the GOP as the root cause for what ails Latinos.
During those 88 years, we have had low high-school graduation levels, high unemployment, poor-paying jobs, low voter turnout and many other issues. These problems are not a new phenomenon.
I will offer suggestions to improve our lot: Stop the constant whining. Get an education. Get off the couch and vote. The opportunities are there. Take them.
Mike Gonzales, Houston

appreciate Houston's premier business group @GHPartnership
 for their support of my proposed Equal Rights Ordinance. Reflects who we are.-A

It‚Äôs not difficult to imagine how disappointed Nathan Mathis must have been last week when the Alabama Democratic Party blocked his access to its ticket in his run for the District 29 state senate seat.
‚ÄúThey said they had some kind of rule,‚Äù Mathis told the Eagle later. ‚ÄúYou and I would call it a ‚Äòcome and kiss the ring‚Äô rule.‚Äù
Having served as a Democrat over the majority of his long political career ‚Äì he‚Äôs served on the county commission and spent several terms in the state House of Representatives ‚Äì Mathis mounted a campaign for Houston County Commission in 2012 as a Republican, as the race would be decided in the GOP primary.
Considering that in Alabama the GOP was the outlier party until after 1986, when Guy Hunt became the first Republican governor since Reconstruction, the current political climate suggests that running as a Democrat would hobble a middle-of-the-road conservative. After all, no Democrats hold statewide office in Alabama today.
However, political parties control their ballots and the state Democrats are well within their rights to deny Mathis for his turn as a Republican just as the GOP stripped incumbent Sen. Harri Anne Smith of her Republican label for having supported then- Congressman Bobby Bright, a Democrat, over Republican Jay Love, who defeated her in an acrimonious party primary for the same seat.
Perhaps party committees have too much control over the electoral process when they can hamstring long-serving candidates like Mathis and Smith should they choose strategy or conscience over blind loyalty. Then again, the parties operate their own primaries, and candidates are well aware of the bylaws and the consequences of breaking them.
Ultimately, elections are decided by voters. A hopeful candidate without party backing can, with some added difficulty, proceed as an independent. And it‚Äôs possible to win without major party backing, as Smith proved following her exile from the GOP fold.
Houston Equal Rights Ordinance quietly being implemented. Don't listen to opponent's lies, read it yourself.-A

Headline Text: Commentary - Weighing difference between 'No limits' and 'Without limits'
Article Text:
In 1975, NBC, the television network, spent $1 million on designing a new logo.
It was nothing fancy, just a big capital "N."
Hard to believe NBC spent that much on a letter that's worth only one point in Scrabble.
A new logo is a huge deal to a major corporation.
Turns out, NBC's new logo was virtually identical to the logo used by Nebraska's PBS stations.
Naturally, Nebraska PBS sued NBC. When the dust - and an out-of-court settlement - cleared, NBC gave Nebraska PBS about $800,000 worth of new equipment.
Let's cut NBC some slack - 1976 was pre-Internet. The network couldn't do a Google search and see that its new logo was already somebody's old logo.
Here comes the Greater Houston Partnership's new image campaign for Houston - with the slogan "Houston: The City With No Limits," a splashy video with the theme song "Best Day of My Life" and an optical-illusion logo. Concentrate, squint ... there it is, the letter H!
The partnership took more than a year to develop this campaign, with input from the mayor's office, the Greater Houston Convention and Visitors Bureau, multinational corporations, community leaders and local chambers of commerce. Two Texas marketing agencies "conducted extensive market and brand research, created the brand architecture and developed the creative elements."
I wonder if they Googled to see if another city already was using the "no limits" bit. Danger, Will Robinson!
Killeen adopted the slogan "A City Without Limits" in 2004. (The home to Fort Hood added a second slogan, "Where Freedom Grows," in 2008.)
"No Limits" ... "Without Limits" ... as children say, same difference.
And the song, "Best Day of My Life" is featured in TV commercials for Lowe's home handyman stores.
Maybe we should be thankful that the Greater Houston Partnership didn't decide to call Houston ... "Bean City" or "The Large Easy." Or pick "I Wish I Was an Oscar Meyer Weiner" for our theme song.
Thursday mail delivery
Did you notice that the "H" in our new "City With No Limits" is made up entirely of negative space? In the graphic design world, negative space is the white space where no color or design is present. Subtext: Houston: Limitless negative space. Maybe that Austin creative firm just stared out of the window while they were stuck in traffic, sweating to death. Laughing with you. John LaCarter, Houston
I don't understand the need to sell Houston. There are already more people than the roads can handle. When is enough, enough? We are busting at the seams. I am glad there are people willing to shovel snow. We are full! I prefer the message be "Houston is a mosquito-infested swamp. Stay where you are!" Regards,
Patrick Haussler, Houston
The Greater Houston Partnership's campaign hopes to lure businesses to move here and convince young professionals to live here. Houston needs more people and a greater tax base so it can raise money to fill potholes and repair streets ... which are already clogged, and more businesses and people will clog them even more.
As Jerry Seinfeld says, good luck with all that.
I don't know what the attendance was at the Art Car Parade, but you can't compare it to the Thanksgiving Day parade. People lined the streets from Waugh, through downtown, and back. Maybe the guy operating the drone could make a guess.
Have you ridden in one of the cars before? It is astounding. You are welcome to ride in my car at the parade next year. It's called Texas Natives.
Chris Greene, Houston
I wasn't knocking the Art Car Parade. I just rolled my eyes at organizers claiming that 315,000 people attended. I like and support the event.
And I'll take you up on that offer to ride in your car next year. But 315,000 is just a ridiculous figure.
Also, it's a city regulation that event organizers must provide one portable toilet for every 300 people they expect.
Did you see 1,000 port-o-potties downtown that day?
Continuing to allow folks to judge #HERO for themselves  http://houstontx.gov/equal_rights_ordinance.pdf  Text starts on page 6. Gee, bathrooms not even mentioned!-A

.@markaudacity
 #HERO is on first page of website under "city headlines", not on the "ordinance feedback" page. Just checked it.-A
I leave the really stupid things people say about #HERO on my feed so that other people can see the REALLY stupid things that people say.-A
Once more: #HERO doesn't require unisex bathrooms. It's still illegal for a man to enter a women's bathroom or locker room. Read it & see.-A
Eye roll at myths on #HERO. Covers 14 characteristics: race, vet, etc. Doesn't mandate unisex toilets or let men into women's bathrooms.-A

Headline Text: OPERA America Welcomes Seven New Members to Its Board of Directors and Re-Elects Six Current Members
Article Text:
NEW YORK, July 21 -- OPERA America issued the following news release:
OPERA America, the national nonprofit service organization for opera, is pleased to announce that seven new members have been elected to its Board of Directors. Elections were held during OPERA America's recent Annual Business Meeting at Opera Conference 2014 in San Francisco, CA.
Serving first terms are Emilie Roy Corey (trustee, National Guild for Community Arts Education, New York), Larry Desrochers (general director and CEO, Manitoba Opera, Winnipeg, Canada), Robert Ellis (board member, San Francisco Opera and Opera Parallele, San Francisco), Perryn Leech (managing director, Houston Grand Opera), Zizi Mueller (president, Boosey & Hawkes, New York), Eric Owens (bass-baritone, New York) and Jill Steinberg (photographer; board chair, VisionIntoArt, New York).
"I am delighted to welcome these outstanding new members to the Board of Directors," stated OPERA America President and CEO Marc A. Scorca. "Each of these seven individuals, representing the administrative, publishing, governance and artistic spheres of our industry, brings a different set of valuable skills to the leadership of OPERA America at this exciting time in our industry. With their added perspectives, we look forward to furthering our work to increase opera's civic impact," he continued.
At the Annual Business Meeting, six current members of the Board of Directors were also re-elected to a second term: * David Bennett (executive director, Gotham Chamber Opera)
* Keith Cerny (general director and CEO, The Dallas Opera)
* Carol F. Henry (trustee, Los Angeles Opera)
* Timothy O'Leary (general director, Opera Theatre of Saint Louis)
* Kenneth G. Pigott (trustee, Lyric Opera of Chicago)
* Stephen Trampe (trustee, Opera Theatre of Saint Louis)
Four officers of the Board of Directors were re-elected to their posts:
* Frayda B. Lindemann, Ph.D. (trustee, the Metropolitan Opera) as chairman * Stephen Trampe (trustee, Opera Theatre of Saint Louis) as vice-chairman * Darren K. Woods (general director, Fort Worth Opera) as vice-chairman
* Timothy O'Leary (general director, Opera Theatre of Saint Louis) as treasurer Two members of the Board of Directors were newly elected to officer posts:
* Susan F. Morris (trustee, The Santa Fe Opera) as vice-chairman
* William Florescu (general director, Florentine Opera Company) as secretary The OPERA America Board of Directors oversees the organization's portfolio of programs, including professional development activities, research and advocacy, educational offerings, and grant initiatives such as the Building Opera Audiences program and The Opera Fund in support of new works. The Board of Directors meets three times each year, and the next meeting will take place in October in Milwaukee, WI.
BOARD OF DIRECTORS: NEW MEMBER PROFILES Emilie Roy Corey
Trustee, National Guild for Community Arts Education
Since 2005, Emilie Roy Corey has been a trustee of the National Guild for Community Arts Education, the only national service organization for community arts educators. She has served on the boards of numerous other cultural organizations, including the Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center, New York City Opera and the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music. From 1995 to 2000, Corey acted as board president of the Council of Senior Centers and Services, and more recently she joined the foundation board at PBMC Health, a community hospital located in Riverhead, NY. A native of Worcester, MA, Corey attended Simmons College in Boston and subsequently spent two years as a Peace Corps volunteer in Brazil. After returning to the U.S., she earned her master's degree in social work from Adelphi University and embarked on a twenty-year career in community services for the elderly, working for the Human Resources Administration, the Department for the Aging and the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies. After retiring in 1991, Corey began piano and voice lessons at the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music and later continued her studies at the Greenwich House Music School and the Lucy Moses School.
Larry Desrochers
General Director and CEO, Manitoba Opera
Larry Desrochers has been general director and CEO of Manitoba Opera (MO) since 2000. Under his leadership the company has experienced a creative and organizational renaissance. He has improved the quality of productions, hired an increased number of Canadian artists and expanded MO's education and community engagement programs. Desrochers commissioned MO's first new opera, Transit of Venus, and presented the North American premiere of a children's opera, Jason and Hanna. He posted operating surpluses in 12 of the last 13 seasons. Prior to joining Manitoba Opera, Desrochers was the executive director of the Winnipeg Film Group, where he increased training, exhibition and distribution programs for independent filmmakers. He also oversaw major touring exhibitions of Manitoba films to South America and France. He began his career as associate artistic director of the Royal Manitoba Theatre Centre, where he founded the Winnipeg Fringe Festival. He produced and directed the 1999 Pan American Games opening and closing ceremonies, featuring more than 5,000 performers, including Canadian rock band The Guess Who, reunited for that occasion. Trained as a theater director, he has staged productions at a number of theaters in Canada, including premieres of a new works. Desrochers has served on a variety arts boards and committees and is the past chair of Opera.ca. He is a Distinguished Alumnus of the University of Winnipeg and a recipient of the Winnipeg Arts Council Making a Difference Award for his contribution to arts and culture in Manitoba. He is also a member of OPERA America's Strategy Committee.
Robert Ellis
Board Member, San Francisco Opera and Opera Parallele
Robert Ellis has had a lifelong interest in opera, and he currently serves on the boards of San Francisco Opera and Opera Parallele, a contemporary opera company also based in San Francisco. He works as an advisor, investor and director of Internet companies. Over the past two decades, Ellis has undertaken numerous Internet ventures: He served as a principal of xoom.com, which completed an IPO in 1999 and later merged with NBC's Internet properties; founded Compact Publishing, an early digital publisher, which was sold to The Learning Company in 1995; acted as CEO of eNature, which was sold to the National Wildlife Federation; and founded Bonjour Paris, a travel destination site. Earlier in his career, Ellis was vice president of Time-Life Inc. and worked as a correspondent for TIME magazine. Ellis was a co-producer with Tod Machover, Keith Cerny, The Dallas Opera and the MIT Media Lab of the February 2014 nine-city simulcast of Death and the Powers from the Winspear Opera House in Dallas. Perryn Leech
Managing Director, Houston Grand Opera
Perryn Leech has been managing director of Houston Grand Opera (HGO) since May 2011. He previously served as HGO's chief operating officer and, before that, as technical and production director. In his current role, Leech oversees all aspects of the company operations, which are sustained by an annual budget of $25 million, and leads an eleven-member Senior Management Team. In 2012, Leech spearheaded the development and implementation of HGO's new strategic plan, A Voice for Houston, establishing the company's business and artistic vision for the future. In that same year he also launched a historic fundraising campaign, Inspiring Performance - The Campaign for Houston Grand Opera, which is on target to meet its goal of $165 million by the end of 2014. Before his tenure at HGO, Leech spent five years as technical director at Welsh National Opera and prior to that was production manager at English National Opera in London. He had previously worked for twelve years as a freelance production electrician in London's West End and toured with many companies in the UK and Ireland. From 1989 to 1996, Leech was the head of lighting at the Edinburgh International Festival. It was during this time that he first collaborated with HGO on their two productions at the Playhouse Theatre - Nixon in China and Four Saints in Three Acts. Leech serves on the boards of Houston Downtown Alliance, the Electronic Media Association, Houston Arts Combined Endowment Foundation, and Wortham Center Operating Company.
Zizi Mueller
President, Boosey & Hawkes
Zizi Mueller joined Boosey & Hawkes in 2008 and became its president in 2012. During her tenure as publisher at Boosey & Hawkes, she has instituted the Emerging Composers and New Voices projects, innovative programs supporting young and emerging composers. Additionally, Mueller has signed Osvaldo Golijov, Sebastian Currier, Anna Clyne, Sean Shepherd and Oscar Bettison to the Boosey & Hawkes roster. As president of Boosey & Hawkes, Mueller represents the leading composers of contemporary music and opera and has collaborated on projects with many distinguished presenters, including the San Francisco Symphony, the New World Symphony, the Metropolitan Opera, the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the New York Philharmonic and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, among others. Mueller came to Boosey & Hawkes with a wealth of performance and production experience. As executive and artistic director of MOSAIC, Mueller commissioned works from a wide spectrum of international composers and performed throughout the Americas and Europe. She has collaborated with celebrated theater directors, video artists and choreographers. As a performer and record producer, Mueller has produced projects for Naxos, Bridge Records, Newport Classics, New World Records and Premiere Records, among others. She is on the board of the Music Publishers Association and serves on the Symphony & Concert Committee of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers. Zizi Mueller received her training at The Juilliard School.
Eric Owens Bass-baritone
The outstanding American bass-baritone Eric Owens continues to garner high praise across the globe for his many performances, which encompass a widely varied repertoire of opera, concerts and recitals. In addition to being Wolf Trap Opera's inaugural artist in residence, Owens enjoys a 2014 summer season of performances of Berlioz's Romeo et Juliette with Chicago's Grant Park Festival as well as scenes from Mussorgsky's Boris Godunov and Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 at the Aspen Music Festival. He rejoins Sir Simon Rattle, Peter Sellars and the Berlin Philharmonic for additional performances of Bach's St. Matthew Passion at the Lucerne Festival in Switzerland, and he will also perform at London's BBC Proms festival. Owens' 2014-2015 season starts off with performances of Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 with Maestro Riccardo Muti and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and continues with additional performances of Bach's St. Matthew Passion with the Berlin Philharmonic in New York as part of Lincoln Center's White Light Festival. His opera performances this season include performances of The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess with Lyric Opera of Chicago, the title role in Wagner's The Flying Dutchman with Washington National Opera and his role debut as King Philip II in Verdi's Don Carlo with Opera Philadelphia. His upcoming concert performances include Ravel's L'enfant et les sortileges with the Swedish Radio Symphony under the baton of Essa-Pekka Salonen, Scarpia in Puccini's Tosca with Leonard Slatkin and the St. Louis Symphony, and a role debut of Golaud in Debussy's Pelleas et Melisande, as well as additional performances of Ravel's L'enfant with Maestro Salonen and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. In the summer of 2015, Owens returns as artist in residence to The Glimmerglass Festival, where he will perform the title role in Verdi's Macbeth for the first time. Highlights of his recent career include performances of Alberich in Wagner's epic Ring cycle with the Metropolitan Opera, the title role in Handel's Hercules with the Canadian Opera Company, Dvorak's Rusalka with Lyric Opera of Chicago, and Amonasro in Verdi's Aida with Gustavo Dudamel and the Los Angeles Philharmonic, in addition to the King in Handel's Ariodante, Porgy, Capellio in Bellini's I Capuleti e i Montecchi and Lodovico in Verdi's Otello, all with San Francisco Opera. Owens has created challenging contemporary roles, including the title character in Elliot Goldenthal's Grendel (world premiere at Los Angeles Opera, subsequently Lincoln Center), the Storyteller in John Adams' A Flowering Tree (Peter Sellars' New Crowned Hope Festival in Vienna) and General Groves in Adams' Doctor Atomic. (Photo by Paul Sirochman Photography)
Jill Steinberg
Photographer; Board Chair, VisionIntoArt
Photographer Jill Steinberg is the board chair of VisionIntoArt (VIA), a nonprofit new music and interdisciplinary arts production company and Professional Company Member of OPERA America, as well as a board member and philanthropic investor of Original Music Workshop (OMW), a nonprofit music venue that provides support to a wide range of composers, musicians and emerging talent in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, opening fall 2015. As a live performance photographer, she has documented VisionIntoArt's biennial 21c Liederabend co-productions at Galapagos Art Space, The Kitchen and Brooklyn Academy of Music, VIA's annual FERUS Festival, and VIA productions at The Kennedy Center, Krannert Center, Park Avenue Armory and Bay Chamber Music Festival. Since 2012 she has photographed Original Music Workshop's In Situ concerts as their building has undergone a transformation from a sawdust factory to a state-of-the-art performance space as well as OMW's Ex Situ concerts at The Greene Space, Federal Hall and Pier 15. She also works with Beth Morrison Projects, Opera on Tap, Heartbeat Opera and the terraNOVA Collective and has published in The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, Time Out New York, Time Out Amsterdam and Music Listening Today, among other publications. As a photographer, Steinberg has a unique perspective on the behind-the-scenes workings of small and emerging performing arts companies and their artists. As board chair of VIA, board member of OMW, Strategic Committee member of PROTOTYPE - OPERA/THEATRE/NOW and now, as a member of OPERA America's board, she will continue to champion them. She and her husband, William Steinberg, are founding donors to the National Opera Center.
