As part of the discovery process, lawyers for the city obtained subpoenas for communications relating to the anti-HERO campaign ‚Äî including subpoenas to five Houston pastors active in opposition to the ordinance, but not parties to the lawsuit.
‚ÄúThe pastors were instructed to turn over ‚Äúall speeches, presentations, or sermons‚Äù related to HERO.
Religious leaders and civil libertarians from across the spectrum have spoken out against the sweeping scope of the subpoenas, pointing out that the First Amendment protects the preaching and teaching of religious leaders from government oversight or intrusion.
At first, Houston Mayor Annise Parker appeared to defend the subpoenas, tweeting that sermons on political topics were ‚Äúfair game.‚Äù But a few days later, she acknowledged that the subpoenas were overly broad and agreed to remove the request for ‚Äúsermons.‚Äù
The pastors and ADF, however, weren‚Äôt satisfied, arguing that the subpoenas would still require the pastors to turn over 17 different categories of information, including private communications with their church members.
Page 2 of 2 - Under pressure to reverse course, Mayor Parker announced that the city would withdraw the subpoenas entirely.
Coeur d‚ÄôAlene city officials also appear to have either changed their position or rejected the position attributed to the city attorney by publicly acknowledging that Hitching Post is exempt from the city‚Äôs non-discrimination law when performing religious marriages.  Some commentators have compared the Hitching Post controversy to conflicts across the country involving wedding vendors such as florists, bakers and photographers who have thus far failed to get exemptions from non-discrimination laws. But whatever the merits of those decisions, Hitching Post is a very different case.
It‚Äôs true, of course, that for-profit businesses are places of public accommodation generally subject to non-discrimination laws. But ordained ministers ‚Äî whether in a non-profit or for-profit setting ‚Äî are protected by the Free Exercise and Free Speech clauses of the First Amendment from being compelled by government to perform religious ceremonies that violate their faith.
If government officials in other cities want to avoid unnecessary conflicts and lawsuits like those that have divided Houston and Coeur d‚ÄôAlene, they should think carefully how to protect First Amendment rights even as they work to implement laws protecting LGBT people from discrimination.
Striking a balance between ending discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and upholding religious freedom will not be easy. As happens whenever competing claims clash in a pluralistic democracy, there will be winners and losers.
But surely Americans on all sides can agree on at least this: Under the First Amendment, religious leaders have the right to practice their faith ‚Äî including preaching sermons and performing religious ceremonies ‚Äî without governmental interference or intimidation.
Charles C. Haynes
Religious Freedom Center
Newseum Institute
Washington, DC

Headline Text: This is Viewpoints for Thursday, Nov. 6, 2014
Article Text:
Stop the money
I just signed an Internet petition to stop sending tax dollars to nations that persecute Christians. It was addressed to both Congress and President Obama. It seems that $8 billion of U.S. taxpayer dollars have been sent to Pakistan as it persecutes Asia Bibi, a Christian mother of five sentenced to die for her faith.
We must stop sending money to nations that persecute persons of other religious faiths. As a wave of persecution sweeps across the Middle East and refugees flee for their lives -- it√≠s time for the money to stop. Not one thin dime for persecution.
-- Hill Kaplan
Macon
No BRAC
The head cheerleader for the Democratic Party, Frank Gadbois, needs to fact check himself while he continually talks about the √¨next√Æ round of BRAC. Let me be of assistance to him:
The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2014 specifically prohibits authorization of future BRAC rounds: No future Base Realignment and Closure round for military installations within the United Sates, its commonwealths, territories and possessions for realignment or closure shall be authorized until, at the very earliest, the Department of Defense has completed and submitted to Congress a formal review of the overseas military facility structure, which incorporates overseas basing consolidations, an assessment of the need for bases to support overseas contingency operations, and the Department of Defense√≠s Strategic Choices and Management Review. In May 2014, it was attempted to fund another round of BRAC, although funding was not approved in a vote in May of that year.
With that being said, I√≠m sure Gadbois will still have plenty to complain about. -- Ron Renno
Forsyth
Real oppression
Houston, Texas, Mayor Annise Parker signed the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance into law on May 28, 2014. The ordinance applies to businesses that serve the public, private employers, housing, city employment and city contracting. Religious institutions were said to be exempt. Violations based on denying individuals because of sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information or military status could be fined up to $5,000.
During the summer, collected petition signatures supporting repeal were invalidated, a suit against the city was filed and city attorneys subpoenaed sermons given by local pastors who oppose the law.
Parker√≠s actions are a barely veiled endeavor to silence the word of God, which stands contrary to her personal lifestyle and an increasingly depraved American society. Historically, such suppression has been tried by more potent powers than the Houston mayor. God and his word have adroitly triumphed over the persecutions of prison, fire and sword by Pharaoh, Pilate, Herod, Ananias, Caiaphas other religions and, yes, even other Christians. The mayor and City Council of Houston will, no doubt, be swallowed up by its own irrelevance.
-- John Wayne Dobson Macon
Success the American way
I read an article yesterday written by former military veteran, mayor and congressman Jim Marshall published in The Telegraph, citing √¨Politicians should not lead business recruiting.√Æ After reading the point by point article, I enthusiastically endorse his sentiment in this instance; however, in regard to jobs being outsourced offshore, I do not believe that either politicians or businessmen can return goods production back to the shores of America.
In order to grasp this fundamental assessment, you only need to understand the underlying principles of √¨supply and demand.√Æ There are no existing factory, plant or manufacturing entities in America capable of getting their goods produced below labor costs prevalent in the offshore markets. Accordingly, it is impossible for America√≠s businesses to successfully compete against foreign competition in such an environment.
Federal Prison Industry Inc., (Unicor) off the top, may be the only entity in the U.S. that perhaps come close to matching prevailing labor cost in offshore markets.
However, the irony -- America doesn√≠t want to compete against this entity either -- given the lesser of the two evils, which one would you choose, offshore or Unicor?
Further, I cannot project any sustainable incentive in sufficient form to induce those American companies, opting to do business offshore to return to America. The rationale is just not there.
It would be wise that we come to grips with the status quo and pursue other viable options designed to create jobs here in Georgia and throughout America. Why should we punish them for doing what we taught them to do in our institutions of higher learning?
Be angry at the president, Congress, the policy makers if you will, but not at those excelling in the pursuit of the American dream. As consumers, we love the low prices we generally expect at Wal-Mart and other discount retailers, but, on the other hand, we criticize them for the venues they chose to produce its products. What hypocrisy.
To turn this corner, we need folks like Jim Marshall, with the requisite political and business savvy to lead Middle Georgia from the bottom to the top. We need to support and encourage the efforts of MEDC and other advocacy groups seeking to bring and sustain economic empowerment to the citizens of Middle Georgia. I would definitely like to see the leaders of such organizations come together as one body, bringing into its membership smaller communities such as Montezuma, Fort Valley, Baldwin County, etc., collectively pooling their resources to defeat the main issue of today: an unacceptable level of unemployment.
Is it possible to put egos aside and bring such an organization into existence? It can be reasonably generalized, that these smaller communities simply do not have the wherewithal to advocate for their respective survival. However, they individually and collectively do have resources (land) to bring to the table.
-- John Haugabrook Warner Robins
Tribute to law enforcement
I would like to give honor and thanks to the law enforcement personnel who serve and protect us. They leave their loved ones to go out to fight crime and enforce other laws. I feel empathy for the family in Monroe County who lost their loved one and for the family whose loved one was injured. I feel empathy for anyone who has lost a loved one who worked in law enforcement.
As an advocate against violence, I feel they are brave individuals for working in law enforcement with the high rate of violence and crime prevalent today.
I would like to give recognition to the officers who work the evening shift a the Medical Center who showed how helpful and patient many officers can be.
-- Renee Lee Macon
Red-light runners
There is a three second differential between one light turning red and the cross traffic getting the green light. That means for three seconds all four traffic lights are red. A red light means STOP and not √¨I have three seconds to make it through the intersection before the other lights turn green.√Æ That logic is flawed for two reasons:
1. Running a red light is illegal. 2. It is extremely dangerous. Some internal chronometers are a second or two off. I√≠ve seen people sail through intersections up to two seconds after the light had turned green for the opposite lanes.
Maybe the city, county and state police should stop hiding behind concrete lane dividers and bushes looking for speeders and try to stop red-light runners.
-- William D. Carter
Bonaire
Thank you
The community of Elberta would like to give a special thank-you to County Commission Chairman Tommy Stalnaker and the Houston county road crew for a job well done. Thank you and God Bless.
-- Vernon Smith Warner Robins

Headline Text: Thousands rally on behalf of Houston pastors hit with subpoenas
Article Text:
Thousands showed their support Sunday the five Houston pastors who drew national attention for challenging the city's now- withdrawn effort to subpoena their sermons.
I Stand Sunday, a combination church service and religious-freedom rally, drew an estimated 6,000 congregants to hear a high- profile line-up of speakers at Grace Community Church in Houston. The two-hour event was simulcast to nearly 700 churches and 3,000 home groups.
While the pastors were the focus, speakers warned that the Houston subpoenas represent only the latest example of a growing threat to religious liberty in the United States.
"This was never really about subpoenas, it was not about sermons or speeches. This was about political intimidation," said Family Research Council president Tony Perkins. "It was about trying to silence the voices of the churches and the pastors."
Houston Mayor Annise Parker dropped the subpoenas last week after a national outcry, but the issue is far from resolved. Members of a pastor-led coalition filed a lawsuit in August against the city attorney's decision to reject petitions for a voter referendum on the city's newly passed gender-neutral "bathroom bill."
"Mayor Parker, she's so committed to her own agenda that she's willing to trample on our right to vote, speak and practice our faith freely," said Khanh Huynh, senior past of the Vietnamese Baptist Church. "My message to Mayor Parker, the city attorney and all those who have threatened our freedom is very simple: Let the people vote."
Mr. Huynh, one of those served with a subpoena, said he was one of the "boat people" who fled Vietnam after communists took over his country in the aftermath of the Vietnam War.
"The freedom of speech and freedom of religion were among the first to be lost in Vietnam, and now I'm facing the same marching boot of tyranny right here where I live," Mr. Huynh told the crowd to cheers and applause.
Pastor Magda Hermida said the city's subpoenas for sermons, emails and other communications related to the equal-rights ordinance reminded her of the conditions she fled in Cuba more than 50 years ago.
"We used to live in Cuba in a police state in which our possessions, our speech, our faith were monitored closely by the government with the fear of punishment if we said something or did something those in power didn't like," Ms. Hermida said. "We never thought we would see happening that is now in this country here in Houston, in our beloved America, but it is here and it is now."
Former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee said Christians need to become more involved in the political process. He said there are 80 million evangelicals in the United States, but only about half are registered to vote, and only about half of those vote in presidential elections.
"And we wonder why it is we're seeing the kinds of things we're seeing in cities like Houston, Texas," Mr. Huckabee said. "I'll tell you why. It's because a lot of people in our churches have said, 'I just don't want to get involved.' My dear friends, when the government comes to your pastor and says, 'Cough up all of the sermons, sermon notes and correspondence that the pastor has had with his own parishioners,' you are already involved."
Other prominent speakers included Ronnie Floyd, president of the Southern Baptist Convention; Phil and Alan Robertson of A&E's "Duck Dynasty," and radio talk-show host Todd Starnes of Fox News & Commentary.  A group of supporters of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, known as HERO, gathered nearby Sunday for a counter-protest, holding signs that spelled out, "Stand for Love."
"You cannot use your faith as a blank check to discriminate against others," Tiffani Bishop of GetEqual Texas, which organized the demonstration, told the Houston Chronicle.
Although she withdrew the subpoenas, Ms. Parker has defended the ordinance, saying last week that, "I don't want to have a national debate about freedom of religion when my whole purpose is to defend a strong and wonderful and appropriate city ordinance against local attack."
Steve Riggle, pastor of Grace Community Church pastor, said the subpoenas have galvanized the religious community to push back against government intrusion into matters of faith. Several videos shown during the I Stand Sunday event featured business owners in trouble with the law for refusing to provide services for same-sex weddings.
"We've been in this battle regarding this ordinance for many months, but when the mayor decided to send subpoenas to all of us, it seemed like it was the match that was the ignition needed to raise a firestorm all over the nation," Mr. Riggle said.
He also announced that foes of the ordinance will gather at 11 a.m. Wednesday at city hall for a post-election rally.
"I'd like to see all of you and everyone you can bring to city hall to deliver the mayor a message, a really vocal message, and it's real simple: Mayor, let the people vote," Mr. Riggle said.

Headline Text: Inside the First Amendment - Gay rights can‚Äôt trample free speech
Article Text:
Conflicts in Texas and Idaho in recent weeks have reinvigorated fears in conservative religious circles that expanding protections for LGBT rights will threaten their religious freedom.
In Houston, city lawyers obtained subpoenas requiring five pastors to turn over sermons and other communications that mention the city‚Äôs equal rights ordinance. With assistance from the Alliance Defending Freedom, the pastors sued to nullify the subpoenas as overly broad and irrelevant to the case.
Meanwhile, in Coeur d‚ÄôAlene, Idaho, the city attorney opined earlier this year that two Pentecostal pastors who run a for-profit wedding chapel called ‚ÄúHitching Post‚Äù must offer services to same-sex couples in compliance with a local ordinance banning discrimination based on sexual orientation in places of public accommodation.
A few weeks ago, the owners of Hitching Post ‚Äî again with help from ADF ‚Äî filed suit to prevent city officials from forcing them to perform same-sex wedding ceremonies or face prosecution for violating the city‚Äôs anti-discrimination law.
The pastors say they decided to sue after police officials contacted them about a complaint from a same-sex couple who were refused service by the Hitching Post.
In their zeal to uphold nondiscrimination, city attorneys in both places were, to put it charitably, tone-deaf to the protections of the First Amendment.
The Texas controversy centers on an amendment to the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance passed by the city council last May which, among other things, expands protections for gay and transgender people.
Opponents of the ordinance attempted to place a repeal on the ballot in November, but their petition was rejected for not having enough valid signatures. Four taxpayers then sued the city, claiming that the referendum petition was wrongly invalidated.
As part of the discovery process, lawyers for the city obtained subpoenas for communications relating to the anti-HERO campaign ‚Äî including subpoenas to five Houston pastors active in opposition to the ordinance, but not parties to the lawsuit.
‚ÄúThe pastors were instructed to turn over ‚Äúall speeches, presentations or sermons‚Äù related to HERO.
Religious leaders and civil libertarians from across the spectrum have spoken out against the sweeping scope of the subpoenas, pointing out that the First Amendment protects the preaching and teaching of religious leaders from government oversight or intrusion.
At first, Houston Mayor Annise Parker appeared to defend the subpoenas, tweeting that sermons on political topics were ‚Äúfair game.‚Äù But a few days later, she acknowledged that the subpoenas were overly broad and agreed to remove the request for ‚Äúsermons.‚Äù
The pastors and ADF, however, weren‚Äôt satisfied, arguing that the subpoenas would still require the pastors to turn over 17 different categories of information, including private communications with their church members.
Under pressure to reverse course, Parker announced this week that the city would withdraw the subpoenas entirely.
Coeur d‚ÄôAlene city officials also appear to have either changed their position or rejected the position attributed to the city attorney by publicly acknowledging that Hitching Post is exempt from the city‚Äôs nondiscrimination law when performing religious marriages. Some commentators have compared the Hitching Post controversy to conflicts across the country involving wedding vendors such as florists, bakers and photographers that have thus far failed to get exemptions from nondiscrimination laws.
But whatever the merits of those decisions, Hitching Post is a very different case.
It‚Äôs true, of course, that for-profit businesses are places of public accommodation generally subject to nondiscrimination laws. But ordained ministers ‚Äî whether in a nonprofit or for-profit setting ‚Äî are protected by the Free Exercise and Free Speech clauses of the First Amendment from being compelled by government to perform religious ceremonies that violate their faith.
If government officials in other cities want to avoid unnecessary conflicts and lawsuits like those that have divided Houston and Coeur d‚ÄôAlene, they should think carefully about how to protect First Amendment rights even as they work to implement laws protecting LGBT people from discrimination.
Striking a balance between ending discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and upholding religious freedom will not be easy. As happens whenever competing claims clash in a pluralistic democracy, there will be winners and losers.
But surely Americans on all sides can agree on at least this: Under the First Amendment, religious leaders have the right to practice their faith ‚Äî including preaching sermons and performing religious ceremonies ‚Äî without government interference or intimidation.

Headline Text: Inside the First Amendment: As LGBT rights expand, remember the First Amendment
Article Text:
Conflicts in Texas and Idaho in recent weeks have re-invigorated fears in conservative religious circles that expanding protections for LGBT rights will threaten their religious freedom.
In Houston, city lawyers obtained subpoenas requiring five pastors to turn over sermons and other communications that mention the city's equal rights ordinance. With assistance from the Alliance Defending Freedom (ADF), the pastors sued to nullify the subpoenas as overly broad and irrelevant to the case.
Meanwhile, in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, the city attorney opined earlier this year that two Pentecostal pastors who run a for-profit wedding chapel called "Hitching Post" must offer services to same-sex couples in compliance with a local ordinance banning discrimination based on sexual orientation in places of public accommodation.
A few weeks ago, the owners of Hitching Post -- again with help from ADF -- also filed suit to prevent city officials from forcing them to perform same-sex wedding ceremonies or face prosecution for violating the city's anti-discrimination law. The pastors say they decided to sue after police officials contacted them about a complaint from a same-sex couple who were refused service by the Hitching Post.
In their zeal to uphold non-discrimination, city attorneys in both places were, to put it charitably, tone-deaf to the protections of the First Amendment.
The Texas controversy centers on an amendment to the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance (HERO) passed by the city council last May which, among other things, expands protections for gay and transgender people.
Opponents of the ordinance attempted to place a repeal on the ballot in November, but their petition was rejected for not having enough valid signatures. Four taxpayers then sued the city, claiming that the referendum petition was wrongly invalidated.
As part of the discovery process, lawyers for the city obtained subpoenas for communications relating to the anti-HERO campaign -- including subpoenas to five Houston pastors active in opposition to the ordinance, but not parties to the lawsuit.
"The pastors were instructed to turn over "all speeches, presentations, or sermons" related to HERO.
Religious leaders and civil libertarians from across the spectrum have spoken out against the sweeping scope of the subpoenas, pointing out that the First Amendment protects the preaching and teaching of religious leaders from government oversight or intrusion.
At first, Houston Mayor Annise Parker appeared to defend the subpoenas, tweeting that sermons on political topics were "fair game." But a few days later, she acknowledged that the subpoenas were overly broad and agreed to remove the request for "sermons."
The pastors and ADF, however, weren't satisfied, arguing that the subpoenas would still require the pastors to turn over 17 different categories of information, including private communications with their church members.
Under pressure to reverse course, Mayor Parker announced this week that the city would withdraw the subpoenas entirely.
Coeur d'Alene city officials also appear to have either changed their position or rejected the position attributed to the city attorney by publicly acknowledging that Hitching Post is exempt from the city's non-discrimination law when performing religious marriages.
Some commentators have compared the Hitching Post controversy to conflicts across the country involving wedding vendors such as florists, bakers and photographers who have thus far failed to get exemptions from non-discrimination laws. But whatever the merits of those decisions, Hitching Post is a very different case.
It's true, of course, that for-profit businesses are places of public accommodation generally subject to non-discrimination laws. But ordained ministers -- whether in a non-profit or for-profit setting -- are protected by the Free Exercise and Free Speech clauses of the First Amendment from being compelled by government to perform religious ceremonies that violate their faith.
If government officials in other cities want to avoid unnecessary conflicts and lawsuits like those that have divided Houston and Coeur d'Alene, they should think carefully how to protect First Amendment rights even as they work to implement laws protecting LGBT people from discrimination.
Striking a balance between ending discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and upholding religious freedom will not be easy. As happens whenever competing claims clash in a pluralistic democracy, there will be winners and losers.
But surely Americans on all sides can agree on at least this: Under the First Amendment, religious leaders have the right to practice their faith -- including preaching sermons and performing religious ceremonies -- without governmental interference or intimidation.

Headline Text: Protecting the church from the state
Article Text:
Much has been made about the importance of keeping church and state separate - such as the dozens of lawsuits over the years from civil libertarians to keep Nativity scenes or the Ten Commandments as far from government property as possible.
Almost invariably, the focus in such controversy has been on how to keep the church out of the state, not the other way around. Until now.
It seems now the focus needs to be keeping the state - or more specifically, state and local governments - out of the churches. Consider these recent cases in point:
* In Houston, five Christian pastors were served with subpoenas by city prosecutors to turn over emails and transcripts of sermons addressing homosexuality.
The city earlier this year passed the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, providing broad anti-discrimination protections to gay and transgendered residents. Both a lawsuit and a petition gathering signatures to repeal the law ensued, and the pastors - who weren't involved in the lawsuit but did support the signature drive - were issued subpoenas, with Houston Mayor Annise Parker tweeting the emails and sermon transcripts were "fair game."
* In Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, the owners of the Hitching Post Wedding Chapel were told their refusal to perform same-sex weddings violated the city's non-discrimination ordinance.
Warren Wilson, the city attorney, told an Idaho paper that the chapel "would probably be considered a place of public accommodation" and would therefore "be subject to the ordinance." This is in spite of the facts the chapel is registered as a "religious corporation" with the state and the stated mission of the owners - a husband and wife who are both ordained Pentecostal ministers - is to perform "one-man-one-woman marriages as defined by the Holy Bible."
* In California, elective abortion is now deemed part of "basic health services" that all insurance plans must cover - including the plans bought and provided by churches for their clergy and staff.
This all comes from regulatory changes, as the state's Department of Managed Health Care - prompted by the American Civil Liberties Union - has reinterpreted a four-decade-old state law on health services covered by insurance, now ordering abortion be covered by all plans. Ironically, California's DMHC - along with the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services - exempt churches from any contraceptive mandates, yet they've now issued a no-exception abortion mandate.
It's disappointing, but not surprising, that many of the same groups and individuals who protest even the slightest religious acknowledgement in public affairs are silent with regard toward these unwelcome intrusions of the state into church matters. Many are unsympathetic to religious stances to same-sex marriage, homosexuality and abortion, given that all three are becoming increasingly accepted in secular society. But even though all may have won several sizable legal battles both here and abroad, the practices remain contradictory to doctrines and principles of many of the world's most prominent religions.
In theory, those religious principles and practices are protected by the First Amendment. In reality, however, protections for religious conscience are proving to be woefully inadequate. The presumption seems to be that the free exercise of religion is only acceptable if it can justify itself in the eyes of the state. That's contrary to both the letter and spirit of the U.S. Constitution.
We recognize the importance of keeping government from being dominated by religion, but the threat today is not creeping theocracy, but rather government insertion into private matters of religious faith. The First Amendment that was written to prevent the "establishment of religion" also forbids "prohibiting the free exercise thereof." If that doesn't protect matters of conscience unpopular with the day's latest trends and causes, then those words have no meaning.

Headline Text: Sermons are free speech too - WHITE: Houston steps over the line in questioning pastors' sermons
Article Text:
IN SOME countries, authorities stifle political and social dissent-countries like Egypt and Sri Lanka and Saudi Arabia and Iran. Now you can add the United States to that list. Because in Houston, we have a problem.
Last summer, the Houston City Council passed an ordinance called HERO, or Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, which prohibited discrimination on the basis of "sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, familial status, marital status, military status, religion, disability, sexual orientation, genetic information, gender identity, or pregnancy" in housing, private employment, public accommodations, public contracting and several other categories.
Some people objected, finding the ordinance overly broad. Did it mean, for example, that a biological male who considers himself female (gender identity) could use a women's rest-room (public accommodations)?
Maybe, maybe not. Still, opponents circulated a petition to place the ordinance on the ballot so voters could choose to keep it or overturn it. City officials rejected the petition, throwing out pages and pages of signatures they found irregular. Opponents filed a lawsuit. And then things got really ugly.
In September, the city attorney issued "discovery" subpoenas to five Houston pastors requiring them to submit all "speeches, presentation, or sermons related to HERO, the Petition, Mayor Annise Parker, homosexuality, or gender identity, prepared by, delivered by, revised by, or approved by you or in your possession." It further requested all "documents or communications to, from, CCing, BCCing, or forwarded to you, or otherwise in your possession, referring to" the mayor, city attorney, HERO, the Petition, etc.
Has anyone in Houston seen the First Amendment lately? You know, the one about freedom of religion and speech? Because your government has apparently misplaced it. Or hasn't read it for a while. The subpoenas were so intrusive, so invasive, they clearly had one purpose: to make it so costly for pastors to speak out about a cultural practice or ordinance they believe is wrong that it would silence all but the most bold.
Although threatened with contempt of court, the pastors balked at complying. Good for them. Because government power brokers had just crossed a line. (I'd invoke the Nazis here, who forced their will on the German church, but I've always thought that should be a last resort. I will recommend, however, you look up one word: Bonhoeffer.)
Now it's true that after an uproar, the Houston subpoenas were rewritten and the word "sermons" taken out. The city's excuse for the "mistake" was that the expansive orders were composed by an outside, pro bono group. An activist group, in other words, which would love to shut up opponents. Especially pastors. But simply taking out the word "sermons" doesn't weaken the oppressive effect of the subpoenas. Isn't a sermon a speech?
Some might argue that pastors and churches shouldn't be involved in politics. But how would that have played out in the civil rights era? Should the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. have just remained quiet? Or back further, during the slavery debates, should Falmouth abolitionist Moncure Daniel Conway have shrugged his shoulders at that great evil? From its very beginnings, America has benefited from the checks and balances that come from a robust application of all three First Amendment rights: freedom of religion and of speech and a free press. Because sometimes what's popular and or politically correct just isn't right.
Ah, but it's a dangerous thing to allow liberty free rein in a society. All kinds of things might happen. People may question government. Get all up in arms about what city councils want to do. Think for themselves. Discover the truth.
Last month, Peter Kirsanow, a commissioner with the United States Commission on Civil Rights, wrote a letter to Mayor Parker, asking that she instruct the city attorney to withdraw the subpoenas, calling them clearly overbroad and destined to have a chilling effect on political and religious speech. He writes, "A person's religious views on civil rights, equal rights, homosexuality, and gender identity have nothing to do with whether there are enough valid signatures to place a referendum on the ballot. This discovery request impermissibly probes the religious beliefs of private citizens simply because they supported a political effort."
And finally, just last week, Houston saw the light. On Wednesday, Parker instructed the city's legal department to withdraw the subpoenas.
Amen. Look, I understand this issue is sensitive. You and I may never personally agree on gender issues, along with abortion, premarital sex, dog breed bans, whiskey, HOA covenants and/or the Redskins. But the day government tries to shut you up, the day it uses the power of the courts to intimidate you and keep you from expressing your beliefs, on that day I will advocate for you. Because when we lose the First Amendment, we've lost America.
Linda J. White lives in Fauquier County.

Staged Faces
F.A.C.E.S., standing for Faith Always Conquers Every Storm, is the title of a play presented by Dramatically Inspired Works and playwright/director Denisee Gaston at 7 p.m. today at the Franciscan Center Life Theatre at Lourdes College, 6832 Convent Blvd., Sylvania. Doors open at 6, and admission is $20 at the door.
Billed as a gospel musical stage play, F.A.C.E.S. is about three women: Bethany, her sister, and her best friend. They all have issues and secrets and present different faces to family and friends.
Missionary to Cambodia in Sylvania
The Rev. Romeo del Rosario, the country director of the United Methodist Church in Cambodia, will speak Sunday at both the 9:30 and 11 a.m. services at Sylvania First United Methodist Church, 7000 Erie St., Sylvania. Born in the Philippines, Rev. del Rosario has served Methodism as a pastor in the California-Pacific Conference, a teacher in Sierra Leone, a United Methodist Church liaison in Jerusalem's West Bank, a seminary dean in Malaysia, and the top officer in a Filipino seminary. He earned his Ph.D. In ecumenics and missions at Boston University.
Muslims and Christians in conversation
Juan Ricardo Cole, a history professor at the University of Michigan who is an expert on the Middle East and South Asia, will be the facilitator Sunday at 2:30 p.m. for First Presbyterian Church of Maumee's Muslim Christian Dialogue, held in the church's Fellowship Hall at 200 E. Broadway, Maumee. Church members, participating Muslims, and other attendees will have table discussions during a potluck meal; this is part of ongoing monthly meetings of Christians and Muslims, and some upcoming sessions will be held in area mosques.
Standing Simulcast
On Sunday at 7 p.m. both the Church on Strayer, 3000 Strayer Rd., Maumee, and Monroe Missionary Baptist Church, 14260 S. Dixie Hwy., Monroe, Mich., will host a live telecast from Houston of ‚ÄúI Stand Sunday,‚Äù a religious-freedom event organized by the Family Research Council, with speakers including the Family Research Council's president, two commentators from Fox News Channel, two people from the TV show Duck Dynasty, and others.
‚ÄúI Stand Sunday‚Äù is being staged in response to the subpoenas of speeches and communications of five Texas ministers who supported a petition to overturn the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance. The subpoenas were withdrawn by Houston Mayor Annise Parker Wednesday.
Toledo Jewish Book Festival turns 10
The Toledo Jewish Book Festival marks a decade with its activities in November.
The activities begin Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. when novelist Lisa Barr speaks for a ‚ÄúToledo Reads‚Äù function at the Registry Bistro Ballroom, 144 N. Superior St. Attendees should have read her novel, Fugitive Colors, the story of an artist trying to save people and art from the Nazis during World War II. Admission is $15, $35 if also buying the book, and reservations can be made through Monday at registration@jewishtoledo.org or 419-724-0354. Later events feature children's books Nov. 9, a caddie's memoir Nov. 11, food-related books Nov. 12 and 14, and a book on yoga and Judaism Nov. 13. For more information, go to jewishtoledo.org/book-festival-2014.
Jung life
‚ÄúCarl Jung as Soul Mate‚Äù is the subtitle of a one-day retreat at the Lial Renewal Center, 5908 Davis Rd., Whitehouse, Nov. 8 from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. on understanding the human experience more mindfully and consciously. The Rev. John Blaser, a senior-status priest who is a board member of Toledo's Center for Servant Leadership and who is being trained as a Jungian and Christian tradition dream leader, will offer four reflections based in both Catholic spirituality and the religious psychology of Carl Jung on psyche and soul.
Cost is $30 and includes lunch. Preregistration is requested at lialrenewalcenter.org, 419-877-0432, or mdpfahler@toledosnd.org.

Staged Faces
F.A.C.E.S., standing for Faith Always Conquers Every Storm, is the title of a play presented by Dramatically Inspired Works and playwright/director Denisee Gaston at 7 p.m. today at the Franciscan Center Life Theatre at Lourdes College, 6832 Convent Blvd., Sylvania. Doors open at 6, and admission is $20 at the door.
Billed as a gospel musical stage play, F.A.C.E.S. is about three women: Bethany, her sister, and her best friend. They all have issues and secrets and present different faces to family and friends.
Missionary to Cambodia in Sylvania
The Rev. Romeo del Rosario, the country director of the United Methodist Church in Cambodia, will speak Sunday at both the 9:30 and 11 a.m. services at Sylvania First United Methodist Church, 7000 Erie St., Sylvania. Born in the Philippines, Rev. del Rosario has served Methodism as a pastor in the California-Pacific Conference, a teacher in Sierra Leone, a United Methodist Church liaison in Jerusalem's West Bank, a seminary dean in Malaysia, and the top officer in a Filipino seminary. He earned his Ph.D. In ecumenics and missions at Boston University.
Muslims and Christians in conversation
Juan Ricardo Cole, a history professor at the University of Michigan who is an expert on the Middle East and South Asia, will be the facilitator Sunday at 2:30 p.m. for First Presbyterian Church of Maumee's Muslim Christian Dialogue, held in the church's Fellowship Hall at 200 E. Broadway, Maumee. Church members, participating Muslims, and other attendees will have table discussions during a potluck meal; this is part of ongoing monthly meetings of Christians and Muslims, and some upcoming sessions will be held in area mosques.
Standing Simulcast
On Sunday at 7 p.m. both the Church on Strayer, 3000 Strayer Rd., Maumee, and Monroe Missionary Baptist Church, 14260 S. Dixie Hwy., Monroe, Mich., will host a live telecast from Houston of ‚ÄúI Stand Sunday,‚Äù a religious-freedom event organized by the Family Research Council, with speakers including the Family Research Council's president, two commentators from Fox News Channel, two people from the TV show Duck Dynasty, and others.
‚ÄúI Stand Sunday‚Äù is being staged in response to the subpoenas of speeches and communications of five Texas ministers who supported a petition to overturn the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance. The subpoenas were withdrawn by Houston Mayor Annise Parker Wednesday.
Toledo Jewish Book Festival turns 10
The Toledo Jewish Book Festival marks a decade with its activities in November.
The activities begin Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. when novelist Lisa Barr speaks for a ‚ÄúToledo Reads‚Äù function at the Registry Bistro Ballroom, 144 N. Superior St. Attendees should have read her novel, Fugitive Colors, the story of an artist trying to save people and art from the Nazis during World War II. Admission is $15, $35 if also buying the book, and reservations can be made through Monday at registration@jewishtoledo.org or 419-724-0354.
Later events feature children's books Nov. 9, a caddie's memoir Nov. 11, food-related books Nov. 12 and 14, and a book on yoga and Judaism Nov. 13. For more information, go to jewishtoledo.org/book-festival-2014. Jung life
‚ÄúCarl Jung as Soul Mate‚Äù is the subtitle of a one-day retreat at the Lial Renewal Center, 5908 Davis Rd., Whitehouse, Nov. 8 from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. on understanding the human experience more mindfully and consciously. The Rev. John Blaser, a senior-status priest who is a board member of Toledo's Center for Servant Leadership and who is being trained as a Jungian and Christian tradition dream leader, will offer four reflections based in both Catholic spirituality and the religious psychology of Carl Jung on psyche and soul.
Cost is $30 and includes lunch. Preregistration is requested at lialrenewalcenter.org, 419-877-0432, or mdpfahler@toledosnd.org.

Headline Text: INSIDE THE FIRST AMENDMENT ‚Äî Charles C. Haynes - As LGBT rights expand, remember the First Amendment
Article Text:
Conflicts in Texas and Idaho in recent weeks have re-invigorated fears in conservative religious circles that expanding protections for LGBT rights will threaten their religious freedom.
In Houston, city lawyers obtained subpoenas requiring five pastors to turn over sermons and other communications that mention the city‚Äôs equal rights ordinance. With assistance from the Alliance Defending Freedom (ADF), the pastors sued to nullify the subpoenas as overly broad and irrelevant to the case.
Meanwhile, in Coeur d‚ÄôAlene, Idaho, the city attorney opined earlier this year that two Pentecostal pastors who run a for-profit wedding chapel called ‚ÄúHitching Post‚Äù must offer services to same-sex couples in compliance with a local ordinance banning discrimination based on sexual orientation in places of public accommodation.
A few weeks ago, the owners of Hitching Post ‚Äî again with help from ADF ‚Äî also filed suit to prevent city officials from forcing them to perform same-sex wedding ceremonies or face prosecution for violating the city‚Äôs anti-discrimination law. The pastors say they decided to sue after police officials contacted them about a complaint from a same-sex couple who were refused service by the Hitching Post.
In their zeal to uphold non-discrimination, city attorneys in both places were, to put it charitably, tone-deaf to the protections of the First Amendment.
The Texas controversy centers on an amendment to the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance (HERO) passed by the city council last May which, among other things, expands protections for gay and transgender people.
Opponents of the ordinance attempted to place a repeal on the ballot in November, but their petition was rejected for not having enough valid signatures. Four taxpayers then sued the city, claiming that the referendum petition was wrongly invalidated.
As part of the discovery process, lawyers for the city obtained subpoenas for communications relating to the anti-HERO campaign ‚Äî including subpoenas to five Houston pastors active in opposition to the ordinance, but not parties to the lawsuit.
‚ÄúThe pastors were instructed to turn over ‚Äúall speeches, presentations, or sermons‚Äù related to HERO.
Religious leaders and civil libertarians from across the spectrum have spoken out against the sweeping scope of the subpoenas, pointing out that the First Amendment protects the preaching and teaching of religious leaders from government oversight or intrusion.
At first, Houston Mayor Annise Parker appeared to defend the subpoenas, tweeting that sermons on political topics were ‚Äúfair game.‚Äù But a few days later, she acknowledged that the subpoenas were overly broad and agreed to remove the request for ‚Äúsermons.‚Äù
The pastors and ADF, however, weren‚Äôt satisfied, arguing that the subpoenas would still require the pastors to turn over 17 different categories of information, including private communications with their church members.
Under pressure to reverse course, Mayor Parker announced this week that the city would withdraw the subpoenas entirely.
Coeur d‚ÄôAlene city officials also appear to have either changed their position or rejected the position attributed to the city attorney by publicly acknowledging that Hitching Post is exempt from the city‚Äôs non-discrimination law when performing religious marriages.
Some commentators have compared the Hitching Post controversy to conflicts across the country involving wedding vendors such as florists, bakers and photographers who have thus far failed to get exemptions from non-discrimination laws. But whatever the merits of those decisions, Hitching Post is a very different case.
It‚Äôs true, of course, that for-profit businesses are places of public accommodation generally subject to non-discrimination laws. But ordained ministers ‚Äî whether in a non-profit or for-profit setting ‚Äî are protected by the Free Exercise and Free Speech clauses of the First Amendment from being compelled by government to perform religious ceremonies that violate their faith.
If government officials in other cities want to avoid unnecessary conflicts and lawsuits like those that have divided Houston and Coeur d‚ÄôAlene, they should think carefully how to protect First Amendment rights even as they work to implement laws protecting LGBT people from discrimination.
Charles C. Haynes is director of the Religious Freedom Center of the Newseum Institute, 555 Pennsylvania Ave., N.W., Washington, DC 20001. Web: www.religiousfreedomcenter.org Email: chaynes@newseum.org

Headline Text: As LGBT rights expand, remember the First Amendment
Article Text:
Conflicts in Texas and Idaho in recent weeks have re-invigorated fears in conservative religious circles that expanding protections for LGBT rights will threaten their religious freedom.
In Houston, city lawyers obtained subpoenas requiring five pastors to turn over sermons and other communications that mention the city‚Äôs equal rights ordinance. With assistance from the Alliance Defending Freedom (ADF), the pastors sued to nullify the subpoenas as overly broad and irrelevant to the case.
Meanwhile, in Coeur d‚ÄôAlene, Idaho, the city attorney opined earlier this year that two Pentecostal pastors who run a for-profit wedding chapel called ‚ÄúHitching Post‚Äù must offer services to same-sex couples in compliance with a local ordinance banning discrimination based on sexual orientation in places of public accommodation.
A few weeks ago, the owners of Hitching Post ‚Äî again with help from ADF ‚Äî also filed suit to prevent city officials from forcing them to perform same-sex wedding ceremonies or face prosecution for violating the city‚Äôs anti-discrimination law. The pastors say they decided to sue after police officials contacted them about a complaint from a same-sex couple who were refused service by the Hitching Post.
In their zeal to uphold non-discrimination, city attorneys in both places were, to put it charitably, tone-deaf to the protections of the First Amendment.
The Texas controversy centers on an amendment to the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance (HERO) passed by the city council last May which, among other things, expands protections for gay and transgender people.
Opponents of the ordinance attempted to place a repeal on the ballot in November, but their petition was rejected for not having enough valid signatures. Four taxpayers then sued the city, claiming that the referendum petition was wrongly invalidated.
As part of the discovery process, lawyers for the city obtained subpoenas for communications relating to the anti-HERO campaign ‚Äî including subpoenas to five Houston pastors active in opposition to the ordinance, but not parties to the lawsuit.
The pastors were instructed to turn over ‚Äúall speeches, presentations, or sermons‚Äù related to HERO.
Religious leaders and civil libertarians from across the spectrum have spoken out against the sweeping scope of the subpoenas, pointing out that the First Amendment protects the preaching and teaching of religious leaders from government oversight or intrusion.
At first, Houston Mayor Annise Parker appeared to defend the subpoenas, tweeting that sermons on political topics were ‚Äúfair game.‚Äù But a few days later, she acknowledged that the subpoenas were overly broad and agreed to remove the request for ‚Äúsermons.‚Äù
The pastors and ADF, however, weren‚Äôt satisfied, arguing that the subpoenas would still require the pastors to turn over 17 different categories of information, including private communications with their church members.
Under pressure to reverse course, Mayor Parker announced this week that the city would withdraw the subpoenas entirely.
Coeur d‚ÄôAlene city officials also appear to have either changed their position or rejected the position attributed to the city attorney by publicly acknowledging that Hitching Post is exempt from the city‚Äôs non-discrimination law when performing religious marriages. Some commentators have compared the Hitching Post controversy to conflicts across the country involving wedding vendors such as florists, bakers and photographers who have thus far failed to get exemptions from non-discrimination laws. But whatever the merits of those decisions, Hitching Post is a very different case.
It‚Äôs true, of course, that for-profit businesses are places of public accommodation generally subject to non-discrimination laws. But ordained ministers ‚Äî whether in a non-profit or for-profit setting ‚Äî are protected by the Free Exercise and Free Speech clauses of the First Amendment from being compelled by government to perform religious ceremonies that violate their faith.
If government officials in other cities want to avoid unnecessary conflicts and lawsuits like those that have divided Houston and Coeur d‚ÄôAlene, they should think carefully how to protect First Amendment rights even as they work to implement laws protecting LGBT people from discrimination.
Striking a balance between ending discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and upholding religious freedom will not be easy. As happens whenever competing claims clash in a pluralistic democracy, there will be winners and losers.
But surely Americans on all sides can agree on at least this: Under the First Amendment, religious leaders have the right to practice their faith ‚Äî including preaching sermons and performing religious ceremonies ‚Äî without governmental interference or intimidation.
Charles C. Haynes is director of the Religious Freedom Center of the Newseum Institute in Washington, D. C. He can be reached at chaynes@newseum.org.

Headline Text: HOUSTON 2014: THE YEAR IN REVIEW - POLITICS, IMMIGRATION HERALD BIG CHANGES - Election drama, tragic losses and tears of joy all played out as oil prices plummeted
Article Text:
Amid the daily rumble of a great city, the news can swing from quiet lows to crashing crescendos.
This year brought us November's raucous election, outbursts surrounding the city's controversial equal rights amendment, rising indignation over potentially violent sex offenders being housed in a residential neighborhood, and an ominous sucking sound as the price of crude oil plunged precipitously, probably taking with it a quarter-million jobs from Texas and other oil-producing states.
There was the sound of silence, of mourning, too, as six Spring residents and four Cypress residents were slain in their homes and four workers of a LaPorte chemical plant were fatally overcome by an escaping cloud of toxic gas.
The news struck notes of surprise as a top Texas criminal courts judge announced that he opposes the death penalty, and brought peals of joy as wedding bells rang for Mayor Annise Parker and her life partner of more than 20 years.
These are the stories that brought Houston to great highs and lows in 2014: Houston Equal Rights Ordinance
As contention reached a fever pitch, the Houston City Council in May voted 11-6 to extend equal rights protections to gay and transgender residents. The measure, supported by Mayor Annise Parker, the first openly lesbian mayor of a major American city, was greeted with applause from supporters who packed the chamber. Opponents responded with a petition drive calling for a referendum on the ordinance, which duplicates federal laws banning discrimination based on sex, race, age, disability and other factors. When city officials ruled thousands of petition signatures invalid, ordinance foes sued. A trial is set for January.
Stay family killings
Six members of a Spring family, including four children, were slain in an execution-style shooting in July when, authorities allege, a former member of their extended family came searching for his ex-wife, who was not in the home. Killed were Stephen Stay, 39; his wife, Katie, 34; and their children, Bryan, 13; Emily, 9, Rebecca, 7; and Zach, 4. Another child, Cassidy, 15, suffered a minor head wound. Authorities said Ron Haskell, 33, disguised as a FedEx delivery man, forced his way into the home, tied up family members, then shot them. He has been charged with capital murder.
Cypress family slain
A quiet neighborhood in suburban Cypress was rocked in January when the bodies of Maoye Sun, 50; his wife, Mei Xie, 49; and their sons, Timothy, 9; and Xiao, 7; were found shot to death in their home. The bodies were discovered when Sun, an employee of a Houston oil field equipment maker, failed to appear at work. Each of the victims, whose bodies were found in separate parts of the house, was shot in the head. No arrests have been made.
GOP juggernaut
Texas continued its love affair with the Republican Party in November when former Attorney General Greg Abbott led the GOP juggernaut by defeating former Fort Worth Democratic state Sen. Wendy Davis with 59 percent of the vote. Fueled by anti-Obama sentiment, the trend continued with Houston state Sen. Dan Patrick's victorious campaign for lieutenant governor. He won 58 percent of the votes over San Antonio state Sen. Leticia Van de Putte. Republicans also claimed attorney general, land commissioner, comptroller and other top statewide positions. Election 2014 marked the first time in 24 years that an incumbent governor did not seek re-election.
Astrodome redux
Once the "Eighth Wonder of the World," Houston's fabled Astro‚Äãdome got an influential endorsement for redevelopment in December from the Urban Land Institute, which argued the stadium should be converted into an indoor park with lawns, gardens, a promenade of oak trees and exhibit space for festivals and community events. The Dome's future has been in question since 2013 when voters defeated a proposed (SEE UNPUBLISHED CORRECTION) $217 bond issue for its redevelopment. County Judge Ed Emmett said the proposal from the urban planners, economics and designers,has "almost a 100 percent chance" of succeeding.
DuPont deaths
Four workers at DuPont's 800-acre plant in La Porte died in November when a faulty valve released a toxic chemical used to make insecticides. Killed when methyl mercaptan escaped from the containment vessel were Crystle Wise, 53; Wade Baker, 60; and Gilbert Tisnado, 48, and his brother, Robert Tisnado, 39. The younger Tisnado and Baker rushed into the gas-filled area without gas masks after they heard a woman's cry for help. When radio contact with them was lost, Gilbert Tisnado donned a gas mask and also entered the deadly area. Finding his brother overcome by the fumes, he removed his gas mask to render aid and also perished.
Roilings In oil
Soaring U.S. oil output, spurred by hydraulic fracturing and a refusal by OPEC to curb production, created a fuel glut that had producers scrambling to cut costs and employees. Oil futures plunged 46 percent in 2014, with Brent Crude for February delivery dropping to $58.36 a barrel on Monday. Analysts say the bearish turn in the oil business likely will persist through the first half of 2015. Texas and seven other oil-producing states could lose up to 250,000 jobs in that period. The glut, however, has put a smile on the face of American motorists, though, with the cost of regular gasoline at its lowest point since 2008. AAA reports that average cost per gallon hovers at $2.30 a gallon.
Top judge opposes executions
Texas Court of Appeals Justice Tom Price in November became the first judge on the state's highest criminal court to publicly oppose the death penalty. The Dallas Republican's concerns, which centered on the chance of executing an innocent person, were voiced in a dissent to a court decision clearing the way for the Dec. 3 execution of Kerr County double-killer Scott Panetti. The U.S. Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals stayed Panetti's execution hours before he was to be put to death. Panetti, said to be schizophrenic, was convicted of fatally shooting his wife's parents.
For whom the wedding bells toll
Mayor Annise Parker in January married Kathy Hubbard, her life partner of 23 years, in a private ceremony in Palm Springs, Calif. "This is a very happy day for us," Parker said. "Kathy has been by my side for more than two decades, helping to raise a family, nurture my political career and all of the other ups and downs and life events that come with a committed relationship." Parker, 56, the first openly lesbian mayor of a major city, has been Houston's top municipal executive since 2010. In 2012, she joined 78 American mayors in calling for equal marriage rights for gay couples.
Unaccompanied minors
Texas saw a flood of unaccompanied minors from Latin American countries trying to cross the border, prompting complaints about immigration enforcement as well as pleas for assistance. Harris County in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 received the largest number of unaccompanied Central American minors placed with private sponsors by the U.S. Office of Refugee Settlement. Of the 53,518 youngsters placed with sponsors during that period, 4,028 came to Harris County. More than 85,000 unaccompanied minors were intercepted entering the U.S. since Oct. 1, 2009. The influx prompted President Barack Obama to advocate expedited screening and deportation. In September, Houston clergy with The Metropolitan Organization called for the city to put out the welcome mat to those fleeing Latin American violence.
Sex offenders Texas Office of Violent Sex Offender Management was hit by scandal in April after 23 offenders in civil commitment - a process in which inmates who have completed sentences are retained because they are too dangerous to release - were placed, unannounced to neighbors or political representatives, in Houston's Acres Home neighborhood. In the resulting uproar, the agency was reviewed, Gov. Rick Perry fired the agency's board chairman and the agency director resigned. In September, agency officials in response to a Houston Chronicle inquiry, also admitted they were unaware that Texas courts had freed two potentially violent sex offenders on the condition that they leave Texas. One was sent to Utah, the other to Virginia. Both since have been convicted of additional sex crimes.
Voter seesaw
First it was on, then it was off, then it was on. Legal wrangling over Texas' controversial voter ID law, enacted in 2013, might have left voters' heads spinning as, on Oct. 9, a Corpus Christi U.S. District Judge declared the law unconstitutional. The law, he said, would effectively disenfranchise hundreds of thousands minority voters. Five days later, a three-judge panel of the U.S. 5th Circuit Court of Appeals overturned the ruling, saying that a change just days before the general election would confuse voters. The law requires voters to present a valid picture ID. On Oct. 18, the U.S. Supreme Court backed up the New Orleans appeals court without specifying the reasons. Turnout in the election was about 5 percent less than in the previous gubernatorial election - and the role the law played in the decrease continues to be debated.
Up, up and away
Space X, the first private con-cern to ferry supplies to the International Space Station, in August announced it had chosen Boca Chica Village near Brownsville as the site for its fourth space launch facility. Construction on the approximately $100 million facility began in September, and the first flights could launch as early as 2016. Elon Musk, CEO of Space X, says the site will be used to launch the company's Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy vehicles and a variety of reusable suborbital launch vehicles.
Need a lift?
Sixteen months of gear-grinding controversy lurched to a halt in August when the City Council voted 10-5 to open Houston's heavily regulated paid ride market to new entrants such as Uber and Lyft. Such services use smartphone applications to connect willing drivers, who use their personal vehicles, with interested riders.
Alfred Dewayne Brown
Sentenced to die for the April 2003 murders of store clerk Alfredia Jones and Houston police officer Charles Clark, Alfred Dewayne Brown insisted he had been at his girlfriend's home at the time of the crime. After seeing news of the killings on tele‚Äãvision, he said, he telephoned his girlfriend. Records of the land-line call, though, could not be produced. Last year, however, the missing phone records turned up, and in November, the Texas Court of Appeals reversed the conviction, saying Brown's attorneys were denied access to evidence that could have supported his alibi. Harris County District Attorney Devon Anderson now must retry Brown, dismiss the case, or look for some middle ground. The case highlighted the grand jury process, including who is chosen for duty, and the tactics used on witnesses who go before the jurors.
