After seeing news of the killings on tele‚Äãvision, he said, he telephoned his girlfriend. Records of the land-line call, though, could not be produced. Last year, however, the missing phone records turned up, and in November, the Texas Court of Appeals reversed the conviction, saying Brown's attorneys were denied access to evidence that could have supported his alibi. Harris County District Attorney Devon Anderson now must retry Brown, dismiss the case, or look for some middle ground. The case highlighted the grand jury process, including who is chosen for duty, and the tactics used on witnesses who go before the jurors.
More online

Headline Text: Houston's mayoral race is drawing a crowd
Article Text:
Who's in the running
A look at those who'll definitely be in the race, those who are likely and other possibilities. Page A15
The race to succeed Mayor Annise Parker is shaping up to be Houston's most crowded in decades, with a half-dozen candidates already having declared they will run and another half-dozen possibly joining them.
The campaign for Houston's top job will only begin with velocity on Feb. 1, but candidates for months have quietly met with key donors, activists and interest groups in search of the unbeatable coalition that would deliver a victory in 12 months' time. Top-level strategists have been hired, lawsuits have been filed, and now more than ever, the candidates' names are becoming known.
Most observers consider Rep. Sylvester Turner, with his support base from the African-American population that could cast a third of next year's vote, to be the man to beat in November. Yet his fortunes to win in a December runoff - all but guaranteed to be needed in a large field - depend heavily on whom he faces in a one-on-one comparison.
Councilmen Oliver Pennington and Stephen Costello have committed to the race, with Pennington going as far as to send mailers to potential supporters in July, 18 months before the first votes are to be cast. Ben Hall, who lost to Parker in 2013, launched radio advertisements last month, and former Kemah mayor and Chronicle columnist Bill King designated a campaign treasurer. Former Democratic congressman Chris Bell also is an all-but-filed entrant.
Six weeks before the campaign fundraising floodgates open, the field is settling save for a potential entrant who looms over much of the discussion in Houston power circles: Harris County Sheriff Adrian Garcia, who has not yet declared his intentions. Legally, Garcia cannot make an affirmative move toward running without being forced to resign his county post, though he has acknowledged the pressure he faces from others.
That pressure, though, is pushing him in both directions. Commissioners Court likely would replace Garcia with a Republican sheriff ahead of the next election cycle.
"You're going to be giving them an early 2016 gift," said Democratic Sen. Sylvia Garcia, who had the sheriff at her home this month and expressed concern about a run. "Nobody wants a Latino mayor more than I do, but it's got to be the right time."
Likewise, some Democrats also worry that their down-ballot judicial candidates could be hurt in 2016 without Garcia at the top of the county ticket.
'It's our time now'
"I know there are some people in the Hispanic community that don't want to give up the safe bet, but our community - it's our time now," said Jacob Monty, an immigration lawyer who is a Republican supporter of Garcia. "I think he proves that you can be progressive and fiscally conservative."
Backers of Garcia, the county's highest vote-getter in 2012, assert that he would pose the strongest political challenge to Turner. Analysts note, however, that Latinos, presumably Garcia's base, make up only between 10 and 15 percent of the electorate.
Garcia also will confront the same challenge that tests the political mettle of all candidates - collecting enough checks to compete. "If he can put the money together, he would definitely be a top-tier candidate because he has significant name identification," said Nancy Sims, a political analyst at Pierpont Communications. Sims said Garcia would need to raise at least $2 million to $3 million to broadcast his message.
If Garcia does not enter the race, Councilman Ed Gonzalez, a close friend of Garcia, could look to capture Latinos' support. Other prominent Hispanic leaders look to pass on the race, including Metro chairman and Parker ally Gilbert Garcia and Hispanic Chamber of Commerce head Laura Murillo. Both expressed some signs of interest earlier, but do not appear to be joining the field.
Other alternatives
Garcia's exit also could create political lanes for other Democratic alternatives to Turner, like Bell. Though Bell has not formally committed to the race, he has filed a lawsuit challenging Turner's fundraising strategy and plans to make an official announcement in January.
The other four candidates most seriously weighing bids are: Councilman Jack Christie, an at-large councilman uncertain whether he can raise the money needed to compete; County Treasurer Orlando Sanchez, who like Garcia would have to resign to run for mayor; Sean Roberts, a local attorney; and businessman and political neophyte Marty McVey.
Councilmen Michael Kubosh and C.O. Bradford considered the race earlier this year, but both now say they are unlikely to launch campaigns. And despite floating the idea that he was open to a run, outgoing Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst said this month he had no plans to do so.
Conservatives have not yet coalesced around any of the six non-liberal candidates: Pennington, Costello, Hall, King, Christie or Sanchez.
"Right now, there's no clear conservative choice yet, but people are obviously angling for being it," said Paul Bettencourt, the new Republican senator from northwest Harris County.
Parker's political strategists themselves are split, with 2009 campaign manager Adam Harris advising Garcia and others like Grant Martin and Sue Davis, top advisers on Parker's three mayoral races, working for Turner. Parker herself stood in the front row at Turner's birthday celebration this fall, a fundraiser that brought in $400,000 for his unopposed re-election contest and sparked Bell's lawsuit.
Turner has raised money this fall despite the city fundraising blackout until Feb. 1, by officially placing the money in his state legislative account. He plans to transfer much of that money to his mayoral campaign - an end-around that Bell believes violates the law and spirit of the blackout ordinance. A judge will decide whether to temporarily block Turner's plan on Jan. 12.
Turner's office may have allowed him to raise money this fall, but it prevents him from doing so since Saturday, when the state's legislative fundraising blackout period began. When Turner's competitors begin to fill their coffers in February, he will have to rely on the money he is raising now until the legislative blackout period ends in mid-June.
'A powerful position'
Turner's 25 years in the Legislature gives him his own advantages, said Austin lobbyist Bill Miller, as does his political alliance with top Democratic Sen. John Whitmire. Turner will have the power to influence the budget and help deliver in Austin what he will be running on in Houston.
"Most candidates would trade their ability to raise money for the ability to spend $90 billion," Miller said. "That's a powerful TEXT MISSING IN PAPER) position." Mayoral contenders
A look at the definite, likely and potential candidates to run for Houston mayor next year:
Definites
Sylvester Turner: Seen by many to be the front-runner in the field, the longtime state representative is expected to draw on the support of Houston's African-American voters.
Oliver Pennington: The Republican city councilman began his campaign earlier than all other candidates, sending mailers to potential supporters in July.
Stephen Costello: Costello, an at-large councilman, chairs council's budget committee and likely will run as a moderate.
Ben Hall: Hall lost in 2013 to Annise Parker, but the self-funding attorney has already launched radio advertisements this fall ahead of his next mayoral bid.
Chris Bell: Bell, a former congressman, has filed a lawsuit challenging Turner's fundraising strategies and is likely to announce in January.
Likelies
Bill King: King, a former Chronicle columnist and the former mayor of Kemah, has frequently talked about running for mayor and this year has designated a campaign treasurer, the first step before a run.
Marty McVey: A businessman, McVey has no prior political experience and is not expected to be a top-tier candidate.
Sean Roberts: Roberts, an attorney, challenged Democratic congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee in 2010 but received less than 5 percent of the vote.
Potentials
Adrian Garcia: The Harris County sheriff likely would rise quickly to the top of the field if he entered the race, but he would have to resign his job as the county's top cop.
Orlando Sanchez: The county treasurer who lost in the 2003 runoff to Bill White has kept his name in the mix this year, though he would need to resign like Garcia would.
Ed Gonzalez: The mayor pro-tem of City Council is experienced but likely would run only if Garcia, his close friend, passed on the race.
Jack Christie: The at-large councilman is seriously weighing a bid, though he said he will decline to run if he is not confident he can raise the money needed to compete.
Gilbert Garcia: The chairman of Metro is a close ally of Mayor Parker and is still deciding whether to run, though sources say he is not sending signals suggesting he will.

Headline Text: PAC makes gay, transgender rights - an issue in District 6 c ouncil race
Article Text:
A political action committee opposed to gay marriage has jumped into a City Council race, arguing the stakes include religious freedom.
Texas Values Action, a group founded by conservative activist Jonathan Saenz, sent a mailer earlier this week to potential voters in far Northwest Austin's District 6, touting candidate Don Zimmerman. The piece describes Zimmerman as pro-life and against gay marriage, and noted he opposes extending spouse benefits to the same-sex partners of government workers. The flier touts Zimmerman's opposition to a proposed ordinance requiring single-occupancy bathrooms in public places to be gender-neutral.
The flier contrasts those stands with Zimmerman's opponent in the Dec. 16 runoff, Jimmy Flannigan. The flier states Flannigan founded the Austin Gay and Lesbian Chamber of Commerce; does not think abortion should be banned; and thinks same-sex couples should receive the same benefits as heterosexual couples, as the city provides. He also supports the gender-neutral bathroom ordinance, which originated in part to ensure transgender people are more comfortable using public restrooms.
Saenz said Texas Values Action is getting involved as part of a larger effort to curb what he considers overreach on the part of city governments. He noted that in July, his and other conservative groups helped persuade a federal judge to throw out an abortion- related Austin ordinance, which required religiously based pregnancy centers that do not offer abortions to post signs announcing that they do not offer medical care.
"As we see it, more local governments in Texas are being more aggressive in attacking religious freedoms," Saenz said. "This is clearly relevant to the election."
His mailer was posted on Towleroad, a news outlet focused on gay issues. In response, Stonewall Democrats posted on the site: "Now that the finish line to the City Council run-off is in sight, it's ‚Äòhere we go again' with inflammatory and divisive rhetoric intended to suggest that LGBTQ people are anti-family. Nothing could be further from the truth. So, wake up Mr. Saenz, you are in Austin and it's 2014."
Zimmerman has written extensively about his belief that homosexuality is wrong. In a 2006 Republican primary for state representative, Zimmerman appealed to voters on the grounds that he was most active in supporting a state ban on gay marriage. (It passed. He lost.)
Even so, sexuality had gone little-mentioned in this City Council campaign. Flannigan has maintained from the beginning that in his district, sexual orientation and gender issues do not matter and voters are focused on issues such as taxes and traffic. He once said a potential constituent he had known for a while said he did not approve of Flannigan's sexual orientation - but quickly added, "Can you really fix traffic?" To which Flannigan said he replied: "The number one issue facing Austin's gay and lesbian community is... (dramatic pause)... traffic!"

Cleveland City Council kicked up a firestorm last month by debating an ordinance in committee that would require that access to bathrooms, showers, locker rooms and dressing rooms be provided on a nondiscriminatory basis regardless of ‚Äúrace, religion, color, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, national origin, age, disability, ethnic group or Vietnam-era or disabled veteran status.‚Äù
Whether intended or not, as written, the proposed ordinance effectively requires as a matter of law that both genders be given access to all bathrooms and locker rooms in public accommodations within city limits, except for those at establishments with fewer than four employees, private clubs or religious institutions.
The measure remains under consideration in City Council‚Äôs Workforce and Community Benefits Committee. Is there a balance to be found here?
Christopher Evans, editorial writer, Northeast Ohio Media Group: Ordinance 1446-13 offers the transgender community the right to use public restrooms, showers and locker rooms just like everyone else. I don‚Äôt see the problem here. I think City Council would rather wring its hands and dither over a no-brainer antidiscrimination measure than deal with real issues such as the use of deadly force by city police officers.
Sharon Broussard, editorial writer, Northeast Ohio Media Group: I don‚Äôt have a problem with transgender people using whatever bathroom makes them comfortable, particularly since they may be subject to violence, often from hostile men. But I am not comfortable with a broad, gender-neutral bathroom ordinance that would make it easier for heterosexual men with criminal intent or just kinky habits to gain access to bathrooms used by women and children. And they are out there. How to balance both of these rights is tricky, but I think that Cleveland‚Äôs ordinance is far too broad.
Thomas Suddes, editorial writer: If this hasn‚Äôt proved to be a problem in Columbus, why should it be a problem in Cleveland? Answer: It won‚Äôt be. Public policy should be fact-based, not phobia-based. If the most populous city in Ohio ‚Äî which Columbus is ‚Äî can handle this, then surely Cleveland, which prides itself on its comparative sophistication vis-a-vis downstate Ohio, and which moreover is an international visitors‚Äô center, can handle it, too.
Peter Krouse, editorial writer, Northeast Ohio Media Group: The concerns of the transgender community are legitimate, and there is a balance to be found here, but I‚Äôm not sure where that is. I don‚Äôt think opening up all bathrooms to both sexes is the answer. That would deny people ‚Äî males and females ‚Äî the privacy they deserve and possibly put them in uncomfortable or compromising situations. It could also create a fertile environment for predators to strike.
Kevin O‚ÄôBrien, deputy editorial page editor, The Plain Dealer: Just go by the external appearance of the plumbing the good Lord gave you and keep your ‚Äúexpressions‚Äù to yourself. Leave the seat down in the ladies‚Äô room and up in the men‚Äôs room, lest you tempt these hyperactive social engineers to pass a law about that, too.
Elizabeth Sullivan, opinion director, Northeast Ohio Media Group: It‚Äôs important that transgendered individuals remain safe when doing something as basic as using a public restroom where they can face ‚Äî and have faced ‚Äî hostility and violence. But those dangers won‚Äôt evaporate just because of an ordinance. The obvious answer is to add, wherever possible, some gender-neutral bathrooms and locker rooms to give everyone peace of mind. Cleveland‚Äôs ordinance can‚Äôt require that, given the costs, but it can be stated a little less broadly to assure that the law is not misused.
If any of you ‚Äúreporters‚Äù had a 10-year-old daughter, it would be a different story. You are all freaks. ‚Äî Susan Daniels The first time I see a guy walk in the bathroom my wife or granddaughters are in will be the time someone better call an ambulance. ... Men‚Äôs rooms are for guys, ladies‚Äô rooms are for women. ‚Äî OHGuy
‚ÄúPublic policy should be fact-based, not phobia-based.‚Äù Good luck with that. Have you listened to the right‚Äôs talking points on climate change, as just one example? ‚Äî vette78man
Have you ever seen the inside of some men‚Äôs restrooms? Whew! Ladies and trans people out there, they can be quite disgusting. Be careful what you wish for people. You can bet that someone will purposely soil those transgender bathrooms just to make a point. ‚Äî CarlosDanger
This whole bathroom thing is pathetic. Like there aren‚Äôt serious matters that need attention. ‚Äî LiveFree

Headline Text: Bell throwing his hat in the ring again - Ex-councilman, first official mayoral candidate, plans to tackle infrastructure
Article Text:
Chris Bell, a former city councilman and one-term Democratic congressman, formally announced his campaign for Houston mayor on Sunday, vowing to modernize how the city fills potholes and fixes sidewalks.
Bell became the first candidate to officially kick off a mayoral run in what is expected to be a wide-open, hotly contested race this year. Bell, 55, acknowledged that the race could get ugly and signaled that he would be ready to return fire as soon as he received it.
"I know my competitors will do their best to try and define me. They might even talk about some of the political races that I have run and lost," Bell told a crowd of supporters on a windy, sunny afternoon at Sam Houston Park. "And that's fair game - because if necessary, I'll talk about races they've run and lost."
Bell has lost three elections in a row, a record that has been fodder for opponents such as state Rep. Sylvester Turner, who is considered the front-runner but has himself lost two bids for mayor. Bell's punch on Sunday follows an aggressive legal push over the past three months to limit the amount of money that Turner can transfer from his officeholder account to his mayoral account.
Bell has long been animated by good-government causes, but after being unable to win an early victory in district court this month, he told reporters Sunday he may drop his suit if he determines it is a "distraction."
Some question whether he has the political base, as an Anglo Democrat, and fundraising ability to advance to a runoff in a heavily splintered field. Candidates likely will need to raise $2 million before November to be competitive.
High name ID
However, Bell has experience working donors and has high name identification in a field in which few others do: An internal Bell poll last week showed Bell and Turner tied, and Bell's campaign believes he has a lot more room to grow. And his top strategist, Bill Hyers, has experience winning tough mayoral races, guiding Bill de Blasio in New York to an upset victory in 2013.
Bell believes that infrastructure is the issue that will persuade Houston voters to cast a ballot for him in November. He promised Sunday to build or improve 200 miles of sidewalks during his first term and to synchronize traffic lights. He also pledged a "technological revolution" in the way Houston fixes its roads.
"Our streets are broken and clogged and just about making us crazy," Bell said. "When you have as many potholes as we do, you attack them in an almost military-style approach, drafting a tactical plan and putting together the army you need, temporary or otherwise, to get them filled."
As mayor, Bell also said he would focus on thwarting minor crime, expanding library services for pre-kindergarten students, and tackling Houston's looming pension and budgetary problems.
"But let me make one thing perfectly clear: We are not going to balance our budget on the backs of the men and women who protect us every day - the police and firefighters," he said.
Eight other candidates have signaled they will join Bell in the field to replace term-limited Mayor Annise Parker: Turner; city councilmen Oliver Pennington and Stephen Costello; former Chronicle columnist Bill King; 2013 mayoral runner-up Ben Hall; airline executive Joe Ferreira; businessman Marty McVey; and Harris County Sheriff Adrian Garcia, who has not officially committed to the race.
Money to be raised
Bell told reporters he was excited for the pent-up energy of the long-anticipated race to be released.
"We have a lot of money that needs to be raised," he said. "We have a lot of support that needs to be built."

Headline Text: Houston Grand Opera: Historic 2014 Fundraising Campaign Raises $172.9 Million
Article Text:
Houston Grand Opera's Historic Fundraising Campaign
Raises $172.9 Million, a First for Houston Performing Arts
Houston, January 19, 2015‚ÄîHouston Grand Opera (HGO) has completed its fundraising campaign by raising an unprecedented $172.9 million, topping its goal of $165 million by December 31, 2014. Inspiring Performance‚ÄîThe Campaign for Houston Grand Opera was the company's first comprehensive fundraising campaign, and the most successful campaign in the history of Houston's performing arts community.
Inspiring Performance was co-chaired by Houston businessmen and HGO board members J. Scott Arnoldy, Chairman, President, and CEO of Triten Corporation and Albert Chao, President and CEO of Westlake Chemical Corporation. "Thanks to the tremendous generosity of donors from across Houston, the great state of Texas, and beyond," said Arnold, "Houston will have great opera for years to come, and a stronger future as a great American city."
HGO Managing Director Perryn Leech added, "We are humbled by the outpouring of support for HGO's mission and vision: to create the blueprint for a 21st century opera company, one that is world-class, affordable, and deeply connected to its community. We have already taken some thrilling steps to meet these goals and are extremely proud to be serving Houston at this new level."
Noted HGO Artistic and Music Director Patrick Summers, "An opera company must mature but never get old. HGO must continue to grow and to advance our art form so that more people in our dynamic, fast-growing city can experience the transformative power of opera for decades to come."
Inspiring Performance's success was driven by the visionary strategic plan adopted by HGO's board of directors, which focused on those three strategic pillars of excellence, relevance, and affordability. Among the projects and priorities the campaign has funded are:
* 30 new main stage productions.
* 17 world premieres, 1 American premiere.
* The NEXUS initiative, which has funded more than 175,000 free or deeply discounted tickets and subscriptions since its inception in 2008.
* Bringing Richard Wagner's epic Ring cycle to Houston for the first time.
* Critically acclaimed performances of Mieczyslaw Weinberg's long-suppressed opera The Passenger in Houston and at New York's Park Avenue Armory as part of the Lincoln Center Festival.
* The world's first mariachi opera, Cruzar la Cara de la Luna/To Cross the Face of the Moon. * Artistic growth of the HGO Orchestra and Chorus.
* Increased investment in outstanding young operatic talent through the HGO Studio, whose alumni (such as Anna Mar√≠a Mart√≠nez, Joyce DiDonato, and many others) are building major careers around the world.
  * The continued success of the High School Voice Studio (HSVS), 100% of whose graduates have been accepted into higher

In response to "Bill would let officials avoid gay marriage" (Feb. 25):
Uphold the law or find another job
A bill to allow public servants to avoid performing same-sex marriages? Really?
What about firefighters who don't want to put out fires at same-sex couples' homes, police officers who don't want to respond to crimes at same-sex couples' homes, or teachers who don't want to teach children of same-sex marriages?
Public servants must uphold the law. Our law guarantees separation of church and state. If public servants don't like it, they need to find a different job in the private sector.
Julie Blanton
Charlotte
In response to "Group fights LGBT bathroom issue" (Feb. 25):
It's about common sense; vote no on bathroom ordinance
I urge the mayor and Charlotte City Council to vote no on the "bathroom bill."
This is not about being politically correct. It is a moral issue, and a common sense issue.
I urge city officials to stand on the side of common sense and defeat this proposed ordinance. Ray Holt
Charlotte
Vote yes to ensure safety of city's socially disadvantaged
The writer is associate rector at St. Peter's Episcopal Church.
As an Episcopal priest, I am continually moved by Jesus' example of hospitality and kindness toward those in his culture who were shunned and socially disadvantaged, e.g. prostitutes, ethnic minorities, and even people who exercised oppressive political power like centurions.
This ordinance aligns with the compassionate spirit of Jesus.
I support it because it is an important statement of the City's commitment to ensuring the safety of its citizens and to eliminating barriers that prohibit citizens from contributing to the common good.
Rev. Joslyn Ogden Schaefer Charlotte
In response to "Defying GOP, Obama vetoes Keystone XL pipeline bill" (Feb. 25):
I'm OK with Keystone veto; let pipeline process play out
This is about bypassing and circumventing prudent review processes.
I don't think that obviating rules to rush profits on a stable resource is a good idea, and I like the beach, fish and shrimp.
Nebraska probably feels the same way about their aquifer, cows and amber waves of grain.
For some reason, they don't like foreigners condemning their private land for profit, and want due process.
I think I like Nebraska, surf 'n turf, and roasted corn on the cob. No rush...
William Hollar
Kannapolis
In response to "Can't fault UNC Board for trying to balance the scales" (Feb. 22 Forum):
Conservatively inclined professors may appear liberal
The writer is a retired history professor.
Forum writer Thomas Cochran Sr. finds fault with pervasive liberalism at universities.
I would just like to say this: The only way to make universities less liberal is to compromise the integrity of genuine education.
Education means opening minds, not defending a priori positions.
It is obvious that professors who pursue true education are open to a broad spectrum of opinions, which makes them appear "liberal," even if they are conservatively inclined.
Elmar B. Fetscher
Charlotte
In response to "Major snowstorm strikes" (Feb. 26):
Snow headline was bigger surprise than lack of flakes
When weather forecasters warn us of "six to seven inches of pure snow" and that doesn't happen, we make jokes and understand.
When the Charlotte Observer headline bellows "Major snowstorm strikes" after the contrary fact, we are puzzled at best and shocked at worst. An explanation is in order.
John V. Doyle
Matthews
Editor's note: We were dependent on the National Weather Service forecast, which called for 6-8 inches of snow in the Charlotte region as of 10 p.m. Wednesday. We finished our front page an hour earlier than normal to give Observer carriers more time to deliver the newspaper.

Headline Text: The Buzz - Anonymous comments from our readers on the issues of the day
Article Text:
Most secure job in Charlotte: Repairman for moving sidewalks at the airport.
Amazing to see people we elected ready to flush their legacy over a bathroom ordinance.
Dr. No vetoes Keystone XL. He must have faced a Specter.
Bravo for vetoing the Keystone XL, Mr. President!
I have "sincerely held" beliefs against being governed by idiots.
Using religion to legalize discrimination is hardly Christian.
In the spirit of equal rights, can a gay magistrate refuse to marry a straight couple?
It offends my religion to pay taxes.
To unite, emphasize our positives. To divide, our negatives. Clear as Reagan vs. Obama.
Three-quarters of all businesses fail. Are those the odds we want for our children's schools?
Snow: Nature's way of hiding man's ugliness.
How does an inch of snow turn into 12 inches of stupid?

Justified honor
Regarding "Hooray for love" (Page B7, Saturday), what an odd pronouncement, "The Civil War was about hate."
Can we simplify all war and say it was about hate?
Was the American Revolution about hate? I thought it was about independence from England.
Was World War II about hate? I thought it was about Hitler invading Europe and the Japanese attacking Pearl Harbor.
What about the Texas War with Mexico? Was it about hate? I thought it was because Mexico violated its agreement with Texian settlers and Santa Anna, self-styled Napoleon of West, was set on war for his own aggrandizement and profit.
Was the War Between the States about hate? The South was fighting for independence from the North. The brave men of the South risked their lives for freedom.
Texas Confederate Heroes Day is just that; it is to honor our Confederate heroes. It is not to honor the Yankees. Let the Yankees have all the holidays they want, but don't try to take away our Confederate Heroes Day. Barbara Duvall Wesolek, Houston
Name change OK
I do not have a problem with changing the name of Confederate Heroes Day. I do, however, object to the statement declaring the Civil War was about hate. Slavery has always been wrong, we know that.
The Civil War was about economics and a way of life. Hate had nothing to do with it. Duncan Chapman, Houston
...
Heck of an upset
Regarding "Even 25 years later, Tyson loss stunning" (Page C7, Feb. 11), if trainer Cus D' Amato had been handling Mike Tyson, I think Buster Douglas would have been down in the first three rounds.
Fred Harwell, posted on HoustonChronicle.com Medicine costs
Regarding "Cancer doc planning drive to cut drug costs" (Page B1, Tuesday), Dr. Hagop Kantarjian should be applauded for his efforts to highlight the high price of cancer drugs worldwide and particularly here in the U.S. Health care in America is a highly profitable and powerful business. The fact that Congress has enacted legislation to prevent the federal government from negotiating drug prices for the Medicare program shows how much power the lobbyists have over Americans' daily lives.
In addition, cancer patients in the U.S. pay twice as much for drugs as patients in other countries. This is shameful, but Congress fails to act.
The U.S. can and should learn from the experience of other countries in dealing with the drug companies. Leverage America's purchasing power and negotiate with the drug companies in the same way that the Canadians and Europeans do.
Bill Meyer, Kingwood Treat all with respect
Regarding "Vigil honors 3 Muslim students shot to death in N. Carolina" (Page B1, Monday), what kind of resentment can cause someone to shoot 3 college students in the head as happened in the recent Chapel Hill shootings? Some say it was over a "parking dispute," but the answer may lie in the growing Islamophobia in the country.
As we try to understand the reasons behind this senseless slaughter, we should remember to treat everyone by their deeds, and call an "act of terrorism" an act of terrorism - irrespective of the religious affiliations of the perpetrator.
The loss of one child is too much pain to bear. The loss of three young, vibrant people with their lives ahead of them is a pain I cannot imagine.
Abass Abubakr-Bibilazu, Houston
Hard lessons
Regarding "Chicago team stripped of 2014 U.S. title" (Page C5, Thursday), it is pretty obvious that there was some deception going on with regard to the makeup of the Chicago roster. Therefore, I would like to respond to those wondering out loud about this being about race versus boundaries.
The adults in charge of the Chicago Little League team cheated. I do not think that cheating is a race issue, but I think it is definitely a character issue. I choose to judge these adults on the basis of their character, as evidenced by their behavior.
Sadly the Chicago team members lost something they could have treasured the rest of their lives. Mike Ganis, Houston
Trouble in Spring
Regarding "TEA to review Spring ISD probe" (Page A1, Saturday), while school officials at Spring Independent School District have clearly fallen down on the job, students and their parents also bear some responsibility for this mess. Surely a parent who checks his child's report card should know that a failing grade in a class means that class must be repeated. And what thinking student or parent could believe that one receives credit for taking the same class more than once?
This is what happens when parents abdicate the responsibility for their child's education to a school system - be it public or private. Texas graduation requirements, easily found with a simple Internet search, appear in an easy-to-understand two-page document. It's time for Texas parents to "trust but verify" when it comes to their children's education.
Aletha Evert, Houston Equal rights ordinance. Regarding "Both sides confident after mixed verdict" (Page A1, Saturday), I find it a sad commentary on our city's administration that a personal agenda is driving decision-making by those who are supposed to be representatives of the citizens at large.
Regardless of one's personal opinion of the equal rights ordinance, the only thing that the citizens have been asking is that it be put to the vote of the people.
The petition was not to overturn the ordinance. Whether it is 10,000 or 100,000 signatures should not be the point. A significant number of Houston-ians have spoken.
There was an election held in November. The ordinance could have been placed on the ballot at little or no cost, certainly less than the legal fees the city is paying now.

Headline Text: Equal Rights Ordinance - Both sides confident after mixed verdict
Article Text:
The city claimed victory Friday when the jury in the trial surrounding Houston's equal rights ordinance found that the law's opponents submitted a repeal referendum petition that contained forgery and other flaws.
However, it issued a series of decisions that was far from a clean sweep for either side.
The ruling is not final, and a judge now will consider the jury's findings about the work of more than 100 circulators of the petition that the city rejected last summer, citing overwhelming notary and signature-gatherer errors.
District Judge Robert Schaffer was not present for Friday's ruling after nearly six days of jury deliberation. Attorneys on both sides said he now will begin counting which signatures are valid to see if opponents have reached the needed 17,269-signature threshold. Schaffer retains wide legal discretion in what he deems valid.
The jury's ruling Friday will trigger a series of legal dominoes that, eventually, will yield a definitive answer: The judge will count the signatures, issue a decision on whether the petition is valid and then the case almost certainly will go to the appellate courts.
Attorneys on both sides, however, were quick to say the jury's verdict would prompt Schaffer to rule in their favor.
"Anyone who was hoping that the jury's verdict would give a clear indication that the Houston equal rights ordinance is valid and will withstand this attack should be thrilled and dancing in their kitchen because that's what the jury did here," attorney Geoffrey Harrison said. "The jury rejected out of hand the repeal petition from the plaintiffs."
Harrison contends the group is more than 10,000 signatures below the threshold. He said the jury's ruling that 12 of 13 circulators in question submitted pages containing forgery and that some high-volume circulators did not properly sign the pages they collected bodes well for the city. The law's conservative opponents, however, maintained they would prevail when the judge begins his review, saying he has the power to reject some of the jury's findings.
Lawyer Andy Taylor cited the jury's conclusion that none of the 13 circulators in question submitted pages containing fraud as a victory. And on the big-ticket question of whether 98 different circulators correctly "signed and subscribed" the pages they submitted, Taylor said he was encouraged by the 33 signature gatherers the jury found had done so.
"The thing that is super significant here is that the jury found no fraud," Taylor said. "This mayor has been claiming for over six months that these hardworking citizens committed fraud, and this jury found that they did not. So they can take that to the bank."
Parker 'very pleased'
Mayor Annise Parker said in a statement Friday that she was "very pleased" with the jury's ruling and expects the judge ultimately will rule that critics' petition had failed. She also said she hopes the opponents will not take the fight to the appellate courts.
"I believe that the majority of Houston wants this divisive fight to be over so that we are able to provide equal rights protections for all of our residents," Parker said. "The city is confident it will prevail."
The ruling marked yet another twist in the political saga that has unfolded since City Council last spring approved the ordinance with an 11-6 vote. The law bans discrimination based not just on sexual orientation and gender identity but also, as federal laws do, sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information, as well as family, marital or military status. The ordinance applies to businesses that serve the public, private employers, housing, city employment and city contracting. Religious institutions are exempt.
Critics of the ordinance, largely conservative activists, object to the protections it extends to gay and transgender residents. They sued the city when Parker and former City Attorney David Feldman rejected their petition to force a repeal referendum last summer.
From the outpouring of impassioned testimony in council chambers to, months later, the outcry over the city's admittedly botched subpoenaing of certain pastors, controversy around the law has erupted numerous times.
But the jurors were not contemplating the merits of the ordinance and were instead handed the unenviable task of poring over the 5,199-page petition and answering six questions about the work of more than 100 circulators. Those questions were about technical issues such as whether certain circulators both "signed and subscribed" petition pages they collected, whether the city could have determined a specific signature gatherer's identity and whether petition pages contain fraud or forgery. Ten of the 12 jurors signed off on the final decision.
Judge commends jurors
Schaffer and attorneys on both sides marveled at the level of scrutiny jurors applied to the charge, submitting a flurry of detailed questions and, in one instance, calling attention to an improperly redacted page in a sea of thousands of documents.
"The length of this deliberation nobody could have anticipated," Schaffer said Thursday.
The deliberations lasted almost as long as the trial, which spanned seven days of testimony and featured everyone from Parker to plaintiff Jared Woodfill to Feldman on the stand.
"It was a very personal trial," Woodfill said. "But I'm excited about the ruling."
Likewise, Harrison said the city had good reason to celebrate.
"This is an exciting moment and an exciting result for anyone who cares about equal rights in Houston," Harrison said.
Both parties will get a better sense of whether their claims to victory are likely to hold up when Schaffer meets with the attorneys on Feb. 19 to discuss what happens next.

Headline Text: HOUSTON GIVES - HOUSTON HEROES - Advocating for new opportunities - As a training director at First Person, Melanie Pang focuses on changing the way nonprofits operate
Article Text:
How to help
To learn more about the programs offered by First Person, go to firstpersonhouston.com.
To learn more about the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, go to thecaucus.org.
Melanie Pang says she doesn't have much time to volunteer.
"I don't always have the privilege because I'm so busy trying to pay off my student debt and support myself and my family," she says. Pang lives with her partner, Kendall Cande Toarmina, and their two rescue dogs near the Texas Medical Center.
Pang has instead turned her life mission into her work.
"I definitely got the feeling that I was supposed to be using my voice. I grew up with a lot of limitations," she says. "Through school, I started to see that a lot of those limitations just don't really exist."
Pang, 28, uses her skills to "create equal access to opportunity for all people." She's a training director at First Person, a consulting firm that provides strategy and leadership for socially responsible organizations Among Pang's projects are CAN DO Houston (Children and Neighbors Defeat Obesity), where she serves as project manager.
"I took this job to try to change the way nonprofits work," Pang says. "I would love to see a social enterprise model that would help create economic opportunities for those people who are on the verge of homelessness or experiencing homelessness. We could actually be employing those people, giving them those soft skills, giving them the guidance.
"That's one of my pie-in-the-sky dreams."
Pang grew up in Missouri City as the youngest of four children to a Chinese father and Filipino mother (who she calls "a huge inspiration"). She attended Elkins High School and earned a full music-education scholarship to the University of Houston. But something just didn't feel right.
"I started to get this urge, this itch to do more. I was in a wonderful program, but being in music can sometimes be limiting. I felt like college was all about expanding my world view, not narrowing it," Pang says.
She gave up her scholarship, got a job and switched to journalism. The new major required an internship, and she found one in the communications department at the Houston Food Bank. That's when her life finally - and fully - clicked into place.
"After hearing all of their stories, I was like, 'I can't just write about this. I have to do something about it.'," she says.
Pang earned her bachelor's degree in journalism in 2010. She was one of the first students to minor in GLBT studies and served as president of GLOBAL, the school's gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender, questioning, inter-sex and asexual alliance. She went on to a master's degree in social work.
She lectured at the university during the 2012-2013 year as part of the GLBT studies course and the Women's, Gender and Sexuality Studies Program. She also worked as a community case manager for Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of Galveston-Houston as part of St. Jerome's Unaccompanied Refuge Minor Foster Care Program.
"I had that sort of Miss America mentality. 'I just want to help people,' " Pang says. "I thought going to school was going to help me find my niche. At the end of school, I felt like I had even more options. But I thought, 'Why do I have to choose only one passion?' "
Pang recently was named social worker of the year by the local chapter of the National Association of Social Workers and was featured in OutSmart magazine's list of emerging LGBTQ women leaders.
She's also a tireless advocate for the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, which bans discrimination based on sexual orientation, gender identity, sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information, family, marital or military status.
"It's still shocking to so many people (that) LGBT people are currently not protected," Pang says. "Here is our shining opportunity to do something about that."
Though her days of practicing the French horn and dreams of becoming a music teacher are distant memories, Pang still finds a connection to her advocacy work.
"In band and in music (classes), there was so much about harmony and unity and modesty. I think music is a great model for leadership in teaching people how to work toward a single purpose," she says.
"My little oompah-oompah part in the march is not super-important and should not take over everything. It's more about, how I can bring them into the room and how I can elevate their voices? That's not so different from music."

RELIGION
Senate OKs sermon protections
Voting 30-1, the Texas Senate on Tuesday approved legislation to protect ministers and religious leaders from being compelled to provide the government copies of their sermons.
Senate Bill 2048 by Sen. Joan Huffman, R-Houston, also exempts religious leaders from having to testify about a sermon in lawsuits to which the government is a party.
The legislation was inspired by the city of Houston's 2014 subpoenas to five Houston pastors who opposed the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, which bars businesses from discriminating against gay, lesbian and transgender people.
SB 2048 next goes to the House. - Chuck Lindell, American-Statesman HIGHWAYS
Senate backs ending DPS diversion
The Texas Senate on Tuesday endorsed ending the diversion of State Highway Fund money to the Department of Public Safety.
The lost money for DPS - which amounted to $812.6 million in 2014-15 - would be replaced with money from the state's general fund. The move also would require voters to approve a constitutional amendment striking language allowing highway money to be diverted to DPS.
Senate Bill 139 and Senate Joint Resolution 12 next go to the House, where a proposed constitutional amendment is awaiting a floor vote.
- Chuck Lindell, American-Statesman

Headline Text: Transgender supporters take concerns to Austin - Jenner interview raises hopes for families
Article Text:
Jenner's interview captured why some genuinely love the Kardashians: HoustonChronicle.com/Jenner
Clutching a picture of her 9-year-old son Benjamin, a tearful Ann Elder said Monday that she had loved and cared for the adopted child for years before she truly got to know him.
"By the age of 3, my little girl started having trouble with wearing female clothing, kept saying that she didn't want to be 'pretty,' that she wanted to be 'handsome,' " said Elder, a Friendswood native. After three years of doctors' visits and many long talks, Benjamin was diagnosed as "gender variant," she said.
"At 7, my child fully transitioned to a boy, and he is the happiest kid I've ever seen," Elder said. "The day we went to Target to buy him boys' underwear was the day I finally met my child."
Elder was one of two dozen advocates for transgender Texans who rallied outside the Texas Capitol early Monday, just three days after gold medal decathlon winner Bruce Jenner declared, "I am a woman" in an ABC-TV interview with Diane Sawyer.
The Austin gathering came amid battles over the rights of gay, lesbian and transgender people at the state and local levels. Texas lawmakers in this session have filed more than 30 bills that could restrict LGBT rights, while in Houston a conservative activist is continuing to try to force an election that would bar men "who perceive or express themselves as women" from entering women's restrooms.
Katrina Stewart, executive director of Transgender Education Network of Texas, said as more transgender Americans like Jenner become more visible, the community experiences both more acceptance - and more backlash.
"We're very hopeful for the Bruce Jenner interview that happened the other day and how that's going to play out in allowing people to better hear, better be of the mindset to listen to the stories of their neighbors and friends," said Stewart. "What we want to do is share our stories. We're not here to make people scared. But that fear shows that they are people listening."
Members of the transgender community are particularly concerned about a number of House bills that would make it a crime for a transgender person to use a restroom that is contrary to the sex they were assigned at birth.
Rep. Debbie Riddle, R-Tomball, said she filed her so-called "bathroom bills" in reaction to Houston Mayor Annise Parker successfully pushing for a local ordinance that would ban discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity. The Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, or HERO, originally included language that explicitly would have allowed transgender Houstonians to use bathrooms matching their gender expression; the protections remain but the ordinance now puts the burden on the individual to prove he or she was a victim of discrimination.
"That really opens a door for those who really aren't transgender, but who are pedophiles. And it makes it dangerous for little girls; it makes it dangerous for women," Riddle said. "If you don't care about the safety of children then you might support those kinds of things. But if you care about the safety of children more than you care about political correctness, then you would support the bill."
Rep. Gilbert Pena, R-Pasadena, has filed two bills that would go even further than Riddle's, allowing students to sue and receive $2,000 in relief if they identify a student using a bathroom that doesn't match his or her "biological sex." The bills would also require school districts to provide alternative bathroom and locker rooms for transgender students.
 Pena refused to discuss his bills with the Houston Chronicle, but an anti-discrimination activist said his proposal was appalling. "This is sort of the opposite of small government. This is putting monitors in the bathroom," said Mara Keisling, executive director of the National Center for Transgender Equality. "It's absolutely immoral to put a bounty on a schoolchild's head."
Keisling said even or eight other states have recently proposed similar "bathroom" bills, but no state has yet passed such legislation. Rep. Byron Cook, R-Corsicana, who chairs the State Affairs Committee that determines whether these bills will get a hearing, indicated Monday he does not expect them to go anywhere.
"Those kind of bills require a lot of thought and so I think there's a lot of work that needs to go into related to this," Cook said. "So it would be surprising to me if there was any movement on this issue this late in this session."
The term "transgender" refers to someone whose gender identity or expression does not match the sex he or she was born with. Transgender is unique from "transsexual," in that a transgender person may choose to live as a woman or man - by dressing and identifying themselves as such - without taking hormones or having surgery.
Monday's lobbying effort was successful, the advocates said. Staffers in Pena's office even pledged to meet with LGBT activists after the session to discuss their experiences, said Transgender Education Network of Texas board member Brandon Beck.
Elder, the mother of the transgender son, said she hoped the lobbying further humanized the issue for lawmakers and the public.
"I prayed to God and I said to God I want to be a mother," she said. "My commitment to God is to raise a child in his honor. ... It is my belief that I am still abiding by my commitment to God. This is God's child, and I'm making sure he's going to get the emotional support, the hormonal support, the education, to be everything we all love in our children."
In my #Houston, and in yours, we value #equalrights for all! #HERO #HOUEquality #StateofHOU
Breakfast with Council Members Cohen & Laster and city team that passed Houston Equal Rights Ordinance 1 year ago.-A

Headline Text: Baseball: Mariners hope to build some momentum vs. Keuchel
Article Text:
(SportsNetwork.com) - The Seattle Mariners shoot for back-to-back wins for
just the second time this month as they host the Houston Astros at Safeco
Field in the second of a three-game set on Saturday night.
Seattle has alternated wins and losses over the last eight decisions,
rebounding from a 7-0 shutout versus San Francisco on Thursday by capturing a 5-2 triumph versus the Astros in the series opener. Unfortunately for the Mariners, they are still five games under .500 at home and are the only team
in the AL West that has a negative scoring differential (minus-47) currently.
In snapping a five-game win streak by Houston, the leader in the AL West by 2 1/2 games over Texas, starting pitcher Roenis Elias evened his record at 4-4
by giving up just two runs on four hits, while striking out 10 in his seven
innings of work. Carson Smith eventually came on to grab his fourth save of
the campaign.
On offense, Mark Trumbo finally showed some signs of life by knocking in three of his team's five runs, although he is still hitting just .188. Robinson Cano produced three hits and scored twice, while Nelson Cruz had a pair of hits and
as many walks for the hosts.
"It's an important series. I can't kid you and say it's not," commented
Seattle manager Lloyd McClendon. "It really is. This is important for us to
make a statement and try to continue to move forward and do the things we need to do to get back in this race."
Lance McCullers was tagged with the loss for Houston as the starter
surrendered five runs -- three earned -- on six hits and three walks over 4  1/3 innings. McCullers, who is now 3-2, struck out six.
The meeting starting promising enough for the Astros as George Springer sent
the very first pitch of the contest into the seats for his 11th home run of
the season, but after that the visitors managed just three hits and one more
run. Marwin Gonzalez had two of those hits, one being his fourth home run.
Prior to last night the Astros were 27-0 on the season when hitting multiple
home runs.
Gunning for his ninth win of the campaign for Houston will be fourth-year man
Dallas Keuchel. The left-hander has alternated wins and losses over his last
five decisions, coming off a victory against Colorado on Monday at home.
In that contest Keuchel gave up three runs on four hits and a pair of walks,
while striking out four in 6 2/3 innings of work. The hurler had a perfect
game working through the first five frames before the Rockies finally broke
through.
In seven previous appearances against Seattle, all but one of those being
starts, Keuchel has a 3-3 mark with a 2.25 ERA.
Over on the other side, Taijuan Walker is hoping his recent efforts will carry
over to tonight, having won two straight and three of his last four outings.
The right-hander went up against the San Francisco Giants on the road Monday
and scattered seven hits, but permitted just a single earned run while fanning
six over seven innings. In the last two games Walker, who is 3-1 in his career
versus Houston, has surrendered only two runs on 15 hits and struck out 12.

Headline Text: What Mumbai can learn from US' equal rights ordinance
Article Text:
Mumbai, June 1 -- The silent discrimination that many in Mumbai suffer in public spheres such as employment or housing recently came to light with the story of an MBA graduate being denied a job because of his religion.
A possible solution to this problem could just be in the unlikeliest of places - the metropolis of Houston. One of the most populous cities in the United States, Houston celebrated one year of bringing in a unique law - one that bans all forms of discrimination in all streams of public life.
Called the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance (HERO), the law is one of the most comprehensive pieces of legislation with a list of 15 categories of possible discrimination. What makes the HERO so progressive is that while it provides protection against religion and race-based discrimination, it also includes two crucial categories - sexual orientation and gender identity.
Spearheading this legislation was one of the few openly gay politicians - Mayor Annise Parker, who was in Mumbai recently to speak to the city's investors about Houston. Speaking to HT, Parker said the ordinance was as much about setting right conventional wrongs as it was about sending out the right signals.
"We didn't have any laws to protect the rights of the Lesbian Gay Bisexual Transgender (LGBT) community against discrimination. This ordinance was our way of saying Houston as a city is open and welcoming to everyone, no matter what their personal choices are," said Parker.
Now, any act of discrimination is a punishable offence. The law covers a wide range of categories - including race, national origin, marital status and disability. It also covers access to public and private spaces such as restaurants, banks and hotels, among other establishments.
Getting the law passed was not easy. Conservative sections of society were opposed to the bill. What pushed Parker was her own struggle with her identity. "I began working for gay rights in the '70s, which was quite a repressive time with people getting arrested and stigmatised because of their sexual identity."

Headline Text: Mayor pulls back on charter amendments - Changing term limits and revenue cap held in favor of HERO after recent court decision
Article Text:
With her signature nondiscrimination law likely to appear on the November ballot, Mayor Annise Parker left in doubt Wednesday whether she will ask City Council to also place before voters long-discussed changes to term limits and the city's revenue cap.
Parker said she has no interest in putting the latter two items to amend the city charter to a vote only to see them fail because they lacked robust campaigns behind them.
"It was my full expectation that I'd be spending my remaining campaign funds and my personal time advocating for these two good- government items, but because of the presence of HERO (the Houston equal rights ordinance) on the ballot, I'm going to be having to split my energy over there," she said. "There is no - at this point - group willing to step up and advocate for the other two. I'm not going to put some things out there just to fail. It may be more timely to bring the charter amendments to next November's electorate, and I can leave that decision to the next mayor."
Term-limited Parker, the first openly gay mayor of a major American city, said she will discuss with council members and make a final decision in the coming days on what items to place on the agenda for the group's Aug. 5 meeting.
The equal rights ordinance bans discrimination based not just on sexual orientation and gender identity - the flash points for opponents - but also, as federal laws do, sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information, as well as family, marital or military status. The ordinance applies to businesses that serve the public, private employers, housing, city employment and city contracting. Religious institutions are exempt. Violators could be fined up to $5,000.
Amendments left out
Political observers say the divisive ordinance's appearance on the ballot may skew the electorate by rallying conservatives to show up for what are typically extremely low-turnout municipal elections, and could undercut discussion of other issues in the mayoral and council races, such as the city budget and crumbling streets.
University of Houston political science professor Brandon Rottinghaus said Parker's wariness of moving forward with complicated governance issues when such a clear-cut social issue will be on the ballot is well founded.
"You'll have pro and con on HERO, and that's going to create a politics and a set of voters that may not reflect the kind of voters that would otherwise come out for an issue of importance to city finances," he said. "I think she's wise in that way to push things off to make sure those issues get the kind of hearing they deserve instead of the kind of hearing they'd otherwise get in the politics of the moment."
Councilman C.O. Bradford took a different view, suggesting the voters drawn out by an open mayoral field and controversial city issues would be those best positioned to decide issues of municipal governance. He called for more charter amendment options, not fewer.
If the mayor does not post an item inviting broad discussion of all council members' ideas, Bradford said, he will seek a special council meeting for that purpose. Among the ideas worthy of discussion, he said, is the ability for council members to place items on the agenda; currently only the mayor has that ability.
"I don't think one single item can lock down the city's business," Bradford said, referring to HERO. "If council is not afforded this opportunity because the mayor doesn't post it, it makes my point again about how the process is broken down here." Proposals unpopular
The heaviest political lift, the mayor acknowledged, would be to seek an increase in the revenue cap to allow more spending for public safety, as occurred in 2006 under former Mayor Bill White.
The cap, first approved in 2004, limits the annual increase in city property tax revenues to the combined rates of inflation and population growth. Last year, the city hit the cap for the first time, forcing a cut in the tax rate. Houston would have had $53 million more to spend in the current budget without the cap, and confronts a $126 million budget deficit next summer, driven by soaring pension and debt costs, as well as the cap.
Neither City Council nor voters appear inclined to entertain an increase. A council committee in February voted not to send any cap modifications to voters, and an overwhelming share of respondents in a recent KUHF-KHOU poll opposed any tax increase. Still, Parker said she will seek input from the police and fire unions to gauge their willingness to take on a revenue cap campaign.
The other significant change to the charter that Parker had pledged to advance was a shift from three two-year council terms to two four-year terms starting in 2019. That idea has drawn support on the council, but twice as many respondents in the recent poll favored the status quo over the proposed change.
Regardless of what items come up next week, the equal rights ordinance is certain to be debated - under orders from the Texas Supreme Court. The justices on Friday ended months of legal wrangling over whether a repeal petition opponents of the law submitted last year contained enough valid signatures by ruling that the council must repeal the ordinance or place it before the public.
Legal battle continues
Another set of legal wrangling may also result in a petition filed by anti-gay activist and Houston Community College trustee Dave Wilson appearing on the ballot. Wilson seeks a vote to amend the city charter and bar men "who perceive or express themselves as women" from entering women's restrooms by defining gender identity the "innate identification ... assigned at birth." It would require businesses to adopt the same definition.
The city is in the process of appealing a state district judge's ruling Tuesday that the names on Wilson's petition, which he submitted July 9, must be counted. Parker's legal team has contended his proposal is invalid because it attempts to undercut the equal rights ordinance not via the process set forth for repealing ordinances but by amending the charter.
