Headline Text: Houston Unites Launches Campaign to Support Equal Rights Ordinance
Article Text:
HOUSTON, Aug. 12 -- The American Civil Liberties Union of Texas issued the following news release:
Today, the Houston Unites campaign launched to prevent the repeal of Houston's Equal Rights Ordinance (HERO) on the November ballot. Houston is the most diverse city in the country, but is also the only city of its size in the country lacking an equal rights ordinance. HERO's anti-discrimination protections extend to fifteen separate categories -- including race, gender, gender identity, veteran status, disability, age and sexual orientation -- and would provide Houstonians with a local recourse to discrimination complaints that is timely, effective and affordable.
Members of the Houston Unites coalition voiced their support for the ordinance and urged Houston voters to educate themselves on the protections for all citizens:
Dr. James M. Douglas, President, NAACP Houston Branch: "The NAACP has and will always be focused on the elimination of discrimination against all people. As an organization, we have always been and will continue to be inclusive, not exclusive. HERO is not just about black, brown or red. HERO is also not just about male and female. Instead, HERO is about every one of us. Hopefully, we can continue to grow as a city by recognizing that we are all members of the human race and that the only way we can achieve our goal of becoming a great city is by accepting the rights of all of us to equally participate in this society we call Houston, Texas."
Bobby Singh, Principal, Isani Consultants, L.P.: "If we fail to protect HERO in November, we're sending a clear message to the rest of the country that we aren't a business-friendly destination. That depending on who you are, we might not want to do business with you. And that's wrong. Every person in our city deserves the chance to be successful and to live and work without fear of discrimination."
Leslie Jackson, Minister at Cathedral of Hope Houston: "I know the stories of those who have faced discrimination because of who they are or whom they love. They are our neighbors, our coworkers, our friends and family members. I believe Jesus calls me and all Christians to treat them with dignity and respect and to oppose, with determination, the discrimination they have faced."
Ann Elder, mother of a transgender child: "HERO is important to me because it will ensure my son, whom I am so proud of and love dearly, can grow up safe and sound. I know my boy has a bright future and so much to offer. HERO is about ensuring he and all children can reach their full potential."
Sonia Corrales, Chief Program Officer, Houston Area Women's Center: "As the Chief Program Officer of the Houston Area Women's Center, the safety of women and children is my first priority. I've worked my entire career to protect women and to support those who have experienced violence. Sexual assault is a terrible crime that affects people in every community. It's real; it's scary; and it has absolutely nothing to do with our city's equal rights ordinance."
Rabbi Roy A. Walter, Rabbi Emeritus, Congregation Emanu El: "We are all God's children, regardless of our religious beliefs, our race or ethnicity, our sex or age, our sexual orientation or gender identity. No one has a monopoly on God's love. And we all have the right to live our lives free from discrimination."
Houston Unites is the coalition working to elevate the diversity of voices supporting HERO. The leading coalition partners include: ACLU of Texas, Equality Texas, Freedom For All Americans, Human Rights Campaign, NAACP Houston Branch and Texas Freedom Network.

Headline Text: Let's wait - A term limit vote shouldn't be placed in the shadow of the equal rights ordinance.
Article Text:
After years of study and debate, term limits have almost made their way to the November ballot - and the timing couldn't be worse. Everyone's attention is on the Houston equal rights ordinance, and City Coucnil should keep it that way.
At today's City Council meeting, our elected local representatives are scheduled to decide whether Houston should have a referendum vote on changing term limits. An ad hoc committee on charter reform, which included each council member, has recommended that the question be put up to the voters. The choice would be between the status quo or a White House model - keeping our current system of three, two-year terms or shifting to two, four-year terms for the mayor, controller and City Council members.
Houston's term limits have a structural influence on the way that business gets done in our local government, and political observers have argued about their efficacy dating back to their original implementation in a 1991 referendum. These pages have long advocated for changing or eliminating this barrier to voters selecting the candidates of their choice.
However, it is difficult to have a thorough conversation about this topic when the fight over Houston's equal rights ordinance is sucking up all the oxygen in the room. If the so-called HERO is going to be on the November ballot, then City Council would be smart to ensure that it doesn't have to share the spotlight.
Referendum-style government risks radical policy swings based more on turnout than a true political will. Emotional arguments and inflamed passions risk overshadowing an important vote on term limits - one that deserves greater focus than a runner-up position.
While we agreed with the ad hoc committee on charter reform at the time, new facts on the ground should lead council members to reconsider their votes. Beyond the fight over the equal rights ordinance, changes to fundraising laws also raise additional issues that haven't yet been considered. City Hall candidates used to be prohibited from raising money for 10 months between election cycles. This blackout ordinance, passed in 1992, was temporarily blocked by a federal judge earlier this year.
Under the U.S. Supreme Court's 2010 decision in Citizens United v. FEC, monetary donations to political campaigns are protected as free speech. Houston policy makers have yet to comprehend the long-term local consequences of this ruling. Before moving forward on a vote, City Council should appoint a commission of experts to study how campaign fundraising interacts with term limits.
Houston is hot enough already, and campaigns don't really turn up the heat until after Labor Day. Let's wait for things to cool off before considering the dry, technical business of changing term limits.

It's a beautiful day in #Houston‚Äî& at 10 CST, Houstonians will stand together to keep discrimination out of our city!
We're getting setup now for our press conference announcing the launch of our historic campaign to defend #HERO!

Personal choice
Regarding "Anti-HERO campaign will sow division where it should not be" (Page B13, Sunday), the Rev. Rudy Rasmus is spot-on with his statement that we should all love our neighbor and treat everyone with dignity and respect. But he misses the mark by failing to understand that the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance (HERO) is not about love and dignity; it's about government.
We have the freedom to associate with whom we choose, but that implies that we also have the freedom to not associate with whom we choose. That is what "discrimination" is. Would Jesus approve? Probably not. But is it a crime? No way.
It's one thing for police to protect life and property from theft and violence. But HERO gives government agents the power to override personal choice and arrest and punish someone from exercising this basic right of association.
David M. Woods, Houston Must win
Regarding "Skip the piousness and give Rice a call" (Page C1, Monday), the column provided the perfect argument for why Ray Rice should be allowed to play in the NFL again: because the Texans need to win!
How have I missed why many sports players get to live by different rules from the rest of us? Of course, it's so their teams can win (Translate: Make money).
Why does it matter whether a young woman gets punched out in an elevator or another raped on a college campus? If sports teams don't keep an open mind about letting players who commit such acts play, well, they might lose!
Paige Hagle, Houston Just laughs
Regarding letter to the editor "Bacon-fried" (Page B7, Saturday), writer Pat Koenig was "horrified" by U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz's rifle bacon stunt. Can we all stop overreacting and keep things in perspective? Aborted fetus body parts for sale is "horrifying." The Ted Cruz video was "silly" at worst (although I had a good chuckle when I read about it).
Diane Sulpizio, Houston Trump-worthy
Regarding too many articles and syndicated columns on "the Don," and after much trenchant soul-searching, I've decided to like Donald Trump. His flaws are many: self-deprecating humor, over-the-top self-aggrandizement, self-well-almost-anything, and bad hair. But, other than the hair, these are also the things I like about him.
He's proud of what he's done. He's proud of who he is. He's proud of what he's built. He should be.
He knows he's flawed in areas of diplomacy, humility and political correctness. But being "politically correct" sometimes means tippy-toeing around the real issue and calling a spade a, well, heart (i.e., less dark, fewer sharp edges, easier to stomach). As president of the United States, he might be an abomination. Then again, he might not. Back in the day, Teddy Roosevelt was a boisterous, pompous reactionary and Ronald Reagan, on his best day, a B-actor. At the very least, he's likely convincing the GOP that candor and heart are not necessarily antithetical to campaigning and potentially winning an election. 
That's definitely something to like. Clyde Miner, Friendswood

Headline Text: Rights law foes challenge ballot language - Suit alleges that measure is written in a way that would confuse voters
Article Text:
The ballot language
752 Words
 "Shall the City of Houston repeal the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, Ord. No. 2014-530, which prohibits discrimination in city employment and city services, city contracts, public accommodations, private employment, and housing based on an individual's sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, familial status, marital status, military status, religion, disability, sexual orientation, genetic information, gender identity, or pregnancy?"
More online
Read more about the equal rights ordinance fight at HoustonChronicle.com/equalrights
Equal rights ordinance opponents on Friday sued Mayor Annise Parker for the second time this week, challenging the ballot language that will go to voters in November and marking yet another chapter in the protracted legal battle over her signature non- discrimination law.
At issue is whether the ballot item should ask voters if they favor repealing the law or not - or if they support implementing the law or not. City Council approved sending the equal rights ordinance to voters on Wednesday, under order from the Texas Supreme Court to either repeal the law or affirm it and place it on the November ballot.
Then, City Council tackled the ballot language. Attorney Andy Taylor, who represents the opponents, told City Council he believed City Charter does not allow for a suspended ordinance to be voted on by repeal - enforcement of the law has been tabled under the court's order. The current ballot language asks "shall the city of Houston repeal the Equal Rights Ordinance," so a supporter of the law would vote against it, and an opponent would vote in favor.
In a news release, Taylor said Parker "decided to play games with the language in an effort to confuse voters on the effect of a 'Yes' or 'No' vote." Taylor said that those opposed to the ordinance might instinctively vote against a ballot item that pertains to the law without realizing that they should instead cast a vote in favor of repeal.
Taylor submitted an emergency request to the Texas Supreme Court on Friday morning and was granted an expedited schedule by early afternoon. The city must respond by Thursday and all ballot items face an Aug. 24 deadline.
Conservative activist Jared Woodfill, a plaintiff in the case along with Pastor F.N. Williams Sr., said opponents viewed the court's quick response as "very positive."
"The ballot language is deceptive, and it's unlawful," Woodfill said. "And we believe the court again is going to hold her accountable for it."
Parker issued a statement Friday, noting that the language on the ballot is similar to a sentence included in the repeal referendum petition that opponents submitted to the city last year. That petition asked voters to sign if they wanted the law repealed. She also pointed to a 1997 Texas Supreme Court ruling that gave the city the authority to craft ballot language for a referendum.
"This lawsuit isn't about whether the ballot language is easy to understand or complies with the law," Parker said in the statement. "The pastors group is opposed to a Houston free of discrimination for all and will do anything they can to try to confuse the voters." The equal rights ordinance bans discrimination based not just on sexual orientation and gender identity - the flash points for opponents - but also, as federal laws do, sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information, as well as family, marital or military status.
The ordinance applies to businesses that serve the public, private employers, housing, city employment and city contracting. Religious institutions are exempt. Violators can be fined up to $5,000.
Conservative opponents submitted a petition to send the law to voters last summer, but city officials rejected it, saying it was riddled with errors and did not contain the needed 17,269 valid signatures from Houston residents. That triggered a lawsuit from opponents and the subsequent district court and Supreme Court rulings.
On Monday, opponents again filed suit against Parker, seeking unspecified court costs and other damages associated with the earlier lawsuit. Three pastors also are suing Parker for damages and legal costs incurred when the city, as part of a broad discovery request, issued subpoenas that included a demand for certain sermons. Those subpoenas eventually were pulled down amid significant backlash.
Parker took flak for that incident in remarks made by Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., during Thursday night's GOP presidential candidates debate. Through a spokeswoman, Parker declined to comment on the remarks.

Headline Text: Houston council moves transgender 'bathroom bill' to November ballot
Article Text:
Houston voters will decide in November whether to repeal the city's hotly contested equal-rights ordinance, also known as the transgender "bathroom bill," after a Wednesday vote of the city council.
The council voted 13-4 in favor of a ballot measure that asks voters whether to repeal the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance (HERO), which bans discrimination based on sexual orientation, gender identity and other characteristics, requiring businesses open to the public to allow opposite-sex bathroom use.
The council, which passed the ordinance in May 2014, had little choice after the Texas Supreme Court ruled July 24 that the city had violated its charter by overruling the city secretary's approval of petitions to place the measure on the ballot.
The decision represents an enormous victory for the pastor-led coalition fighting the ordinance, but the ballot language approved Wednesday by the council could ignite another court fight.
The four council members who voted against the ballot measure argued that language should be framed so that voters who oppose the ordinance would be able to vote "no" on the HERO, instead of "yes" on the repeal.
At Wednesday's meeting, which was live-streamed, the council rejected an amendment to reframe the ballot language brought by council member C.O. Bradford. His proposal would have asked the voters, "Shall the city of Houston implement" the equal-rights ordinance.
"I guess it'll be back to the courthouse again and that's unfortunate, because we could get it right and we could move this thing forward for the voters to vote on it, and not spend hundreds of thousands of additional dollars," Mr. Bradford said. "But I think that's where we are."
Council member Michael Kubosh accused Mayor Annise Parker and other council members of trying to stack the deck in favor of the ordinance, calling the approved ballot language "very confusing."
"So when somebody walks in, the natural reaction to most people in a proposition is to vote 'no,'" Mr. Kubosh said. "There's a lot of 'no' voters that will vote 'no' no matter what the ordinance is. I think the language is a purposeful attempt to mislead voters and I think council member Bradford's ‚Äî laugh all you want, mayor‚Äîcouncil member Bradford's proposition is clear and direct, in your words, and does not mislead voters."
"You need a proposition that states, if you want HERO implemented, you vote 'yes.' If you do not want HERO implemented, you vote 'no,'" Mr. Kubosh said.
Council member Ellen Cohen countered that, "I guess I put a lot more stock into the intelligence of the Houston city voters than perhaps some of my colleagues."
"What we're proposing is, 'Shall the city of Houston repeal?' Those six words, I don't think, are confusing," Ms. Cohen said. "As opposed to, 'Shall the city of Houston implement?' I think that's confusing."
Other council members pointed out that the approved language meshed closely with the language in the petition to overturn the ordinance, but council member David Martin argued the city charter calls for an affirmative vote to overturn an ordinance.
The charter says that "such ordinances or resolutions shall not take effect" unless a majority of voters "vote in favor thereof," he said. [T]he charter tells us, not a petition, not anything else, that we must put an ordinance on the ballot where qualified voters at such elections shall vote 'in favor,'" Mr. Martin said. "So 'in favor' means, 'Yes, implement HERO.' A vote against it means, 'No, do not implement HERO,' according to the city charter."
When asked if the language was consistent with the charter, however, First Assistant City Attorney Deidra Penny said that it was. "The language that was originally proposed is consistent with the city charter and the Supreme Court decisions," Ms. Penny said.
The high court gave the Houston city council 30 days either to repeal the ordinance or place it on the November ballot. Shortly before moving the ordinance to the ballot at Wednesday's meeting, the council voted 12-5 to keep the law in place.
Several pastors filed a lawsuit Monday seeking unspecified court costs and damages from the city incurred when the city issued subpoenas last year for sermons as part of the ongoing legal fight.
"This new lawsuit is not about civil rights or religious freedom," said Ms. Parker in a Monday statement. "It's about politics. It is being waged by a small group that wants to take Houston backward instead of moving it forward."

Headline Text: Equal rights ordinance goes to voters - Council vote puts embattled law on November ballot following a yearlong battle over the controversial issue
Article Text:
More than one year after City Council passed an equal rights ordinance that drew a flood of impassioned testimony, the same body again voted on the embattled law Wednesday, this time sending the issue to voters in November and officially unleashing warring campaigns that are likely to draw national attention.
That City Council found itself voting on the nondiscrimination law a second time was due to a fiercely fought, yearlong legal battle over the ordinance. Since City Council passed the ordinance 11-6 in May 2014, thousands of repeal petition signatures have been counted and parsed for errors, two lawsuits have been filed against Mayor Annise Parker and now millions in campaign donations are likely to pour in as both sides appeal to voters.
Last month, the state's highest court rejected a district judge's ruling siding with Parker and instead found that the city should have accepted a repeal petition that conservative foes submitted last summer. The court ordered City Council to either repeal the ordinance or send it to voters.
On Wednesday, City Council opted for the latter, voting 12-5 to affirm the ordinance and, in doing so, effectively placing the law on the November ballot for possible repeal. Councilwoman Brenda Stardig and Councilmen Oliver Pennington, Michael Kubosh, Jack Christie and Dave Martin voted to repeal the ordinance, mirroring their votes against the law in 2014. Councilman Dwight Boykins, who also voted against the ordinance last year, said he voted to affirm the ordinance Wednesday to honor the wishes of his constituents to vote on the matter.
Term-limited Parker, the first openly gay mayor of a major U.S. city, said this week that her "temper is a little ragged and my patience has grown quite thin on this issue." She will spend her last few months in office helping to raise money and campaign against a repeal but said she does not intend to become a "poster child" or devote all her time to the issue.
Critics have dinged Parker in the past for calling the issue a personal one.
"I don't see how anyone can see the men and women who come in and fill this council chamber on multiple Tuesday afternoons or to talk privately to them and not be moved," Parker said. "Particularly for the transgender community, these are people who, in order to be comfortable in their own skin, often give up their families, their jobs, their income and accept a life of poverty just to be right with themselves. And how someone cannot be moved and not feel emotional, I do not understand. I mean the stories are heartbreaking."
The equal rights ordinance bans discrimination based not just on sexual orientation and gender identity - the flash points for opponents - but also, as federal laws do, sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information, as well as family, marital or military status.
The ordinance applies to businesses that serve the public, private employers, housing, city employment and city contracting. Religious institutions are exempt. Violators can be fined up to $5,000.
Conservative opponents submitted a petition to send the law to voters last summer, but city officials rejected it, saying it was riddled with errors and did not contain the needed 17,269 valid signatures from Houston residents. That triggered a lawsuit from opponents and the subsequent district court and Supreme Court rulings. Opponents organizing
On Wednesday, plaintiff and conservative activist Jared Woodfill said opponents were already organized for the campaign and reaching out to national groups for support. Earlier this week, opponents again filed suit against Parker, seeking unspecified court costs and other damages associated with the earlier lawsuit. Three pastors also are suing Parker for damages and legal costs incurred when the city, as part of a broad discovery request, issued subpoenas that included a demand for certain sermons. Those subpoenas eventually were pulled down amid significant backlash.
"The eyes of the country are going to be on Houston, Texas," Woodfill said. "(Parker) tries to say that it's about racial discrimination, it's about handicapped people, that it's about ethnicity. But really what this is about is the LGBT agenda."
Woodfill said the opponents' campaign is likely to focus on the perceived threat of male sexual predators dressed in drag entering women's restrooms. Foes have dubbed the measure the "Sexual Predator Protection Act."
The ordinance protects transgender residents' ability to use the restroom consistent with their gender expression, regardless of their biological sex, but puts the onus on the individual to prove he or she was a victim of discrimination.
Brad Pritchett, who has spearheaded the pro-equal rights ordinance effort, said he has anticipated that issue would take center stage. Just hours after City Council voted Wednesday, supporters already had launched a "Houston Unites" petition online.
"We know that the one thing they are going to talk about is the same stuff they've been pushing - this line of argument that's blatantly untrue," Pritchett said. "So for us, it's an opportunity to really wage an aggressive public education campaign. This is an ordinance that protects all Houstonians."
Around the dais Wednesday, council members largely reiterated why they opposed or supported the equal rights ordinance in 2014.
Pennington, who voted against the ordinance last year, cast a vote to repeal it Wednesday and said he thinks the law raises social issues that should not be handled in a legal setting.
"What we would be doing if this ordinance is adopted is passing along this problem to the courts and the lawyers," Pennington said. "The problem that we have between the races and the problems between the different parts of our society are more complex than that, and it requires the politicians and the neighborhood people and all others to get involved."
Councilman Robert Gallegos shared a personal story in supporting the ordinance. He said that about a decade ago, he applied for a sales position with a freight company in Houston. He was not given an interview, and instead "basically told that I could go to apply in the Valley - I guess due to the fact that I'm Hispanic." Gallegos said the incident was an "insult," and he filed a complaint with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
'Protect the citizens'
"If we would have had this ordinance in place I could have gone to the Office of Inspector General and they could have done the inspection, which would have been a lot easier and a lot simpler," Gallegos said. "I am supporting this due to the fact that we need to protect the citizens and the residents of the city of Houston."
After passing the equal rights ordinance ballot language, City Council delayed a vote on another proposed ballot item that would change elected officials' terms from three two-year terms to two four-year terms. In order to meet a late-August deadline, council must vote on the issue next week.

Headline Text: For At-Large 5 - Philippe Nassif has the energy and skills to be an effective council member.
Article Text:
You have to say this about City Councilman Jack Christie: He's a conscientious public servant. Holding the At-Large 5 seat, the two- term incumbent is, in his words, "a workhorse, not a show horse," is always well prepared and seems to get along with others on the council. For those reasons and others, we endorsed him in 2013 for a second term on the council. We cannot endorse him for a third.
Despite his work on the council and his record of service on the State Board of Education and on the Spring Branch school board before being elected to the council in 2011, we find it incongruous that a chiropractic physician who has taken a special interest in health care plans for city employees opposes vaccinations. He contends that they jeopardize children's health and that there are other, more effective ways to nurture natural immunity. He's best known for his comment two years ago that "you don't die from the flu." In our view, opposition to vaccinations goes against the overwhelming scientific consensus and is a dangerous position for an elected official to hold, particularly one whose experience is in medicine.
Christie, 67, faces four challengers: Sharon Moses, an attorney who works for the city of Houston; Philippe Nassif, a community organizer with Care USA; Brad Batteau, a real estate investor, and Charles Tahir SEE CORRECTION, a businessman with Allen Medical Services Inc.
Nassif is our choice for At-Large 5. Granted, the 30-year-old son of Mexican and Lebanese immigrants is young, but he's been involved in public service for more than a decade. He offers voters detailed positions on transportation and infrastructure, fiscal responsibility and quality-of-life issues. He would work, for example, to address growing income inequality in Houston by advocating for affordable housing and providing incentives for developers to provide controlled-price rental units in developments across the city. He also supports the Houston equal rights ordinance (which Christie opposes).
Nassif's business initiatives include a reassessment of parking-space requirements, making the city permitting process speedier and more transparent and energetically recruiting businesses to relocate to Houston, while also encouraging businesses around the world to invest here.
Obviously, Nassif can't match the incumbent's record of public service. As Christie pointedly reminded him during their joint interview with the Chronicle editorial board, "I was doing public service before you were born." True enough, but we're confident that the younger man has the energy, the intellect and the commitment to public service to be an effective council member.

Headline Text: For District B - Jerry Davis is the only candidate in this race who understands how City Hall works.
Article Text:
Jerry Davis is sick of "bitch sessions." Those are his words, not ours.
In their meeting with the Chronicle editorial board, Davis' opponents had little difficulty listing the problems that face District B. Illegal dumping, stray dogs and crime and lagging economic development continue to hamper the majority African-American district. The real challenge is in finding solutions.
"This is what plagues District B," Davis, who is running for his third term, said at the meeting. "These are the types of things that we must stop."
It isn't enough to complain. Davis wants answers. But when you're a district council member in a strong-mayor system, answers can be hard to come by.
"The mayor puts items on the agenda and that's how it goes," David said.
He points out that council members need to work with the mayor and department heads if they want to implement policy or make changes for their districts. In this race, Davis is the only candidate who understands how the system functions and how a council member can pull the levers of power at City Hall to benefit his constituents.
In the private sector, Davis, 42, serves as executive director of Making It Better, a nonprofit youth program.
In his time on council, he has worked to place security cameras to catch illegal dumpers. He also successfully promoted a controversial tax incentive to encourage Krogers to expand its distribution center in northeast Houston. While we question the efficacy of these enticements, it shows that Davis uses every tool at his disposal to fight for District B.
That district covers plenty of venerable neighborhoods, including the Fifth Ward and Acres Homes. It also includes plenty of real estate prime for development. Davis hopes to capitalize on that potential with a proposal to build a new police headquarters on city- owned land in his district. Mayor Annise Parker's idea to relocate that key station to a downtown office building has fallen through, and Davis' plan is one of the few solid ideas on the table.
The councilman said he supports the Houston equal rights ordinance, but only came to that position after talking with people and educating himself. It is an education that plenty of other politicians could use.
He also said that he supports looking at raising the revenue cap to help balance the city budget. "You're talking pennies on the dollar per household," he said.
As Davis faces his third and final term, there is simply nobody else in this race who can match his knowledge and experience. Voters better start looking now for an effective replacement when term limits force him from office.

Headline Text: For a third time - Brenda Stardig deserves a final term at City Hall.
Article Text:
When out-of-towners look at a place like District A, they probably see sprawl. When Houstonians look at it, they probably see home. Located roughly between Interstate 10 and U.S. 290, west of Loop 610 West, it is a district of single-family neighborhoods and feeder-road developments. Brenda Stardig is on the verge of completing her nonconsecutive second term as district councilwoman, and she has earned a third.
Stardig, 53, came into office with a r√©sum√© impressive in its breadth and depth of civic involvement. She served on her neighborhood civic club, was head of a superneighborhood, sat on a tax increment reinvestment zone, a chamber of commerce and the Houston-Galveston Area Council. However, she was booted after her first term in a low-turnout election and replaced by Helena Brown. Rather than a constructive member of council, District A found itself with a ineffective rabble-rouser representative. Two years later, voters put Stardig back on council, and she started to put important infrastructure projects back on track.
A real estate broker by trade, Stardig told the editorial board that she's spent her time on council trying to prioritize the needs over the wants of her district. She lists public safety, infrastructure and economic development as the top three concerns.
While she supported the creation of the ReBuild Houston program, Stardig told the editorial board that she is not confident in its implementation.
"I'm very much about the conservative approach of pay-as-you-go," she said. "But I'm very unsettled in the implementation."
On pensions, she said that the city has to keep its promises made to workers but also should transition to something more predictable than our current system.
"Right now there's a lot of unknowns because there's not access to the information necessary to calculate, to predict the future."
Stardig said she opposed the Houston equal rights ordinance because she believed there were other ways to address discrimination. While we believe that Stardig was wrong in her vote, she fares much better than her opponent. Iesheia K. Ayers- Wilson, a 35-year-old tax preparer, told the editorial board that she thinks businesses should be allowed to discriminate against people based on religion.
Stardig has demonstrated that she has the skill to effectively represent her district, and voters should give her a final term.

Headline Text: Ups and downs - Farewell to Yogi, howdy to elegant Kajiya, and a special salute to Colbert.
Article Text:
THUMBS UP
It ain't over 'til it's over, but it is for Yogi Berra, the most beloved baseball player in history. He passed away at age 90 this week. We had a front-row seat to his brilliance when he came to a fork in the road and took it to Houston in 1986 to begin a four-year run as the Astros' bench coach. We'll be at his funeral in spirit. "Always go to other people's funerals," Yogi advised, "otherwise they won't come to yours."
THUMBS UP
Another brilliant athlete is making Houston home. The stunningly elegant Yuriko Kajiya, a principal with the Houston Ballet, is featured on this week's list of Next Generation Leaders from Time Magazine. Whether as the lead in "Manon" 10 days ago or in the current Fall Mixed Rep, the Japanese-born Kajiya has the "it" factor. She makes exceedingly difficult moves look effortless (can she fly?), bringing a nonpareil beauty to the Brown Theater stage.
THUMBS UP
As elegant as Kajiya, but in a more natural way, is the majestic whooping crane with its slow but steady wing beat. Here's a "must" item for new Texans. Head on down to the Aransas National Wildlife Refuge to see the whoopers' winter home. The first birds have swooped in from Canada and 300 are expected to follow. Google Texas Parks and whooping cranes.
THUMBS DOWN
It's taken the Astros half a decade to not suck. So why would we expect Stephen Colbert to be good a month into a new job? Get this: In a skit mocking our esteemed former governor's exit from the GOP primary, Colbert laid this egg: "Citizens, last week the games lost a brave fighter in Rick Perry; I'd like to say he's gone to a better place, but he lives in Houston." Sorry, Colbert, but this is war. Unless you crawl down here on your hands and knees begging for forgiveness, we will have NASA program every DVR in America to record Fallon or Kimmel.
THUMBS DOWN
No one who has crossed the editorial board threshold is as self-certain (viz. intransigent) as Ted Cruz. His logic, he trusts, is superior to all. But our Supreme Court lawyer had it wrong when he called out Pope Francis over the death penalty. "I believe the death penalty is a recognition of the preciousness of human life, that for the most egregious crimes, the ultimate punishment should apply." Would that argument fly with the Prince of Peace? We think not. Nor would it be embraced by the dozen men exonerated from Texas' death row for crimes they did not commit.
THUMBS DOWN
So where did the senator learn his logic? Maybe at home. Here's what Rafael Cruz, Ted's dad, had to say at a rally against the Houston equal rights ordinance this month: "It is appalling that in a city like Houston, right in the middle of the Bible Belt, we had a homosexual mayor. Why? Because too many people have been sitting in their pews or sitting at home with this business about 'separation of church and state.' "
THUMBS DOWN Lance Berkman, the retired Astros player, traveled North America to city after city with equal rights ordinances in place. None of those towns has seen the parade of horribles that fear-mongering opponents of Houston's ordinance preach. But they've enlisted the Rice grad to bellow the hollow party line on a radio ad.

Headline Text: District F - Incumbent Councilman Richard A. Nguyen deserves a second term in office.
Article Text:
Houston is the nation's most diverse city, and incumbent Richard A. Nguyen, our choice for District F, serves what may be the most international district in town. Centered along the Westpark Tollway toward the city's far western edges and with a small portion in Fort Bend County, District F is home to large parts of Asia Town, especially Vietnamese communities, as well as a growing Hispanic base.
In a district where residents are immigrants or children of immigrants, Nguyen's life story is familiar. He was born in Saigon, Vietnam, and immigrated with his family to the United States in 1975, at age 11.
Nguyen spent 10 years working for the city's Solid Waste Management Department before pulling off the biggest political upset of 2013 when he vanquished two-term incumbent Council Member Al Hoag. Although he had no campaign war chest, he won his surprise victory fueled only by what he described as motivation and mission. Internecine feuds within the Vietnamese community also played a role.
A political neophyte when he stepped into office two years ago, Nguyen has supported Alief Independent School District's COMET program, an after-school program that works with children living in multi-family housing and has secured future bond funds for District F's first multi-service center. He's shown that he's responsive to the people in his district by directly funding overtime for Houston Police Department officers.
Opponent Steve Le is a physician specializing in family medicine. Although he offers an impressive resume, he's not that familiar with city issues, and his opposition to the Houston equal rights ordinance is a mark against him, particularly in the district he hopes to represent.
A third candidate, Rev. Kendall Baker filed on the last day. His primary issue is opposition to HERO, ironic perhaps, since he was suspended as a manager for the city's 311 customer service line after charges of sexual harassment against subordinate female employees were filed against him.
Nguyen, on the other hand, offered a passionate defense of the equal rights ordinance. ("We have nothing to lose but much to gain.") He spent his first term learning the ropes and working with the mayor in an effort to get things done for his district. He deserves a second term.

Headline Text: For District H - Karla Cisneros will work for smart development in changing neighborhoods.
Article Text:
Houston is a city of great diversity, but also economic disparity and segregation, and all these challenges come into full play in District H. The L-shaped district covers the booming single-family neighborhoods of Near Northside and Woodland Heights, and the townhouse rows of the East End. It also covers economically troubled areas north of the 610 loop and industrial developments along Buffalo Bayou toward the Port of Houston. The population is 71 percent Hispanic and nearly half lack a high school diploma, yet the blocks along Navigation Boulevard were recently praised by the insistently hip Vice Media as the scene of Houston's musical golden age.
These conflicting images paint a picture of a district in transition, and it needs a city council member who is dedicated to harnessing growth to help old neighborhoods. Karla Cisneros is the woman for the job.
Cisneros, who will be 61 on Election Day, works as a teacher but resigned to run for office. She also served on the HISD board of education from 2000 to 2006, including a term as board president. She received her undergraduate degree from the University of Virginia and a Master's in Architecture from Rice University.
Cisneros told the editorial board that she thought the city's pensions were unsustainable, but that City Hall needed to honor its promises to employees. She also said that she supported the Houston equal rights ordinance.
However, perhaps more than any other candidate we've met during this cycle, Cisneros targeted economic disparity as the key problem facing Houston. This is the sort of thinking that you often hear from policy experts like Rice University's Dr. Stephen Klineberg, but not nearly enough from our elected officials. "We're increasingly becoming a city of haves and have-nots," Cisneros told the editorial board. "The city has a role, and I don't think they've played it very well in supporting the success of children, our families and our neighborhoods."
While her goals are idealistic, Cisneros' policy solutions are strictly down-to-earth. She points to community involvement and communication at all levels to help encourage smart development that fits with neighborhoods. She also points to public-private partnerships as a way for new growth to help improve lives of long-time residents.
"Protect what's important and help people transition into this more-dense, more-urban city that Houston has become," she said.
Cisneros already has a record of using smart development to help neighborhoods. She led a grassroots effort in Woodland Heights to improve Travis Elementary, including building one of the first SPARK parks. That project helped make the school into the heart of the neighborhood.
Cisneros applies this policy of creating neighborhood cores to Metro, as well.
"One of the opportunities that I see in District H are the 12 Metro [rail] stations that are new," she told the editorial board. "The stations themselves are nice, but they're not connected to the neighborhoods around them."
Cisneros pointed to 380 agreements as a way to transform the stations into transit nodes and encourage economic development. "We need to be smart about our development and preparing for the future."
That smart vote would be for Cisneros.
Voters should avoid Abel Davila, a former Houston Community College board member. In the internal investigation known as the Veselka Report, Davila was specifically fingered for violating board policies and his fiduciary duties.

Headline Text: TV ads slow in race for mayor
Article Text:
With midyear fundraising north of $7 million and a throng of top-tier candidates, Houston voters were expected to see a barrage of mayoral advertising across the airwaves come fall. Yet, the race is only now crawling onto television.
To date, five candidates have paid a combined $1.6 million to advertise on network television, half of what was spent on TV in the last open-seat race in 2009.
Instead, they are embracing other advertising methods and retail politics: door-knocking, community appearances and a seemingly endless slog of forums.
"The campaign's not about who's going to win the air war," University of Houston political scientist Brandon Rottinghaus said. "It's about who's going to win the ground war."
After nearly topping the July fundraising that put this year's mayor's race on track to be the most expensive in recent city history, City Councilman Stephen Costello led the pack to the TV airwaves in late August.
His debut ad focused on three broad policy priorities: infrastructure, public safety and city finances.
Thus far, Costello has spent more on broadcast than any candidate in the race - about $625,000 across KTRK (Channel 13), KHOU (Channel 11), KPRC (Channel 2,) KRIV (Channel 26) and KIAH (Channel 39), according to his campaign - with ads scheduled in two waves through Nov. 2. He also has been advertising on cable since July.
"We saw the opportunity now to break out early, and thanks to successful fundraising and low overhead, we're in a position to go back up and go back up strong," campaign manager Ward Curtin said.
Meanwhile, presumptive front-runners Sylvester Turner and Adrian Garcia, who closed out the first half of the year with more than $1 million in the bank apiece, have invested about $450,000 each in broadcast TV.
A Turner ad began airing this week on the same five Houston-area channels as Costello and briefly introduces the candidate and his policy initiatives: job training, a living wage, community policing, school partnerships and filling potholes.
According to his campaign, Turner also will begin advertising on cable on Oct. 12, having spent $75,000.
Garcia has opted for a more concentrated approach, with his ads slated to run only in the final three and a half weeks before the Nov. 2 election. They will air on six Houston-area channels, including Univision and Telemundo, beginning Oct. 10, according to campaign manager Mary Bell.
"The Garcia campaign is communicating to all voters, including predominantly Spanish speaking voters, and paid communication is a part of that," Bell said, adding, "we're not finished buying."
Even so, political observers characterized this year's mayoral presence on the television airwaves as moderate.
"I've been surprised we haven't seen more TV prior to this point, and more spent on TV for the coming weeks," local political analyst Nancy Sims said. In 2009, the top four finishers spent a combined $3.2 million on television advertising by late October, with former City Councilman Peter Brown putting up more than $1.8 million, then-City Controller Annise Parker about $758,000 and former City Attorney Gene Locke about $630,00.
The fourth candidate, former Harris County Department of Education trustee Roy Morales, stayed off TV.
Rounding out this year's broadcast presence are former Kemah Mayor Bill King and former Congressman Chris Bell.
Federal Communications Commission records show King has spent nearly $20,000 for time on KHOU next week, though campaign spokesman Chris Begala said King also will be going up on three other channels.
"Our intention is to stay up on broadcast until Election Day, but it would not be a deal-killer to be off a day or three," Begala said in an email. "We are engaged in an aggressive mail program, social media, cable and radio buy."
King has spent nearly $300,000 on cable, beginning in May, according to his campaign.
Chris Bell also has made a nominal foray onto television, spending nearly $25,000 to run a 30-second introductory spot this week on KTRK, KHOU, KPRC and KIAH, according to his campaign.
In addition to mentioning some of his campaign priorities, Bell's ad vaguely alludes to other candidates' records by claiming that Bell has "no scandals, no baggage, just an honest plan."
However, no one's television ad directly attacks another candidate.
"There's a kind of staidness to the race - almost boringness to the race - that doesn't lend itself to broadcast TV drama," Rottinghaus said.
Former City Attorney Ben Hall plans to spend at least $250,000 on broadcast "at the appropriate time," according to campaign spokesman Wayne Dolcefino.
Businessman Marty McVey said he does not plan to take his campaign to network TV, though he said he has released ads on a Vietnamese channel.
"I want to engage places that other candidates don't work," McVey said.
With early voting beginning in less than a month, he and others are continuing to shop their messages to voters face-to-face.
"It's going to be a battle over coalition politics, making sure you get your voters out," Rottinghaus said.
Mayor's race aside, Texans for Local Control, a group advocating for local control of municipal pensions, launched more than $120,000 in television ads this week on KHOU and KIAH, FCC records show.
Houston Unites, a campaign supporting the city's embattled equal rights ordinance, will debut an ad on broadcast networks Thursday, according to the campaign, which has spent $400,000 to run it over the next several weeks.

Fake IDs
Regarding "Fake-ID arrest at clinic creates furor" (Page A1, Friday), what is the problem with a person being confronted by police for fake ID? I have to provide an ID every time I check in for medical services to prove I'm a legitimate claimant. The hospital shouldn't have to apologize. These are safety measures to prevent false claims.
Let the activists pay for this person's claims if they're so concerned about immigrants.
Alisa Slack, Houston
Ben Carson
Regarding "Carson: A Muslim 'absolutely' should not be president" (A2, Monday), unless Dr. Ben Carson is intent on amending the U.S. Constitution, he has made a gargantuan error in his campaign.
Regardless of how he feels about Muslims, he cannot advocate that a Muslim not be president of the United States. The Constitution clearly forbids any religious test for public office. Proponents of Carson will argue that he was only expressing his personal opinion, not exercising political advocacy. This may be true.
But still, it was a distasteful thing to say, leaving him very vulnerable to his political opponents. I think Carson has destroyed his chances for the Republican nomination.
John L. Indo, Houston Equal rights
Regarding "Be Hero-ic" (Page B15, Sunday), what seems to be overlooked is the fact that the Houston equal rights ordinance is in many ways superfluous as federal protections are already in place.
The editorial suggests that unless this ordinance passes, Houston could suffer in revenue from outside businesses and events. It's extremely doubtful that it would have that big of an impact, but even if that were true, that does not mean Houston should be bullied to push through a problematic and unpopular ordinance for the sake of money.
Jessica Lewis, Spring JPs at work
"Two Harris County JPs resume weddings" (Page B2, Friday), now that the JPs have chosen to resume the provision of matrimonial services, it seems it is not because of civic duty but simply the desire to get paid for a service that is theirs to provide as a result of holding an elected position.
Only in the world of government would an arrangement like this be allowed. B. Dee Davis Jr., Houston Halcyon days
Regarding "Reuniting with those who knew us when" (Page B9, Sept. 21), Ruben Navarrette's column resonates with me. A decade and a half older than Navarette, I am more nostalgic than he recalling fondly acquaintances and friends from high school, that "special category all its own" and college in Houston and Austin.
As I listen to music or read historical accounts or, even better, see classmates that stir recollections of my school years in the '60s and '70s, I invariably smile and experience a warming in my heart calling to mind that tune "The Way We Were" sung by Barbra Streisand.
Bill Spear Bartlett, Houston Winning performances
Regarding "Chamber Choir leader looks back on 20 years" (Page E4, Friday), it's an incredible organization. Houston should be very proud to have the Houston Chamber Choir!
Wayne Ashley, posted on HoustonChronicle.com Kelsey-Seybold
Regarding "Groups pay physicians to keep patients healthy and save money" (Page D1, Sunday), since 1949, Houston has been home to one of the most successful Accountable Care Organizations in the Nation, Kelsey-Seybold Clinic. In 2012, Kelsey-Seybold received accreditation from the National Committee for Quality Assurance as the first (and still only) Houston-based Accountable Care Organization. More recently, our model of care has helped the city of Houston save more than $42 million over three years.
Accountable Care Organizations are not limited to groups engaged in shared savings programs with Medicare. Rather, some of the most successful ACOs are those which implement a standard of care across the board for all patients, not just the elderly. We all deserve an organization that will monitor for health trends and implement actions to improve outcomes, eliminate medical waste like unnecessary diagnostics or duplicate tests, and reward physicians for the quality of care they provide to patients, not the quantity of patients they see.
Our hope is that eventually, all employers engage with an Accountable Care Organization for their health care needs - we have found that employers who do implement an ACO plan see savings of anywhere between 10-20 percent and a higher member satisfaction rate among their employees.
Spencer Berthelsen, chairman and managing director Kelsey-Seybold Clinic Figuring out Trump
Regarding "Bush targets Trump on immigrant issues" (Page B2, Tuesday), it has taken a while, but I think I have figured out Donald Trump and his quest to be president. Remember Sarah Palin and her run for vice president? After her loss, she returned to Alaska to continue to be governor. It did not take her long to realize her popularity on the lecture tour and the amount of money she could make talking about things that she could not nor should not speak about during a run for office. Her resignation allowed her to tour and not have political responsibility for her words.
Money speaks louder than words, especially if someone does not have to be elected to anything or have to be responsible for their opinions.
David Moss, Kingwood Texans and reality Regarding "Mallett under increasing pressure" (HoustonChronicle.com, Sunday), I think that as fans we need to give our expectations a reality check - this is not a Super Bowl team, neither a playoff one; this team is a work in progress. And having no consistent QB is like a ship without a compass.
Let's support them and hope they finish this season at least 9-7.

Headline Text: For At-large 1 - Tom McCasland has a proven record of cutting waste, fixing broken government.
Article Text:
When government is broken, who do you hire to fix it? For the Harris County Housing Authority, the answer was Tom McCasland. Plenty of candidates can tout their ideas for repairing Houston's problems, but only McCasland has a record of working within government to cut fat, root out corruption and balance budgets. In the race to replace a term-limited Steven Costello for the City Council At-Large 1 seat, voters should send McCasland to City Hall so he can put his skills to work.
McCasland, 42, has a biography that reads like a Horatio Alger story. The child of missionaries, he grew up next to a Navajo reservation in a home that he shared with his nine siblings - no electricity and no running water. From these modest beginnings he ascended to Baylor University for a master's degree in philosophy, Yale Law School and a job at Vinson & Elkins. McCasland stepped into the public eye, however, when he was appointed to head up the troubled county housing authority after a Chronicle investigation revealed that the agency had wasted millions of dollars on unnecessary expenditures, including statues, parties and executive pay.
As CEO, McCasland cut the operations budget while increasing services to the needy and even giving his lowest-paid employees a much-needed raise. Essentially, he took a slush-fund and successfully rededicated it to its true purpose: helping the poor and homeless find safe places to live. This focus on core services is a philosophy that voters should want to see in City Hall.
It is a philosophy that becomes apparent when McCasland discusses his goals if elected. When he met with the Chronicle editorial board, he said that he wanted to follow the same model he set at the housing authority by specifically scrutinizing the city's largest budgetary items and figuring out how to reduce costs.
"One of the largest items in a lot of these entities are middle-level management that aren't doing the job," he said. Instead, he would refocus resources on front-line employees.
McCasland also pointed to unnecessary arrests for low-level marijuana possession as low hanging fruit where the city could easily save money.
"Just the booking fees alone, we're paying $8 million a year," McCasland said, referring to regional statistics. "That $8 million would be much better spent focused on our violent crimes and our serious property crimes."
On pensions, McCasland says that he won't vote for any deal that doesn't cover each year's incurred costs and doesn't put the city on a path to paying down our liabilities. He also wants more transparency and stricter timelines on tax increment reinvestment zones, and supports the Houston equal rights ordinance.
In this field of seven candidates, former police officer Mike Knox and Harris County Democratic Party Chair Lane Lewis also stand out. However, voters should be wary of Chris Oliver, a Houston Community College trustee, who voted for a contract with a major vendor without disclosing it had hired his own company as a subcontractor. He has since apologized for what he calls an "honest mistake," but there's little room for mistakes in this crowded race for At-Large 1.
Among all those candidates, McCasland has a proven record of going above and beyond the call of duty in office and deserves voters' support in this election.

Headline Text: Be HERO-ic - For opponents of the rights ordinance, facts are irrelevant and their claims are absurd.
Article Text:
Let's be frank: The organized opposition to Houston's proposed equal rights ordinance is mendacious, deceitful and irresponsible in the extreme. Attorney Jared Woodfill and his opposition cohorts know that nothing in the ordinance - repeat, nothing - allows male sexual predators dressed in drag to lurk in women's restrooms waiting to attack women and little girls. If they don't know, then they haven't read the ordinance.
And if any city or county across the country, including Texas, has had a dangerous incident with transgender individuals making women uncomfortable by barging into the wrong bathroom, we haven't heard about it. The opponents know they cannot come up with reports of transgender women assaulting anyone in public bathrooms after the passage of anti-discrimination ordinances. They don't exist.
States as diverse as Iowa, Hawaii, Maine and New Mexico, 17 in all, report no evidence of the kind of abuse or assaults that the Houston opponents are predicting. Fort Worth was the first Texas city to pass a nondiscrimination ordinance, 15 years ago. Neither Fort Worth nor any other Texas city has reported problems.
As Richard Carlbom with the pro-ordinance Houston Unites campaign told the Chronicle: "Nothing in the equal rights ordinance changes the fact that it is - and always will be - illegal to enter a restroom to harm or harass other people." And as Chronicle columnist Lisa Falkenberg pointed out recently, if sexual predators "wanted to attack you in a public bathroom, they wouldn't need a city ordinance to do it."
For ordinance opponents, facts are irrelevant. They're using what they consider their most effective tool to defeat an ordinance that partially benefits a group of people whose lifestyle they don't support. That's their real motive. They know that their best hope is to prey on parents' concerns about the safety of their children and to gin up always lurking discrimination against gays and the transgendered. To be blunt, they're playing their fellow Houstonians for chumps.
Reasonable minds can differ on any and all public policy issues, including the need for an equal rights ordinance, but Houstonians should insist that the debate be fair and that it focus on the facts. The fact is, Houston's law provides local protection for all Houstonians. It bans discrimination based on sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information, as well as family, marital or military status, sexual orientation or gender status. And, yes, business owners can still bar people from using a men's or women's restroom if they feel the person isn't of that gender.
Black ministers in Houston have been particularly outspoken against the ordinance, and, by all accounts, they've been highly effective. Their parishioners and congregants need to show a little independence. They need to read the ordinance themselves, consider the experience of other cities and apply a little common sense to the issue.
Here's another fact that opponents prefer to ignore: If it gets repealed, potential new residents, expanding businesses, major sporting events, tourists and convention planners are likely to look askance at a city that seems to bridle at protecting all its people from discrimination. That's why the Greater Houston Partnership, the Greater Houston Convention and Visitors Bureau and the Hotel and Lodging Association of Greater Houston released a joint statement last week supporting the ordinance.
"The perception we have built is that Houston is diverse and welcoming, and people around the country are believing that, and along comes an issue that would lead people to believe we're where we were 20 or 30 years ago," Partnership President Bob Harvey told the Chronicle last week.
Harvey and other Houston business leaders are well aware of what happened in Indiana, where a so-called "religious freedom law" appeared to be a thinly veiled attempt to sanction discrimination. Companies and conventions canceled events planned in the state, and the NCAA, headquartered in Indianapolis, publicly opposed the original version of the law as the city was set to host the Final Four.
Houston, too, is hosting the Final Four in a few months. Dan Gavitt, the NCAA's vice president of basketball championships, told the Chronicle a few days ago that the outcome of the ordinance vote won't affect next spring's event, but "we'll monitor it very closely. It could have an impact on future Final Fours, because there are other options."
We appreciate the need for debate, even though we strongly believe that Houston needs an equal rights ordinance. What we don't need is a nasty, cynical campaign playing on voters' fear and ignorance. This great city is bigger than that.
The equal rights ordinance is Propostion One on the November ballot. We urge Houstonians to vote YES.

Headline Text: Business groups support HERO - They fear repeal of rights law could hurt city economy
Article Text:
Read more about HERO at HoustonChronicle.com/equalrights
Three major local business and hospitality groups are warning voters that the city's economy could take a hit if Houston's embattled equal rights ordinance is repealed in November, boosting supporters' attempts to cast the law as not only a moral issue but also a practical one.
The Greater Houston Partnership, Greater Houston Convention and Visitors Bureau and Hotel and Lodging Association of Greater Houston released a joint statement Thursday backing the ordinance and calling Houston "a diverse and welcoming city."
"Discrimination of any kind is not a Houston value; it's bad for the people of our city and it's bad for our economy," the statement read.
A heated legal battle between opponents and the city ended with a Texas Supreme Court decision in late July ordering City Council to repeal the law or vote to affirm it and place on the November ballot. By a 12-5 vote, City Council opted to put the ordinance before voters in November.
Jared Woodfill, spokesman for opponents, pushed back against the idea that business would suffer if the law is repealed. Critics have homed in on the protections the law extends to transgender residents, arguing it would allow male sexual predators dressed in drag to enter women's restrooms. That and the possibility of litigation under the ordinance would discourage businesses from opening up shop in Houston, Woodfill said.
"The Partnership is taking the position, which I don't think is held by the people," Woodfill said. "Which is that, if we prevent boys from going to girls' locker rooms, somehow people are going to stop going to Houston. That's outrageous and preposterous. What they're hoping that you will do is back down on your deeply held beliefs."
Supporters of the law increasingly have pointed to Indiana, where a so-called "religious freedom law" drew national criticism last spring. Opponents called the law a thinly veiled attempt to allow discrimination, prompting companies and conventions to cancel events planned in the state. The NCAA, headquartered in Indianapolis, publicly opposed the original version of the law as the city was set to host the Final Four. Amid mounting pressure, the state legislature eventually passed an amended version of the bill intended to ease concerns about discrimination against gays and lesbians.
Houston's law bans discrimination based on a series of classes, including sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information, as well as family, marital or military status, sexual orientation and gender identity.
Though the Partnership originally expressed reservations about early drafts of the law, it eventually publicly supported the ordinance before City Council passed it 11-6 last year. A.J. Mistretta, a spokesman for the Visitors Bureau, said Partnership President Bob Harvey encouraged the group to issue the joint statement.
Houston Unites campaign manager Richard Carlbom said the groups' support demonstrates a desire in the business community to remain competitive with other large cities that already have similar nondiscrimination policies in place.
"If this gets repealed, I think a lot of folks will look at Houston and wonder if they should send employees here or hold conferences here," Carlbom said. "They will wonder whether or not there are the appropriate protections in place."
The argument is not new. Mayor Annise Parker and other officials long have warned that Houston's selection to host the 2017 Super Bowl and the 2016 NCAA Final Four, for instance, could be in jeopardy if the law is repealed.
"Houston simply isn't the City it was 20 or 30 years ago," Parker said last month. "It is this open and inclusive atmosphere that helps make Houston attractive to new residents, new business, major sporting events like the Super Bowl and more. The ongoing effort by this group threatens to hurt that image and our progress."
Carlbom and Woodfill said their campaigns will continue to talk about the potential business ramifications of the law as the November election approaches. The dueling campaigns already have hit the radio airwaves with a combined $300,000 in ads.
"It's going to be a close election," Carlbom said. "The community is divided on this."

Headline Text: TEXAS VIEW: Bathroom wars are getting crazy
Article Text:
Texans who grew up in Dallas and San Antonio are probably familiar with the Magic Time Machine, a chain of restaurants known more for their manufactured mayhem than for the quality of their food. They‚Äôll likely recall that when they needed to go to the restroom, a waiter took them by the hand and led them through the dining room, all the while shouting ‚ÄúPotty patrol! Potty patrol!‚Äù Laughter invariably ensued.
If we believed that Jared Woodfill, the former head of the Harris County Republican Party, and his fellow opponents of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance (HERO) were truly concerned about the likelihood of transgender ogres lurking in public restrooms, as they claim in their over-the-top radio ads, we would suggest that Houston restaurants be required to offer a potty patrol service. Of if that‚Äôs too gauche for this sophisticated trans city ‚Äî transnational we mean ‚Äî may we suggest, a la Paris, Rome and London, the required presence of restroom attendants, individuals paid to spend their working hours in public restrooms, with a saucer near the wash basin where patrons deposit tips.
The fact is, Woodfill and company are not concerned that men dressing up as women are just waiting for HERO to pass ‚Äî and, we presume, for the annual women‚Äôs apparel sale at Nordstrom ‚Äî so they can don skirts, blouses and high heels and assault women and girls in public bathrooms. Their aim is to defeat an ordinance that partially benefits gay and transgendered Houstonians, people whose lives they can‚Äôt accept. If they can stir up the general public with scare tactics that border on the absurd, then so be it; they will have saved Houstonians from surrendering to the creeping acceptance of what they believe to be a deviant lifestyle. They ought to be ashamed of themselves, and anyone persuaded by their cynical ploy should be too.
The so-called HERO measure on the November ballot is designed to protect people against discrimination in employment, housing and other sectors. HERO protects gay and transgender people but also bans discrimination based on race, sex, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information. It also bans discrimination based on family, marital or military status. Woodfill and friends focus on the bathroom menace because they calculate that it borders on legitimate concerns about sexual predators and thus will spill over.
‚ÄúNothing in the equal rights ordinance changes the fact that it is ‚Äî and always will be ‚Äî illegal to enter a restroom to harm or harass other people,‚Äù Richard Carlbom with the pro-ordinance Houston Unites campaign told the Chronicle.
In addition, none of the states and municipalities that have had anti-discrimination ordinances for years reports any evidence of the kind of abuse or assaults that the Houston opponents are predicting. Minnesota, for example, began prohibiting discrimination against transgender people more than 20 years ago. A Minneapolis police spokesman told Chronicle columnist Lisa Falkenberg that sexual assaults from the 1993 law were ‚Äúnot even remotely‚Äù a problem, and that a police department inquiry found ‚Äúnothing‚Äù in the way of such crimes in the city. Iowa, New Mexico, Maine and Hawaii are among more than a dozen jurisdictions that also report no problems.
Whether Houston needs an anti-discrimination ordinance has been and continues to be a legitimate topic for citizens to debate. We happen to believe it will be good for Houston; others argue that it‚Äôs superfluous, that protections for some groups already are extended by federal law. Those polar perspectives represent an argument worth having, whereas the bathroom bogeyman claim is beneath the dignity of this great city. We really don‚Äôt need Woodfill and his anti-HERO pals playing potty patrol for us.

It also bans discrimination based on family, marital or military status. Woodfill and friends focus on the bathroom menace because they calculate that it borders on legitimate concerns about sexual predators and thus will spill over.
‚ÄúNothing in the equal rights ordinance changes the fact that it is ‚Äî and always will be ‚Äî illegal to enter a restroom to harm or harass other people,‚Äù Richard Carlbom with the pro-ordinance Houston Unites campaign told the Chronicle.
In addition, none of the states and municipalities that have had anti-discrimination ordinances for years reports any evidence of the kind of abuse or assaults that the Houston opponents are predicting. Minnesota, for example, began prohibiting discrimination against transgender people more than 20 years ago. A Minneapolis police spokesman told Chronicle columnist Lisa Falkenberg that sexual assaults from the 1993 law were ‚Äúnot even remotely‚Äù a problem, and that a police department inquiry found ‚Äúnothing‚Äù in the way of such crimes in the city. Iowa, New Mexico, Maine and Hawaii are among more than a dozen jurisdictions that also report no problems.
Whether Houston needs an anti-discrimination ordinance has been and continues to be a legitimate topic for citizens to debate. We happen to believe it will be good for Houston; others argue that it‚Äôs superfluous, that protections for some groups already are extended by federal law. Those polar perspectives represent an argument worth having, whereas the bathroom bogeyman claim is beneath the dignity of this great city. We really don‚Äôt need Woodfill and his anti-HERO pals playing potty patrol for us.

Headline Text: Area Opinions: Message needed after attack on ref - Message needed after attack on ref
Article Text:
Message needed after attack on ref
The blatant, blindside attack of a game referee waged by two San Antonio Jay high school football players last week deserves a much stronger reaction of outrage and condemnation than what San Antonio-area school officials have offered so far. Suspension of the two players was an obvious first reaction. Criminal prosecution remains an option.
But we believe the entire team's season suspension and the head coach's dismissal would send an unequivocal message to all Texas high school football players: Such egregious misconduct carries the strongest possible consequences.
Last week's attack occurred in the final moments of John Jay's away game against Marble Falls High School, which Jay lost 15-9. From the looks of what happened, the two players who attacked referee Robert Watts were sending their personal message of disapproval over officiating decisions leading up to their loss. As if that somehow justified what they did.
The bad sportsmanship by John Jay players suggest they're not getting the right message from the adults coaching them. This entire team's culture needs to be rewired, from head coach Gary Gutierrez on down.
The John Jay Mustangs need to take the rest of the season off so that cooler heads can prevail the next time players suit up. Dallas
Morning News
Scare tactics over ordinance undignified
If we believed Jared Woodfill, the former head of the Harris County Republican Party, and his fellow opponents of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance were truly concerned about the likelihood of transgender ogres lurking in public restrooms, as they claim in their over-the-top radio ads, we would suggest Houston restaurants be required to offer potty police.
The fact is, Woodfill and company are not concerned that men dressing up as women are just waiting for HERO to pass ‚Äî and, we presume, for the annual women's apparel sale at Nordstrom ‚Äî so they can don skirts, blouses and high heels and assault women and girls in public bathrooms. Their aim is to defeat an ordinance that partially benefits gay and transgendered Houstonians, people whose lives they can't accept.
Defeat Prop 1, The Bathroom Ordinance. Women shouldn't have to undress in front of men!  #UncomfortableForWomen
