Abbott, Paxton don't own the government
Texans, being suspicious of government, have a fine tradition of demanding and receiving open government. It's why the state has open meetings and public information laws. It's a tradition that Gov. Greg Abbott, when he was the attorney general, defended.
Unfortunately, Abbott in his current position and Attorney General Ken Paxton in Abbott's former position are failing in their responsibility to promote and defend open government.
Last month, Paxton requested that cameras not be allowed when the felony financial fraud case against him goes to trial. Why Texas has an attorney general who is a criminal defendant is a whole 'nother long, sad story of voter malpractice we've told before. Before the 2014 primary he already had admitted to failing to register as a financial representative and failing to inform people to whom he had recommended investments that his referrals earned him commissions. That admitted behavior should have been weaselly enough for voters to disqualify him.
But that's not our topic today. It's just incidental background that got us to the point where now Texas has an attorney general under criminal indictment for alleged transgressions wholly unrelated to him being a political candidate or officeholder. Today's topic is that the officeholder tasked with upholding Texas' fine tradition of open government is trying to circumvent it in spirit ‚Äî for his own personal ends.
We have a situation in which the glare of the camera would be good for open government but embarrassing to Paxton. A case as high-profile as a criminal trial brought against the state's attorney general deserves all the public scrutiny that can be mustered. Paxton's attempt to un-muster it is a clear conflict of interest ‚Äî doing what's bad for the people but good for him. He should resign or at least take an unpaid leave.
Abbott's lack of transparency has to do with an open records request by The Texas Tribune for email exchanges regarding public health policy. The Tribune obtained the emails ‚Äî but from another party, the Health and Human Services Commission. The emails should have come from Abbott for several reasons: because he initiated the exchanges, because as the former attorney general he should know and appreciate the public information law as well as anyone, and because as the state's top official he should set a good example.
Abbott started the correspondence in reaction to a Houston Chronicle opinion column about the state's continued mean-spirited, politically motivated, financially bone-headed refusal to accept billions of federal Medicaid expansion dollars provided under Obamacare. The adjectives are ours, not the column author's.
The author, Ken Janda, CEO of nonprofit insurer Community Health Choice, pointed out that Texas' health care safety net was "in serious danger of meltdown" because of the Medicaid refusal decision. Abbott defended Texas' right of refusal in court with partisan zeal as attorney general and maintains it as a policy decision as governor.
Abbott informed aides by email that he wanted to "see the financials" of Janda's nonprofit and that it was his understanding that large public hospitals such as those served by Community Health Choice are "rolling in dough," according to the Tribune.
It smacks of petulant retaliation on Abbott's part. It looks like he was using his power to pursue a vendetta. That is not the purpose of the power voters gave him. The emails are an embarrassment. But, just like Paxton and his move to block cameras from his trial, that's beside the point. The people have a right to see their government in action.
___
The Dallas Morning News. Sept. 8, 2015.
After high school football players attack official, time to send a message
The blatant, blindside attack of a game referee waged by two John Jay High School football players last week deserves a much stronger reaction of outrage and condemnation than what San Antonio-area school officials have offered so far. Suspension of the two players was an obvious first reaction. Criminal prosecution remains an option.
But we believe the entire team's season suspension and the head coach's dismissal would send an unequivocal message to all Texas high school football players: Such egregious misconduct carries the strongest possible consequences.
Last week's attack occurred in the final moments of John Jay's away game against Marble Falls High School, which Jay lost 15-9. From the looks of what happened, the two players who attacked referee Robert Watts were sending their personal message of disapproval over officiating decisions leading up to their loss. As if that somehow justified what they did.
Unconfirmed reports indicate that Jay players were upset after allegedly overhearing racial slurs earlier in the game, which some attributed to Watts. A Jay player was ejected in the third quarter for throwing a punch at an opposing player, then arguing with an official. Then Star Jay quarterback Moses Reynolds was ejected in the fourth quarter for throwing a punch at an opposing player.
On the next play, Jay sophomore Victor Rojas and senior Mike Moreno staged their attack on Watts, with one hitting him full force in the back and the other jumping on top of the referee once he was on the ground. The hits were unquestionably deliberate.
Rojas and another uninvolved player were ejected for the attack. Moreno stayed in the game on defense for the final play. After the Marble Falls quarterback took a knee to run out the clock, Moreno plowed into him.
A YouTube video of the assault on Watts, a 14-year veteran referee, has received more than 7 million views. Moreno and Rojas were suspended both from the team and from school while Northside ISD authorities review next steps.
The repeated examples of bad sportsmanship by John Jay players suggest that they're not getting the right message from the adults coaching them. This entire team's culture needs to be rewired, from head coach Gary Gutierrez on down. The John Jay Mustangs need to take the rest of the season off so that cooler heads can prevail the next time players suit up.
And even though Gutierrez reportedly has apologized, it's clear that his leadership failed to give John Jay players a crystal clear understanding of what constitutes out-of-bounds behavior. An ironic quote that Gutierrez shared via Twitter on July 16 sums up our feelings exactly: "If you're not teaching it that way, then you must be allowing it to happen that way." Houston Chronicle. Sept. 2, 2015.
Bathroom bogeyman: Scare tactics about the HERO ordinance are beneath the dignity of this great city.
Texans who grew up in Dallas and San Antonio are probably familiar with the Magic Time Machine, a chain of restaurants known more for their manufactured mayhem than for the quality of their food. They'll likely recall that when they needed to go to the restroom, a waiter took them by the hand and led them through the dining room, all the while shouting "Potty patrol! Potty patrol!" Laughter invariably ensued.
If we believed that Jared Woodfill, the former head of the Harris County Republican Party, and his fellow opponents of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance (HERO) were truly concerned about the likelihood of transgender ogres lurking in public restrooms, as they claim in their over-the-top radio ads, we would suggest that Houston restaurants be required to offer a potty patrol service. Of if that's too gauche for this sophisticated trans city ‚Äî transnational we mean ‚Äî may we suggest, a la Paris, Rome and London, the required presence of restroom attendants, individuals paid to spend their working hours in public restrooms, with a saucer near the wash basin where patrons deposit tips.
The fact is, Woodfill and company are not concerned that men dressing up as women are just waiting for HERO to pass ‚Äî and, we presume, for the annual women's apparel sale at Nordstrom ‚Äî so they can don skirts, blouses and high heels and assault women and girls in public bathrooms. Their aim is to defeat an ordinance that partially benefits gay and transgendered Houstonians, people whose lives they can't accept. If they can stir up the general public with scare tactics that border on the absurd, then so be it; they will have saved Houstonians from surrendering to the creeping acceptance of what they believe to be a deviant lifestyle. They ought to be ashamed of themselves, and anyone persuaded by their cynical ploy should be too.
The so-called HERO measure on the November ballot is designed to protect people against discrimination in employment, housing and other sectors. HERO protects gay and transgender people but also bans discrimination based on race, sex, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information. It also bans discrimination based on family, marital or military status. Woodfill and friends focus on the bathroom menace because they calculate that it borders on legitimate concerns about sexual predators and thus will spill over.
"Nothing in the equal rights ordinance changes the fact that it is ‚Äî and always will be ‚Äî illegal to enter a restroom to harm or harass other people," Richard Carlbom with the pro-ordinance Houston Unites campaign told the Chronicle.
In addition, none of the states and municipalities that have had anti-discrimination ordinances for years reports any evidence of the kind of abuse or assaults that the Houston opponents are predicting. Minnesota, for example, began prohibiting discrimination against transgender people more than 20 years ago. A Minneapolis police spokesman told Chronicle columnist Lisa Falkenberg that sexual assaults from the 1993 law were "not even remotely" a problem, and that a police department inquiry found "nothing" in the way of such crimes in the city. Iowa, New Mexico, Maine and Hawaii are among more than a dozen jurisdictions that also report no problems.
Whether Houston needs an anti-discrimination ordinance has been and continues to be a legitimate topic for citizens to debate. We happen to believe it will be good for Houston; others argue that it's superfluous, that protections for some groups already are extended by federal law. Those polar perspectives represent an argument worth having, whereas the bathroom bogeyman claim is beneath the dignity of this great city. We really don't need Woodfill and his anti-HERO pals playing potty patrol for us.
___
Austin American-Statesman. Sept. 4, 2015.
Supporting equal justice and police not mutually exclusive
Americans shouldn't have to choose sides between law enforcement and equal justice.
But the comments by politicians and law enforcement officials following two police-related shootings in Texas suggest that is unfortunately the current state of affairs in the dialogue about law enforcement and use of force.
Any shooting death is a tragedy. In Houston on Aug. 28, the victim was a Harris County sheriff's deputy who was slain while filling his car at a gas station. The suspect, who allegedly unloaded his gun execution-style into the body of deputy Darren Goforth, has a history of criminal activity and mental illness. In San Antonio, the victim was a 41-year-old man, Gilbert Flores, who had already injured his wife and child as part of a domestic dispute and was behaving erratically, before Bexar County deputies shot and killed him on the lawn while his hands were apparently raised.
There will be some who will recoil at the prospect of calling both Goforth and Flores "victims." The circumstances leading up to their deaths do not change their status. Freddie Gray in Baltimore was a victim. Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, was a victim. Officers Wenjian Liu and Rafael Ramos of New York were victims. All are cases that have roiled the national conscience over the past 12 months about the role of race in law enforcement. But the tragic nature of these episodes should not curtail the overdue push for change. It is only through those sometimes tense ‚Äî but hopefully deliberative ‚Äî discussions that we will finally find solutions.
We must support law enforcement officers, who do an incredibly dangerous and difficult job. At the same time, we must require accountability from those who abuse the authority bestowed by the badge. We should be able to mourn Goforth's loss without also being asked to pass judgment on the national Black Lives Matter movement that has brought much-needed attention to policing, use of force and the criminal justice system.
In the months since Ferguson, especially after the grisly murders of officers Liu and Ramos while sitting in their patrol car, law enforcement officials have argued that the Black Lives Matters movement has placed officers in grave danger. That fear is clearly what motivated the disappointing comments by Harris County Sheriff Ron Hickman after Goforth's death, when he referenced a "dangerous national rhetoric that is out there today," saying it "has gotten out of control."
Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick similarly played into this false narrative last week with an interview on Texas Standard: "I'm tired of this 'certain lives matter.' All lives do matter and particularly law enforcement. And there is a war on police, by some people. It's a small percentage of people in this country, but they're deadly. It only takes a few of that small group of people who spew this hate toward law enforcement to take the life on an innocent officer."
He goes on to suggest that we should not "worry about the one officer or two officers out there on a YouTube dashcam video who did something wrong. If they were wrong, I'll file a complaint, and if their department feels they were wrong, then suspend them or fire them."
The numbers however simply don't bear out either point. Nationally police firearms deaths are about 13 percent lower in 2015 than last year at this time, according to the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund. Goforth's death and the death of an Illinois officer last week bring the total of deaths by gunfire in 2015 to 26. Total deaths in the line of duty are currently higher at 85, including traffic accidents and heart attacks.
Every officer killed in the line of duty is one too many. They are our protectors and peacekeepers. It is not a duty that most take lightly ‚Äî but the magnitude of the task also requires every organization to be capable and open to introspection and public critique.
Minority communities have long complained about unequal treatment and police brutality. But it is the videos that Patrick so casually dismisses that are pushing more policymakers to do something about it. Responses like Patrick's highlight a culture that suggests that if a brown-skinned person is accused of a crime, then they deserve what they get ‚Äî even if it is death. Patrick may be confident in the ability of a simple complaint to set things right, but history suggests that this often not the case.
To that end, our focus should be on justice.
Let's be clear: Activists do not get a free pass. Anyone involved in calls to harm or threatens legitimate police work is a danger to the public and engaging in hate speech. Causing law enforcement to unnecessarily look over its shoulder when quick, decisive thinking is required puts us all at risk.
However, the conversations that are taking place as result of the Black Lives Matter movement should be welcomed. Better policies and better training will help ensure that we all have equal protection under the law.
We can embrace the premise that black and brown lives matter and support our police officers and deputies. We shouldn't accept anything less. Fort Worth Star-Telegram. Sept. 4, 2015.
Let lawmakers set new direction for horse racing If Texas racing needs fixing, let the work begin.
Ranchers, horse trainers and spokesmen say the industry is suffering. They say Texas tracks will struggle without new revenue from electronic games, or maybe casino gambling.
Neither is legal in Texas. Both would require thorough review by both lawmakers and the public, not the agency vote state racing commissioners have tried.
State officials have given the commission a deadline to reverse a vote to add slot-like electronic "historical racing" games used elsewhere.
But if gaming is not the answer, leaders must decide what is.
Now is the time for Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick and Texas House officials to appoint a joint interim committee on the future of pari-mutuel racing.
The one-day shutdown of Lone Star Park at Grand Prairie and other Texas horse and dog racing tracks last week has left both industry leaders and track patrons uncertain about the future.
If lawmakers do not set a course quickly, the industry will continue to suffer along with pari-mutuel revenue.
The question should not be only how to save racing, but also if it should be saved.
Total revenue is down by half since 2000, and attendance is on a steady decline. As a result, the purse money for thoroughbreds has shrunk more than 40 percent in the last 10 years, and employment has declined as thoroughbred owners go to races in other states.
The reason is one of simple economics: Other states offer richer purses financed by more gamblers and more games.
Years ago, officials at an Arkansas park devised slot-like race replays called "historical racing," and the state has added video slots and gaming. The 2004 and 2006 openings of two Oklahoma casinos barely across the state line also eroded Texas racing attendance and revenue.
Texas lawmakers have consistently rejected casino slots and any similar electronic games. But the pressure will only intensify to expand gambling for the sake of jobs and the racing industry.
Lawmakers need to make tough choices about racing's future. A joint committee should get started.

Trailblazer
Regarding "Unsung Hero", (Page B8, Thursday) I was honored to get to meet Phyllis Frye at a GLBT fundraiser several years ago. She has quite a sense of humor, which I imagine helped her deal with a lot of the difficulties she has encountered in her life.
I have thought of her often recently, while reading about the opposition to HERO and the scare tactics about restrooms. That evening, she and I were both attired in formal dresses, and we chatted briefly in the women's restroom while washing our hands. It was entirely appropriate for each of us to be in that room, even though a DNA analysis would have shown her to have a Y chromosome.
I hope that the voters of Houston are sensible enough to see that the restroom issue is a non-issue. The issue is discrimination. And none of us should be willing to tolerate that.
Jeanne Southern, Houston End histrionics
Regarding "Bathroom bogeymen" (Page B15, Sunday), I am getting disgusted with the constant diatribes against "Mayor Parker's Bathroom Ordinance" blared on the radio. It's the same tripe that men will come into women's bathrooms!
I lived through the era of the Summit, Astrodome and other venues where hordes of women had to avail themselves of the men's facilities. Seldom did the men have to utilize the women's baths because men are better equipped to get in and get out.
Simply, these righteous folks need to travel to other parts of the world where bathrooms are not labeled as gender-specific bathrooms. Our office building has six bathrooms that are not gender-specific. We have never had an issue. Please folks, just read the ordinance
Bob Ryan, Houston About trust
How can our esteemed city government be trusted to get the equal rights ordinance right? Is discrimination ever a good thing? The answer is clearly no.
But we have all seen how the city has handled criticism of the ordinance (subpoenaed sermons), not to mention questionable ballot language and the faulty counting of petition signatures. Until they prove otherwise, how can we trust them to administer HERO?
Does anyone need further proof? We have police and fire pensions that the city agreed to. They appear to be unsustainable, and no one at the city has a clue how to fix the problem. What about the "rain tax"? Great idea until you realize that it would be our city government administering the fund. It sure didn't take long, as many predicted, before the City Council was raiding the fund for members' pet projects.
Lastly, what about the streets - one of the most basic of city services. Every other major city in the country seems to be able to keep their streets in good stead, but not Houston. It's all a matter of trust. City government needs to earn our trust by fixing the problems facing this great city. Fix those, earn our trust and then let's get after HERO.
Jim Kirkpatrick, Houston
...
Refugees seeking safety
Regarding "Hungary plays hardball: migrant tempers flare" (Page A10, Thursday), yes, the western democracies need to oppose the Islamic state as strongly as we can. But we're not employing a valuable weapon in this fight.
Millions of refugees have fled the territories occupied by ISIS in Iraq and Syria. An estimated four million have left Syria. Europe and the United States should resettle more of these unfortunate people. Then they can tell their stories, ripping off the propaganda veil that ISIS has spread over its atrocities.
Nancy Perich Daly, Houston Fiscal incongruity
Regarding "A big step toward more bayou trails" and "Cell-ban signs at schools debated," the cell-ban article stated that Mayor Annise Parker questioned the expenditure of $2.34 million to comply with the Texas state law for signage in school zones to help protect school children from distracted drivers. The "bayou" article quotes Parker supporting the expenditure of $220 million on green-space recreational improvements as "one of the most exciting things I've had the opportunity to work on as mayor."
Obviously, Mayor Parker has prioritized her massively expensive green agenda over the safety of school children.I suspect that a vast majority of Houstonians would prefer that Parker allocate the $2.3 million for the legally mandated school zone safety warning signs and spend the balance of $217.7 million on repairing our decrepit Third World streets which could also include conjoined bike paths.
Edward A. Vesely, West University Place Fiercely defiant
Regarding "Couple at center of Kentucky fight" (Page A6, Thursday), it's time to get rid of the "little terrorist" of Rowan County, Ky., Kim Davis. Enough is enough.
As a government employee, she has no right to defy the U.S. Supreme Court, which has legalized same-sex marriage in all 50 states. Her job is to serve the people of Rowan County. Her personal beliefs do not supersede her oath to serve the people. If she won't comply with the law then she needs to be reassigned to a different position and replaced with someone who will obey the law and serve the people.
Robert Nackman, Houston State's rights
Regarding "My religion prohibits gay marriage" cartoon (Page B8, Thursday), I realize the editorial pages can reflect a variety of, at times, distasteful opinions to both ends of the political spectrum. Your choice to run a cartoon comparing a simple clerk who finds gay marriage distasteful to an ISIS killer is just repulsive.
She has a right to her viewpoint and actions in what should be a state's rights issue, not federal dictate. I am sure it does not include beheading someone.
Roger Schuelke, Kingwood. Airing hard tradeoffs
Regarding "Waiting to Exhale" (Page B8, Thursday), the leaders of the city of Houston might be happy if the petrochemical industries along the Houston Ship Channel relocated to foreign nations and then fired all of the petrochemical plant employees.
Relocating U.S. jobs to Third World nations raises the living standards of those nations while creating unemployment in the USA and lowering the living standards of U.S. citizens!

Headline Text: HERO picks up some high-level support
Article Text:
Houston's anti-discrimination ordinance picked up White House support Thursday when a spokesman said the president and vice president were "confident that the citizens of Houston will vote in favor of fairness and equality."
"While the administration generally does not take a formal position on specific proposals or initiatives, the president and vice president have been strong supporters of state and local efforts to protect Americans from being discriminated against based on who they are and who they love," said the spokesman, Jeff Tiller.
The remarks, first reported by Buzzfeed News, followed those of Democratic presidential frontrunner Hillary Clinton, who tweeted her support of the ordinance known as HERO Thursday.
"No one should face discrimination for who they are or who they love - I support efforts for equality in Houston & beyond. #HERO #YesOnProp1," Clinton wrote on Twitter.
The ordinance bans discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, as well as sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information, as well as family, marital or military status.
The ordinance, which can carry fines of up to $5,000, applies to businesses that serve the public, private employers, housing, city employment and city contracting; religious institutions are exempt.
Opponents of the measure, which they refer to as "the bathroom ordinance," say the ordinance would allow men dressed in women's clothing to enter women's restrooms to commit sexual assaults. The highest-profile opponents to date include Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick and former Astros star Lance Berkman, who stated his opposition to the ordinance in a television advertisement.
Also Thursday, Academy Award-winning actress Sally Field was in town to voice her support for the ordinance.
The question of whether the ordinance will be upheld has dominated Houston politics for much of the year, and recent attacks about public restroom access have drowned out discussion of discrimination.
City Council approved the ordinance in May 2014, but a judge ordered the city in July to repeal the ordinance or put it before voters on the November ballot after opponents sued the city, complaining the Parker administration illegally ignored their petitions seeking to have the law repealed.
The ordinance is on the ballot as Proposition 1 in next Tuesday's election.

Headline Text: Rangel: All eyes on Houston's anti-discrimination vote
Article Text:
AUSTIN ‚Äî Houston voters elect a new mayor on Tuesday but despite a crowded field that includes a veteran state representative, a former congressman and a former sheriff, a contentious local proposition is getting most of the attention and it's even eclipsing the seven statewide propositions on the ballot.
And no wonder.
Civic and business leaders are deeply divided on Proposition 1, an ordinance that would prohibit discrimination based on race, religion, national origin, sexual orientation, gender identity and 10 other categories.
Yet it is gender identity opponents are mostly focused on.
For instance, for Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, a Houstonian, the measure would let men use women's bathrooms and other public facilities for ladies.
"No woman should have to share a public restroom or locker room with a man," Patrick says in an ad paid for by his campaign.
"This is absurd," he said. "Years ago, a decade ago, we would laugh on even thinking about that the people would cast a ballot to keep men out of ladies' rooms."
But for supporters of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, or HERO, the attacks Patrick and other opponents of the so-called "bathroom ordinance" use are pure demagoguery.
"The lieutenant governor must know it's illegal now ‚Äî and will always be ‚Äî to enter the wrong restroom," Richard Carlborn, spokesman for supporters of the ordinance, told the Houston Chronicle.
"The Houston Equal Rights Ordinance doesn't change that," Carlborn said. "What's shocking is that funders of those opposed to the equal rights ordinance want to roll back protections ‚Äî in 2015 ‚Äî of African-Americans, veterans, women and many other Houstonians."
The HERO fight, which is getting national attention because Houston is the fourth largest city in the nation and has its first openly gay mayor, is a reminder that despite the June 26 U.S. Supreme Court ruling that legalized same-sex marriage, lesbian, gay, bi- sexual and transgender Texans still faces numerous obstacles, ordinance supporters say.
"This is another example of the fact that securing the freedom to marry does not solve the problems or provide full equality for gays and transgender people living in Texas," said Chuck Smith, executive director of Equality Texas, an LGBT advocacy group.
"If it does pass, and I am hopeful that it will, it will provide a local mechanism for over 2 million Houstonians to be able to deal with discrimination if and when it should happen," Smith said.
Equally important, if Houston voters approve the ordinance, it would send a strong message to the rest of the state and to the entire nation that the city is fair, tolerant and a good place to live or for business, Smith said.
However, if the ordinance ‚Äî which the Houston City Council approved last year but the Texas Supreme Court ruled later Houston voters should be the deciders ‚Äî is rejected, it will embolden opponents of similar measures in Austin, Dallas, Fort Worth, San Antonio and other smaller cities, Smith and other HERO supporters fear. Political observers such as Mark P. Jones of Rice University and Brandon Rottinghaus of the University of Houston say it is difficult to predict whether the ordinance will pass or be defeated.
"It is pretty tight," Rottinghaus said. "I legitimately think it could be like 50-50."
A higher than average voter turnout is expected because the stakes are high for both camps.
But regardless of the outcome, when the Republican-dominated Texas Legislature is back in session in 2017 anti-LGBT legislation is expected, Smith said.
Patrick, the presiding officer of the Texas Senate, has already issued a long list of interim charges ‚Äî issues state lawmakers take an in-depth look the year before they are in session ‚Äî and they include religious liberty.
Patrick, Gov. Greg Abbott and State Attorney General Ken Paxton have argued Texans don't have to comply with the U.S. Supreme Court's same-sex ruling if it violates their religious beliefs.
In short, no matter what Houston voters decide, it looks like same-sex marriage, gender identity and other related issues will remain in the spotlight.

Headline Text: HERO picks up some high-level support
Article Text:
Houston's anti-discrimination ordinance picked up White House support Thursday when a spokesman said the president and vice president were "confident that the citizens of Houston will vote in favor of fairness and equality."
"While the administration generally does not take a formal position on specific proposals or initiatives, the president and vice president have been strong supporters of state and local efforts to protect Americans from being discriminated against based on who they are and who they love," said the spokesman, Jeff Tiller.
The remarks, first reported by Buzzfeed News, followed those of Democratic presidential frontrunner Hillary Clinton, who tweeted her support of the ordinance known as HERO Thursday.
"No one should face discrimination for who they are or who they love - I support efforts for equality in Houston & beyond. #HERO #YesOnProp1," Clinton wrote on Twitter.
The ordinance bans discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, as well as sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information, as well as family, marital or military status.
The ordinance, which can carry fines of up to $5,000, applies to businesses that serve the public, private employers, housing, city employment and city contracting; religious institutions are exempt.
Opponents of the measure, which they refer to as "the bathroom ordinance," say the ordinance would allow men dressed in women's clothing to enter women's restrooms to commit sexual assaults. The highest-profile opponents to date include Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick and former Astros star Lance Berkman, who stated his opposition to the ordinance in a television advertisement.
Also Thursday, Academy Award-winning actress Sally Field was in town to voice her support for the ordinance.
The question of whether the ordinance will be upheld has dominated Houston politics for much of the year, and recent attacks about public restroom access have drowned out discussion of discrimination.
City Council approved the ordinance in May 2014, but a judge ordered the city in July to repeal the ordinance or put it before voters on the November ballot after opponents sued the city, complaining the Parker administration illegally ignored their petitions seeking to have the law repealed.
The ordinance is on the ballot as Proposition 1 in next Tuesday's election.

Headline Text: Rangel: All eyes on Houston's anti-discrimination vote
Article Text:
AUSTIN ‚Äî Houston voters elect a new mayor on Tuesday but despite a crowded field that includes a veteran state representative, a former congressman and a former sheriff, a contentious local proposition is getting most of the attention and it's even eclipsing the seven statewide propositions on the ballot.
And no wonder.
Civic and business leaders are deeply divided on Proposition 1, an ordinance that would prohibit discrimination based on race, religion, national origin, sexual orientation, gender identity and 10 other categories.
Yet it is gender identity opponents are mostly focused on.
For instance, for Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, a Houstonian, the measure would let men use women's bathrooms and other public facilities for ladies.
"No woman should have to share a public restroom or locker room with a man," Patrick says in an ad paid for by his campaign.
"This is absurd," he said. "Years ago, a decade ago, we would laugh on even thinking about that the people would cast a ballot to keep men out of ladies' rooms."
But for supporters of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, or HERO, the attacks Patrick and other opponents of the so-called "bathroom ordinance" use are pure demagoguery.
"The lieutenant governor must know it's illegal now ‚Äî and will always be ‚Äî to enter the wrong restroom," Richard Carlborn, spokesman for supporters of the ordinance, told the Houston Chronicle.
"The Houston Equal Rights Ordinance doesn't change that," Carlborn said. "What's shocking is that funders of those opposed to the equal rights ordinance want to roll back protections ‚Äî in 2015 ‚Äî of African-Americans, veterans, women and many other Houstonians."
The HERO fight, which is getting national attention because Houston is the fourth largest city in the nation and has its first openly gay mayor, is a reminder that despite the June 26 U.S. Supreme Court ruling that legalized same-sex marriage, lesbian, gay, bi- sexual and transgender Texans still faces numerous obstacles, ordinance supporters say.
"This is another example of the fact that securing the freedom to marry does not solve the problems or provide full equality for gays and transgender people living in Texas," said Chuck Smith, executive director of Equality Texas, an LGBT advocacy group.
"If it does pass, and I am hopeful that it will, it will provide a local mechanism for over 2 million Houstonians to be able to deal with discrimination if and when it should happen," Smith said.
Equally important, if Houston voters approve the ordinance, it would send a strong message to the rest of the state and to the entire nation that the city is fair, tolerant and a good place to live or for business, Smith said.
However, if the ordinance ‚Äî which the Houston City Council approved last year but the Texas Supreme Court ruled later Houston voters should be the deciders ‚Äî is rejected, it will embolden opponents of similar measures in Austin, Dallas, Fort Worth, San Antonio and other smaller cities, Smith and other HERO supporters fear. Political observers such as Mark P. Jones of Rice University and Brandon Rottinghaus of the University of Houston say it is difficult to predict whether the ordinance will pass or be defeated.
"It is pretty tight," Rottinghaus said. "I legitimately think it could be like 50-50."
A higher than average voter turnout is expected because the stakes are high for both camps.
But regardless of the outcome, when the Republican-dominated Texas Legislature is back in session in 2017 anti-LGBT legislation is expected, Smith said.
Patrick, the presiding officer of the Texas Senate, has already issued a long list of interim charges ‚Äî issues state lawmakers take an in-depth look the year before they are in session ‚Äî and they include religious liberty.
Patrick, Gov. Greg Abbott and State Attorney General Ken Paxton have argued Texans don't have to comply with the U.S. Supreme Court's same-sex ruling if it violates their religious beliefs.
In short, no matter what Houston voters decide, it looks like same-sex marriage, gender identity and other related issues will remain in the spotlight.

Headline Text: White House offers support for Houston equal rights measure
Article Text:
HOUSTON (AP) ‚Äî An ordinance that would establish nondiscrimination protections for gay and transgender people in Houston, the nation's fourth largest city, got support this week from heavy hitters including the White House and high tech giant Apple.
Houston residents will vote Tuesday on the contested Houston Equal Rights Ordinance.
"While the Administration generally does not take a formal position on specific proposals or initiatives, the President and Vice President have been strong supporters of state and local efforts to protect Americans from being discriminated against based on who they are and who they love," White House spokesman Jeff Tiller said in a statement Thursday.
"We're confident that the citizens of Houston will vote in favor of fairness and equality."
Supporters of the ordinance say the measure would not only offer increased protections for gay and transgender people, but it would provide a wealth of protections against discrimination based on sex, race, age, religion and other categories.
Opponents, who contend the ordinance would infringe on their religious beliefs against homosexuality, have focused their campaign on labeling it the "bathroom ordinance," alleging that it would open the door for sexual predators to go into women's restrooms. The "bathroom ordinance" strategy has been called highly misleading by Houston Mayor Annise Parker, who is gay, and other supporters of the ordinance.
Cupertino, California-based Apple said its "stores and our company are open to everyone, regardless of where they come from, what they look like, how they worship or who they love."
"Apple supports Proposition 1 as it sends a clear message that Houston is focused on a future of inclusion, diversity and continued prosperity," the company added in its statement.
Apple CEO Tim Cook came out last year as the first openly gay chief executive of a Fortune 500 company.
Houston's ordinance also has received support from Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton, who on Thursday tweeted: "No one should face discrimination for who they are or who they love_I support efforts for equality in Houston & beyond."
The high-profile support comes as the outcome of Tuesday's vote is considered uncertain, with one political expert believing the measure is leaning toward being defeated.
Robert Stein, a political scientist at Rice University in Houston, said the ordinance "could go to defeat by a big margin" because of possibly heavy Republican voter turnout.
"That's probably why you have the efforts in the last days of the election (to show support from) the president, Hillary Clinton," he said.
Kevin Nix, a spokesman for Houston Unites, the campaign backing the ordinance, said the high-profile support will "boost the momentum as we head into Tuesday."
"I think it's going to be a tight race but we're feeling pretty good," he said.
Houston Unites announced Friday that other companies also have offered their support of the ordinance, including General Electric, Hewlett-Packard and BASF. But Jared Woodfill, a spokesman for Campaign for Houston, which is fighting the ordinance, called the big-name support a sign of desperation.
"It's a Hail Mary pass at the last minute that is not going to work," he said.
Woodfill said opponents of the ordinance have included a diverse group of individuals, including pastors from all denominations and local and state elected officials.
One of those officials, Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, on Thursday tweeted: "HOUSTON: Liberals from Hollywood and Washington, D.C. are trying to impose their radical agenda in Texas. Vote NO on Houston's Prop 1!"

Headline Text: Commentary - Indiana provides a lesson on the Equal Rights Ordinance
Article Text:
When voting on the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, remember Indiana.
Ultraconservative lawmakers there introduced a so-called Religious Freedom Restoration Act that legalized discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity earlier this year.
Responsible Republican leaders, including former U.S. Sen. Richard Lugar and Indianapolis Mayor Greg Ballard, warned that it would condone bigotry and hatred. Dozens of Indiana business leaders called for an additional law explicitly banning discrimination against those groups. The bigots ignored their pleas, and Indiana Gov. Mike Pence signed the act into law on March 26.
That's when the backlash began.
National business leaders couldn't condemn the law fast enough. Apple, Wal-Mart, the NBA, the NFL, the NCAA, PayPal, Yelp and dozens of religious denominations demanded the law's repeal or overhaul. Marc Benioff, CEO of Salesforce, announced his company would suspend all travel to Indiana. Angie's List canceled a $40 million expansion of its Indianapolis headquarters. #BoycottIndiana trended on Twitter.
After a week of outrage, the Indiana Senate and House leaders announced a new law that would forbid discrimination. Supporters of the original act declared defeat.
The lesson? Discrimination is bad for business.
Now a small minority of Houstonians are trying to leverage a traditionally low-turnout election to repeal an equal rights ordinance that is already embraced in 15 other major cities and is boilerplate policy at most large corporations.
If misguided voters repeal HERO, it won't be the bigots who pay the price in H-town. Businesses will suffer the boycotts, and talented workers will decline job offers in what many will call Hate-town.
"Do you want Houston to be seen as a city that discriminates or not?" said Laura Murillo, CEO of the Houston Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, which has 180,000 members. "There has been so much investment in hotels, restaurants and other businesses to attract out-of-town visitors, we don't want anything to reflect a discriminatory environment."
Houston's business organizations almost universally support HERO, Murillo said. The Greater Houston Partnership played a major role in drafting the ordinance, and dozens of major corporations and trade organizations are rallying support for it.
Because Texas universities don't graduate enough students to meet business demand, local companies must recruit from outside the state to find workers with advanced degrees. Younger workers care about equal rights, and any employer will tell you that Houston isn't perceived to be as idyllic as cities like San Francisco, Chicago and New York.
"People have a choice of whether they come here for leisure, for a convention, to relocate a business or to move here for a job," said Ric Campo, CEO of real estate giant Camden Property Trust. "Millennials are the future workforce, and we have to show that we are a city that stands for what they believe in, a diverse city where we protect people."
Rebuke from the public
Ask Houston Texans owner Bob McNair how important equal rights are to his business and employees. After he wrote a check to his buddies leading the fight against HERO, he felt the sting of public disapproval and quickly asked for a refund. He knows to put commerce ahead of ill-advised culture wars.
And there is no doubt this vote is about discrimination. Dr. Steven Hotze made that abundantly clear with his hateful, ignorant and misleading rhetoric about gays. Hotze acolyte Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, an expert in polemics and misdirection, has won several elections by promoting bigotry against homosexuals and transgender people, and now he's using those tactics against HERO.
If you are naive enough to think this fight is about bathrooms, that word does not appear in the ordinance. Bad behavior in public restrooms will remain just as illegal as it is now. Bigots have used the "we must protect the womenfolk" trope for centuries to stir emotions, justify discrimination and even promote lynchings. Don't ruin the city's reputation based on misinformation.
Community standards
HERO protects 15 groups, including pregnant women, veterans and senior citizens. The ordinance's punishments are so mild that they do little more than encourage our better angels to overcome our personal prejudices.
In other words, HERO is not so much a law, but a statement about the kind of community and people we want to be. If you care about the reputation and prosperity of your business, your employer or your city, vote yes on Proposition 1.

Headline Text: Houston Baseball Legend Stokes Trans Bathroom Panic
Article Text:
Fear-Mongering
Ex-Astros star Lance Berkman is appearing on ads all over Houston saying he's worried about 'troubled men' sharing a restroom with his daughters. But the trans women have more to fear.
Shop ‚ñæ
Houston Astros legend Lance Berkman is afraid that his four daughters could use the same restroom as transgender women, and
he wants you to know about it.
In an ad for Campaign for Houston‚Äîa PAC opposed to the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance (HERO), an LGBT nondiscrimination measure supported by Mayor Annise Parker that will be decided by a ballot proposition on Nov. 3‚ÄîBerkman introduces himself with his baseball credentials before segueing into some of the worst transphobic fear-mongering the debate over LGBT legal protections has seen so far.
"I would like to protect my girls from as many threats that are out there as I possibly can."
"My wife and I have four daughters," the recently retired athlete says in the ad. "Proposition 1 would allow troubled men who claim to be women to enter women's bathrooms, showers, and locker rooms."
Berkman adds in a behind-the-scenes video for the spot that the idea of transgender people is "a little strange to [him]," before sounding the alarm over the possibility that a child predator could abuse the ordinance to attack his daughters.
"As a husband and a father, you feel like you're in a position of protector over your family," Berkman says. "I would like to protect my girls from as many threats that are out there as I possibly can."
In the October buildup to the vote, Campaign for Houston has been getting as much mileage out of the one-time MLB player as it can. Berkman, who played for the Astros from 1999 to 2004, has been featured in radio spots, and one Houston resident told The Daily Beast that he has been receiving robocalls featuring a recorded message from Berkman for the past few weeks. As Proposition 1 picks up endorsements in the final days before the election, Berkman's star status has been invoked as proof that the anti-HERO campaign is still going strong.
Asked if Campaign for Houston was struggling, spokesman Jared Woodfill told KPRC, "Absolutely not," adding, "We've got a lot of high-profile people, including Lance Berkman and others, who've taken a strong, principled stand."
Right off the bat‚Äîpun intended‚Äîit should be made clear that Berkman's widely publicized fears about transgender people in bathrooms are completely unsubstantiated.
As The Daily Beast's Jay Michaelson noted earlier this year, "To be clear, there is not a single case‚Äînot one‚Äîof a trans woman assaulting other women in a public restroom."
The Advocate also confirmed in March that "there has never been a verifiable, reported instance of a trans person harassing a cisgender [non-transgender] person." In April, Mic surveyed the Transgender Law Center, the Human Rights Campaign, the American Civil Liberties Union, and the National Center for Transgender Equality, none of which could find statistical evidence of the sort of violence that critics like Berkman fear will result from nondiscrimination ordinances. Lance Berkman played in St. Louis. Guess his girls didn't go to his games! SL has a non-discrimination ordinance.-A http://t.co/gzEbKIYOd9
‚Äî Annise Parker (@AnniseParker) October 5, 2015
Then Lance Berkman went to Dallas. Oops. Dallas amended its Charter to clarify gender identity protections. Can you spell hypocrite?-A
‚Äî Annise Parker (@AnniseParker) October 5, 2015
Indeed, as Mayor Parker noted on Twitter, Berkman and his family have already lived in cities that have LGBT nondiscrimination ordinances.
On the other hand, there is plenty of evidence to prove that bathrooms are dangerous and often inaccessible places for transgender people.
In a survey of transgender people by the Williams Institute at the UCLA School of Law, 68 percent of respondents reported experiencing verbal harassment in a public restroom, and 9 percent reported experiencing a form of physical assault. Eighteen percent had been denied access to a public restroom. The 2011 National Transgender Discrimination Survey (PDF) found that 22 percent of transgender employees had been denied access to an appropriate restroom in their own workplace.
Going to the bathroom is an experience fraught with anxiety for transgender people. And for good reason‚Äîunlike the specter of the trans bathroom predator that critics like Berkman repeatedly raise, stories about the violence trans people face in bathrooms can be confirmed.
In 2011, a young transgender woman named Chrissy Lee Polis tried to use the restroom at a McDonald's in Maryland and was brutally beaten by another woman and a 14-year-old-girl. A McDonald's employee simply filmed the incident rather than intervening. The employee was later fired and Polis's adult attacker was imprisoned.
Berkman's advertisements highlight one of the cruelest ironies of today's anti-trans panic: While critics suggest repeatedly that transgender people in bathrooms are dangerous, bathrooms are one of the most dangerous places for transgender people to be.
And although Berkman might find transgender identity "a little strange" or believe that transgender people are "troubled," his 15-year career in baseball doesn't exactly credential him to contradict the conclusions of the American Medical Association, the American Psychiatric Association, the American Psychological Association, the American Public Health Association, and several other leading health care associations (PDF). Even with more than 350 home runs.
Campaign for Houston did not respond to The Daily Beast's request for comment and clarification. A spokesperson for the Houston Astros told The Daily Beast that the team has no comment on Berkman's participation in Campaign for Houston.
Houston's HERO legislation‚Äîa nondiscrimination ordinance that would prohibit anti-LGBT discrimination in employment, housing, and public accommodations‚Äîhas been caught in legal and judicial turmoil for over a year.
In 2014, Mayor Parker, who is openly lesbian, introduced the legislation to the Houston City Council, where it passed 11-6 last May to the dismay of some local pastors, who supported a campaign to repeal the ordinance by petition. In July of this year, the Texas Supreme Court ruled that the ordinance must either be repealed or put on the ballot. Now, on Nov. 3, Houstonians will decide on HERO in what looks to be a tight vote: Support for HERO is at 43 percent and opposition at 37 percent in the latest poll.
With Texas often named as one of the worst states in the country for LGBT people, the debate over HERO in Houston has drawn national attention. Houston is the fourth most populous city in the United States and the most populous to elect an openly gay mayor.
With no evidence to support the anti-transgender scare tactics that are often used to argue against nondiscrimination ordinances, opponents like Berkman frame the issue as a matter of preventing crimes rather than responding to an established threat. In his Campaign for Houston ad, Berkman says, "It's better to prevent this danger by closing women's restrooms to men rather than waiting for a crime to happen."
This despite the fact that nondiscrimination ordinances have already been passed in other major cities without incident and laws are already in place to prosecute anyone who enters a restroom for the wrong reasons, according to the Parker administration.
"It is already illegal for anyone to enter a restroom to cause a disturbance," Janice Evans, chief policy officer for Mayor Parker, told The Daily Beast. "That will not change if HERO remains in place."
Berkman might be a local legend, then, but his opposition to Proposition 1 is based in myth.

Headline Text: Garcia spends big as he looks to make runoff - Former sheriff boosted advertising to counter criticism of his record
Article Text:
Adrian Garcia outspent his chief rivals in the Houston mayor's race over the last month, hoping to hold what polls suggest is his slipping grip on a spot in the likely December runoff.
The final round of campaign finance filings before the Nov. 3 election, covering the period from late September through last Saturday, showed Garcia's $1.1 million outlay made up a third of all six top campaigns' spending for the period.
About $860,000 of the former Harris County sheriff's expenditures were for advertising, double that of former Kemah Mayor Bill King, who some polls show is Garcia's closest rival.
Garcia needed to increase his advertising to combat a slew of negative attacks from opponents related to his management of the sheriff's office, said Mark Jones, a University of Houston political scientist.
"Originally, he was holding back quite a bit, hoping to have a larger war chest going into the runoff," Jones said. "But he does not occupy the clear-cut second post that he did two months ago. He is still within striking distance, but he can't hold much back; it's a now-or-never situation."
Campaign spokeswoman Mary Bell said Garcia's spending has been timed to reach voters who are still undecided in the race to succeed term-limited Mayor Annise Parker.
"This campaign, like Adrian Garcia as a public servant, has been fiscally responsible in deploying its resources to the right voters at the right time," Bell said.
Candidate spending
City Councilman Steve Costello, who has been a strong fundraiser but trails Garcia and King in most polls, posted the second- highest outlay for the period, at $732,000. Of that, he spent $652,000 on advertising and was helped by another $251,000 in ad spending by a political action committee organized to support him called Houstonians for the Future.
King spent $572,700 in the period, about $429,000 of it on advertising. He stopped running TV ads in the middle of last week but was to resume them on Tuesday, campaign spokesman Jim McGrath said.
That gap is not concerning, McGrath said, pointing to consistent radio buys, key endorsements and strong early turnout from conservative areas.
"We like where we are," McGrath said. "We could spend a good chunk of money on broadcast, but it's all about getting the most bang for your buck. We like cable."
State Rep. Sylvester Turner, who remains the presumed frontrunner, raised nearly $400,000 in the period, spent the third-highest amount at $626,000 and entered this week with $285,000 on hand - roughly the same amount as Garcia and Costello. King entered the week with $123,350 banked.
Former Congressman Chris Bell, who has lagged in fundraising, spent $106,000 in the period and entered the final week with $60,500 on hand. Former City Attorney Ben Hall, who loaned his campaign $850,000 earlier in the year, continued to post low fundraising totals and spent $134,000 in the period, leaving himself nearly $694,000 on hand.
In the heated campaign over Houston's equal rights ordinance, supporters raised $1.7 million, more than quadruple opponents' reported $385,845.
Critics of the law have two political action committees, and as of Monday night the campaign had filed a report for only one. Spokesman Jared Woodfill said the group had raised $323,350 in addition to the $62,495 reported in the group's first filing.
Supporters drew big-ticket donations from national lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender advocacy groups, including $250,000 from the American Civil Liberties Union of Texas, more than $186,000 from the Human Rights Committee and $150,000 apiece from Colorado's Gill Action and the New York-based American Unity Fund. Mayor Annise Parker kicked in another $90,000 from her campaign fund.
'Grassroots coalition'
Houston Unites campaign manager Richard Carlbom touted the significantly higher fundraising total as proof of a groundswell of support for the law. The campaign has raised almost $3 million since launching in mid-August.
"Compared to the handful of wealthy opponents funding the rollback of needed protections for African Americans, Latinos, women and veterans, we have put together a massive, diverse grassroots coalition backing Houston's Equal Rights Ordinance," Carlbom said in a written statement.
mike.morris@chron.com twitter.com/mmorris011 katherine.driessen@chron.com twitter.com/katdriessen By the numbers
$1.1 million: Amount Adrian Garcia spent in the past month.
$732,000: What Steve Costello spent in the same period.
$626,000: Amount Sylvester Turner spent.
$572,700: Bill King's expenses last month.

Headline Text: HOUSTON TO VOTE ON LGBT NONDISCRIMINATION ORDINANCE
Article Text:
After a drawn-out showdown between Houston's popular lesbian mayor and a coalition of conservative pastors, voters in the nation's fourth-largest city will soon decide whether to establish nondiscrimination protections for gay and transgender people.
Nationwide, there's interest in the Nov. 3 referendum: Confrontations over the same issue are flaring in many places, at the state and local level, now that nondiscrimination has replaced same-sex marriage as the No. 1 priority for the LGBT-rights movement.
"The vote in Houston will carry national significance," said Sarah Warbelow, legal director of the Human Rights Campaign, a national LGBT-rights group. She noted that Houston, with
2.2 million residents, is more populous than 15 states.
The Houston Equal Rights Ordinance would consolidate bans on discrimination tied to race, sex, religion and other categories in employment, housing and public accommodations, and extend such protections to gays, lesbians, bisexuals and transgender people.
Two recent polls commissioned by Houston TV stations showed supporters of the ordinance with a slight lead, but each poll indicated that about one-fifth of likely voters were undecided.
Opponents contend the ordinance would infringe on their religious beliefs against homosexuality. Copying a tactic used elsewhere, they also have labeled it the "bathroom ordinance," alleging that it would open the door for sexual predators to go into women's restrooms.
"Even registered sex offenders could follow women or young girls into the bathroom," says an ad produced by Campaign for Houston, which opposes the ordinance.
The measure's supporters denounce these assertions as scare tactics, arguing that such problems with public bathrooms have been virtually nonexistent in the 17 states that have banned discrimination based on gender identity.
Mayor Annise Parker, whose election in
2009 made Houston the largest U.S. city with an openly gay mayor, is among those expressing exasperation.
"The fact there is so much misinformation and not just misinformation, just out and out ludicrous lies, is very frustrating," Parker recently told reporters. "I'm worried about the image of Houston around the world as a tolerant, welcoming place if this goes down."

Headline Text: Showdown in Houston over nondiscrimination ordinance
Article Text:
HOUSTON - After a drawn-out showdown between Houston's popular lesbian mayor and a coalition of conservative pastors, voters in the nation's fourth-largest city will soon decide whether to establish nondiscrimination protections for gay and transgender people.
Nationwide, there's interest in the Nov. 3 referendum: Confrontations over the same issue are flaring in many places, at the state and local level, now that nondiscrimination has replaced same-sex marriage as the No. 1 priority for the LGBT-rights movement.
"The vote in Houston will carry national significance, said Sarah Warbelow, legal director of the Human Rights Campaign, a national LGBT-rights group. She noted that Houston, with 2.2 million residents, is more populous than 15 states.
The contested Houston Equal Rights Ordinance is a broad measure that would consolidate existing bans on discrimination tied to race, sex, religion and other categories in employment, housing and public accommodations, and extend such protections to gays, lesbians, bisexuals and transgender people.
The outcome is considered uncertain. Two recent polls commissioned by Houston TV stations showed supporters of the ordinance with a slight lead, but each poll indicated that about one-fifth of likely voters were undecided.
Opponents contend the ordinance would infringe on their religious beliefs against homosexuality. Copying a tactic used elsewhere, they also have labeled it the "bathroom ordinance, alleging that it would open the door for sexual predators to go into women's restrooms.
"Even registered sex offenders could follow women or young girls into the bathroom, says an ad produced by Campaign for Houston, which opposes the ordinance.
The measure's supporters denounce these assertions as scare tactics, arguing that such problems with public bathrooms have been virtually nonexistent in the 17 states that have banned discrimination based on gender identity.
Mayor Annise Parker, whose election in 2009 made Houston the largest U.S. city with an openly gay mayor, is among those expressing exasperation.
"The fact there is so much misinformation and not just misinformation, just out and out ludicrous lies, is very frustrating, Parker recently told reporters. "I'm worried about the image of Houston around the world as a tolerant, welcoming place if this goes down.
Parker has vented some of her frustration on Twitter in tweets criticizing former Houston Astros player Lance Berkman. In ads for Campaign for Houston, Berkman said the ordinance would "allow troubled men who claim to be women to enter women's bathrooms, showers and locker rooms.
Parker, who is completing her third and final term, has encountered criticism herself. When opponents sued the city - seeking to force a referendum on the ordinance after the city council approved it in May 2014 - city attorneys tried to subpoena sermons from five pastors who opposed the measure. The pastors said the request violated their religious freedom, and the city later dropped the effort.
The lawsuit eventually reached the Texas Supreme Court, which in July ruled the conservative activists should have succeeded in their petition drive to put the issue before voters.
In a sermon last month, Ed Young, pastor of Second Baptist Church, one of the nation's largest churches, called the ordinance "totally deceptive and urged his congregation to vote against it because "it will carry our city ... further down the road of being totally, in my opinion, secular and godless.
Richard Carlbom, campaign manager for Houston Unites, which supports the ordinance, said the measure is not simply about anti- LGBT discrimination but about multiple forms of bias. Between May 2014 and September 2015, most discrimination complaints in the city related to race and gender; only about 5 percent involved LGBT discrimination.
Several national LGBT-rights groups have deployed staff in Houston to support the ordinance, including Freedom for All Americans. Its CEO, Matt McTighe, praised Houston's cultural diversity, but said it was the only one of the 10 largest U.S. cities without LGBT nondiscrimination protection.
For years, the top priority of the gay-rights movement in the U.S. was winning nationwide legalization of same-sex marriage. When that occurred via a Supreme Court ruling in June, there was broad agreement among activists that the next priority should be obtaining nondiscrimination protections in all 50 states.
At present, Texas is one of 28 states with no statewide protections, although many municipalities in those states have adopted local nondiscrimination policies. Of the other 22 states, 17 prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity in employment, housing and public accommodations, and New York will soon join that group. Four states have less sweeping protections.
LGBT activists would like to replace this patchwork of laws with a comprehensive federal nondiscrimination law, and such a measure - the Equality Act - was introduced in July. But it's given no chance of passage in the current Republican-controlled Congress; none of its more than 200 co-sponsors are from the GOP.
Faced with that reality, LGBT-rights supporters are waging a state-by-state, city-by-city campaign to extend anti-bias protections.
"We're now at a moment where we're having conversations with more conservative parts of the country - it's not easy, said Sarah Warbelow. "These are educational efforts - bringing people along on what it means to provide protections for the LGBT community and helping people understand that the sky doesn't fall when you do that.
At the state level, activists consider Pennsylvania the most likely to join in establishing statewide protections.
LGBT nondiscrimination has been on the Pennsylvania legislature's agenda for more than a decade but there's never been a floor vote, largely due to Republican opposition. Now there's growing GOP support for the latest measure, introduced in August, and supporters believe it will prevail if skeptics can be assured it won't erode religious liberties.
"I'm confident that if this bill is given a vote in the Senate and House, it will pass, said state Sen. Pat Browne, a lead Republican sponsor. "The people we represent believe this is something we should do.
In Indiana, prospects are unclear for a Democratic plan - backed by many major corporations - to push for statewide LGBT protections. The topic has been divisive since the spring, when Republican Gov. Mike Pence and the GOP-controlled Legislature incurred a backlash for a religious objections law that critics said would allow businesses to discriminate against LGBT people.
In the absence of a statewide law, several smaller Indiana cities - including Pence's hometown of Columbus - recently joined Indianapolis and Bloomington in adopting local LGBT protections. Similar efforts failed in the cities of Goshen and Elkhart.
There's been action recently in several other states. In September, Fayetteville became the fifth Arkansas municipality to pass an LGBT nondiscrimination ordinance in defiance of a new state law aimed at prohibiting such local protections. In Alaska's largest city, the governing assembly of Anchorage passed an ordinance Sept. 29 by a 9-2 vote. In Arizona, an ordinance was approved in Sedona.
Other cities across the U.S. will be watching Houston on Nov. 3, said James Douglas, a supporter of the ordinance who is president of Houston's NAACP chapter."All those cities that are smaller than us are looking to us because they want to be like us, Douglas said. "And we want to give them a perfect example of what a major, diverse city ought to look like.
