Headline Text: Patrick takes to the airwaves to oppose HERO - LIeutenant governor lends voice, pocketbook to TV, radio ads, blasts Parker over ordinance
Article Text:
With the start of early voting Monday, Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick began lending his voice and his pocketbook to radio and TV ads urging Houston voters to reject the city's embattled equal rights ordinance.
At a news conference Monday in Houston, Patrick echoed the chief criticism of equal rights ordinance opponents - that the law would allow men to enter women's restrooms - and he blasted Mayor Annise Parker, saying she "ought to be embarrassed" by the ordinance.
In Patrick's TV ad, set to begin Tuesday airing on cable and network stations, he tells voters that "no woman should have to share a public restroom or locker room with a man."
The radio and TV ads totaling about $70,000 were paid for by Texans for Dan Patrick. The former Republican state senator from Houston defended his decision to wade into a local issue.
"I think this is an extraordinary circumstance," Patrick said. "This is absurd. Years ago, a decade ago, we would laugh at even thinking about that the people would cast a vote to keep men out of ladies rooms."
Richard Carlbom, spokesman for supporters of the ordinance, pushed back on Patrick's ad in a statement Monday.
"The lieutenant governor must know it's illegal now - and will always be - to enter the wrong restroom," he said. "The Houston Equal Rights Ordinance doesn't change that. What's shocking is that funders of those opposed to the equal rights ordinance want to roll back protections - in 2015 - of African-Americans, veterans, women, and many other Houstonians."
Jared Woodfill, spokesman for opponents, hailed Patrick's ads as a sign of growing momentum. "It's outstanding to see an elected official at his level standing against the ordinance," Woodfill said.
Last week, opponents of the law released a controversial ad that closes with a man entering a stall occupied by a young girl. Patrick's ad takes a considerably less dramatic approach, simply showing photos of bathrooms with gender designations.
The issue of bathroom access has driven much of the debate surrounding the law that City Council passed 11-6 last year. Opponents of the law claim it will allow any man who claims to be a woman access to a woman's restroom, Supporters of the law, however, point to a long-standing law that bars anyone from entering a restroom of the opposite sex with the intent to cause a disturbance.
Under the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, or HERO, discrimination based on sexual orientation, gender identity, sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information, as well as family, marital or military status, is banned. Opponents criticize the protections the law extends to gay and transgender residents.
Businesses that serve the public, private employers, housing, city employment and city contracting are subject to the ordinance and could face fines of up to $5,000 for violations. Religious organizations are exempt.
During the few months the equal rights ordinance was in effect - the city suspended enforcement for more than a year while litigation was pending - 11 discrimination complaints were filed. Five of the cases alleged racial discrimination, another five LGBT discrimination, and one claimed gender discrimination. Supporters of the ordinance have sought to cast the law in a broader scope in recent weeks, unveiling an ad last week that features veterans covered under the law.
Both supporters and opponents have been spending heavily as they look to flood the airwaves during early voting, which runs from Oct. 19-30 leading up to the Nov. 3 election.
During the first campaign finance period, both groups shelled out more than $1 million combined.

Headline Text: Ups and downs - Jolanda's big leap, the Big Jinx from Austin and raising a toast to the craft brewers.
Article Text:
Thumbs up: We'd be surprised if there's a street on the planet with as much construction as Travis between Alabama and the north end of downtown. We counted 14 new developments and more than a handful of tower cranes on that two-mile stretch. The billion- dollar question, of course, is what happens in the current economy after these buildings are topped out? Until then, hug a general contractor, an architect and a developer today.
Thumbs down: The problem with driving downtown is that traffic lights remain out of sequence, creating a maddening crawl from end-to-end. Who's to blame? A lame-duck mayor? A Public Works Department forgetting about its customers? The new Metro rail line? We don't know. But we'd sure like leadership who cares.
Thumbs down: One of those mayoral candidates, the former sheriff, uses a 3-year-old Chronicle endorsement in his television ads and implies it's current.
Thumbs up: State Rep. Garnet Coleman, flanked by an A-list of elected officials, launched a petition drive to rename Dowling Street as Emancipation Avenue. Richard Dowling was a Confederate officer, and it is believed the street, which bisects an African- American neighborhood, was named after him in the late 1800s to remind local residents of their place in the racist South. We wholeheartedly wish Coleman success in his effort.
Thumbs up: If there's an election for Chief Avenger in Crush City, our unqualified endorsement goes to Jolanda Jones. The former city councilwoman and current candidate for HISD trustee spotted a thief breaking in to her car in the Third Ward midday this week. The one-time UH track great sprinted after the fleeing vehicle and leapt on it before inertia thwarted her effort to stop the crooks.
Thumbs down: Sorry, Greg, but we're blaming the Astros collapse on you. Gov. Greg Abbott tweeted a congratulatory message to the Astros on their victory Monday. The problem is somebody hit "send" before the deal was sealed, the ultimate jinx. Kansas City scored five runs minutes later, and the Astros' players are at the beach today. What about sticking to policy instead of sports, sir?
Thumbs down: As long as we're offering elected officials advice today, can't they do something about parking lot operators charging $50 for spots on playoff game days? It's called price gouging.
Thumbs up: If there's any doubt that confusion reigns with the Texans, don't just focus on the offense, defense and special teams. Team owner Bob McNair this week wrote a $10,000 check to opponents of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance. Meanwhile, team President Jamey Rootes, who soon becomes chair of the Greater Houston Partnership, has pointed out the perils of not passing the ordinance, which GHP supports. Opponents of HERO are leading a divisive, politically motivated attack that is the last-gasp of homophobia in town. McNair should stop payment on that check.
And finally today, we toast scrappy craft brewers like Houston-based Saint Arnold, Karbach and Buffalo Bayou Brewing. Not only do they make tasty suds, but they and their peers have the big boys, InBev and SABMiller, looking for savings from consolidation. One place the giants won't cut costs: lobbying expenses.

Talk about diversity
Regarding "Clinton, Sanders clash in debate" (Page A1, Wednesday), for a party that touts diversity, what was on stage was old, rich, white people.
Contrast that with the GOP: both old and young, an African-American, two Hispanics, a woman and an Indian-American.
Darrell Lockridge, Houston
Term limits
Regarding "Prop. 2. Voting "yes" will change City Council term limits" (Page B7, Tuesday), with the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance dominating the conversation around the Houston city elections, another very important vote has flown a bit under the radar.
Also on the ballot is the vote to change city council members' term limits from three, two-year terms to two, four-year terms. This important proposition could change the way Houston politics will look for the foreseeable future.
The term limits will affect how the city is run, how effective candidates will be at their job and how candidates campaign for their office.
With the way that the term limits are set up right now, candidates have to start campaigning almost as soon as they're elected. If voters approve Proposition 2, that will change for the better.
Erik Dolliver, campaign organizer Texas Public Interest Research Group, Austin Seeking solutions
Regarding "Aiming for sanity" ( Page B11, Oct. 12), thank you for an excellent editorial. I vote in every election, and I am and will be supporting groups that are working toward common-sense regulations to reduce gun deaths.
Julie Grothues, Houston

Headline Text: Proposition 2 could keep officials around - Term limits would be increased now if measure passes
Article Text:
Think hard about your choices for mayor, controller and City Council this fall: If the winners mess up, you might have to wait twice as long to kick them out.
Lost in the chaos of Houston's first open mayoral race in six years and the brawl over the city's nondiscrimination ordinance is what will appear on the ballot as City of Houston Proposition 2: changing Houston's 24-year-old system of term limits to let officials serve up to two four-year terms, rather than the current maximum of three two-year terms.
The change would take effect immediately, allowing some incumbents to serve longer than the six years they originally signed up for. Mayor Annise Parker had proposed delaying the effective date of the change to affect no incumbents; council overrode that proposal.
"You have the right to vote people out, and if you're not voting them out they must not be doing that bad of a job," said Councilman Jerry Davis, who supports the ballot item. "It allows us to get in here and get some work done. One year in, one year back out there talking to people trying to get re-elected. It's not enough time. When you get the hang of it, then it's time to go."
Total of 10 years
The term limits shift would let current freshman council members serve two more four-year terms, for a total of 10 years. Those serving their second terms, such as Davis, would be permitted one 4-year term, for a total of eight years. Those finishing their third terms, including Parker, are not permitted to run again.
Since voters first limited local leaders' stay in each office to three two-year terms in 1991, changes to term limits have been discussed five times, with the sixth attempt this year finally placing an item before voters.
Supporters of the measure say council members barely learn the ways to make change in government before they are flushed out, making an already strong-mayor form of government even stronger, allowing the bureaucrats in her employ to "wait out" council members whose proposals they dislike and empowering experienced lobbyists.
Those skeptical of the change say shorter terms allow a regular infusion of new thinking into city government by lessening the bulwark of incumbency and ensuring independence from entrenched interests. This is a particular risk, they say, since a court this year killed city rules that prevented officials from raising money year-round.
Though pundits originally had predicted the item was doomed without organized support - of which there has been none - a recent poll conducted by Rice University political scientist Bob Stein showed 44 percent of likely voters support the change, 40 percent oppose it and 15 percent are unsure.
Support falls
When told the measure would allow some incumbents to stay in office longer, however, voter support fell to 31 percent and opposition rose to 48 percent
"When you're told this is essentially a benefit for the people who are in office, you reverse your position," Stein said. "The people who are voting still don't know it's being implemented in 2016." Supporters included progressives who typically oppose term limits, Stein said, and black voters who like their current representatives. About 60 percent of those who said the city is doing an "excellent" or "good" job support the change, he said, a figure that fell sharply among those who grade the city's performance as "fair" or "poor." Conservatives, who generally distrust government, he said, also were opposed.
Councilman C.O. Bradford, who opposed placing the item on the ballot, said the city charter needs far more sweeping revisions to ensure, among other things, that council members have more input and that the budget process is more effective. Only touching term limits, he said, won't help.
"The local governance process is broken and until you fix the process, why leave people at City Hall for a longer term without accountability? It's not a good policy," Bradford said. "It exacerbates the difficulty that exists at City Hall today."
Parker said longer terms are a "good government" reform she has long supported, but the mayor said it was a "terrible mistake" to make them take effect immediately. Parker said she would still be willing to campaign for the current ballot item, but is instead focusing her attention - as are many voters - on protecting the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, city Proposition 1, from repeal.
Backing from council
Davis and Councilman Larry Green say they both are campaigning for the term limits change in their districts.
Both also pushed back on the idea that wording of the proposition was an example of self-serving incumbents wanting to stay in office longer.
"I'm very happy to serve my six years and be done, but I do think it is in the best interest of the city to have two 4-year terms because I just think you get better government," Green said. "Whenever it's implemented, somebody is going to benefit, whether now or down the road. I think you should just focus on the actual concept as opposed to who's benefitting and who's not.
"I just think we spend more time serving our constituents," Green said, "as opposed to campaigning and fundraising."

Headline Text: HERO debate goes off-topic - Claims about restroom access dominate talk
Article Text:
McNair donates to HERO opponents: Page B1
Although Houston's 36-page equal rights ordinance makes no mention of public restrooms, access to restrooms has become the focus of a raging public debate with the law set to go before voters on Election Day.
Opponents of the ordinance, largely conservative Christians, have flooded radio and TV with ads saying the law gives men dressed in women's clothing, including sexual predators, the ability to enter a women's restroom. On Tuesday, the group released a TV spot that closes with a man bursting into a stall occupied by a young girl.
Supporters of the law, however, said the ordinance would in no way protect predators, pointing to a longstanding city law that bars someone from entering a restroom of the opposite sex with the intent to "cause a disturbance." Legal experts agree the equal rights ordinance does not offer any protections to those who commit crimes, such as the oft-cited example of sexual assault, in a bathroom or any other place.
University of Houston law professor Peter Linzer said the law does not mean someone can enter a bathroom with the intent to commit a crime, regardless of gender.
"It's a phony issue," Linzer said. "If you commit a crime in a bathroom, you're going to be prosecuted, and HERO is not a defense."
Under the Houston equal rights ordinance, or HERO, discrimination based on sexual orientation, gender identity, sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information, as well as family, marital or military status, is banned. Opponents criticize the protections the law extends to gay and transgender residents.
Businesses that serve the public, private employers, housing, city employment and city contracting are subject to the ordinance and could face fines of up to $5,000 for violations. Religious organizations are exempt.
'Misleading' argument
City Council passed the ordinance last year. During the few months it was in effect - the Parker administration suspended enforcement while opponents sued the city for more than a year - 11 discrimination complaints were filed. Five of the cases alleged racial discrimination, another five LGBT discrimination and one claimed gender discrimination. A settlement was reached in one of the five LGBT cases, and the gender case was closed due to insufficient evidence. The rest are pending investigation while the law is on hold awaiting November's election.
"It's a little misleading to focus on bathrooms," said Matthew Festa, a law professor at the South Texas College of Law. "What the law really does is broaden the protected classes, but all you hear about is the bathrooms."
The ordinance does not specifically entertain bathroom access; draft language that addressed the restroom issue head-on was thrown out amid political pushback last spring.
The abandoned provision said it was illegal to "deny any person entry to any restroom, shower room, or similar facility if that facility is consistent with and appropriate to that person's expression of gender identity." It went on, however, to offer business owners a defense if they denied someone access to such a facility with the "good faith belief that the gender or gender identity of the person discriminated against was not consistent with the gender designation of the facility."
But the final version of the law offers no mention of restrooms, referring more broadly to public accommodations.
Former city attorney David Feldman, who drafted the rights law, said business owners still retain the right to deny a person they believe to be a man access to a women's restroom, or vice versa. Where the equal rights ordinance applies is in how the business owner or manager phrases such an objection, Feldman said.
If the owners were to tell a patron they genuinely believed the person to be a man attempting to enter a women's restroom, Feldman said it would be difficult to prove discrimination. But a slur or attack on someone's gender identity, for instance, would put the business owner in violation of the law.
"The problem as I see it is that the debate itself is an irrational one," Feldman said. "It's based on a false premise, the false premise is that any guy has a right to go into a ladies' restroom."
Concern for employers
Joe Gagnon, a labor attorney with Fisher & Phillips LLP, said he views the bathroom protections as an "open issue." Gagnon said that under the current ordinance, business owners, managers and employers are best to err on the side of caution. It's not clear under what circumstance an employer or business owner could legally deny someone access to a restroom, Gagnon said.
"It's complicated," Gagnon said. "And the concern I have for employers is that they have little clarity on what constitutes discrimination."
Recently, opponents drafted a memo of examples they say prove men have used access to women's restrooms for criminal purposes. The examples largely include men donning women's clothing to videotape women in rest-rooms, an illegal act. In the only instance of sexual assault documented in the memo, a man falsely claiming to be transgender gained access to two women's shelters in Toronto in 2013 where he sexually assaulted two women. The man was convicted and given a life sentence, according to the Toronto Sun.
Campaign spokesman Jared Woodfill said he is concerned the same could happen in Houston.
"Under the law, as a female in a restroom, a male who believes he is a female can walk in there and shower with you," Woodfill said. "If it's a locker room, they can change clothes with you while they are there. They can make you uncomfortable and violate your sense of privacy."
Mayor Annise Parker pushed back this week on the idea that the ordinance in any way presents a public safety threat. The law is intended to protect someone's consistent gender identity, not someone seeking to illegally gain access to a restroom.
"Two-hundred cities, 17 states have the same ordinance that we do or very similar wording that we do," Parker said. "This just doesn't happen. It is illegal for a sexual predator to go into a women's restroom and attack anyone, and the idea that somehow the city of Houston is giving them free license is so offensive."
Supporters of the ordinance have also questioned the authority of opponents on the issue of sexual conduct, given allegations against one of the group's leaders.
Controversial opponent
The Rev. Kendall Baker, a vocal member of Campaign for Houston and candidate for City Council District F, was indefinitely suspended from his position as a 311 supervisor with the city after an investigator substantiated sexual harassment claims lodged against him. The Office of Inspector General report issued in 2013 found that Baker had "solicited sexual acts, made crude comments about female anatomy and engaged in inappropriate physical contact by hugging subordinate female employees."
Baker said the findings of the OIG report were inaccurate and retaliatory. "That was an act of discrimination," Baker said. "It was a wrongful termination."
During an exchange at City Council with Baker last year where he questioned whether the Office of Inspector General was up to the task of investigating complaints made under the equal rights ordinance, Parker made reference to Baker's own history with the OIG.
"You are proof we do a good job in the OIG, sir," she said.
Baker is featured heavily in the opponents' campaign ads, including a radio spot where he calls the ordinance "shameful."
"We have a moral obligation to protect women from the potential danger of perverted men," Baker says in the ad.
A recent KHOU/KUHF poll showed that, among supporters of the law, only 15 percent said they could not support the ordinance given the knowledge than a man who identifies and dresses as a woman could use a women's restroom.

Headline Text: McNair gives to HERO critics - Texans owner calls law divisive, urges rewrite
Article Text:
Houston Texans owner Bob McNair has donated $10,000 to opponents of the city's embattled equal rights ordinance, entering the political fray over the law headed to voters this fall.
McNair, a billionaire and frequent GOP donor, mailed the $10,000 check to opponents earlier this week.
Though the donation is relatively small compared to heftier checks cut by some state and local Republican leaders - the group spent half a million in the first seven weeks - opponents heralded McNair's contribution as a significant statement.
"The HERO supporters have tried to scare people into believing that we would lose the Super Bowl," said Campaign for Houston spokesman Jared Woodfill. "Obviously, if there were any truth behind that, Bob McNair wouldn't be donating to the folks that are opposed to the ordinance."
Critics of the law, largely Christian conservatives, object to the nondiscrimination protections it extends to gay and transgender residents and allege it would allow men into women's restrooms. The ordinance also bans discrimination based on sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information, as well as family, marital or military status.
The ordinance applies to businesses that serve the public, private employers, housing, city employment and city contracting. Religious institutions are exempt. Violators can be fined up to $5,000.
Supporters of the ordinance, including Mayor Annise Parker, have warned that repealing the law could damage the city's economy and could jeopardize high-profile events such as Houston's 2017 Super Bowl.
McNair, in a statement released Thursday, noted Houston's diversity and said he believes it is a city that "works to ensure that everyone is treated respectfully and fairly," but raised objections to the ordinance.
"I strongly believe that everyone who lives or works in or visits Houston should be treated with the utmost dignity and respect," McNair said. "Because of the way the HERO ordinance is written, it has begun to separate rather than unite our community. This problem can be solved by defeating the current bill in November, thoughtfully rewriting it and then resubmitting it to the voters."
City Council member Ellen Cohen, a prominent supporter of the law, said that given McNair's history of giving to conservative causes and candidates, this donation came as "no surprise."
"He's one man who happens to own a sports team but the organizations involved in attracting business and conventions support the ordinance," Cohen said. "The Houston convention center and visitors bureau, GHP, the Houston sports authority - just to name a few - have come out in favor of the equal rights ordinance."
Richard Carlbom, campaign manager for supporters of the law, released a statement saying the "vast majority of Houston business interests taking a position on Proposition 1 support it."
"They know discrimination is bad for business and bad for the city's image," Carlbom said. "Over time, companies, including sporting franchises, will stop wanting to come here."
Supporters of the law often point to Indiana, where a so-called "religious freedom law" drew national scrutiny last spring. Opponents of the law there said it was discriminatory, and companies and conventions canceled planned events in the state. The NCAA, headquartered in Indianapolis, publicly opposed the original versions of the law as the city was preparing to host the Final Four. Amid growing political pressure, Indiana's Legislature eventually passed an amended version of the bill intended to ease concerns about discrimination against gays and lesbians.
In a recent KHOU/KUHF poll of likely voters, the economic case that supporters have posited, saying businesses and major events would not come to a city without the law's protections against discrimination, proved persuasive for some.
Among opponents of the law, 24 percent said they would change their mind if told that the National Football League would not come to Houston for the 2017 Super Bowl and the National Collegiate Athletic Association would take the Final Four elsewhere if the law was repealed.
Another 64 percent said they would not change their opposition, and 11 percent were unsure.

Headline Text: HERO debate goes off-topic - Claims about restroom access dominate talk
Article Text:
McNair donates to HERO opponents: Page B1
Although Houston's 36-page equal rights ordinance makes no mention of public restrooms, access to restrooms has become the focus of a raging public debate with the law set to go before voters on Election Day.
Opponents of the ordinance, largely conservative Christians, have flooded radio and TV with ads saying the law gives men dressed in women's clothing, including sexual predators, the ability to enter a women's restroom. On Tuesday, the group released a TV spot that closes with a man bursting into a stall occupied by a young girl.

Controversial opponent

Kendall Baker, a vocal member of Campaign for Houston and candidate for City Council District F, was indefinitely suspended from his position as a 311 supervisor with the city after an investigator substantiated sexual harassment claims lodged against him. Headline Text: Poll: Equal rights law supporters edge past foes - Ordinance's opponents say issue turns on small number of votes, but those in favor claim growing momentum
Article Text:
With both campaigns ramping up spending before Election Day, supporters of Houston's contentious equal rights ordinance are leading opponents by 6 percentage points, a new poll shows.
Overall, 43 percent of respondents to the KHOU/KUHF poll released Sunday supported the ordinance, 37 percent opposed it, and 18 percent were unsure of their stance. The poll offers some empirical heft to the prediction in many political circles that the fate of the ordinance will turn on a relatively small number of votes.
Broken out by race, black residents were the most evenly divided on the issue, with 40 percent in support, 39 percent opposed and 20 percent undecided.
Rice University political scientist Bob Stein, who helped run the poll, said black voters may be the most suggestible on the issue leading up to Election Day.
"The largest proportion of undecided voters are African-American," Stein said. "Otherwise, generally, we tended to see that people had staked out their positions on this issue and felt very strongly one way or the other."
Proponents of the law heralded the poll as a sign the ordinance is picking up broad support. The campaign Houston Unites reported about $1.3 million in donations during the most recent fundraising period, more than doubling critics' haul.
"Yet another poll shows the momentum is on the side of the treating everyone fairly and equally under the law," campaign manager Richard Carlbom said in a written statement.
Opponents, however, viewed the poll as evidence that the race will be close and that there's opportunity to sway the bloc of undecided voters.
"We're going to be very aggressive and expose this ordinance for what it really is," said Jared Woodfill, the group's campaign spokesman. "What this race will really prove is who has the better turnout model."
Political scientists have said they expect the embattled law's presence on the ballot to drive up the usually low voter turnout in November, potentially a factor in the open mayor's race.
In the last open-seat mayor's race, about 19 percent of registered voters cast a ballot. But precisely how much the law will skew turnout is hard to predict, Stein said.
The ordinance has been contentious since City Council passed it in May 2014.
The law offers legal remedies against local discrimination to 15 protected classes: sexual orientation, gender identity, sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, religion, disability, pregnancy and genetic information, as well as family, marital or military status.
Opponents criticize the protections the law extends to gay and transgender residents, alleging it would allow men dressed in women's clothing, including sexual predators, to enter women's restrooms. Businesses that serve the public, private employers, housing, city employment and city contracting are subject to the ordinance and could face fines of up to $5,000 for violations. Religious organizations are exempt.
In the poll, among those who said they support the ordinance, 72 percent said they would not change their support if they knew a man who identifies and dresses as a woman could use a woman's restroom under the law.
Another 15 percent said they could not support the ordinance given that knowledge and 12 percent said they were unsure.
Even more effective in moving voters, however, was the economic case that supporters have posited, saying businesses and major events would not come to a city without the law's legal protections against discrimination.
Among opponents of the law, 24 percent said they would change their mind if told that the National Football League would not come to Houston for the 2017 Super Bowl and the National Collegiate Athletic Association would take the Final Four elsewhere if the law was repealed.
Another 64 percent said they would not change their opposition and 11 percent were unsure.
"The rhetoric on the economic argument is quite salient," Stein said.
"Particularly among African-American women, that issue really moves voters."
About 59 percent of those surveyed identified as white, 22 as black, 12 as Hispanic and 4 as Asian. Democrats made up about 42 percent, Republicans 23 percent and independents 23 percent. Twelve percent declined to answer.
The margin of error in the weighted poll was plus or minus 4.1 percentage points and included 567 registered Houston voters who said they were either certain or very likely to vote in November.

Headline Text: Turner for mayor - Standing out in a crowded field, the veteran legislator has the skills to lead City Hall.
Article Text:
Houston is unique.
No, that's not our half-baked proposal for the city's next tourism campaign. It is a statement of fact about City Hall. Among the 10 largest cities in Texas, Houston is the only one that has a mayor-council form of government. Other cities rely on an appointed manager to designate department heads, write the budget and run the day-to-day operations of the city. Houston vests all that power in the mayor. So when you hear mayoral candidates say that they're running to be Houston's CEO, that's not campaign puffery.
It is a high-risk, high-reward gambit to place this much power in a single position. The role of mayor demands a candidate who understands the dynamics of municipal policy, can navigate the political jetties of the most diverse city in the nation and also has the managerial skills to run a 10,000-person operation and $5 billion annual budget. Those talents don't always overlap. None of the seven major candidates running for mayor can claim a complete resume.
Perhaps there will be some grand moment of revelation before early voting begins, but so far each candidate seems to share the same muted vision of Houston's future. The political debate begins and ends with potholes, pensions and public safety. Those are important issues, but they can't even begin to encapsulate the historic diversity and potential of a city like Houston. Voters deserve to hear competing symphonies and they're getting only focus-tested jingles.
Because there is no perfect candidate on the ballot, voters should look for someone who has the talents best suited to fixing the problems that currently threaten Houston's long-term success: Sylvester Turner.
For the past six years, Houston has been well led by Annise Parker's competent hand. But being right on the issues only gets you part way there. Politics isn't just about policy - it is about people. Turner, more than any other candidate, grasps this reality.
How can you defend a long-term Rebuild Houston plan if Houstonians still are hitting potholes? What's the point of a pension solution if you can't get it passed in Austin? How can people feel safe when police don't respond to routine property crimes?
As Turner told the editorial board, "people want to see improvements now."
The technically correct answer of a well-informed policy wonk is little solace if you're dealing with a busted tire or burgled car. Houstonians need to know that their city is working for them today.
Turner, 61, was born and raised in Acres Homes in northwest Houston, the very community that he's represented in Austin for more than a quarter century. During his time in the Legislature he's proven himself a capable member of the loyal liberal opposition who can deftly wield the political process to his own benefit - and to that of his constituents, he'll remind you. But Turner is more of a team-builder than a partisan warrior, with an oft-praised ability to get people on board and remind his colleagues of their moral duty in government.
Now on his third run at the mayor's office, Turner speaks with the insight of a veteran politician. Sometimes this means an overreliance on agreeable platitudes, but it also leads him to balance long-term goals with political immediacy.
From police to potholes and economic prosperity, he has released impressively thorough issue papers that keep an eye on the horizon without losing sight of the problems in front of us. Turner has been a key supporter of the Houston equal rights ordinance and backs the Rebuild Houston program as a dedicated funding source for streets and drainage.
On pensions, Turner goes beyond the other candidates by calling for comprehensive reform of the city's finances. Every time Parker hit firefighters on pensions, they seemed to push back just as hard. At this point, it is difficult to see how Steve Costello or Bill King would be more successful. Instead, Turner wants to bring everyone to the table so that folks don't feel like they're being turned into a target.
He attempted that strategy during the last legislative session by backing a deal that would lower the city's payments in the short-term but raise the long-term liability. When he met with the editorial board, Turner said the failed bill was supposed to serve as a stop-gap to help bridge the city's continuing budget crisis while getting both sides talking. We opposed the plan then and we're still skeptical now. However, as someone with support from the city's three key public unions, Turner is well prepared to bring consensus to a pension solution that closes annual funding gaps and pays down the city's liabilities.
We can only guess what political machinations led the city's three key public unions to endorse Turner before meeting with any other candidate. And time has obscured the scandals that bogged down Turner during his last two mayoral campaigns. Despite all the baggage that comes with a long-time legislator, Turner still stands as the candidate best suited for City Hall.
Former Harris County Sheriff Adrian Garcia entered the race with high hopes. He had served on City Council, had the executive experience of the sheriff's department and routinely demonstrated a sharp policy focus with his mental health advocacy. However, Garcia stumbled on the campaign trail, routinely answering deep questions with shallow responses. Reports of deaths, violence and ignored whistleblowers at the county jail also undermine his record as chief law enforcement officer.
Councilman Steve Costello similarly provides a balance of political service, executive experience and policy chops. His engineer's mentality can be a welcome presence around the horseshoe, but his technocratic style, so much like Mayor Parker, will mean more of the same if he's elected mayor. Houston needs a new operating style at City Hall and Costello can't promise that.
Of all the other candidates, Bill King provides the sharpest critique and greatest insight into the way our city is run. He's traveled across the city, and written dozens of Chronicle columns, arguing about how Houston's problems stem from a failure of management. His advocacy for better organization within City Hall, and focus on measurable results, is reminiscent of former mayor Bill White's first campaign. However, as mayor he would be the antithesis of Turner when it comes to uniting people around a cause. It isn't enough to be right - you also have to get the votes. Nevertheless, any future mayor would be wise to give King a seat at the table.
As Houston continues to grow, we need a leader who can connect our diverse city and build bridges that link wise policy with smart implementation. This leader needs to be able to see the big picture and understand how each gear of our churning metropolis connects to the greater whole. From his perch in Austin, Turner has spent decades watching the political process turn at City Hall. We believe that this experience leaves him well prepared to keep it running smoothly.

Headline Text: Briefs ; Berkman under fire for TV ad
Article Text:
Former Houston Astros star Lance Berkman's public opposition to the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance is drawing fire from the city's mayor.
In one of a series of Twitter messages, Mayor Annise Parker, who is openly gay, called her fellow Rice University alumnus a ‚Äúhypocrite‚Äù over a television commercial Berkman recorded for the anti-HERO Campaign for Houston PAC.
The ordinance, which awaits voter approval Nov. 3, bans discrimination on the basis of sex, race, color, ethnicity, sexual orientation and gender identity. In the spot, Berkman attacks what he calls the ‚Äúbathroom ordinance‚Äù that he says ‚Äúwould allow troubled men to enter women's public restrooms, showers and locker rooms.‚Äù Berkman, who notes he has a wife and four daughters, says the ordinance would ‚Äúput them in harm's way‚Äù and is ‚Äújust wrong.‚Äù
Japanese pitcher banned for betting: The Yomiuri Giants' Satoshi Fukuda has been suspended for betting on games, including those involving his own team. He bet on 10 Nippon Professional Baseball games and 10 major league games in an attempt to win back money he lost gambling on high school baseball games in August and is said to have lost more than $8,000. There is no indication he fixed any of the games.
Soccer
U.S. wins another Olympic qualifier
Substitute Jerome Kiesewetter sparked the offense with a goal and an assist in the second half, and the United States beat Panama 4-0 in CONCACAF Olympic qualifying on a rainy night in Commerce City, Colorado.
Already through to the semifinal round, the Americans didn't have much to play for and rested several of their starters. Scoreless at halftime, the U.S. caught a break early in the second half when Panama defender Fidel Escobar knocked in a crossing shot. Kiesewetter then scored three minutes later and Jordan Morris right after that.
Luis Gil wrapped up the scoring by converting a penalty kick, helping the Americans advance out of Group A with a 3-0 record. Canada was second.
Messi's dad in hot water: Barcelona prosecutors are calling for the arrest of Lionel Messi's father in a tax fraud case. Messi has been cleared of wrongdoing.
Tennis
Djokovic unbeaten at China Open
Novak Djokovic improved his perfect record at the China Open to 25-0 by beating Simone Bolelli of Italy 6-1, 6-1 in the first round. Rafael Nadal also advanced to the second round, beating wild-card entry Wu Di 6-4, 6-4. On the women's side, U.S. Open champion Flavia Pennetta rallied to advance to the third round with a 3-6, 6-0, 6-4 win over Teliana Pereira.

TV
ESPN limits plugs for DraftKings
LAS VEGAS ‚Äî ESPN is cutting sponsored DraftKings elements from within its shows but not commercials from the daily fantasy sports site. That‚Äôs according to ESPN Outside the Lines host Bob Ley, who revealed the shift during his show Tuesday.
The change comes as daily fantasy sports behemoths DraftKings and FanDuel respond to reports a DraftKings employee may have accessed valuable company data before winning second place in a FanDuel contest, an incident likened to possible insider trading. The companies say there‚Äôs no evidence anyone misused internal data.
ESPN says in a statement Tuesday‚Äôs change affected DraftKings billboards appearing during news shows, the clips saying a segment was ‚Äúbrought to you by‚Äù the company, calling the removal a standard procedure ‚Äúto avoid any suggestion of influence on our coverage.‚Äù
BASEBALL
Mayor: Berkman‚Äôs stand hypocritical
HOUSTON ‚Äî Former Houston Astros and St. Louis Cardinals star Lance Berkman‚Äôs public opposition to the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance is drawing fire from the city‚Äôs mayor.
In one of a series of Twitter messages, Mayor Annise Parker, who is openly gay, called her fellow Rice University alumnus a ‚Äúhypocrite‚Äù over a television commercial Berkman recorded for the anti-HERO Campaign for Houston PAC.
The ordinance, which will be up for voter approval Nov. 3, bans discrimination on the basis of sex, race, color, ethnicity, sexual orientation and gender identity. In the spot, Berkman attacks what he calls the ‚Äúbathroom ordinance‚Äù that he says ‚Äúwould allow troubled men to enter women‚Äôs public restrooms, showers and locker rooms.‚Äù Berkman, who notes he has a wife and four daughters, says the ordinance would ‚Äúput them in harm‚Äôs way.‚Äù
The Houston Chronicle reported the mayor termed Berkman a hypocrite for not criticizing equal rights ordinances in other major U.S. cities where he‚Äôs played ball.
HOCKEY
Blackhawks place Rozsival on I.R.
CHICAGO ‚Äî The Chicago Blackhawks have placed defenseman Michal Rozsival on long-term injured reserve.
The Blackhawks also recalled defenseman Ville Pokka from Rockford of the American Hockey League and assigned defenseman Viktor Svedberg to the IceHogs.
Rozsival broke his left ankle in Game 4 of Chicago‚Äôs second-round sweep against Minnesota in the playoffs. He re-signed with the Stanley Cup champions last month. The Blackhawks host the New York Rangers in their season opener tonight.

Headline Text: Houston transgender bathroom bill debate centers on differing definitions of 'men'
Article Text:
HOUSTON ‚Äî The noisy debate over this city's Proposition 1 has centered on whether it would allow men to use women's public restrooms, which boils down to how you define "men" and "women."
In a battle that has ranged from bathroom etiquette to gender rights to constitutional debates over religious freedom, a key skirmish broke out after former Houston Astros baseball all-star Lance Berkman appeared in an ad saying that the Nov. 3 ballot measure would "allow troubled men who claim to be women to enter women's bathrooms, showers and locker rooms," and the Yes on 1 campaign fired back.
"Prop. 1 will NOT allow men to enter women's restrooms," says a post on the website Houston Unites, the group supporting Proposition 1.
By "men," however, the campaign is excluding biological men who identify as women. Proposition 1 would ban discrimination in public accommodations such as restrooms based on 15 characteristics, including gender identity.
In other words, anyone who tries to stop a biological man who identifies as a woman from using a women's room would be in violation and could face fines of up to $5,000, if the measure succeeds.
"Obviously, when somebody identifies as transgender, it's a transitioning process that we don't really know where people are at in that," said Richard Carlbom, campaign manager for Houston Unites. "Ultimately, people who live and work in society as women should be using the women's restroom, and people who live and work in society as men should use the men's restroom."
Proposition 1 allows voters to decide the fate of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, the hotly contested law pushed by Houston Mayor Annise Parker, a Democrat, and passed by the Houston City Council last year. The law was moved to the Nov. 3 ballot after a signature-gathering campaign that went to the Texas Supreme Court.
Before the ordinance, Houston relied on Texas and federal law, which do not include gender identity. Framing the debate
By refusing to exclude access to public restrooms based on gender identity, as some other Texas jurisdictions have done, the mayor and City Council triggered a public outcry against the ordinance led by local pastors and backed by social conservatives. The hotly contested ballot measure also has overshadowed a lively mayor's race and other citywide elections with a media blitz as both sides battle to define the debate.
The Houston Unites campaign has fought to move the discussion away from restrooms and into the realm of discrimination prevention, noting that Proposition 1 also protects against discrimination based on traits such as race, ethnicity, gender and sexual orientation.
The campaign's first television ad featured two local clergy in support of the measure. "As Christians, we believe in treating others as we want to be treated," one of them said.
Houston Unites has also touted the support of business groups such as the Greater Houston Partnership and Visit Houston. A full- page ad published last weekend in the Houston Chronicle signed by 36 businesses argued that Proposition 1 is needed to preserve "Houston's reputation as a friendly, welcoming place." But the Campaign for Houston, which opposes Proposition 1, has countered with hard-hitting videos and posts charging that the measure will make women and girls vulnerable to attacks in public restrooms by men.
"A man who goes into women's bathrooms, showers and restrooms is not a hero, he is a pervert," says one online ad by the Campaign for Houston, whose slogan is "No men in women's bathrooms."
Campaign for Houston spokesman Jared Woodfill noted that the law doesn't say that men who identify as women have to dress like women, making it nearly impossible for business owners to figure out whether biological men entering women's rooms are transgender or not.
"The language for gender identity under the ordinance doesn't say you have to dress like a female. You only have to identify as a female," Mr. Woodfill said.
Supporters of Proposition 1 insist that such arguments amount to scare tactics. They point out that it will remain illegal to enter a public restroom to "harm or harass" others.
The Yes on Prop 1 campaign also has the clear financial advantage, raising $1.2 million since Aug. 12, more than twice as much as the Campaign for Houston, according to campaign finance reports submitted Monday.
Another plus for supporters is that the ballot language never mentions public restrooms, but rather asks voters whether they are in favor of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, "which prohibits discrimination in city employment and city services, city contracts, public accommodations, private employment, and housing" based on the 15 characteristics.
No recent polling on the issue has been released, but Mr. Carlbom said, "When people look at the question as it is on the ballot and are asked the question, 'Do they support an equal rights ordinance?' we do very, very well."
As long as voters understand the connection between Proposition 1 and the public restroom issue, however, Mr. Woodfill is confident the nays will prevail.
"Once folks are educated about what this ordinance means to them in terms of public safety and males being able to enter female restrooms, they overwhelmingly reject it," Mr. Woodfill said.

Headline Text: Equal rights law advocates raise $1.26 million - Campaign finance reports show supporters of HERO more than doubled donations collected by foes in ballot measure battle
Article Text:
See an interactive on campaign funding as well as videos and Q&As with the candidates at HoustonChronicle.com/Election2015
Supporters of Houston's contentious equal rights ordinance raked in $1.26 million during seven weeks of official fundraising, more than doubling opponents' efforts and fueling a fierce and frenzied media campaign to court voters before the law hits the November ballot.
In campaign finance reports filed Monday that reflect late summer totals, both sides spent more than $550,000, largely on dueling TV and radio ads. But the more than $521,000 that supporters of the law still had left in campaign coffers as of Sept. 25 dwarfed the $58,000 that opponents reported in cash-on-hand.
That the fight over the city's embattled equal rights ordinance is drawing significant money comes as little surprise. Following more than a year of litigation, City Council opted in August to send the law to the ballot after a Texas Supreme Court ruling ordered the city to either repeal the ordinance or put it to voters. Campaigns that had long waited in the wings quickly took centerstage.
Opponents object to the protections the law extends to gay and transgender residents and allege that it allows male sexual predators dressed in drag to enter women's restrooms. Boosters of the law say it provides basic and necessary local protections for residents and warn that a repeal would dramatically harm Houston's image and economy.
The vote is likely to be close, according to Rice University political scientist Bob Stein.
"This is a matter of messaging now," Stein said. "The fundraising puts the supporters of HERO in a competitive if not advantage position."
In the race to succeed Mayor Annise Parker, total fundraising came in relatively low for a contest that has been on track to be the most expensive in recent city history.
The eight mayoral contenders who filed reports Monday raised a total of at least $1.8 million over nearly three months, while in the first half of the year candidates took in more than $7 million.
In all, they spent more than $4 million from July through late September, leaving them with more than $3 million in the bank collectively and less than a month to go before the Nov. 3 election.
Garcia leads list
At this point in the race, candidates' cash on hand is key, local political analyst Nancy Sims said.
"They need to have all their funds in place for their get-out-the-vote efforts," Sims said, noting that four of the candidates have money to deploy.
Despite sustaining recent political attacks from many of his rivals, former Harris County Sheriff Adrian Garcia again led the pack in fundraising, receiving nearly $585,000 in contributions for the period ending Sept. 25.
Having already raised more than $1.5 million in the first half of the year, Garcia closed the reporting period with the most available cash: more than $831,000. He reported spending more than $1 million since midsummer.
State Rep. Sylvester Turner also crossed the $500,000 threshold, reporting $527,000 in contributions and almost $1.3 million spent in nearly three months, leaving him with $507,000.
City Councilman Stephen Costello, whose fundraising rivaled Garcia's in the first half of the year, took in another $267,000.
He has $697,000 in the bank after spending $871,000 during the reporting period.
Houstonians for the Future, an independent committee organized to support Costello, has been running television ads on his behalf.
As for former City Attorney Ben Hall, he again raised and spent little - $58,000 and $111,000, respectively - leaving him with roughly $769,000.
Former Kemah Mayor Bill King and former Congressman Chris Bell, on the other hand, closed the reporting period with less than half a million in the bank.
King raised $284,000 and loaned himself an additional $150,000.
Having spent some $627,000 in late summer, King reported $322,000 in available cash.
Bell posted comparatively low fundraising numbers, raising $127,000 and spending $240,000 during the reporting period.
He heads into the home-stretch of the campaign with just $92,000 remaining.
A special purpose political action committee supporting Bell, Houston Forward, reported having some $10,000 on hand.
'Not intimidated'
Meanwhile, businesswoman Victoria Lane raised $11,000 and loaned herself another $9,000. After spending about $14,000, she closed the period with some $5,000 in the bank.
Businessman Marty McVey raised just $45 and spent $4,000. His finance report did not list cash on hand.
In the battle over the city's equal rights ordinance, Jared Woodfill, spokesman for opponents, said the campaign is unfazed by supporters' significant fundraising totals.
Opponents reported a $100,000 donation from conservative developer Al Hartman, $25,000 from Harris County Commissioner Jack Cagle and $5,000 from Houston state Rep. Gary Elkins, among others. Longtime anti-gay activist Steve Hotze also loaned the campaign $50,000.
"We're absolutely not intimidated at this point," Woodfill said. "I believe the momentum is in our favor and clearly this is an ordinance that the people in Houston don't want."
In a news release, the Houston Unites campaign said it expected to spend $2 million before the November election. The campaign said 80 percent of its nearly 700 donors are Houston residents.
But its efforts were also fueled by big-ticket contributions from national groups and figures.
Close vote expected The Washington, D.C.- based Human Rights Campaign contributed more than $200,000, and New York philanthropist Jon Stryker, a frequent donor to LGBT causes, pitched in $100,000. Colorado's Gill Action and New York-based American Unity Fund, both LGBT advocacy groups, donated a combined $200,000.
Campaign manager Richard Carlbom, in a written statement, said the group had "certainly done well on the money front so far."
"But, there is a great sense of urgency around fundraising this week and next," Carlbom said. "We know from past ballot campaigns that equal rights opponents spend significant dollars in the final weeks. We must remain competitive with them in what will, no doubt, be a close election."

A full- page ad published last weekend in the Houston Chronicle signed by 36 businesses argued that Proposition 1 is needed to preserve "Houston's reputation as a friendly, welcoming place." But the Campaign for Houston, which opposes Proposition 1, has countered with hard-hitting videos and posts charging that the measure will make women and girls vulnerable to attacks in public restrooms by men.
"A man who goes into women's bathrooms, showers and restrooms is not a hero, he is a pervert," says one online ad by the Campaign for Houston, whose slogan is "No men in women's bathrooms."
Campaign for Houston spokesman Jared Woodfill noted that the law doesn't say that men who identify as women have to dress like women, making it nearly impossible for business owners to figure out whether biological men entering women's rooms are transgender or not.
"The language for gender identity under the ordinance doesn't say you have to dress like a female. You only have to identify as a female," Mr. Woodfill said.
Supporters of Proposition 1 insist that such arguments amount to scare tactics. They point out that it will remain illegal to enter a public restroom to "harm or harass" others.
The Yes on Prop 1 campaign also has the clear financial advantage, raising $1.2 million since Aug. 12, more than twice as much as the Campaign for Houston, according to campaign finance reports submitted Monday.
Another plus for supporters is that the ballot language never mentions public restrooms, but rather asks voters whether they are in favor of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, "which prohibits discrimination in city employment and city services, city contracts, public accommodations, private employment, and housing" based on the 15 characteristics.
No recent polling on the issue has been released, but Mr. Carlbom said, "When people look at the question as it is on the ballot and are asked the question, 'Do they support an equal rights ordinance?' we do very, very well."
As long as voters understand the connection between Proposition 1 and the public restroom issue, however, Mr. Woodfill is confident the nays will prevail.
"Once folks are educated about what this ordinance means to them in terms of public safety and males being able to enter female restrooms, they overwhelmingly reject it," Mr. Woodfill said.

Headline Text: Berkman jab at Houston Equal Rights Ordinance draws fire
Article Text:
HOUSTON (AP) ‚Äî Former Houston Astros star Lance Berkman's public opposition to the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance is drawing fire from the city's mayor.
In one of a series of Twitter messages, Mayor Annise Parker, who is openly gay, called her fellow Rice University alumnus a "hypocrite" over a television commercial Berkman recorded for the anti-HERO Campaign for Houston PAC.
The ordinance, which awaits voter approval Nov. 3, bans discrimination on the basis of sex, race, color, ethnicity, sexual orientation and gender identity. In the spot, Berkman attacks what he calls the "bathroom ordinance" that he says "would allow troubled men to enter women's public restrooms, showers and locker rooms." Berkman, who notes he has a wife and four daughters, says the ordinance would "put them in harm's way" and is "just wrong."

Headline Text: Houston transgender bathroom bill debate centers on differing definitions of 'men'
Article Text:
HOUSTON ‚Äî The noisy debate over this city's Proposition 1 has centered on whether it would allow men to use women's public restrooms, which boils down to how you define "men" and "women."
In a battle that has ranged from bathroom etiquette to gender rights to constitutional debates over religious freedom, a key skirmish broke out after former Houston Astros baseball all-star Lance Berkman appeared in an ad saying that the Nov. 3 ballot measure would "allow troubled men who claim to be women to enter women's bathrooms, showers and locker rooms," and the Yes on 1 campaign fired back.
"Prop. 1 will NOT allow men to enter women's restrooms," says a post on the website Houston Unites, the group supporting Proposition 1.
By "men," however, the campaign is excluding biological men who identify as women. Proposition 1 would ban discrimination in public accommodations such as restrooms based on 15 characteristics, including gender identity.
In other words, anyone who tries to stop a biological man who identifies as a woman from using a women's room would be in violation and could face fines of up to $5,000, if the measure succeeds.
"Obviously, when somebody identifies as transgender, it's a transitioning process that we don't really know where people are at in that," said Richard Carlbom, campaign manager for Houston Unites. "Ultimately, people who live and work in society as women should be using the women's restroom, and people who live and work in society as men should use the men's restroom."
Proposition 1 allows voters to decide the fate of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, the hotly contested law pushed by Houston Mayor Annise Parker, a Democrat, and passed by the Houston City Council last year. The law was moved to the Nov. 3 ballot after a signature-gathering campaign that went to the Texas Supreme Court.
Before the ordinance, Houston relied on Texas and federal law, which do not include gender identity. Framing the debate
By refusing to exclude access to public restrooms based on gender identity, as some other Texas jurisdictions have done, the mayor and City Council triggered a public outcry against the ordinance led by local pastors and backed by social conservatives. The hotly contested ballot measure also has overshadowed a lively mayor's race and other citywide elections with a media blitz as both sides battle to define the debate.
The Houston Unites campaign has fought to move the discussion away from restrooms and into the realm of discrimination prevention, noting that Proposition 1 also protects against discrimination based on traits such as race, ethnicity, gender and sexual orientation.
The campaign's first television ad featured two local clergy in support of the measure. "As Christians, we believe in treating others as we want to be treated," one of them said.
Houston Unites has also touted the support of business groups such as the Greater Houston Partnership and Visit Houston. A full- page ad published last weekend in the Houston Chronicle signed by 36 businesses argued that Proposition 1 is needed to preserve "Houston's reputation as a friendly, welcoming place." But the Campaign for Houston, which opposes Proposition 1, has countered with hard-hitting videos and posts charging that the measure will make women and girls vulnerable to attacks in public restrooms by men.
"A man who goes into women's bathrooms, showers and restrooms is not a hero, he is a pervert," says one online ad by the Campaign for Houston, whose slogan is "No men in women's bathrooms."
Campaign for Houston spokesman Jared Woodfill noted that the law doesn't say that men who identify as women have to dress like women, making it nearly impossible for business owners to figure out whether biological men entering women's rooms are transgender or not.
"The language for gender identity under the ordinance doesn't say you have to dress like a female. You only have to identify as a female," Mr. Woodfill said.
Supporters of Proposition 1 insist that such arguments amount to scare tactics. They point out that it will remain illegal to enter a public restroom to "harm or harass" others.
The Yes on Prop 1 campaign also has the clear financial advantage, raising $1.2 million since Aug. 12, more than twice as much as the Campaign for Houston, according to campaign finance reports submitted Monday.
Another plus for supporters is that the ballot language never mentions public restrooms, but rather asks voters whether they are in favor of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, "which prohibits discrimination in city employment and city services, city contracts, public accommodations, private employment, and housing" based on the 15 characteristics.
No recent polling on the issue has been released, but Mr. Carlbom said, "When people look at the question as it is on the ballot and are asked the question, 'Do they support an equal rights ordinance?' we do very, very well."
As long as voters understand the connection between Proposition 1 and the public restroom issue, however, Mr. Woodfill is confident the nays will prevail.
"Once folks are educated about what this ordinance means to them in terms of public safety and males being able to enter female restrooms, they overwhelmingly reject it," Mr. Woodfill said.

Headline Text: For District J - Mike Laster attracted a serious challenger but has earned his third term at City Hall.
Article Text:
Mike Laster may be the only incumbent council member to face a serious challenger this year who wasn't inspired by the Houston equal rights ordinance. Taking a charge at the two-term representative from District J is Jim Bigham, the current president of the Sharpstown Civic Association - a position once held by Laster. In a meeting with the editorial board, Bigham explained that while he once supported Laster, 54, he now feels that the councilman doesn't adequately represent local needs.
"I just believe that we need a stronger voice for southwest Houston," Bigham said. "There have been a number of issues that the community has reached out to the council member and asked for his support, and we did not get that support."
On his website, Bigham lays out in detail the specifics of where he sees Laster going off course, such as problems with tax increment reinvestment zones and disagreements on the city animal regulations. However, when viewed against the backdrop of citywide concerns, these political punches land softly. The race between the two looks all too much like the insider politics of a neighborhood association dragged onto a district-wide ballot.
There's more to District J than Sharpstown.
The southwest district, bordered by the Westpark Toll Road , Southwest Freeway, Loop 610 West and Beltway 8, might as well serve as Houston's Ellis Island. More than 70 different nationalities are represented across the area and less than one-third of the residents speak English at home. Poverty is pervasive, and prevalent apartment complexes pose plenty of challenges for safety and providing city services - the whole district is about three times as densely populated as the rest of Houston.
However, successful single-family neighborhoods dot the district. Laster calls them "rowboats of prosperity inside a lake of economic challenges."
This district has a deep need for important constituent services, and Laster has dedicated his office to providing them. From working with the Urban Land Institute on redesigning Richmond to helping Gulfton youth collaborate on creating a skatepark, Laster puts his longtime City Hall expertise to good use.
In addition to his time on the Sharpstown Civic Association, Laster has worked as a senior city attorney and as former chair of the Sharpstown Tax Increment Reinvestment Zone. He was a key proponent of the Houston equal rights ordinance - an important tool for his diverse district. On pensions, Laster says that we need a new system for new hires at the Houston Fire Department, but also warns against cuts that could drive needed public safety workers to retire.
Besides Bigham, Laster faces two other challengers: Dung Le, who said he is running as a bridge to connect minority voters, and Manny Berrera, a former City Hall staffer perhaps best known for his bizarre anti-gay tirades in the comment sections of local political blogs.
Laster has earned his third term at City Hall, but we hope to see Bigham run again in the next election.

Headline Text: Letters to the editor for Nov. 30, 2015
Article Text:
Put focus on Obama‚Äôs background
It has come to my attention again just how far the mainstream media leans to the left, even though they should by all rights be on an even keep. I see they wish to hammer Ben Carson over things that were said years ago. But when it comes to the current president, they are silent on things pertaining to his background.
Carson even brought up in a news conference about President Obama‚Äôs hidden school records. This was quickly ignored by the press. One must wonder why.
Even after the short form of live birth certificate was brought out, which the authorities at the time said this was all they had. They were very clear there were no other birth documents on file at the time. Then a couple of years later, they miraculously found a copy of the long form of live birth certificate.
Also, why have no mainstream media ever tried to uncover the reason why so much of his school records have been hidden from public view? His school transcripts are not open to the public. What of his application for college as a foreign student? Then there is the Social Security number issued to Obama from a state he has never lived in his life.
The mainstream media goes after GOP candidates, but will not do likewise to Democrats. If the mainstream media were a ship, they would be in danger of listing so far to port they would sink.
Michial Lawrence, Brazoria ‚ÄòHoly spirit‚Äô is Jehovah‚Äôs power
Mr. (G.L.) Kidwell‚Äôs reference (letters, Nov. 14) to Acts 2 confirms my point. The holy spirit is Jehovah‚Äôs power sent forth to accomplish his will and purposes, as in creation, beginning with his son (Rev. 3:14). He has made it operative on people in many cases, such as to inspire scripture, to enable Judge Sampson to destroy Dagon‚Äôs temple (Judges 16:28), to empower the 120 (Acts 1:15) with immediate ability to speak in the languages of those gathered in Jerusalem for Pentecost celebration.
This was done to establish the transfer of favor from the Jewish nation, and recognize the Christian congregation, with Christ Jesus as head, as God‚Äôs chosen people (1 Peter 2:9-10). Thus the ‚Äúgood news‚Äù would travel back with these ones upon their return to their territories.
Holy spirit is ours for the asking ‚Äî not a person, but power beyond what is normal in our quest to serve our God, follow his son‚Äôs example, and in understanding the scriptures.
Holy spirit is indeed personified in some instances, just as ‚Äúwisdom‚Äù is spoken of as having children (Luke 7:35).
At Revelation 3:10-11, Jesus in his glorified form states he has a God. (The red letter edition is good for clarification that Jesus is speaking).
Jesus honored his father (and God) and obeyed him, because of his love for him (John 14:31). He paid the ultimate price, buying back our original destiny, everlasting life.
We show our love for both in doing what they say (Luke 6:46, John 14:31). Russell Amundsen, Lake Jackson
HERO opponents were not ‚Äòhaters‚Äô
I‚Äôm often thankful for the distance separating myself from Houston and all the craziness there. The Brazosport area may not be Mayberry, and Houston might not quite be Chicago or San Francisco ‚Äî yet, but the differences are still vast. One such time of thanks was during their recent squabble over the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance (HERO).
Fortunately, with the push of a button on the TV remote or click of a mouse, I‚Äôve been able to turn off the madness when the racket gets too much to handle. But never fear, leave it to The Facts Managing Editor Michael Morris to shove it back in my face. First he runs a poll on Facebook asking opinions about the failed ordinance. Then he writes a editorial (column, Nov. 11) telling us how everybody opposed to HERO is a ‚Äúhater.‚Äù
Why should I be surprised? We all know that anyone who speaks negatively about Obama is a racist. Only stands to reason that anyone against HERO is a hater, or as Mayor Parker put it, a transphobe.
My take on all this varies considerably from the likes of Mr. Morris. It‚Äôs not that people in general are racist, transphobes and haters. They‚Äôre just sick and tired of having an endless supply of special interests groups shove their agendas down their throats. You take a step back to make room for one offended group and before you know it, you‚Äôre on your butt getting stomped by the stampede. Maybe, just maybe ‚Äî enough is enough.
