Headline Text: It's a wrap: Editorials for the week of Nov. 22-28
Article Text:
Sunday, Nov. 22
It stands to reason that there would be a formal contract governing the $250 million deal between the state's Major Events Reimbursement Program and the Circuit of the Americas. After all, written contracts are the standard way of doing business between individuals, businesses or governments.
So it came as a surprise when Gov. Greg Abbott's office and Bobby Epstein, chairman of the Circuit of the Americas, in response to our question to see a written contract, told us there was no formal contract. There should be. It would have avoided the confusion that currently is endangering the future of Formula One in Austin.
Monday, Nov. 23
Voters soundly defeated the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance in a Nov. 3 referendum. In a Two Views commentary, Republican political consultant Matt Mackowiak called the ordinance's defeat a victory for public safety. Democratic consultant Glenn Smith, director of Austin's Progress Texas PAC, criticized the opposition's "no men in women's bathrooms" strategy, writing, "their real concern is not bathroom security. They want a world safe only for people like themselves."
Tuesday, Nov. 24
Three out of four Austin police officers live outside the city they were hired to protect. This is a problem. To correct it, city officials are considering offering financial incentives to encourage more Austin police officers to live in the city.
The American-Statesman's editorial board awaits details of any benefits the city might offer its police officers, as well as calculations about the possible costs before taking a position on this latest manifestation of a long-debated issue. But in the past, the board has supported moves to encourage Austin's public safety workers to live inside the city.
Wednesday, Nov. 25
American-Statesman reporters Lilly Rockwell and Christian McDonald recently took a close look at the numbers behind the wage gap for city of Austin employees. The average woman in the city government's workforce, excluding first responders, made 96 cents for every $1 a man earned. In nearly half the city jobs reviewed, women earned more than men.
But digging a little deeper shows there is still some work to do. The city government's workforce is overwhelmingly male, especially in upper management and other higher-paying positions. And while women by and large are paid similarly to men in the same jobs, women are overrepresented in lower-wage positions.
Thursday, Nov. 26
For more than 10 years, Community First! has been on a mission to provide chronically homeless individuals with permanent housing in a caring environment.
We visited the homeless center in eastern Travis County, envisioned and run by Mobile Loaves & Fishes. Amid ongoing construction, residents are slowly moving in. After a decade in the making, the fact that this project is coming to fruition is reason for many to be thankful. Friday, Nov. 27
Angeline Close Scheinbaum, an associate professor of advertising and public relations at the University of Texas, and Julie Irwin, a marketing professor at UT, pondered the future of Black Friday for a Two Views commentary. Close Scheinbaum foresees Black Friday giving way to a Black Weekend as the blending of in-store and online shopping continues. Irwin thinks that stores that cater to shoppers motivated by price, like Best Buy or Wal-Mart, are likely to maintain the Black Friday tradition while higher-end stores such as REI, which closed its stores Friday, slowly retreat from it.
Saturday, Nov. 28
The Texas Department of Public Safety says its troopers treat all motorists equally. As proof it is free of racial profiling, DPS points to more than a decade of annual reports it has published on the race and ethnicity of the drivers state troopers have stopped, warned, ticketed, searched and arrested.
There are flaws in the agency's results, however; its comparison of traffic stops against statewide population percentages of race and ethnicity is misleading. Its reports would be more accurate if DPS tracked what percentage of motorists of a given race are searched, cited or arrested after they are stopped. And that is what legislators should demand of DPS.
Please visit statesman.com/s/opinion to read last week's complete editorials and commentaries.

Where they stand on the issues City finances
Houston is facing a projected $126 million budget deficit next fiscal year, largely driven by rising pension costs, which this year topped $350 million, and a nearing spike in debt payments. Houston has also run into a voter-approved revenue cap, which dictates that the city may not increase annual property tax collections by more than the combined rates of inflation and population growth, or 4.5 percent, whichever is lower.
Turner
1 Calls for comprehensive financial reform, attributing the city's financial strain to pension costs, the revenue cap, a nearing spike in city debt payments and the property taxes set aside for economic development in targeted areas known as tax increment reinvestment zones
1 Acknowledges the city must address its rising pension costs but has not specified his plan 1 Favors lifting the revenue cap to allow more public safety spending or to pay down city debt King
1 Considers pension reform the defining issue of the race
1 Favors switching new hires from defined- benefit to defined-contribution plans. To address the city's $3.2 billion unfunded liability, King would seek legislative approval to offer cash discounts to workers already in the defined-benefit system and issue bonds to cover the remaining gap.
1 Opposes lifting the revenue cap ...
Infrastructure
Funding for Houston's pockmarked roads long came from borrowing. But in 2010, voters approved ReBuild Houston, a pay-as-you- go infrastructure program intended to use a monthly drainage fee paired with three other funding sources to pour billions into fixing the city's roads. The ReBuild model of using data to fix the worst streets first has drawn criticism from residents eager to see their roads repaired. The drainage fee is currently being litigated.
Turner
1 Supports ReBuild Houston and maintains the city needs a dedicated revenue source for infrastructure improvements but says the program could have been better implemented
  King 1 Opposes ReBuild Houston but says he would continue collecting the drainage fee that funds the program and instead use that revenue to finance infrastructure bonds
...
Public safety
A 2014 study found that 21,000 cases with workable leads went uninvestigated the year before, which HPD attributes to a staffing shortage. The police chief has asked for $105 million over five years for a net increase of 590 officers, with a focus on bolstering the agency's investigative unit.
Turner
1 Calls for adding 540 officers by 2020, a plan he says would cost $85 million. Turner would finance the increase by asking voters to modify the revenue cap for public safety spending.
1 Supports the use of body cameras King
1 Says the city needs more police officers but has pushed for a department analysis first to determine whether cuts and/or reassignments are necessary
1 Supports the use of body cameras
...
Economic inequality
Houston recently ranked 15th for income inequality among the 50 largest U.S. cities, according to the Brookings Institution, and census data shows about 22 percent of Houston residents lived below the poverty level in 2014.
Turner
1 Says the mayor's core responsibilities include addressing economic inequality and educational opportunity
1 Proposes a job training program tied to infrastructure work
1 Says recipients of city tax incentives should be required to pay wages commensurate with those of municipal employees
King
1 Says the city's economic inequality is largely a global problem that cannot be solved locally
1 Calls for the city to subsidize the construction of single-family homes to spur home ownership
1 Criticizes the economic development zones known as TIRZs that lock up tax dollars in areas that are already developed but supports their use in blighted neighborhoods
...
Houston Equal Rights Ordinance
Repealed by voters this November, the city's equal rights ordinance would have extended protections to 15 classes, including gay and transgender residents. The law also covered characteristics already federally recognized, such as race, sex and veteran status. Turner
1 Favored HERO
1 Says he respects the will of the voters
King
1 Opposed HERO
1 Says he would organize a meeting with HERO stakeholders to discuss next steps
***
In their own words
Sylvester Turner
1. What three qualities do you think are most important for the Houston mayor to have and why?
1. A track record of getting results - because opinions alone are not enough once you are in the mayor's chair; 2. A demonstrated ability to work with everyone, no matter their politics - because you are the mayor of all the people, not just a few; 3. A vision for Houston - because you cannot lead if you don't know where you are going.
2. Describe a time when you worked with a group to solve a problem. What was your role? How did you settle on your ultimate approach? What was the outcome?
I worked with our Republican leadership in the Texas House of Representatives, my Democratic colleagues and representatives of Texas public employees to make our state's Employee Retirement System actuarially sound. It was costing taxpayers $500 million a year. Over two legislative sessions, we built trust and surrendered hard positions so we could move forward together. House Bill 9 in the last session was authored by the chair of the Appropriations Committee, the chair of the Pension Committee and myself. We succeeded in ensuring the pension fund will become actuarially sound and created a way to pay off the staggering, unfunded liability while keeping our promises to hard-working state employees.
3. Pick a major policy problem or crisis that Mayor Annise Parker has faced during the past two years and explain how you would have approached it differently and how that reflects your approach to the mayor's office. Explain not just how you would have addressed the problem externally, but also how you would have worked with council members and staff internally to get their buy-in.
I have great respect for Mayor Parker. My campaign is looking forward, not backward, so I will decline to comment on her work. I will say that after 26 years in the Legislature, with the majority of my service in leadership roles, I have deep experience in working with legislative bodies across party lines and philosophical divides. It's easy to make assumptions about and question the motives of people you don't know - so as a legislator and a leader, I have worked to get to know my colleagues personally. And my working assumption is that all elected representatives are doing what they believe is in the best interest of their constituents. I look forward to working with the members of City Council as I did with the members of the Texas House.
4. Describe a time when a decision you made was attacked and how you handled it. How did you communicate with stakeholders? What was the resolution?
In the 2005 legislative session, the Children's Health Program-CHIP - was drastically cut, leaving many kids without health care. In 2007, I was determined to see that funds were restored to CHIP. The Republican speaker told me that no Republicans would vote for that. I told him, I would get it done. I crafted House Bill 109 to increase CHIP enrollment and then engaged Republican legislators like John Davis and Susan King to help. The bill passed out of committee 8-1. On the House floor, we agreed that no amendments would be made to the bill, either to increase or decrease funding. For nearly five hours, I and the other supporters fended off amendments from both Democrats and Republicans, sticking to our agreement. I was determined to pass this bill and changing it could have led one side or the other to vote against it. I argued "Let us not sacrifice the good for the perfect." In the end, HB 109 passed with 134 votes, almost equally divided between Democrats and Republicans. The Senate passed the bill, the governor signed it and, as a result, 130,000 more children received access to health care.
5. In August, the first day of school at the Houston Independent School District's new Arabic Immersion Magnet School was met with protests, and demonstrators said the school was anti-American and that immigrants should be assimilated. Had you been mayor at the time, how would you have handled that situation?
Everyone has a right to their own views, but no one has a right to frighten and intimidate children and their parents - at our schools or anywhere else. As mayor, I would work with the school district and our police department to protect our parents and kids without interfering with the rights of citizens to peacefully protest.
Bill King
1. What three qualities do you think are most important for the Houston mayor to have and why?
1. Pragmatic, not ideological; 2. Open to hearing opposing and diverse views on subjects; 3. Not afraid to make decisions.
2. Describe a time when you worked with a group to solve a problem. What was your role? How did you settle on your ultimate approach? What was the outcome?
I chaired the task force that redrafted the hurricane evacuation plans after Hurricane Rita. We had hundreds of meetings with stakeholders and experts to identify what went wrong and what solutions were viable. New plans were eventually drawn up. The evacuation for Hurricane Ike several years later went much smoother. However, our work also led eventually to the discussion about some kind of surge protection system because we also concluded there was no evacuation solution that would result in no loss of life.
3. Pick a major policy problem or crisis that Mayor Annise Parker has faced during the past two years and explain how you would have approached it differently and how that reflects your approach to the mayor's office. Explain not just how you would have addressed the problem externally, but also how you would have worked with council members and staff internally to get their buy-in.
The mayor has punted on dealing with pension reform, the most serious long-term issue facing the City. Instead of proposing a comprehensive solution, she focused entirely on the fire fighter plan which actually is in the best financial shape for what I must conclude were political reasons. In my opinion she should have come forward with a comprehensive proposed solution and then vetted that with the various stakeholders. That is not to suggest that everyone would have ultimately agreed on a plan. But at least when she went to the Legislature there would have been a process and a comprehensive proposal on the table.
4. Describe a time when a decision you made was attacked and how you handled it. How did you communicate with stakeholders? What was the resolution?
When I was the mayor in Kemah, there were many issues regarding parking near the Boardwalk. The city developed a plan to designate a certain area as our Entertainment District and to revise the parking requirements in that area to more realistically reflect the needs associated with the high volume of visitors we had on the weekend. The plan was basically a compromise between the commercial interest associated with the Boardwalk and the adjacent neighborhood. As with any compromise neither side was completely satisfied, but we ultimately implemented the plan and after it was in place for a few months both side realized it was something they could live with.
5. In August, the first day of school at the Houston Independent School District's new Arabic Immersion Magnet School was met with protests, and demonstrators said the school was anti-American and that immigrants should be assimilated. Had you been mayor at the time, how would you have handled that situation?
The mayor's principal responsibility in this situation would be ensure the safety of the students and their families and I believe I would have anticipated this possibility and made sure police were on hand to ensure the protests were peaceful and the students and families were not harassed. My understanding is that the protests were only a one-day event. However, had they persisted I would have called on groups like Interfaith Ministries or the Anti-Defamation League to intervene and seek a reconciliation between the groups.
***
What insiders say about them
Sylvester Turner
1 "He has a remarkable facility for really being able to communicate in an authentic fashion with just about anyone."
Bobby Lapin, Turner's former attorney
1 "He knows how to use his stature and his political power to achieve his objectives."
State Rep. Senfronia Thompson
1 (Asked for three adjectives to describe her dad) "Collaborative, passionate, results-oriented."
Ashley Turner, Sylvester's daughter
1 "He was very savvy at knowing the questions to ask to vet out a particular issue and, at times, it would almost appear that he knew the answers before someone replied."

1 "Bill is good at thinking things through to their logical end and making sure that there are not unintended consequences."
Marcus Jonesi, King's longtime colleague
1 "I never saw him up in arms being reactive about anything, he's just very, very strategic."
Bridget Samuel, worked with King at Interfaith Ministries
1 "He is extremely detailed and very pragmatic, very logical. What's very interesting about Bill is as good as he is at the spoken word, he's even better at the written word."
Greg Collins, served on Kemah City Council with King
1 "Bill is driven as much as anything. ... When he latches on to an issue, he's driven to see it through."
Robert Eckels, former Harris County judge

Headline Text: It's Debatable: Arguing Houston gay ordinance - Charles: HERO statute is a flawed ordinance
Article Text:
This week, Arnold Loewy and Charles Moster debate the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance. Moster is a former litigation attorney in the Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush presidential administrations who currently has offices in Lubbock and Amarillo. Arnold is the George Killiam Professor of Law at Texas Tech University School of Law.
Charles: HERO statute is a flawed ordinance
An ordinance referred to by proponents as "HERO" (which stands for "Houston Equal Rights Ordinance) was recently placed on the ballot in Houston. The ordinance, on its face, would have banned discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity "in city employment, city services, city contracting practices, housing, public accommodations, and private employment." This ordinance was soundly rejected with 61 percent of voters choosing to vote against. So why would Houstonians vote to reject this ordinance?
Both critics and proponents of HERO have been particularly vocal about the policy issues underlying their respective positions. Proponents of HERO believe the ordinance is necessary to ensure equality. Personally, I do not believe that the issue with HERO and its ultimate rejection by the voters has anything to do with equality. I believe the issue with HERO deals with the public's justified fear of the potential consequences of seemingly benign laws.
Critically, accommodation laws such as HERO are not set out to provide equal treatment. Ordinances such as HERO seek to give "affirmative accommodations" that are above and beyond what is acceptable to the general populace. And indeed, HERO seeks accommodation in a way that could intrude upon the safety and comfort of members of the general populace.
The largest complaint with these so-called accommodation laws is that the sexual orientation/gender-identity provision of the ordinance would allow anyone who identifies as female to enter women's restrooms. This means anyone would be allowed to enter into the women's restrooms ‚Äî sex offenders, predators, you name it. Of course, the law doesn't intend to do this. However the reality is that HERO could potentially provide protection for unscrupulous people with ill-intended motives to enter a bathroom, claim to identify as a woman and wreak havoc on the innocent.
Further, HERO is a flawed ordinance with issues that predate the referendum vote. HERO was originally passed by the Houston City Council. After HERO was challenged through the court system, the Texas Supreme Court overturned the ordinance on the basis the City Council lacked the authority to enact such an ordinance. According to the court, "The legislative power reserved to the people
of Houston is not being honored."
Essentially, the Texas Supreme Court ruled that the people should be free to decide HERO's fate through a referendum. A referendum was held, and the people of Houston decided that HERO was not the ordinance for them. Considering that the Supreme Court of the United States has not decided to extend sexual orientation the same protections that it extends to race, national origin, or religion, there is nothing wrong with Houston voting against this accommodation ordinance.
I certainly believe everyone should be treated with respect. However, we should be wary of how we allow government to encroach into our lives, especially in situations such as this, where the majority is against such encroachments.
Arnold: Ordinance did not force gay acceptance
Mr. Moster tells us that "accommodation laws such as HERO are not set out to provide equal treatment. Ordinances such as HERO seek to give 'affirmative accommodations' that are above and beyond what is acceptable to the general populace." Oh really? I closely examined the HERO ordinance and nowhere did I find such a preference.
I never saw a provision that said that when a same sex couple comes into a crowded restaurant that they need to be moved to the head of the line in front of the heterosexual couples who have been waiting. Neither did I see a provision that required that required a grocery store to hire a transgendered person over a better qualified "straight" person who had previously applied for the job. Additionally I found no provision calling for an unmarried couple to be able to bump a married couple from an apartment lease that the married couple was in the process of negotiating for.
The reason that I could not find such provisions in HERO is they don't exist. Thus, when Mr. Moster speaks of "affirmative accommodations that are above and beyond what is acceptable to the general populace," he must mean legislatively compelled non-discrimination is unacceptable to the populace. Although that may be true (one can't be sure since such a small proportion of the electorate actually voted), it just shows that voters opposed enforced equality, not that they opposed "affirmative accommodations."
Mr. Moster refers to HERO as "flawed." So far as I can tell from his description, the only flaw in the ordinance was that under Texas law it should have been presented to the people rather than simply enacted by the town council. That does not render the substantive provisions flawed, it simply says that procedurally they should have been passed in a different manner. I assume, for purposes of argument, that it was within the power of the citizens of Houston to reject HERO. That, however, does not make their rejection wise.
I am glad Mr. Moster believes "that everyone should be treated with respect." However, he wants us to be wary of laws that compel such respect ("encroach into our lives" as he puts it). How is this different from opposition to the Civil Rights act of the Sixties? There, as here, (at least some) people did not extol the virtue of segregation but did extol the right of businesses to practice it. I think if one owns a business serving the public, he should expect government interference with his choice to discriminate.
Finally, the "potty" problem. First, there is nothing in the ordinance that addresses the restroom issue. Second, HERO by its terms is subordinate to federal or state laws. Thus, if Texas forbids males (including transgendered males) to use a female restroom, nothing in HERO would countermand that. Finally, even without HERO, a violent predator could dress as a woman and enter a female restroom and wreak the kind of havoc Mr. Moster wrongly assumes could be wrought only under HERO.
Even if Mr. Moster's strained construction of HERO were adopted, the person who would most benefit from it is the cross-dressing transgendered man. It is obvious that such a man would be a whole lot safer in the women's room than the men's room. Since he would do his business in a private stall, it is unlikely that anyone would even know that he wasn't a woman. But if he and his dress and heels had to use the men's room, his safety might well be significantly compromised. So, it is time to dispense with red herrings and address the serious question of whether all minorities should be able to go about their business without fear of discrimination, even if it takes legislatively mandated non-discrimination to accomplish that goal.
Charles: HERO is unwanted government encroachment
I agree legislation is sometimes necessary to fight various forms of discrimination. However, HERO absolutely fails to serve that purpose. Again, I oppose HERO as its unwanted encroachment of government on the daily lives of citizens more than outweighs any potential benefit that the ordinance might bring.
Under HERO, Houstonians can file complaints if they allege that they've been discriminated against. HERO then requires the Houston Inspector General to become involved, and if necessary, open up a criminal case. If a case is filed, it is heard in Houston's municipal court. Small business owners and government agencies stand to be fined $5,000 for every violation of the ordinance. This is a recipe for enhanced government meddling, not to mention the use of local police powers to intimidate and tax citizens and lawful businesses.
Notably, most of the 15 different categories of protected classes in HERO are already federally protected by existing laws and U.S. Supreme Court rulings/precedent. The exceptions, of course, are for gender identity and sexual orientation. This is not inherently bad ‚Äî there is a reason why the Supreme Court has not extended constitutional protections further: because government should be involved in our daily lives to the most limiting extent possible. Should Congress wish to extend constitutional protections to transgender individuals, it can easily do so. Alternatively, the U.S. Supreme Court could take this issue up when properly presented.
Further concerning about HERO is the fact the city of Houston has sought to subvert the will of the voters at every turn. In short, city officials continue to have problems abiding by their city charter. After the referendum was deemed necessary, the Texas Supreme Court had to step in once again, (amid concerns the Mayor of Houston was furthering her political agenda while sidestepping the procedures that are in place to prevent the very same) because the ballot language was unacceptable. The city of Houston's political maneuvering regarding the ballot language is so concerning that state Sen. Paul Bettencourt released a statement calling for the Senate Intergovernmental Affairs Committee to look into the city's "use of deceptive ballot language and continual erring on election procedure."
When HERO was first passed by the city council, citizens had organized and petitioned for either a repeal or to have the ordinance put forward to popular vote. On Aug. 4, 2014, the city announced it would not reconsider the ordinance. As the Supreme Court of Texas stated, "Yet the City Council decided, of its own accord, not to act, disregarding the City Secretary's certification that the petition had enough signatures." These maneuverings are costing the citizens of Houston considerable time and legal fees given that the Supreme Court of Texas has had to step in three times over the course of the last few months.
Ultimately, the people's right to vote is being protected, and the people of Houston have voiced their preference. Small voter turnout numbers have often been a problem, even with hot-button issues, but the reality is that our democratic process allows for this. For people who feel differently, the only alternative is to get out and vote.
Arnold: Voters misled by imaginary problem
Let's start with a point of agreement. Mr. Moster and I are in accord that "legislation is sometimes necessary to fight various forms of discrimination. But for some reason, he does not appear to think that preventing discrimination against LGBT people is within that category. Let's examine his reasons for that conclusion.
First, he talks about the "unwanted encroachment of government on the daily lives of citizens." What encroachment? If a business doesn't practice discrimination, the law will have no impact on it at all. If it does practice discrimination, it should feel the wrath of government breathing down its neck.
Assume that Bill's delicatessen does not practice discrimination. After John and Mary's wedding they come to Bill's for their post- wedding meal holding hands and are seated. They are followed by George and Sam who have just celebrated their wedding protected by the ruling in Obergefell v. Hodges (the same-sex marriage case), and they are also seated by Bill who does not practice discrimination.
Now, assume that the two couples instead go to Joe's Sandwich Shop on the other side of the shopping center. Once more John and Mary are seated, But George and Sam are escorted out of the restaurant by Joe, who angrily says: "We don't need any fag couples in this restaurant!"
If HERO had passed, Joe would have been fined $5,000 for his outrageous conduct. But with HERO defeated, Joe can get away with this sort of behavior scott free. Frankly, this is an illustration of where "enhanced government meddling," if meddling it must be called is totally appropriate and desirable. And, if HERO had passed, what Joe did would not be part of "lawful business." And, if he wants to avoid a $5,000 fine, all he would need to do is adhere to the law in the same way that recalcitrant restaurants were forced to do when racial discrimination became unlawful.
Mr. Moster is quite right that Congress could extend statutory (though not constitutional) protection to the LGBT community by simply amending the 1964 Civil Rights Act. It does seem strange to me that this would be his preferred method of operation. Traditionally, local choice is thought to be far superior to decisions made in far off Washington. After all, the Houston City Council, for all the flaws that Mr. Moster and the Texas Supreme Court find with its procedures, is still the duly elected representative body of the city of Houston.
Providing a preferred constitutional status for sexual preference is certainly an option for the Supreme Court, indeed one it came close to adopting in Obergefell. But that, along with congressional action, should be a last resort, not a first and preferred resort.
If cities like Houston continue to reject equality it may come to either congressional or judicial imposition of equality on the citizens of Houston. But it should not have to come to that.
When the citizens of Indiana realized that if their Religious Freedom Restoration Act (which appeared to allow discrimination against homosexuals) was causing them to lose convention business and ultimately threatened the Super Bowl, the state needed to retrench. Similarly if major events choose not to come to Houston and mention its lack of an equal rights ordinance as its reason for doing so, I suspect that the good citizens of Houston, like those of Indiana, will quickly rectify the situation.
But none of this should have been necessary. The Houston citizenry should have not have rejected HERO, and perhaps would not have, if they hadn't been misled by the imaginary "potty problem." Let us hope when this mistaken understanding is rectified and when City Council procedures are not the issue that a future band of Houston citizens will do the right thing. That is surely better than having the right thing rammed down its throat by the federal government.

Headline Text: HCC trustee to sue college - Wilson seeks reimbursement for legal fees
Article Text:
Dave Wilson has long been a thorn in the side of Houston Community College trustees. That hasn't changed now that he's one of them.
Wilson, a controversial figure long before he was elected to the HCC board in 2013, has done nothing to diminish his gadfly reputation in his first two years as a trustee. From a campaign criticized as deceptive and a dispute over whether he lives in the district he represents, to a complaint filed against the college and a legal tussle over his exclusion from an executive session, Wilson's actions have rankled his fellow trustees since he took office in January 2014.
Now Wilson is preparing to sue HCC over roughly $50,000 in legal fees stemming from a lengthy and ongoing dispute over the election that put him on the board.
Before he was even sworn into office, Harris County challenged his election in court, contending that Wilson lied about his residency when he claimed to live in an apartment in his northwest Houston warehouse rather than with his wife in a home outside the district. Some critics said Wilson, who is white, had misled voters in the largely black district into believing he is black - something Wilson hasn't explicitly denied, telling the Chronicle soon after the election that "politics is guerrilla warfare."
Before he was elected, Wilson had for years shown up to HCC meetings to speak out against the board's actions. He filed a lawsuit against the college in 2011 when it spent $8.3 million on 22 acres of flood-prone land off Westheimer.
Wilson has also built a reputation as an anti-gay activist, calling on HCC to cancel its plans to sponsor a float in last year's gay pride parade and most recently fighting against the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance.
Wilson has won several rounds in the court dispute over his residency, which the county is continuing to appeal, saying that the case raises important issues of law.
"We believe that a person should not be able to claim the benefit of a residential homestead at one location while registering to vote at a different location," Robert Soard, first assistant county attorney, said in an email. "More fundamentally, an elected representative should not be allowed to serve and set the tax rate for a district in which he does not personally reside."
Wilson says HCC should cover his legal fees, but his fellow trustees disagreed. Wilson wasn't able to garner the votes needed to put the item on an agenda after the state attorney general ruled last month that the college would have to prove paying the fees was for a public good.
"Based on the attorney general opinion we've received regarding this request, I don't feel we have the authority to reimburse trustee Wilson from tax dollars," board chairman Zeph Capo said in a text message. "Wilson's legal dispute with the county began prior to beginning his term as a trustee. Given the AG ruling, I'm taking the advice he often gives us in similar circumstances ... Let 'em sue."
And that's what Wilson plans to do.
"It's going to be soon, it's going to be real soon," Wilson said Monday, after failing to get support from the trustees at last Thursday's meeting.
In August, Wilson filed a complaint with the Harris County District Attorney's office alleging the college unlawfully overpaid for a vacant building. The complaint, still pending, focuses on HCC's February purchase of a former Conn's store for $8.5 million, $3.2 million higher than the original value assigned by the same appraiser in November. The higher value reflected a planned five-year lease of the building to Tesla Motors that never materialized; HCC has yet to find a tenant.
When trustees met in executive session soon after the complaint was filed, they wouldn't let Wilson in. He engaged his attorney to challenge this decision, incurring another $1,300 in legal fees he says the college must pay. The board has let him into every executive session since, including a meeting a week later when the board voted to hire a defense attorney for Chancellor Cesar Maldonado.
"It's not me costing the college more, it's them because they're not doing what's right," Wilson said.

Mayor Annise Parker said Monday she will not attempt to revive the controversial equal rights ordinance that voters resoundingly rejected this month.
Speculation had abounded since Parker, in the days after the sweeping defeat, said the City Council might revisit the ordinance before she leaves office at the end of the year. Though she was limited by time and the fact that several council members are in the midst of tight runoff races, foes seized on that statement. They began making calls warning residents that the law could return.
In a written statement, Parker said, "Considering all the other issues I still want to get finished, I do not see a way that we will be able to revisit the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance before I leave office at the end of the year."
The nondiscrimination law the council approved last year offered protections for 15 classes, including gay and transgender residents, the flash point for opponents of the law.
Businesses that serve the public, private employers, housing and city contracting faced up to $5,000 in fines for violations. Religious institutions were exempt.
After more than a year of legal wrangling, the law went to voters, who rejected it 61 percent to 39 percent.
Now, Parker's statement officially kicks the ordinance to the next mayor. The two candidates in the runoff, former Kemah Mayor Bill King and state Rep. Sylvester Turner, differ on the issue.
Turner has said he supports the law, while King said he opposed it as written.
Jared Woodfill, spokesman for opponents, said the group still plans to start running an ad on network and cable TV today that warns the law could be revived.
"We believe electing individuals who are opposed to the Bathroom Ordinance will prevent it from being resurrected by a future council," he said.

Headline Text: New battle looms over anti-bias ordinance First of 3 meetings Tuesday offer forum for debate over LGBT issue
Article Text:
Minutes after Jacksonville City Council voted down expanding the city's anti-discrimination law to cover lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people, attorney Jimmy Midyette huddled outside City Hall with other crestfallen supporters of the failed legislation.
"We'll figure out how we went wrong and what we can do better," Midyette said on that August night in 2012. "I guarantee you this - we are not done fighting for LGBT rights."
First Baptist Church had its own response to the outcome.
At a Sunday service, the congregation gave a standing ovation to seven City Council members who came to be thanked for standing "in the gap" and opposing the bill.
Three years after the raw emotion during the City Council's 10-9 vote against the measure, the question is back again as Mayor Lenny Curry begins a series of "community conversations" aimed at exploring the issue from various perspectives.
As Curry hears different viewpoints at those meetings, supporters and opponents of expanding the city's anti-discrimination law will vie to win him over to their side. Supporters of the change are hoping Curry will embrace an all-inclusive approach that covers not only sexual orientation but also gender identity and expression, which applies to transgender people.
People against changing the law want Curry to take a strong stance by pledging to veto any legislation that comes out of the council.
The first session in the "community conversations" convened by Curry will be at 6 p.m. Tuesday at Florida State College at Jacksonville's Downtown Campus, followed by another Dec. 3 at Edward Waters College and a third meeting Dec. 15 at Jacksonville University.
Curry has said he rejects discrimination "in any form" but he has not said whether he would support expanding Jacksonville's human rights ordinance - which bans discrimination in the areas of housing, employment and public accommodations - to include LGBT people.
During the campaign for mayor in the spring, Curry said he saw no need for Jacksonville to alter the ordinance.
"I remain unconvinced that we need to change city law on this issue," he said at a televised debate in May. "I've also said that I will lead a public conversation on any serious issue that we have in the city of Jacksonville."
NEWCOMERS WILL DECIDE
The upcoming meetings will involve panel discussions followed by questions and comments from the audience. The identity of the panelists is a bit of a mystery. Marsha Oliver, spokeswoman for Curry, said Friday the panelists had not been finalized.
Turnover at City Hall since 2012 means the newcomers elected in the spring elections will be the decisive votes this time. Curry defeated Alvin Brown, who never took a stand on this issue.
Eight City Council members who cast votes in 2012 are still at City Hall. Council members Greg Anderson, Lori Boyer, John Crescimbeni and Jim Love voted for the legislation three years ago. Council members Matt Schellenberg, Reggie Brown, Doyle Carter and Bill Gulliford opposed the measure. Raymond Johnson, president of Biblical Concepts Ministries, said based on positions taken by City Council candidates in the spring election, he thinks a majority of the council will expand the human rights ordinance, so he wants Curry to veto any legislation passed by the council.
"The HRO was passed in the May election, period," Johnson said. "It was a done deal. Many people falsely celebrated a Republican victory with the City Council in the spring. Unfortunately, we have elected the most pro-homosexual City Council in our city's history, and it's unacceptable."
A simple majority - 10 of 19 council members - is needed to pass legislation. Overriding a mayor's veto requires a super-majority vote, which would be at least 13 council members.
Johnson said he's concerned Curry will use the upcoming meetings "as an excuse to not veto the HRO."
"If he would veto the law, we would support him 100 percent and praise him from the rooftops," Johnson said. "If he does not veto it, he will reap the consequences."
Supporters of expanding the city's anti-discrimination law hope Curry will side with updating the ordinance.
Midyette, who is part of the Jacksonville Coalition for Equality, said a major difference from 2012 is that this time, Curry and City Council members take up the issue after it was "front and center" on the campaign trail.
"It was one of the issues people talked about along with the pension liability and business development," he said. "It just became an important part of the electoral conversation, so having a mayor elected who made it part of his campaign to say he would lead on this issue, and who is doing so now, gives me a lot of hope for our effort this time."
RAPID CHANGES
The second round of debate over the human rights ordinance will play out against a backdrop of rapid changes that have taken place nationally in the sphere of LGBT rights.
Since 2012, same-sex marriage has become the law of the land because of a U.S. Supreme Court ruling. The Boy Scouts of America dropped its ban on gay Scouts and modified its prohibition against gay Scout leaders.
At the municipal level, cities across the country have added more protections for LGBT people, according to annual scorecards by the Human Rights Campaign, which advocates for such laws. The city of Atlantic Beach passed a human rights ordinance in August 2014.
And there has been some backlash. This month, a voter referendum in Houston struck down anti-discrimination laws enacted in 2014. Opponents of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance used "No Men in Women's Bathrooms" signs to urge rejection, arguing the law would allow men dressed as women to go into women's bathrooms.
Jacksonville's human rights ordinance bars discrimination on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, marital status, age and disability.
In 2012, the City Council originally considered a bill that would have expanded the law to cover people regardless of "sexual orientation, gender identity or expression." The language about gender identity and expression applies to people who are transgender.
After opposition surfaced to including "gender identity or expression," a substitute version of the bill dropped that language and would have only added sexual orientation to the ordinance.
That version of the bill met defeat on a 10-9 vote. The City Council then took up the original version with gender identity or expression back in the mix. That version got rejected on a 17-2 vote. City Councilman Tommy Hazouri said Jacksonville needs to include gender identity and expression along with sexual orientation in the human rights ordinance. He said he hopes Curry will recommend an "all-inclusive ordinance" after hearing from people at the upcoming meetings.
Hazouri said other large Florida cities already have such laws on the books.
"Short of that, it would not just be a big disappointment for Jacksonville," Hazouri said. "It would be a disappointment for those continuing to be left behind."
The Duval County Democratic Party will highlight its support for an all-inclusive ordinance when Houston Mayor Annise Parker is the keynote speaker at a Nov. 30 dinner event for the local party organization. Parker supported the ordinance that Houston's City Council enacted in 2014.
Duval County Democratic Party Chairman Neil Henrichsen said he thinks the campaign against Houston's ordinance was "based on inaccurate propaganda that was meant to be fear-mongering and it was successful," he said. "I think in Jacksonville that can be avoided by being very clear on what changing the ordinance will accomplish - that it's protecting the rights of people in the community."
But opponents of expanding the human rights ordinance are pointing to Houston as a reason against a change in Jacksonville.
"I believe you to be a Christian based on your campaign communication," First Conservative Baptist Church Pastor Gene Youngblood wrote in a letter to Curry. "Therefore I know that you do realize the far-reaching impact for the future of our great city if Jacksonville passes an HRO, as was the case in Houston, Texas."
The three meetings convened by Curry will go through December, so any deliberation by the council on HRO legislation would not begin until 2016.
David Bauerlein: (904) 359-4581
MEETINGS
The city will have three meetings to discuss aspects of adding LGBT protection to the city's anti-discrimination law.
- Tuesday at 6 p.m. at Florida State College at Jacksonville's Downtown Campus, 501 W. State St. The topic will be "Supporting the Needs and Well-Being of Families."
- Dec. 3 at 6 p.m. at Edward Waters College's Milne Auditorium, 1658 Kings Road, to discuss "Religious Freedoms, Thoughts and Beliefs."
- Dec. 15 at 6 p.m. at the Jacksonville University Public Policy Institute, 2800 University Blvd. N., to discuss "Understanding the Law and Its Effects on Businesses."

Honoring vets
Regarding "Paying respects on Veterans Day" (Page B1, Thursday), I was among the honorees at the Spring Forest Middle School Veterans Day celebration. My wife and I were shown where to park and escorted in to a scrumptious breakfast prepared by the PTA. Then, the veterans were led into the gymnasium, where we were seated in the middle of the gym.
The students - sixth, seventh and eighth-graders - were in the bleachers and dressed in red, white and blue. They ran the program, introduced the speakers, etc. The students were unbelievable, wanting to shake our hands, telling us "Thank you for serving" and more.
Spring Forest Middle School has been doing this since 9/11. It is great to see young Americans showing such appreciation for veterans.
Charlie Eskridge, Houston Rail sense
Regarding "Planned high-speed rail line won't come downtown" (HoustonChronicle.com, Thursday), I moved to Houston in 1984 to go to grad school, and rail was being debated then.
Fast forward 30 years to 2015, and we don't even have our two airports hooked up to rail yet!
Our priority should be rail connectivity to Hobby and Intercontinental instead of high-speed rail to Dallas. I know which train I would most likely use, and I would guess that most Houstonians would feel the same way.
Many of us make trips to the airport, dropping people off, picking people up and parking and then flying out ourselves. The absurdity of leaving these two airports disconnected from the rail system all this time is hard for me to understand.
Gregg Gebetsberger, posted on HoustonChronicle.com ISIS threat
Regarding "Terror in Paris" (Page A1, Saturday), as we mourn the victims of the horrific attacks in Paris, let us pause a moment to think about our current debate on immigration.
Given the security challenges we face, how can we justify the huge amount of resources that would be required to arrest and remove millions of hard-working residents from this country?
We need to focus our resources on ISIS. For the safety of our country, we need to move beyond campaign sound bites to a thoughtful policy on immigration. Let us come together and protect, rather than divide, our country.
Katherine L. Butler, Houston Wedge issues Regarding "Taking sides on HERO battlefront" (Page B9, Friday), I know well-meaning people on both sides of the defeated Houston equal rights ordinance issue. However, I believe the runoff election will highlight the major ulterior motive behind this ordinance and that is to act as a wedge issue.
The intention is to make people one-issue voters and, in some cases, vote against their own best interests on other issues and candidates. The future will show that if HERO can be dragged out through 2016, it will join its other wedge-issue brethren Planned Parenthood and Benghazi in the presidential elections.
Ron Curtis, Houston Cougar pride
Regarding "Herman couldn't have dreamed up a more electrifying experience" (Page C1, Sunday), it was, hopefully, a watershed night for the Houston Cougars, for backup quarterback Kyle Postma and, most important, for Cougar recruiting!
Tom Hardy, posted on HoustonChronicle.com

Headline Text: Holiday wish - Before the holidays begin, let's take a mom
Article Text:
OpenURL Link
Holiday wish
Before the holidays begin, let's take a moment to thank some truly remarkable and outstanding people: Lisa at Our Daily Bread; the volunteers there; the Presbyterian Church; and above all, the very generous individuals and groups that do enormous good year round.
Here is my holiday wish for you: That you are surrounded by unconditional love in the arms of God. Frank Hurst,
Denton
American victories
The American people showed their disgust with the direction that our country is headed by their voting results on Nov. 3. The sanctuary city sheriff in San Francisco was given the boot.
A tea party governor was elected in Kentucky.
In Houston, the Democratic Party's "bathroom ordinance" was a serious abuse of government power and allowed men dressed in women's clothing to go into women's restrooms. If they were prohibited, a person or business could be fined $5,000. That monstrosity was defeated.
Those are some of our victories. But, then there is the Obama administration demands that an Illinois male student, who identifies as female, should be given unfettered access to girls' facilities: showers, locker rooms and restrooms. Two other states have lost similar cases to the Obama administration (The Washington Post and The New York Times).
A few share a view similar to Belinda Tupper, who said, "Kim Davis is a disgrace. Especially considering the fact that she proclaims herself to be a Christian woman. She was cited with contempt, jailed and is now back to work." (DRC online Sept. 13)
Ms. Tupper should remember Martin Luther King and many other Christians have been jailed and some are now being persecuted and jailed.
Leftists have again pitted themselves against decency, commonsense and Christianity.
Good people are again going to have to stand against destructive unconstitutional ordinances and laws.
Eric Mach,
Denton

e: ‚ÄúPatrick assails LGBT vote ‚Äî He and GOP senator raise bathroom issue; Rawlings defends rights measure,‚Äù Thursday news story.
If anyone needed proof the majority of voters in most elections don‚Äôt know what is on the ballot until they read it in the voting booth and then vote the way an advertisement told them to, it isn‚Äôt our Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick.
On Tuesday, the City Council voted unanimously to specify that Dallas‚Äô anti-discrimination ordinance applies to both ‚Äúsexual orientation‚Äù and ‚Äúgender orientation‚Äù in the Dallas ordinance that has prohibited discrimination in employment, public accommodations and housing.
On Thursday, The Dallas Morning News reported that Patrick released a statement saying the ordinance is ‚Äúto allow men in women‚Äôs bathrooms,‚Äù which, according to The News, is ‚Äúechoing his opposition to the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, which was defeated last week.‚Äù
Ah, our lieutenant governor seems to love the smell of the Political Power of Prejudice (PPP) in the morning. Willa Kulhavy, Garland
Restroom cop
Texas Lt. Gov. and EBM (Executive Bathroom Monitor) Dan Patrick has taken issue with a 2014 charter amendment that provides additional protections for city employees, specifically against discrimination in employment, housing, etc. As the state‚Äôs self- appointed restroom cop, Patrick feels this will lead to a mass pilgrimage of men to use the ladies‚Äô room, which, of course, is well known as a recruitment station for the LGBT community.
Here in Dallas, we‚Äôre used to a certain amount of silliness from our red state leaders in order to keep their way-far-right constituency happy. I mean, why allow a multibillion-dollar revenue generator like casino gambling when the state‚Äôs getting hammered by low oil prices?
We‚Äôve come to realize it‚Äôs the price you pay to live in the state with the best barbecue in the civilized world. But, lieutenant governor, if you really think one of the perks of being transgendered is the ability to use a private stall in a ladies‚Äô room, well, I guess I‚Äôll just have to suffer through the anguish of remaining straight. And you‚Äôll forgive us if we have bigger fish to fry.
Jim Breslauer, Dallas
The post Patrick and prejudice appeared first on Letters to the Editor.

Headline Text: Rangel: Next legislative session shaping up as heated
Article Text:
AUSTIN ‚Äî The start of the 85th Texas Legislature is more than a year away but there are already signs the 2017 session could be one of the most polemical since Republicans gained control of all branches of the state government 13 years ago.
Last month, for example, Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick issued his interim charges ‚Äî issues the lawmakers take an in-depth look at before they are back in session ‚Äî loaded with hot button issues such as school vouchers, religious liberty, banning the so-called sanctuary cities and even reviewing the right of public employees to have union dues deducted from their paychecks.
Two weeks later it was Gov. Greg Abbott's turn to grab the headlines.
Abbott warned Dallas County Sheriff Lupe Valdez her department's policy of dealing with undocumented immigrants who commit crimes "will no longer be tolerated in Texas."
The Legislature "must pass laws that prohibit any policy or action like yours that promotes sanctuary to people in this state illegally," Abbott said.
In addition, with their vocal opposition to the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance that Houston voters overwhelmingly rejected on Nov. 3, Abbott and Patrick signaled the state's opposition to gay rights is not over, even if the U.S. Supreme Court has legalized same- sex marriage.
On the flip side, the Texas Democratic Party is calling on supporters of President Barack Obama's executive order to halt the deportation of an estimated 5 million undocumented immigrants to join next Saturday's "Rally for Immigrant Families" in front of the Governor's Mansion.
"These programs sought to bring temporary relief for millions of immigrant families, bringing them out of the shadows, lifting the fear of deportation, and allowing them to give back to this great country of ours," chairman Gilberto Hinojosa wrote in an email to the party faithful.
"We cannot let Republicans get away with this attack on our communities," Hinojosa said after noting that ‚Äî in his last days as Texas Attorney General ‚Äî Abbott sued the Obama administration.
To the dismay of party officials and immigrant rights advocates, the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals recently agreed with a lower court ruling that blocked Obama's executive order.
The rally has the potential of drawing hundreds of protesters from across the state ‚Äîas it happened in the spring when the Senate considered the sanctuary cities bill Lubbock Republican Sen. Charles Perry authored ‚Äî because the Texas AFL-CIO has endorsed the protest.
"Gov. Abbott has taken an anti-reform position that is tearing families apart," Texas AFL-CIO President John Patrick said in a statement.
"In solidarity with immigrant working people, we are asking the governor to meet with families affected by current immigration policies and to reverse course for the benefit of our state," Patrick said.
Some Democratic legislators have also made it clear though they will likely be outnumbered again, they will oppose Abbott and the Republican majority in the Legislature when illegal immigration, gay rights and other divisive bills are considered. "Gov. Abbott appears to be vying for the title of the most anti-Hispanic governor in the history of Texas," Rep. Rafael Anchia of Dallas said after Abbott called for sanctuary cities legislation.
"As attorney general he sued the federal government over President Obama's immigration executive actions, specifically the implementation of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals and Deferred Action for Parental Accountability programs," Anchia said. "Governor Abbott will soon be known as the Donald Trump of Texas if he continues his ill-advised pursuit of anti-Hispanic policies."
In the end, the success of the legislation Abbott and Lt. Gov. Patrick intend to pursue may depend on the make-up of the House of Representatives.
For instance, though the House State Affairs Committee has scheduled a sanctuary cities hearing on Dec. 10, there is no guarantee such legislation can pass in the lower chamber if Speaker Joe Straus and some of his top lieutenants defeat their respective challengers in the March 1 Republican primary.
That's an issue this column has already addressed and will address again long before that election.

Headline Text: On Glenn Beck's Blaze, Philip Kingston tries to correct 'crazy' surrounding Dallas' anti-bias laws
Article Text:
‚ÄúYour bathroom experience will not change.‚Äù Here we go ... again.
One day after the Dallas City Council voted unanimously to amend a 13-year-old ordinance that already protected the LGBT community from discrimination, council member Philip Kingston went on Glenn Beck‚Äôs website The Blaze to explain that, no, this isn‚Äôt a bathroom ordinance because there‚Äôs no such thing as a bathroom ordinance. There‚Äôs an anti-discrimination ordinance that‚Äôs been on the books since 2002. And there‚Äôs a charter amendment voters overwhelmingly approved by 77 percent in 2014. But despite what they say down in Houston, there‚Äôs no such thing as a bathroom ordinance.
The host of the show is Dana Loesch, author of the book Hands Off My Gun: Defeating the Plot to Disarm America. The other guest is ‚Äúanti-gay crusader‚Äù Jonathan Saenz, president of Texas Values.
No need to recap the background behind the exchange; certainly you‚Äôre up to speed by now and aware that, according to city officials, since 2002 there‚Äôs never been a single complaint filed involving a transgender individual and a bathroom of any kind. It‚Äôs not much of a debate: We miss Loesch‚Äôs set-up for the segment, but do get Kingston‚Äôs polite dismissal of it (‚ÄúAlmost nothing you said in the intro was right ‚Äî I don‚Äôt mean to be argumentative‚Äù). Kingston then explains what happened Tuesday, after which Loesch hands over the mic to Saenz, who insists, among other things, that this 13-year-old law was written behind closed doors on Monday and OK‚Äôd on Tuesday and that ‚Äúthis type of Dallas bathroom ordinance, just like the one in Houston, threatens the safety of women and children.‚Äù
Kingston ‚Äî sporting a ‚ÄúDallas is Great‚Äù tie ‚Äî isn‚Äôt having it.
To sum up his response to Saenz: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs just flat false. That‚Äôs a lie. You‚Äôre just making stuff up at this point. Also false. That‚Äôs like 100 percent made-up. That‚Äôs crazy.‚Äù
In other news: ‚ÄúUkraine Just Passed Protections For LGBT Employees.‚Äù

Headline Text: Backlash not yet evident after defeated Houston HERO vote
Article Text:
Just hours after it became clear that Houston's non-discrimination ordinance, HERO, would be trounced at the polls last week, Houston Mayor Annise Parker predicted a "direct, economic backlash" for the city, akin to criticism and boycott threats in Arizona and Indiana after similar controversies.
But so far, any visible backlash has yet to materialize, and Houston appears at no risk of losing two upcoming major sporting events.
Tagged by opponents as "the bathroom ordinance," HERO would have made it illegal to discriminate against someone based on 15 "protected characteristics" ‚Äî including sexual orientation and gender identity. Opponents' ad campaigns targeted "gender identity" in particular and featured ominous, hulking men stalking little girls into bathroom stalls. That tactic proved largely successful, and the ordinance was defeated by about 61 percent of voters.
In the days after the vote, a petition asking National Football League Commissioner Roger Goodell to revoke Houston's status as host for the 2017 Super Bowl garnered about 3,500 signatures, and Chad Griffin, president of the national Human Rights Campaign, wrote Goodell seeking an "emergency meeting" to discuss pulling out.
But the NFL said its plans aren't going to change.
"We will work closely with the Houston Super Bowl Host Committee to make sure all fans feel welcomed at our events," a statement released by the NFL said. "Our policies emphasize tolerance and inclusiveness."
Similarly, the National Collegiate Athletic Association said it will proceed with plans to hold the Final Four portion of next year's March Madness basketball tournament in Houston. However, Dan Gavitt, vice president of men's basketball championships, conceded that the HERO vote "could impact the NCAA returning to Houston" in the future.
HERO opponents dismissed concerns of economic backlash from the beginning. Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick went one step further, telling The New York Times that even if HERO's defeat did come at a cost, it would be worth it. If organizations like the NFL "would even suggest that the Super Bowl not be played here because we don't want men in ladies' bathrooms, then we need a new commissioner," he said.
If anything, the ordinance's defeat has invigorated Patrick and other opponents of non-discrimination measures that include sexual orientation and gender identity.
On Wednesday, Patrick criticized the Dallas City Council for reaffirming a similar ordinance that the city has had in place for more than a decade.
The response to Houston's vote, relatively quiet outside the LGBT advocacy community, stands in contrast to larger controversies sparked by similar bills in recent years.
Before Arizona Gov. Jan Brewer vetoed a version of the state's Religious Freedom Restoration Act last year, several major companies ‚Äî including the NFL, Delta Air Lines, and Major League Baseball ‚Äî issued statements of concern, and many groups threatened boycotts. The bill would have allowed businesses to deny service to gay and lesbian customers for religious reasons.
Indiana faced a similar backlash earlier this year, when Gov. Mike Pence signed a version of the same bill. The NCAA described itself as "especially concerned," executives at Apple, PayPal and Yelp expressed opposition, and at least one convention threatened to relocate. HERO advocates say they aren't sure why the latest developments in Houston aren't attracting as much attention.
Jessica Shortall, managing director of Texas Competes ‚Äî a coalition of businesses that lobbies for pro-LGBT policies they say will keep Texas economically competitive ‚Äî said it's hard to know what, if any, backlash there will be. "It's impossible to predict to what extent the business community will react to what has happened in Houston," Shortall said.Still, she said, cities can take economic hits in many forms ‚Äî some more subtle than boycotts."On a broader scale, there's a talent issue to think about," Shortall said. "Especially when we're looking at millennials, the brand of a place is something that people who care about attracting talent to a state or region think about."Shortall cited Fort Worth as an example ‚Äî earlier this year, city officials told the Fort Worth Star- Telegram that Facebook examined the city's non-discrimination ordinance, similar in language to HERO, before announcing it would build a new $1 billion data center.The effect of a given policy ‚Äî or lack thereof, in HERO's case ‚Äî isn't always quantifiable, she said."It's the cumulative effect of many individual decisions," Shortall said.

Headline Text: Mayor to Dan Patrick: Dallas' LGBT protections are not 'about where people relieve themselves'
Article Text:
The same people who helped kill Houston‚Äôs Equal Rights Ordinance last week just discovered Dallas has had one on the books for 13 years. And they are not happy about that at all.
On Tuesday the Dallas City Council voted unanimously to fine-tune some language in a long-standing anti-bias ordinance to distinguish between ‚Äúsexual orientation‚Äù and ‚Äúgender identity and expression,‚Äù two things initially grouped together in the definition of ‚Äúsexual orientation‚Äù when Chapter 46 of the Dallas City Code was approved in 2002. The city‚Äôs LGBT Task Force worked on the amendment for a year ‚Äî ever since Dallas voters overwhelmingly passed a charter amendment in November 2014 that added both ‚Äúsexual orientation‚Äù and ‚Äúgender identity and expression‚Äù to the list of protections for city employees.
The ordinance prohibits discrimination in employment, public accommodations and housing.
But in a statement released this morning ‚Äî one that bore the headline ‚ÄúPatrick Statement on Dallas Bathroom Ordinance‚Äù ‚Äî Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick yet again insists the ordinance is intended ‚Äúto allow men in women‚Äôs restrooms,‚Äù echoing his opposition to the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, which was defeated last week. He joins state Sen. Don Huffines, a Dallas Republican, in calling for its repeal.
‚ÄúI was very proud to help lead the recent effort where an overwhelming majority of voters in Houston successfully voted down the misnamed and misguided HERO ordinance,‚Äù says Patrick‚Äôs statement. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why yesterday‚Äôs decision by the Dallas City Council, in closed session, to fast-track the enactment of a similar ordinance to allow men in women‚Äôs restrooms is both mind-boggling and appalling.‚Äù
The vote was conducted in open session ‚Äî because the council cannot take votes behind closed doors. And after it passed, 15-0, Dallas Mayor Mike Rawlings said that Dallas is ‚Äúvery diverse, and we want to make sure everyone is protected.‚Äù
In a statement offered as a response to Patrick‚Äôs, Rawlings said Wednesday afternoon that ‚Äúour job as City Council members is to represent the citizens of Dallas. While we respect others‚Äô points of view, our goal is to protect all of our citizens, including minority groups.‚Äù
Said Rawlings, ‚ÄúYesterday‚Äôs unanimous City Council vote did not change the scope of our 13-year-old anti-discrimination ordinance. We took action that is consistent with what our voters approved last year and the protections already afforded to our employees. It is not forthright or honest to minimize this issue to a question about where people relieve themselves.‚Äù
As the Texas Tribune points out today, Dallas is one of several Texas cities with laws on the books intended to protect lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender employees and residents. Also on the list: Fort Worth, Arlington, Austin, Plano, San Antonio, El Paso, Waco and Brownsville.
‚ÄúThe Lieutenant Governor is infamous for fomenting mob mentality against the interests of minorities,‚Äù says Dallas City Council member Philip Kingston via email. ‚ÄúIn Dallas we believe in equal protection under law.‚Äù
Says Dallas City Council member Adam Medrano, chair of the city‚Äôs LGBT Task Force, Patrick and Huffines are dispensing the same ‚Äúmisinformation that killed the HERO ordinance in Houston. It‚Äôs made up of non-truths. This is not a bathroom ordinance. This is about making sure everyone in the city of Dallas is treated equally.‚Äù
Not so long ago the gay community was furious with Rawlings after he refused to bring a marriage equality vote to the city council, proclaiming it a non-issue over which the council had no control. But in the last 18 months, following a low score on the Human Rights Campaign Municipal Equality Index, the council revised the city‚Äôs Family Medical Leave Ordinance to include a ‚Äúdesignated care recipient,‚Äù and extended pension benefits to the partners of gay and lesbian police officers and firefighters. The city also updated its health-care plan to cover some transgender services.
Medrano says amending Chapter 46 of the Dallas City Code was just the ‚Äúlast piece‚Äù of the task force‚Äôs recent work. But to the lieutenant governor, it‚Äôs the final straw.
‚ÄúThis ordinance isn‚Äôt about discrimination, it‚Äôs about political correctness ‚Äî and Dallas city leaders have put political correctness ahead of both common sense and common decency,‚Äù says Patrick‚Äôs statement. ‚ÄúThe facts are clear. No woman wants a man to be allowed in a ladies restroom or locker room, no matter the reason. And no man wants his wife, daughter, mother, or sister to be forced by law to contend with such an uncomfortable, disruptive, and potentially dangerous intrusion. This ludicrous ordinance, like the one in Houston, reveals officials who are totally out of touch with Texas values.‚Äù
Medrano says the city is taking steps to ‚Äúput the truth out there‚Äù concerning yesterday‚Äôs council action, including reaching out to local legislators. Council members are posting to social media, and Medrano says the city will issue a statement later today. But in the meantime, one of the state‚Äôs most powerful legislators is calling for its repeal.
Yesterday, following the vote, Huffines took to Twitter to attack ‚ÄúDallas‚Äô new sneak-attack LGBT ordinance,‚Äù and said the council had engaged in ‚ÄúObama & Pelosi style sneak-attack governance.‚Äù Kingston told him, via Twitter, to ‚Äústop lying.‚Äù Shortly after that exchange, Huffines launched an online petition intended to ‚ÄúKeep Men Out Of Women‚Äôs Restrooms!‚Äù
Today, says Kingston via email, ‚ÄúThe Lieutenant Governor should try to know something before he shoots his mouth off.‚Äù
Says Patrick in his prepared statement, ‚ÄúI have no doubt that if this issue is put to the voters, as opposed to being decided without adequate public notice and discussion, the people of Dallas ‚Äî like those in Houston ‚Äî will give it a resounding no.‚Äù
But as Kingston and Medrano point out, the issue was put to the voters last November. ‚ÄúAnd,‚Äù says Medrano, ‚Äúit passed with 77 percent of the vote.‚Äù
ADDENDUM:
Here is the original Dallas Morning News story that ran on May 9, 2002, about the initial passage of Dallas‚Äô anti-discrimination ordinance.
Ordinance protecting gays OK‚Äôd
Discrimination ban in Dallas includes housing, employment
By COLLEEN McCAIN NELSON/Staff Writer
Dallas City Council members approved an ordinance Wednesday aimed at protecting gays and lesbians, saying that the anti- discrimination measure was long overdue.
The council voted, 13-2, to adopt the ordinance, which prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation in housing, employment and such public places as hotels and restaurants. Violations would be punishable by fines of $200 to $500.
Dallas becomes one of several dozen U.S. cities that have prohibited discrimination based on sexual orientation. Fort Worth, Houston and Austin have approved similar measures. Prominent business executives, including American Airlines chairman and chief executive officer Donald J. Carty, and a Methodist minister were among the few dozen people who expressed support for the ordinance. Two people spoke against it.
Mr. Carty, who spoke of the success of American‚Äôs anti-discrimination policies, told the council that passing the ordinance is a good business decision. ‚ÄúUltimately, the issue transcends self-interest to something more important,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúTaking a stand against discrimination ‚Äî whether based on race, gender, religion, class, sexual orientation or anything else ‚Äî is not politically correct. It is simply correct.‚Äù
On the mayoral campaign trail, Laura Miller promised to make enacting the ordinance a top priority. Ms. Miller and council members John Loza, Veletta Forsythe Lill, Ed Oakley and Elba Garcia worked with gay and lesbian leaders to draft the proposal.
Mr. Loza told his colleagues that their decision reaffirmed the worth of every Dallas resident.
‚ÄúI have always been proud of Dallas,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAs a gay man, today I am especially proud of my city.‚Äù
Mr. Oakley, who is also gay, said the ordinance simply ensured that all people are treated fairly.
‚ÄúIf you think ... that we‚Äôre trying to give special rights to individuals, that is not the case,‚Äù he said.
Council members Alan Walne and Mitchell Rasansky voted against the measure, saying it would cost too much to enforce and would pose an added burden for small-business owners.
Employers with more than 15 workers must comply. Religious organizations and state and federal offices will be exempt. Substantiated complaints will be sent to mediation. Those that remain unresolved will go to the city attorney.
Mr. Walne said he could not justify the expense of enforcing the ordinance when the city is facing a significant budget shortfall.
Two full-time staff members will be assigned to investigate complaints, and a city attorney will work part time on enforcement. The annual cost of salaries and equipment will be about $169,000. The city staff said employees will be reassigned to enforce the ordinance, bringing the cost of the policy down to $15,000.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not just making a statement; we‚Äôre adding a cost,‚Äù Mr. Walne said.
Clint Freeman, who urged the council to reject the ordinance, said the proposal would regulate or even outlaw beliefs that homosexuality is wrong.
‚ÄúContrary to the implications of the ordinance, there seems to be no evidence of a problem,‚Äù he said.
But Hector Garcia, former chairman of the city‚Äôs Plan Commission and a Texas Human Rights Foundation board member, told the council that discrimination and bigotry are evident in Texas.
‚ÄúRegardless of how you personally feel about gays, lesbians, the transgendered and bisexuals, know that we are your constituents,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe ... deserve the same protections afforded everyone else.‚Äù

Headline Text: MICHAEL MORRIS: "Perverts and freaks" preferred to haters
Article Text:
Ba ck more than four decades, a relative of mine was the star of a televised fundraiser. He‚Äôs not much older than me, and I was still young enough to marvel that someone I know would show up on the same box that sent Jan Brady and Scooby Doo into my house.
He was, literally, a poster child at a time when people like him were ignored and ridiculed for a condition over which he had no control. People judged him and it wasn‚Äôt OK for their own children to have him as a friend.
That was the life of people with mental retardation and developmental disabilities back in the late 1960s and early ‚Äô70s. It was shameful for our society that still had trouble with accepting people who were different than themselves, even if those differences were genetic.
While, thankfully, society has grown up when it comes to how the MRDD community is accepted and allowed to participate, my relative remains the emotional equivalent of a pre-teen. In some ways, when it comes to accepting those different than ourselves, the same can be said of America.
We ridicule them, bully them and try to keep them out of our uncomfortable sights.
That much was obvious when we asked on Facebook for people‚Äôs reaction last week to the defeat of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance. The assaults on the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender community, known as LGBT, were pathetic and shameful.
Among the terms used to describe those whose sexuality is outside mainstream acceptance were ‚Äúperverts‚Äù and ‚Äúfreaks.‚Äù
In insulting them, however, they were assaulting friends and family members who I care for, masking their disgusting judgments in religion and morality. Literally, HERO supporters were being castigated by the holier-than-thou.
I can tell you from experience, from knowing people who are openly gay ‚Äî they were born that way. And those who treat them with outward contempt, I can tell them their judgment is purely one of hate.
I‚Äôm not an expert on the Bible, but I have done a bit of research and I can‚Äôt find any passages or parable where Jesus tells us hating is an acceptable Christian behavior. Quite the contrary.
‚ÄúIf anyone says, ‚ÄòI love God,‚Äô and hates his brother, he is a liar; for he who does not love his brother whom he has seen cannot love God whom he has not seen.‚Äù (1 John 4:20).
To those who wish to respond with Romans 1:26-27 that begins with, ‚ÄúFor this reason God gave them up to dishonorable passions‚Äù that anti-gay folks like to cite as the Bible calling out homosexual behavior as a sin, they should pause a second at a mirror. The person staring back at them, like all of us, is a sinner.
That includes the man who checked out the waitress, the family jealous of a friend‚Äôs much nicer home and the child who slipped a pack of gum into their pocket without paying for it.
We are quick to forgive those behaviors, three of the commandments God sent down from Mount Sinai. But when asked to accept those who identify as LGBT as our brothers and sisters, we instead label them freaks and perverts because of who they choose to love.
If what pours forth from their hearts is a sin, so is the hatred that pours forth from the hearts of those who cast stones upon them. ‚ÄúFor out of the heart come evil thoughts, murder, adultery, sexual immorality, theft, false witness, slander‚Äù (Matthew 15:19).
It is your right to not accept the way those in the LGBT community live their lives.
It also is my right to not ascribe to the hate which fuels yours.

Headline Text: Teacher: Firing was tied to transgender child
Article Text:
An educator this week filed a federal discrimination complaint against a learning center in Katy, alleging that she was wrongly fired for refusing to address a 6-year-old girl as a transgender boy, the teacher's attorneys said Tuesday.
