Madeline Kirksey, a former employee of the Children's Lighthouse Learning Center on Clay Road in Katy, was fired Nov. 3 after she would not agree to treat the child as a male and call the child by a new male name, according to a copy of a filing with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission provided by her attorneys.
Kirksey had served as the Kids Club manager for the local franchise since August 2014, which involved overseeing nearly 100 kids, said Briscoe Cain, an attorney representing Kirksey. Her firing occurred the same day that voters repealed the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, or HERO.
Another of Kirksey's attorneys, Andy Taylor, who also represented the plaintiffs who challenged HERO when it was passed by the Houston City Council, pointed to her protected class as a black female over age 40 who holds religious convictions. He said that her "essence" had been violated. "All of those rights were not vindicated but destroyed," Taylor said at a morning news conference.
In brief remarks, Kirksey said she took offense first because of her beliefs. "I trust God," the Houston resident said.
A spokesman for Children's Lighthouse Learning Centers, which operates franchise locations in multiple states, said by phone Tuesday that he could not comment on matters related to employment. But when pressed by a reporter on whether Kirksey was terminated over her handling of a transgender student, the spokesman said no.
"What's unfortunate here is that a teacher who was fired from a school for a variety of issues decided to call a news station," said the spokesman, Jamie Izaks. "This teacher had an agenda behind it and was very opportunistic with a recent vote and discussion in Houston."
'A real issue'
The learning center franchises, first established in Fort Worth, provide child care for kids ranging from 6 weeks old to age 13. Those between 6 and 13 are typically in an after-school program, rather than full-day, Izaks said.
The company promotes itself online as "the leading values-based educational child care system in the U.S." Izaks said the schools are accepting of all religions and have a reputation for nurturing and raising great students.
Taylor stressed that the child had been attending the school since the start of classes as a "little girl."
Using fake names, Taylor said that the child left school Friday as "Sally" and returned on Monday going by "Johnny." "They had a real issue on their hands," Taylor said of the school staff.
The right response
The child reportedly showed up Monday with a short haircut, and Taylor said the child's gender identity wasn't set in stone.
He said the child continued to use the girls' bathroom. The 6-year-old also played football with the boys and, when hit hard, cried and said, "I'm really not a little boy." Taylor likened the imposition of such a decision over gender on a child to "child abuse." At such a young age, he said, kids haven't even decided what ice cream or cereal they prefer.
As such, the attorney praised Kirksey for standing up not only because of religious reasons but also to protect the child from ridicule and to keep the other children at the school in mind who would have been "mightily" confused.
Other children might have thought of the student's announcement that her gender had changed as a "cruel game of opposite day," Taylor said.
The issue of how to respond to young kids who announce they are transgender in a classroom is not one limited to the Katy area, Taylor noted.
"It's time to take a stand, to push back," he said.
Of the pertinence of the case nationwide, Cain said: "We'd be blindfolding ourselves if we were to say this was an isolated incident."
'Need to be prepared'
The Houston ISD prohibits discrimination against students based on gender identity and expression.
Learning Center teachers are trained to respond appropriately to students who present a variety of issues at school, Izaks said.
"One day they think they're a super hero, the next day they think they're the king of the world," the spokesman said. "... You need to be prepared for everything."
The EEOC enforces federal discrimination laws on the basis of race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age, disability or genetic information. A spokesman said he could neither confirm nor deny that the complaint had been filed.
Lawyers said they plan soon to file a second complaint on behalf of a bus driver for the center who was also recently fired.
Reporter Mihir Zaveri and Ericka Mellon contributed to this report

Headline Text: Mayor to Dan Patrick: Dallas' LGBT protections are not 'about where people relieve themselves'
Article Text:
The same people who helped kill Houston‚Äôs Equal Rights Ordinance last week just discovered Dallas has had one on the books for 13 years. And they are not happy about that at all.
On Tuesday the Dallas City Council voted unanimously to fine-tune some language in a long-standing anti-bias ordinance to distinguish between ‚Äúsexual orientation‚Äù and ‚Äúgender identity and expression,‚Äù two things initially grouped together in the definition of ‚Äúsexual orientation‚Äù when Chapter 46 of the Dallas City Code was approved in 2002. The city‚Äôs LGBT Task Force worked on the amendment for a year ‚Äî ever since Dallas voters overwhelmingly passed a charter amendment in November 2014 that added both ‚Äúsexual orientation‚Äù and ‚Äúgender identity and expression‚Äù to the list of protections for city employees.
The ordinance prohibits discrimination in employment, public accommodations and housing.
But in a statement released this morning ‚Äî one that bore the headline ‚ÄúPatrick Statement on Dallas Bathroom Ordinance‚Äù ‚Äî Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick yet again insists the ordinance is intended ‚Äúto allow men in women‚Äôs restrooms,‚Äù echoing his opposition to the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, which was defeated last week. He joins state Sen. Don Huffines, a Dallas Republican, in calling for its repeal.
‚ÄúI was very proud to help lead the recent effort where an overwhelming majority of voters in Houston successfully voted down the misnamed and misguided HERO ordinance,‚Äù says Patrick‚Äôs statement. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why yesterday‚Äôs decision by the Dallas City Council, in closed session, to fast-track the enactment of a similar ordinance to allow men in women‚Äôs restrooms is both mind-boggling and appalling.‚Äù
The vote was conducted in open session ‚Äî because the council cannot take votes behind closed doors. And after it passed, 15-0, Dallas Mayor Mike Rawlings said that Dallas is ‚Äúvery diverse, and we want to make sure everyone is protected.‚Äù
In a statement offered as a response to Patrick‚Äôs, Rawlings said Wednesday afternoon that ‚Äúour job as City Council members is to represent the citizens of Dallas. While we respect others‚Äô points of view, our goal is to protect all of our citizens, including minority groups.‚Äù
Said Rawlings, ‚ÄúYesterday‚Äôs unanimous City Council vote did not change the scope of our 13-year-old anti-discrimination ordinance. We took action that is consistent with what our voters approved last year and the protections already afforded to our employees. It is not forthright or honest to minimize this issue to a question about where people relieve themselves.‚Äù
As the Texas Tribune points out today, Dallas is one of several Texas cities with laws on the books intended to protect lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender employees and residents. Also on the list: Fort Worth, Arlington, Austin, Plano, San Antonio, El Paso, Waco and Brownsville.
‚ÄúThe Lieutenant Governor is infamous for fomenting mob mentality against the interests of minorities,‚Äù says Dallas City Council member Philip Kingston via email. ‚ÄúIn Dallas we believe in equal protection under law.‚Äù
Says Dallas City Council member Adam Medrano, chair of the city‚Äôs LGBT Task Force, Patrick and Huffines are dispensing the same ‚Äúmisinformation that killed the HERO ordinance in Houston. It‚Äôs made up of non-truths. This is not a bathroom ordinance. This is about making sure everyone in the city of Dallas is treated equally.‚Äù
Not so long ago the gay community was furious with Rawlings after he refused to bring a marriage equality vote to the city council, proclaiming it a non-issue over which the council had no control. But in the last 18 months, following a low score on the Human Rights Campaign Municipal Equality Index, the council revised the city‚Äôs Family Medical Leave Ordinance to include a ‚Äúdesignated care recipient,‚Äù and extended pension benefits to the partners of gay and lesbian police officers and firefighters. The city also updated its health-care plan to cover some transgender services.
Medrano says amending Chapter 46 of the Dallas City Code was just the ‚Äúlast piece‚Äù of the task force‚Äôs recent work. But to the lieutenant governor, it‚Äôs the final straw.
‚ÄúThis ordinance isn‚Äôt about discrimination, it‚Äôs about political correctness ‚Äî and Dallas city leaders have put political correctness ahead of both common sense and common decency,‚Äù says Patrick‚Äôs statement. ‚ÄúThe facts are clear. No woman wants a man to be allowed in a ladies restroom or locker room, no matter the reason. And no man wants his wife, daughter, mother, or sister to be forced by law to contend with such an uncomfortable, disruptive, and potentially dangerous intrusion. This ludicrous ordinance, like the one in Houston, reveals officials who are totally out of touch with Texas values.‚Äù
Medrano says the city is taking steps to ‚Äúput the truth out there‚Äù concerning yesterday‚Äôs council action, including reaching out to local legislators. Council members are posting to social media, and Medrano says the city will issue a statement later today. But in the meantime, one of the state‚Äôs most powerful legislators is calling for its repeal.
Yesterday, following the vote, Huffines took to Twitter to attack ‚ÄúDallas‚Äô new sneak-attack LGBT ordinance,‚Äù and said the council had engaged in ‚ÄúObama & Pelosi style sneak-attack governance.‚Äù Kingston told him, via Twitter, to ‚Äústop lying.‚Äù Shortly after that exchange, Huffines launched an online petition intended to ‚ÄúKeep Men Out Of Women‚Äôs Restrooms!‚Äù
Today, says Kingston via email, ‚ÄúThe Lieutenant Governor should try to know something before he shoots his mouth off.‚Äù
Says Patrick in his prepared statement, ‚ÄúI have no doubt that if this issue is put to the voters, as opposed to being decided without adequate public notice and discussion, the people of Dallas ‚Äî like those in Houston ‚Äî will give it a resounding no.‚Äù
But as Kingston and Medrano point out, the issue was put to the voters last November. ‚ÄúAnd,‚Äù says Medrano, ‚Äúit passed with 77 percent of the vote.‚Äù
ADDENDUM:
Here is the original Dallas Morning News story that ran on May 9, 2002, about the initial passage of Dallas‚Äô anti-discrimination ordinance.
Ordinance protecting gays OK‚Äôd
Discrimination ban in Dallas includes housing, employment
By COLLEEN McCAIN NELSON/Staff Writer
Dallas City Council members approved an ordinance Wednesday aimed at protecting gays and lesbians, saying that the anti- discrimination measure was long overdue.
The council voted, 13-2, to adopt the ordinance, which prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation in housing, employment and such public places as hotels and restaurants. Violations would be punishable by fines of $200 to $500.
Dallas becomes one of several dozen U.S. cities that have prohibited discrimination based on sexual orientation. Fort Worth, Houston and Austin have approved similar measures. Prominent business executives, including American Airlines chairman and chief executive officer Donald J. Carty, and a Methodist minister were among the few dozen people who expressed support for the ordinance. Two people spoke against it.
Mr. Carty, who spoke of the success of American‚Äôs anti-discrimination policies, told the council that passing the ordinance is a good business decision. ‚ÄúUltimately, the issue transcends self-interest to something more important,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúTaking a stand against discrimination ‚Äî whether based on race, gender, religion, class, sexual orientation or anything else ‚Äî is not politically correct. It is simply correct.‚Äù
On the mayoral campaign trail, Laura Miller promised to make enacting the ordinance a top priority. Ms. Miller and council members John Loza, Veletta Forsythe Lill, Ed Oakley and Elba Garcia worked with gay and lesbian leaders to draft the proposal.
Mr. Loza told his colleagues that their decision reaffirmed the worth of every Dallas resident.
‚ÄúI have always been proud of Dallas,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAs a gay man, today I am especially proud of my city.‚Äù
Mr. Oakley, who is also gay, said the ordinance simply ensured that all people are treated fairly.
‚ÄúIf you think ... that we‚Äôre trying to give special rights to individuals, that is not the case,‚Äù he said.
Council members Alan Walne and Mitchell Rasansky voted against the measure, saying it would cost too much to enforce and would pose an added burden for small-business owners.
Employers with more than 15 workers must comply. Religious organizations and state and federal offices will be exempt. Substantiated complaints will be sent to mediation. Those that remain unresolved will go to the city attorney.
Mr. Walne said he could not justify the expense of enforcing the ordinance when the city is facing a significant budget shortfall.
Two full-time staff members will be assigned to investigate complaints, and a city attorney will work part time on enforcement. The annual cost of salaries and equipment will be about $169,000. The city staff said employees will be reassigned to enforce the ordinance, bringing the cost of the policy down to $15,000.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not just making a statement; we‚Äôre adding a cost,‚Äù Mr. Walne said.
Clint Freeman, who urged the council to reject the ordinance, said the proposal would regulate or even outlaw beliefs that homosexuality is wrong.
‚ÄúContrary to the implications of the ordinance, there seems to be no evidence of a problem,‚Äù he said.
But Hector Garcia, former chairman of the city‚Äôs Plan Commission and a Texas Human Rights Foundation board member, told the council that discrimination and bigotry are evident in Texas.
‚ÄúRegardless of how you personally feel about gays, lesbians, the transgendered and bisexuals, know that we are your constituents,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe ... deserve the same protections afforded everyone else.‚Äù

Headline Text: It's our turn, again, for an LGBT battle
Article Text:
Two cities, in two elections, provided one telling intersection last week in America's latest fight for equality.
One election, in Charlotte, resulted in a new City Council poised to reintroduce an anti-discrimination ordinance that includes protections for transgender people. The other election, in Houston, shows how challenging that battle will be.
In Charlotte, voters elected Democrats to the council's four at-large seats, ensuring the same 9-2 majority as the previous council. The difference this time is at-large members Michael Barnes and David Howard - who in March voted against at least of some of the anti-discrimination ordinance - will leave the council in December. They'll be replaced by Julie Eiselt and James "Smuggie" Mitchell, who've said they'd support expanding protections to the LGBT community.
In Houston, however, anti-LGBT activists showed how to defeat such an ordinance. After that city's council passed the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance (HERO) 18 months ago, opponents of the ordinance gathered enough signatures to get a referendum on the issue in front of voters last week.
The activists also launched a distasteful campaign that characterized the ordinance, which protected 15 classes of people, as a vehicle for sex offenders to prey on children in bathrooms. It worked: voters rejected HERO by a 22-point margin last Tuesday.
The same could happen here. Even if Charlotte's City Council passed a new anti-discrimination ordinance, voters across the city could get their say on it. All it would take is the conservative N.C. General Assembly passing a local act allowing for a referendum.
At the least, a reintroduction of the ordinance would result in the same debate that roiled Charlotte back in March. It will be uncomfortable. It will bring out the worst in some of us.
But Charlotte's City Council shouldn't shy away from the discussion, or the fight.
Instead, council members should remind the public that most large cities offer protections for the LGBT community, and that we look comparatively regressive to the businesses, young workers and big events that might be looking our way.
They should also note that while opponents of anti-discrimination ordinances like to make them all about the bathrooms, there are no documented cases of perverts taking advantage of such ordinances to poke around women's bathrooms or pursue children. None.
That is, by the way, the same kind of scary diversion anti-gay activists long used in their fight against laws protecting the rights of homosexuals. It's just as hateful now.
More and more, Americans are realizing this. The day before the Houston vote, the U.S. Department of Education supported a transgender student in Illinois who wanted to use the school restrooms and locker room. Also last week, the Maryland State Department of Education issued guidelines for schools so that they can support transgender and gender non-conforming students.
As with many minorities, the fight for equality will be rocky. But those hard steps have to be taken. Those difficult conversations should be welcomed, not avoided. It's Charlotte's turn, again.

Headline Text: Kleinman: 'This is not a bathroom ordinance, it is an anti-discrimination ordinance update'
Article Text:
Update at 5 p.m.: In response to numerous phone calls and tweets, such as this one from conservative talk-show host Dana Loesch to Dallas City Council member Philip Kingston, council member Lee Kleinman wants to make one thing very, very clear: ‚ÄúThis is not a bathroom ordinance, it is an anti-discrimination ordinance update.‚Äù
As noted earlier today, this is the update of an ordinance dating back to 2002 that protects the LGBT community from discrimination. And as Kleinman points out, last November Dallas residents voted 77 percent in favor of a charter amendment adding both ‚Äúsexual orientation‚Äù and ‚Äúgender identity and expression‚Äù to the list of protections for city employees. Says Kleinman via email, ‚ÄúToday‚Äôs action updated an ordinance to be consistent with that charter amendment as well as Chapter 34″ of the Dallas City Code, which deals with personnel rules and was updated in September 2014.
The Dallas City Attorney‚Äôs Office also offers this summary of today‚Äôs update, for those still confused:
Dallas‚Äôs anti-discrimination ordinance was approved by the city council in 2002 and had not been amended since. The primary purpose of today‚Äôs amendment was to distinguish between the terms ‚Äúsexual orientation‚Äù and ‚Äúgender identity and expression,‚Äù which were grouped together in the definition of the term ‚Äúsexual orientation‚Äù when the original 2002 ordinance was passed. The ordinance as originally approved in 2002 prohibits discrimination in employment, public accommodations, and housing on the basis of both sexual orientation and gender identity; today‚Äôs amendment simply defines gender identity separately from sexual orientation, and changes the wording of Chapter 46 of the Dallas City Code to reflect these separate definitions. With this change, the definitions of ‚Äúsexual orientation‚Äù and ‚Äúgender identity and expression‚Äù in Chapter 46 now match the definitions in the city‚Äôs personnel rules.
Update at 1:30 p.m.: Since the Dallas City Council voted to amend the long-standing ordinance, state Sen. Don Huffines, a first-term Republican, has been tweeting that it was a ‚ÄúObama & Pelosi style sneak-attack governance‚Äù that needs to be repealed. Among his tweets:
Repeal Dallas‚Äô new LGBT ordinance immediately. It was not reviewed or thoughtfully considered by the public. - Don Huffines (@DonHuffines) November 10, 2015
Houston voters soundly said NO to men in women‚Äôs bathrooms. Dallas‚Äô new sneak-attack LGBT ordinance must be repealed & carefully reviewed.
- Don Huffines (@DonHuffines) November 10, 2015
Dallas City Council member Philip Kingston is not impressed:
Went through a year of public discussion and makes no change to the existing public policy of Dallas. Stop lying https://t.co/IIhFU0uVgK
- Philip Kingston (@PhilipTKingston) November 10, 2015
Original post at 11:56 a.m.: Chapter 46 of the Dallas City Code, which was passed in May 2002, makes it illegal to discriminate against someone based on sexual orientation. The ordinance, which applies to everything from employment to housing, has defined sexual orientation as ‚Äúan individual‚Äôs real or perceived orientation as heterosexual, homosexual, or bisexual or an individual‚Äôs real or perceived gender identity.‚Äù Which means that for 13 years, the transgender community has been protected in the city of Dallas. But this morning, the council went the extra step by separating sexual orientation from gender identity. The council voted unanimously on the amendment, which now reads, ‚ÄúIt is the policy of the city of Dallas to bring about through fair, orderly, and lawful procedures the opportunity for every person to obtain employment, access to all places of public accommodation, and housing, without regard to sexual orientation or gender identity and expression.‚Äù
The city‚Äôs LGBT Task Force, of which council member Adam Medrano is chair, has been working on the new language for more than a year.
Despite the long-standing definition in the city code, ‚Äúthe transgender community believes they‚Äôre not included because the definition of gender identity is stuffed into sexual orientation,‚Äù LGBT task force member Patti Fink told the council shortly before the vote. She asked the council to pass the amendment ‚Äúso it‚Äôs clear to those who live in this city [that] they have protections.‚Äù
Said Fink, with the amendment transgender individuals can ‚Äúsee themselves in this ordinance very clearly. This move makes that possible. They don‚Äôt have to look under one line in Section 18 for the definition of sexual orientation to make sure gender identity is included.‚Äù
Following a lengthy closed-door discussion about the amendment at Monday‚Äôs Quality of Life Committee meeting, it was unclear if there‚Äôd be much discussion among the full council. There wasn‚Äôt any, save for a few words from Medrano about the task force‚Äôs work (‚Äúwe‚Äôve been able to do a lot for equality‚Äù) and a brief hear, hear from the mayor.
‚ÄúWords have meaning,‚Äùsaid Rafael McDonnell of the Resource Center, ‚Äúand your vote today will give life to those words and will be seen not only here in Dallas but around the country as support for the LGBT community.‚Äù
The council voted unanimously to amend the ordinance ‚Äî a far cry from what happened in Houston last week, where voters opposed a similar ordinance.
Dallas, said Mayor Mike Rawlings following today‚Äôs vote, is ‚Äúvery diverse, and we want to make sure everyone is protected.‚Äù

Headline Text: The way I see it - News media and Democrat narratives
Article Text:
The second column in November always falls close to Veterans Day, on the 11th. Those who have worn the uniforms of, in no special order, the Navy, the Marine Corps, the Air Force, the Army or the Coast Guard deserve, and are assured of, the respect and gratitude of a nation composed primarily of civilians. Due to the uncertainty and unpredictability of ever-present disagreements and disputes, otherwise peacetime service can be only a hair trigger away from wartime service‚Äîall are to be commended for putting country first. Thank you, veterans.
Over the last week, elections have sent messages, candidates have honed their messages and members of the news media have exercised shameless manipulation and attempted control of the messages. In a ‚Äúmove along‚Äînothing to see here‚Äù moment, voters delivered numerous body blows to the Democrat paradigm of progressive inevitability. In ‚ÄúRepublican Victories Highlight 2016 Stakes,‚Äù a writer at The American Interest wrote, ‚ÄúLast night was a banner night for conservatives, who defeated a number of measures in liberal strongholds, including a transgender bathroom ordinance in Houston, a $15 minimum wage ordinance in Portland, Maine, and a proposed law restricting AirBnB rentals in San Francisco.
‚ÄúBut the most consequential GOP victory came in Kentucky‚Äîa deep red state in presidential elections that has nonetheless had Democratic governors for 40 out of the last 44 years‚Äîwhere the conservative populist insurgent Matt Bevin won the statehouse for Republicans by an almost nine point margin.‚Äù Democrat deep pockets also failed to sway voters in nearby Virginia, where Clinton- ista Governor Terry McAuliffe put it all on the line to gain his party‚Äôs control over the legislature. However, Democrat money prevailed in Pennsylvania Supreme Court contests, illustrating the priority the left gives to having the black-robed judicial branch in their corner.
Conservative electoral gains must be tempered by the reality of leftist/liberal dominance in entertainment, secondary and higher education, the regulatory branch, Obama‚Äôs appointed judges, among government employees, their unions‚Äîand the journalist class. News media leans left and left-er depending on proximity to local markets, with the major metropolitan broadcast, cable and print outlets‚Äîparticularly the New York/Washington, D.C. beltway elite‚Äîbeing dominated by Democrats.
It‚Äôs not really disputable; ‚ÄúRepublicans‚Äô media bias claims boosted by scarcity of right-leaning journalists,‚Äù by Kelly Riddell, illustrated as much in the Washington Times. Party identification, voting patterns, positions on issues and contributions lean, at the minimum, 3 or 4 to 1 in favor of the Democrat left, and up to 9 to 1 among the beltway media elites.
Of citizen-elected representatives, the local and state levels have seen a massive diminishment of Democrat-held seats, legislatures and governors while Obama has held the presidency. ‚ÄúThis creates an interesting dynamic. Because the Democrats‚Äô ranks have been eviscerated at lower levels of office, the stakes for winning the White House couldn‚Äôt be higher. If the party loses the White House in 2016, it will have almost nothing left.
‚ÄúThe prospect of losing everything creates an incentive for Democrats to double down even further on their presidential coalition (i.e. Hillary endorsed the Houston transgender ordinance). But this strategy‚Äîof appealing more and more strongly to the national base rather than reaching out to new segments of voters‚Äîmakes them even less competitive in off-year and state-level elections.‚Äù
It might be a rhetorical question, by Jazz Shaw, in ‚ÄúHas the liberal wing of the Democrats finally pushed the party too far?‚Äù but if you look it up, you‚Äôll find an insightful read with quotes from The Hill‚Äôs Alexander Bolton. He explores the question of ‚Äúwhether or not the ascendant, hard left, liberal wing of the Democrats has finally pushed their party to a tipping point in the run-up to the next presidential election.‚Äù Guns and race are prominent in this analysis.
Even casual observers can‚Äôt have missed the gun control/safety/background check rhetoric‚Äîeven thinly veiled references to confiscation. Hillary promises using executive power in furtherance of the issue. California‚Äôs gun-grabbers are cheering Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom‚Äôs ballot measures outlawing ‚Äúlarge capacity,‚Äù but otherwise standard, magazines; requiring background checks for all ammunition purchases; and mandating reporting of lost or stolen guns.
San Franciscans cheer the departure of its last gun store over required photographing of customers. Los Angeles has outlawed handguns widely owned from even being transported through the city. A map I saw showed it to be physically impossible to leave some municipalities without driving through LA and ordinary travel in SoCal is close to impossible with such guns. Most of us immediately reject the racialist sloganeering of the ‚ÄúBlack Lives Matter‚Äù movement. It reeks of race-grievance mongering. We are inclined to dismiss the obsessive skin-pigment, ‚Äúsocial justice warrior‚Äù fanaticism as yet another permutation of the reparations crowd. In ‚Äú6 Things We Learned About the Democrats,‚Äù Robert Tranciski itemized a few outtakes from their debate: 1) The era of big government is back, 2) Utopian transformation/socialism lives, 3) They have no plans for the economy beyond taxing ‚Äúthe rich‚Äù, 4) They have no concept of national security, 5) Democrats are defined by who they hate, and 6) The conservative Democrat is a dinosaur.

Headline Text: Houston's Anti-LGBT Campaign Was Led by Wingnut Who Would Evict All Gays
Article Text:
HATE
The city's equal-rights ordinance was struck down by voters last week. Secret documents reveal a shocking extremism among those who led the effort.
Last week's repeal of Houston's equal rights ordinance was the biggest setback for the LGBT equality movement in years.
And now, confidential documents provided to The Daily Beast by a leading LGBT rights organization reveal for the first time that the backers of the repeal were not the "usual suspects" on the Christian Right, but a uniquely Texan consortium of sword-swinging, Bible-swearing, fire-breathing extremists who want Texas to secede from the union and who pray for God to smite city officials, backed by a shadowy network of mostly anonymous donors.
"Homosexuals cannot reproduce, so they have to recruit, and they start with children."
First is the lead organizer of the Campaign for Houston, Steve Hotze. If that organization sounds familiar, it's because it is. Back in 1985, Hotze organized the "Campaign for Houston Straight Slate," led by then-mayor Louie Welch who said that the best way to control AIDS would be to "shoot the queers."
Credit Hotze for consistency. In 1982, he said of gays that "they proliferate by one means, and one means only, and that's recruiting. And they recruit the weak. They recruit children or young people in their formative years." And in May, 2015, he said, "Homosexuals cannot reproduce, so they have to recruit, and they start with children."
Hotze is also the founder of the Conservative Republicans of Texas, a home-grown vitamin salesman whose medical treatments have been widely discredited, and the "singer," if that's the word, of two auto-tuned piano pop songs about resisting the "tyranny of the federal government" and seceding from the United States ("Texas should be free‚Äîit should be an independent nation").
"What would Davey Crockett do?" Hotze sings. "I know what I'm going to do‚Äîdefeat Obamacare."
This summer, following the Supreme Court's ruling on same-sex marriage, Hotze launched a "Faith Family Freedom Tour" in Houston, at which time he drew a sword and said, "Our strongest weapon in the fight is the word of God. The word of God is like any two-edged sword. For thousands of years, men fought with swords. Can you imagine that piercing right through the enemy like this? That's what the word of God does. I've decided, I'm not going to fight the homosexuals with sweet words. I'm going to fight them with God's word."
But of course, the sword is just a metaphor, right? Unclear. "Drive them out of our city," Hotze exhorted. "I don't want them in our city. Send them back to San Francisco."
Hotze also distributed a 'manifesto' from 1987 meant to satirize the outrageous claims being made about gay people, and read it aloud as if it were a real manifesto ("We shall sodomize your sons, emblems of your feeble masculinity, of your shallow dreams and vulgar lies.")
Interestingly, Hotze himself signed an actual manifesto, the Coalition on Revival's 1986 "Manifesto for the Christian Church" (PDF) that states, among other things, that women must offer their husbands "gentle, submissive obedience, and not... weary them with constant criticism" and "den[ies] that Christians should marry non-Christians, and that sexual attractiveness or other carnal considerations should dictate a Christian's choice of a mate." Then there's Pastor David Welch. After HERO passed the city council (by a vote of 11-6), Welch was one of the pastors under investigation for improperly soliciting signatures for a political petition in church. This investigation led to the disastrous PR move of the city subpoenaing Welch's sermons, among other records.
It turns out that the subpoena, while terrible optics‚Äîthe City of Houston seemed to be telling pastors what they could and couldn't preach‚Äîwas quite justified. In fact, Welch was in frequent contact with national organizations such as the Alliance Defending Freedom as the anti-HERO fight took shape. And in a video posted last year by Equality Texas, he's seen training people on how to obtain signatures.
Still, of his subpoena, he said, Ben-Carson-like, "as close as anything I've ever seen to Nazi Germany on our soil." (Guess he hasn't seen KKK marches or swastikas painted on synagogues.)
But that's just the beginning. Welch also urged "imprecatory prayers" against the Houston officials examining the suspect signatures. For those of you who skipped that day of Sunday School, imprecatory prayers are those asking God to smite His enemies.
And in his weekly column for the far-right World Net Daily, Welch said of President Obama, "A Christian? I doubt it."
Hotze and Welch were joined by former congressman, and indicted crook Tom Delay. Delay spoke at several anti-HERO events himself, and his longtime lawyer and political crony, Andy Taylor, was also the lawyer for the anti-HERO coalition.
Taylor, incidentally, has not only bailed Delay out several times, but was also the lawyer in Delay's 2003 effort to redraw Texas's congressional districts, for which he billed taxpayers over $750,000.
And let's not forget the group Texas Values, led by extremist Jonathan Saenz (whose wife left him for a woman. Texas Values is, in fact, the lobbying arm of the Liberty Institute, better known as Kim Davis's lawyers.
The Liberty Institute might well be called the Lying Institute. As Media Matters has revealed, they advanced a bogus claim that a soldier was discharged for stating his religious views (in fact, he was at the end of his term), a bogus story that a Texas track star was disqualified after pointing skyward after a run (he was actually giving someone the finger, and, of course, Davis herself.
Saenz has called evolution a "left-wing ideology" that "any respectable scientist" would disagree with, and called the nonexistent 'War on Christmas' "a key front in the radical movement to remove all religious expression from the public square."
These local activists were assisted by national right-wing organizations, led by the Alliance Defending Freedom, Focus on the Family, and Family Research Council. That partnership of local extremists and national names is one reason the anti-HERO campaign was so successful. For example, the locals' initial anti-HERO message was "Unequal Rights," an anodyne phrase that sounds like a 1990s throwback. Smart consultants shifted it to "No Men in Women's Bathrooms," a "Big Lie" that convinced many voters that the anti-discrimination ordinance was really about sexual predators in restrooms.
That's the strategy that ADF and its ilk are now preparing to replicate Houston nationwide.
Finally, there is the tangled web of dark money that bankrolled the HERO repeal. Documents provided to the Daily Beast reveal a plethora of committees involved, including the Conservative Republicans of Texas, Conservative Republicans of Harris County, Campaign for Texas Families, Citizens for American Restoration. But all have the same treasurer, Bart Standley.
And they seem interrelated. For example, the Campaign For Houston (run by Hotze) donated $79,000 to Conservative Republicans of Harris County (also run by Hotze).
Then there's a separate, statewide Campaign For Houston, with separate donors and separate finances. In its filings with the State Ethics Commission, this Campaign For Houston included two line items totaling $200,350, and listed merely as "American Express." The Campaign For Texas Families, meanwhile, received $50,000 from the Texas Family Values PAC, and a handful of five-figure individual donors.
The leading individual donors appear to be real estate executive Allen Hartman, who donated a total of $206,000, and Steve Hotze himself, who gave $146,000.
That money bought a lot of lies. An equal rights ordinance meant to protect LGBT people from being fired from their jobs was twisted into a law meant to let men use women's restrooms. A broad coalition of racial and gender justice organizations were depicted as a radical gay lobby. And transgender people were demonized, misrepresented, and denied their very existence.
But perhaps the biggest lie of all was that the opposition to HERO was led by a broad, faith-based coalition of moderates and conservatives. Hardly. It was led, and won, by the wingnuts.
Liberals are unwilling to accept the overwhelming defeat of Houston's Prop 1. Sign if you support common decency! https://cards.twitter.com/cards/18ce53vrxet/15m2s

Headline Text: Tomorrow, Dallas council will vote on adding 'gender identity and expression' protections
Article Text:
A proposal to add ‚Äúgender identity and expression‚Äù to the city of Dallas‚Äô anti-discrimination ordinance stirred concern at City Hall this morning.
Supporters, led by council member Adam Medrano, said the proposed change to the city‚Äôs law was just some much-needed paperwork ‚Äî ‚Äúclean-up language‚Äù to clarify the protections the city already offers.
In a memo to colleagues late Friday, Medrano wrote that amending the existing ordinance would show that ‚Äúa person‚Äôs gender is determined by the person‚Äôs own perception of their gender.‚Äù And it would make it illegal to deny housing to someone based on their sexual orientation or gender identity.
The proposed rewrite also erases an exemption that previously said property owners could deny renting rooms ‚Äúto persons of the same sex when the dwelling contains common lavatory, kitchen or similar facilities available for the use of all persons occupying the dwelling.‚Äù
Per Dallas City Attorney Warren Ernst, Chapter 46 of the Dallas City Code has defined sexual orientation to include ‚Äúreal or perceived gender identity‚Äù since it was first enacted in 2002.
Council member Rick Callahan, of Pleasant Grove, wasn‚Äôt prepared to sign off on the amendment without discussion.
He said he‚Äôd been out of town at National League of Cities in Nashville (where he said he was running for a board position), just got back in town last night, and hadn‚Äôt had time to read the memo. Said Callahan, he‚Äôs been ‚Äúextremely busy‚Äù and, well, adding this to council‚Äôs voting agenda tomorrow is ‚Äúunfair to the committee and the council.‚Äù
Quality of Life chair Sandy Greyson and two city attorneys told Callahan this isn‚Äôt a change to existing rules, merely a better definition. Said Greyson, adding ‚Äúgender identity and expression‚Äù is merely a ‚Äúfurther explanation of what sexual orientation means.‚Äù
But as we learned in Houston last week, where the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance was defeated by voters after it was reduced to the ‚Äúbathroom ordinance‚Äù by opponents, semantic disputes are often the ugliest.
After nearly 45 minutes behind closed doors, there was no further discussion: Philip Kingston motioned sending the amendment, there was a second and the matter was sent along to the full council for a vote tomorrow.
LGBT Memo

Headline Text: HAYLEY ORR: HERO loss won't be end of the fight
Article Text:
Last Tuesday was Election Day, where voters got to express their opinions on many issues. Though perhaps the one that drew the most attention in this area was Houston‚Äôs Proposition 1, Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, also known as HERO. The goal of this piece of legislation was to protect individuals from discrimination based on sexual orientation, race, age, military status, disability and several other categories.
However, this proposition became most known for its controversial proposal that transgender people be able to use whichever bathroom in which they feel most comfortable.
With a proposition as contentious as HERO, voter turnout was expected to be higher than usual, and it was. Unfortunately for HERO supporters, voters turned out en masse to overwhelmingly defeat the proposition, 61 percent to 39 percent.
Many conservative groups fought hard against this proposition, turning it into a fight to keep men out of women‚Äôs bathrooms. They ran a very dramatic commercial showing a man waiting on a young girl in the bathroom, warning that this proposition would allow sexual predators into areas where women are supposed to feel safe. To some extent, they had a point. But they made their point based on fear rather than on facts.
Pitting a defenseless young girl against a hardened sexual predator in their most notorious ad fed fears that girls would be victimized should this legislation pass. It is that fear that spurred many voters to show up at the polls to cast their votes against it. Whether this is the right move for Houston has yet to be seen, but I have a sense that the fight is not yet over.
In this day and age, sexual orientation and gender identities are things that all governmental bodies will have to address sooner or later. Whether or not one agrees with these people‚Äôs orientations (or ‚Äúlifestyle choices‚Äù), doesn‚Äôt mean they should be overlooked. While I agree men shouldn‚Äôt be allowed in women‚Äôs bathrooms, there are solutions that would work for both sides of the issue, such as unisex bathrooms. However, it appears people would rather keep the fight going than come to any sort of compromise.
The tensions between those on both sides of this issue are extremely high, and it appears they will stay that way for some time.
When are we going to stop treating each other as less than human, and start realizing we‚Äôre all human beings? We all have the same feelings and the same rights. We should be working together to better our community for all of us rather than seeking to negatively affect those with whom we disagree.
No one group has the right to trample on the rights of others.
This works both ways. It‚Äôs only by coming together and finding a solution that works for both sides that these issues, and the animosity associated with them, will die down.

Headline Text: GBU: Motorcycle crashes, the fear factor
Article Text:
The Good: Child sex abuser captured
A La Marque man convicted of sexually assaulting a young girl skipped town after being allowed to stay out on bond on Thursday.
Billy Wayne Atwood Jr., 37, was taken into custody and was being held in the Liberty County Jail, a jail official confirmed Saturday. Atwood went missing Friday after failing to appear in court for sentencing. During his absence, the jury sentenced him to life in prison, according to the Galveston County District Attorney‚Äôs Office. Prosecutors had requested Atwood, who was free on bond, be booked into jail after being found guilty. Judge David Garner denied the request.
Michael A. Smith: It‚Äôs easy to second guess the judge on this one. But he was obligated to walk a fine line between conflicting demands ‚Äî the need to keep the convicted incarcerated and the constitutional right to bond.
Kimberly Worner: What was Mr. Atwood thinking? They are going to come after you ‚Äî even if you are handed a ‚Äòget out of jail free‚Äô card ‚Äî and they are going to catch you. His capture is a nice piece of police work.
The Bad: Motorcycle fatalities
The overall number of crashes involving motorcycles in Galveston County is down compared to past years, but accidents resulting in fatalities and incapacitating injuries remain consistent, according to the Texas Department of Transportation.
That was good news as the 14th annual Lone Star Rally rolled into town. But the good news didn‚Äôt last long. A motorcycle crash on Thursday left a Seabrook man dead and his wife critically injured. No other deaths have been reported as of Saturday. And while the decline in the overall number is positive, University of Texas at Austin Professor Kara Kockelman reminded us that there is still work to be done in reducing serious crashes.
Smith: Given the weather, it‚Äôs noteworthy that there were so few bad accidents this year.
Worner: Riders should always wear a helmet, never drink and ride and take a motorcycle safety course every couple of years. Even experienced riders can use a safety reminder from time to time. In fact, they need it more because as you become comfortable with riding there is a tendency to become overconfident.
The Ugly:
Houston Equal Rights Ordinance defeat
On Tuesday voters in Houston soundly rejected the city‚Äôs equal rights ordinance in a heated political contest that caught the attention of the nation and sparked impassioned debate about social issues, especially rights for gay and transgender individuals. The ordinance would have applied to businesses that serve the public, such as restaurants and hotels, private employers, housing, city employment and city contracting. It would have allowed residents to file a complaint if they felt they had been discriminated against based on protected categories. Religious institutions would have been exempt. Violators would have faced fines up to $5,000.
Smith: It‚Äôs clear that voters in Houston weren‚Äôt ready for everything the ordinance proposed. Supporters should recall that progress is a process, scale the law back some and take another run at it.
  Worner: Once again the opposition played the fear card and they did a mighty good job at it. They turned the whole debate into pedophiles having access to little girls in the restroom. Give me a break. It‚Äôs time that we stop discriminating because we can‚Äôt be bothered with trying to understand an alternative lifestyle.
‚Äî Editorial staff

Headline Text: Kernels of thought on building wealth
Article Text:
Dear Editor:
A farmer gave me the philosophy of the corn on how people get rich in America. A kernel of corn is planted into the ground, where it grows and produces an ear that has a hundred kernels on it. Some kernels are used but others are saved and planted. How many kernels that are saved and planted could give you a thousand kernels?
This philosophy can be seen with immigrants that come to the United States. Many work hard to have an existence living but invest in leaving their children in a better situation than they were by educating them, creating a business or asset that they can use to build wealth. Those children become the middle class. If those children use the same philosophy as their parents their children will become the rich in America. It is very seldom that in one generation you become rich.
An example are the boat people of Vietnam. They came to the Unites States and many settled in New Orleans.
For about 15 years they worked in the hot sun of New Orleans mowing grass and any menial jobs. They invested their time and money educating their kids. Those children now are lawyers, doctors and business owners and have become wealthy. They take care of the parents. They became wealthy in two generations because of planning and investing.
If any generation decides to use up all of the assets the net generation must start over again with existence living and trying to give something to their children to use as seed money to improve their existence. If each generation uses up all of their assets they will be trapped in existence living.
The Obama administration and most Democratic legislators want to take away the seed money by supporting the death taxes. This money could be placed into improving people‚Äôs lives who work hard and plan for the future. The policies that they have in place now give the incentive to spend it all until everyone is back to existence living. We pay taxes all of our lives and now they wish to tax us when we are dead. If this tax is not removed the philosophy of the corn will cease to exist.
If we continue to believe in the Democratic policies and their taking of wealth to create equity and fairness in a couple of more generations everyone will be equally poor.
Outrageous federal intrusion into locker room Harold Horstmann Lohman
Dear Editor:
A Nov. 3 article by Ben Shipiro: ‚ÄúFeds Rule to Force High School Girls to Undress Next to Naked Boys Who Think They‚Äôre Girls‚Äù ( www.breitbart.www.breitbart.com/big-government/2015/11/03/feds-ruleforce- high-school-girls-undress-next-naked-boys-think- theyre-girls/).
Quotes from the article: ‚ÄúOn Monday, the federal government declared itself fit for the madhouse by mandating that a Chicago high school allow a full biological male into the girls‚Äô locker room for all purposes, including nudity. This biological male, the feds determined, was different because he thinks he is a female.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe U.S. Department of Education‚Äôs Office for Civil Rights spent almost two years checking out the Township High School District 211 because of the transgender ‚Äúgirl.‚Äù He filed a complaint with the feds in 2013 after the school refused ‚Äúunrestricted access‚Äù to the girls‚Äô locker room. The district eventually agreed to allow the boy into the girls‚Äô room so long as he used a privacy curtain while disrobing.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt good enough. The feds determined that this still constituted discrimination.
‚ÄúWhy? As John Knight, director of the alphabet-soup LGBT and AIDS Project at the ACLU, stated, this was ‚Äúblatant discrimination.‚Äù Perhaps the district does not see ‚Äúher‚Äù as a ‚Äúgirl‚Äù because ‚Äúshe‚Äù is not a she, a her, or a girl. Nonetheless, the Office for Civil Rights agreed, with Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights Catherine Lhamon averring: All students deserve the opportunity to participate equally in school programs and activities ‚Äî this is a basic civil right. Unfortunately, Township High School District 211 is not following the law because the district continues to deny a female student the right to use the girls‚Äô locker room.‚Äù
The following article provides a glimmer of hope at least until Obama‚Äôs Justice Dept. takes over our schools like they have our police departments. A quote from a Nov. 3 article by Katherine Driessen:
‚ÄúHouston Equal Rights Ordinance fails by wide margin‚Äù ( www.chron.com/politics/election/local/article/HERO-results-6608562.). ‚ÄúThe hotly contested election has spurred national attention, drawing comment from the White House and the state‚Äôs top officials. Largely conservative opponents of the law allege that it would allow men dressed as women, including sexual predators, to enter women‚Äôs restrooms.‚Äù
Why don‚Äôt we hear about this issue from our ‚Äúdriveby‚Äù media? Could it be complicity in the promotion of these outrageous liberal culture destroying issues?

beyoncEÃÅ miffed some members of the LGBT community in her hometown of Houston. Activist Carlos Maza claims he reached out to the singer's camp in August after learning the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance would be up for public vote this month. Local supporters created a hashtag, #BeyBeAHero, to entice her to get involved, which didn't happen. Maza blogged: "It wouldn't have taken more than a single Instagram post . . . She would have inserted herself as a real, active ally, proving her support for the LGBT community is more than mere lip service." President Obama supported the law and Hillary Rodham Clinton tweeted her support. But voters rejected it at the polls on Tuesday.

Headline Text: Commentary - Before the next vote, pro-HERO folks need their own slogan
Article Text:
Read more from this award-winning columnist at HoustonChronicle.com/Falkenberg
Two days after Houston's HERO went down in flames at the polls, I found myself at an education nonprofit fundraiser, where I had just given a speech, talking to a man who had opposed the city's equal rights ordinance.
He seemed to be a nice guy - educated, compassionate. He didn't give off any homophobic vibes. He said he believed the ordinance was unnecessary since it covered people who already enjoyed federal anti-discrimination protections.
I said something like, "So, I guess you didn't buy that whole argument that you shouldn't have to file an expensive, lengthy federal lawsuit to fight discrimination?"
He paused for a second.
"I hadn't heard that argument," he said.
The moment solidified my feeling that, despite national perceptions of Houston after the vote, HERO didn't fail because a large share of us hate gay and transgender people, to whom the ordinance extended protections.
That may be the reason people like Dr. Steven Hotze launched the anti-HERO "Campaign for Houston," just as he did the "straight slate" 30 years before. His motivation is fighting the "cesspools" of homosexuality, or the "homo-fascists," as he calls gay rights advocates.
He and his ilk are always thirsting for the next battle in the culture wars. And they won one with HERO. It helped that only 27 percent of registered Houston voters cast ballots.
There are plenty of theories for why the pro-HERO group Houston Unites failed to defend the ordinance: it didn't have enough time to rally its base. Annise Parker, Houston's first openly gay mayor, became the face of HERO, thereby keeping the focus on gay rights rather than the rights of everybody.
Then, of course, rather than answering their opponents' ugliness with more ugliness, HERO advocates mostly took the high road in TV ads. The high road led to a dead end.
"The morning after, I was wishing we'd run one that said 'lie, lie, lie!' " said Terri Burke, director of the ACLU of Texas. The biggest problem was messaging.
The anti-HERO folks seized on the most vulnerable part of the ordinance - the fact that it protected transgender Houstonians' right to use the public bathroom of their choice - and didn't let go.
"They took that small zone of discomfort, magnified it 100 times, and focused all their energy on that part of the ordinance," said Mark Jones, political science professor at Rice University.
They took an asinine, misleading phrase and repeated it over and over: "No men in women's bathrooms." 'Effective' lies
It was so stupid, it was brilliant.
Jones likened it to the tactic used by social conservatives in their battle to limit abortion access to Texas women. They repeat incessantly that the restrictive laws aren't really about reducing abortion; they're about "protecting women's health."
That claim is untrue, too, as nonpartisan medical experts have testified. I asked Jones if lies have become acceptable in politics as long as you repeat them enough.
"It definitely was effective," Jones said of the anti-HERO campaign, and left it at that.
Then I got to thinking. Why can't equality be simple, too? Why can't an ordinance that really was about American values - freedom from discrimination for 15 different groups of Houstonians - be boiled down to one catchy phrase?
Considering we'll be back at the drawing board next year with a new mayor and a new ordinance, I'll leave you with a few slogans supporters can repeat until they're blue in the face or until voters understand what the damn thing does - whichever comes sooner.
"It's about the Super Bowl, not the toilet bowl!"
Houston is the largest city in the country without a comprehensive anti-discrimination ordinance. That distinction undermines our "world-class" status and suggests we're nothing more than a backwater town. As the folks at the Greater Houston Partnership understood when they endorsed HERO, we need it to compete for conventions, corporate relocations, and, yes, major sporting events.
"Bigotry is bad for business."
Anybody disagree?
"Kick the feds out of our bathrooms!"
Go ahead! Tap into that anti-Washington fervor. Why force Houstonians with discrimination claims to make their cases in federal court? We're Texans. We don't need the feds to settle our disputes.
"Keep bathroom stalking illegal!"
True motivations
Nothing about the HERO ordinance changed a decades-old ordinance banning anyone from entering a restroom to disturb others.
"Make #BlackLivesMatter even more."
During the brief time HERO was in effect, city officials say most of the claims involved racial discrimination.
Here's another good one - "We just need to pee." That's a recent rallying cry of transgender Americans that went viral on Twitter and pretty much sums up their true motivations here.
It's been a long, painful campaign. But another campaign for another version of the ordinance is around the corner. It will be led by our new mayor, to be decided in a runoff between Sylvester Turner and Bill King.
Until then, I'll leave you with this thought: HERO. It's not about the potty. It's not about the potty.
It's not about ...
