Headline Text: Houston equal rights ordinance getting trounced in early returns
Article Text:
With early voting results in, Houston‚Äôs proposed ordinance to establish protections from discrimination for gay and transgender residents and several other classes was behind in the polls by a significant margin.
As the polls closed on Tuesday, early voting figures showed 63 percent of more than 130,000 Houston voters who cast ballots early voted against the measure. The embattled ordinance, better known as HERO, would make it illegal to discriminate against someone based on 15 different ‚Äúprotected characteristics,‚Äù including sex, race, religion, sexual orientation and gender identity.
Ordinance supporters say it‚Äôs intended to protect all Houstonians from discrimination and align Houston with other major cities that have similar measures. But opponents have zeroed in on the gender identity protection, which they argue would allow sexual predators to go into women‚Äôs bathrooms.
With the Houston vote garnering national attention, a loss for HERO supporters would come after a tumultuous year and half since the ordinance was first passed by the Houston City Council in May 2014.
Almost immediately, conservative activists and pastors began collecting signatures to petition a referendum or repeal of the ordinance. City officials later ruled that they hadn‚Äôt collected enough signatures, prompting a lawsuit from the opponents.
The ordinance had been in effect for about three months when it was put on hold as the legal challenge made its way through the courts. In April, a state district judge ruled in favor of the city, saying opponents of the ordinance had not gathered enough valid signatures.
The case went to the Texas Supreme Court, which in July told the city council it had to consider a valid referendum petition and repeal the ordinance or put it up for public vote.
As early voting began two weeks ago, Republican state leaders, including Gov. Greg Abbott and Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, lent their political muscle to the campaign opposing the ordinance. More recently, the Obama administration and national figures including Democratic presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders voiced support for the measure.
Statewide implications
But as the first big LGBT fight since the U.S. Supreme Court legalized same-sex marriage in June, the Houston vote could prove to be a referendum on the Texas gay rights movement, which has pivoted to discrimination protections since the Supreme Court win.
Texas is one of 28 states without statewide laws prohibiting discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity. Democrats‚Äô inability to pass a statewide nondiscrimination measure out of the Republican-controlled Legislature has left the state with a patchwork of protections across the state.
Including the Houston council‚Äôs 2014 vote on HERO, nine Texas cities with a population of more than 100,000 have passed nondiscrimination rules or legislation.
For at least a decade, Fort Worth, Dallas and Austin have counted among cities with ordinances offering LGBT residents some degree of protection against discrimination in employment, housing and other public areas like buses and restaurants. San Antonio and Plano joined that list in 2014.

Headline Text: What to watch for around the country on Election Day 2015 ‚Äî VIDEO
Article Text:
Even as Americans remain transfixed by Donald Trump and the feisty presidential contest that won't actually be decided for another 12 months, Election Day this year arrived Tuesday with plenty at stake.
Voters across the country are heading to the polls to make their picks in local elections, a couple of governors' races, and on dozens of important ‚Äî and sometimes quirky ‚Äî ballot measures in the off-year election.
In Kentucky, the closely fought battle for governor in one of 2015's most-watched contests pits wealthy tea party favorite Matt Bevin, who unsuccessfully took on Sen. Mitch McConnell, against Democratic Attorney General Jack Conway for the open seat. (McConnell is now backing Bevin.)
In Mississippi, incumbent Republican Gov. Phil Bryant looks set to win another term, although the contest has been pushed to the background by a clash over a constitutional amendment that would allow voters to sue the state to boost funding for public schools. In Virginia, Democrats are seeking to capture the state Senate, which Republicans now hold narrowly. And there are notable elections for mayor in Philadelphia, Houston and Salt Lake City.
Meanwhile, heated debate surrounding an effort to defeat a LGBT rights law in Texas could become hot fodder for the presidential candidates, a billionaire is backing a major effort to protect Big Game, and voters in Seattle are weighing a unique answer to the problem of money in politics.
Here are some of the issues being decided Tuesday and that are sure to be dissected in the aftermath as pols, pundits and the press look for clues to what the results all mean in the 2016 contest for the White House:
Houston: LGBT rights on the line down south
"No Men In Women's Bathrooms" ‚Äî that's the rallying cry from opponents of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance (HERO), a law passed by the city last year to protect lesbian, gay and transgender people.
On Tuesday afternoon, the Clinton campaign joined the fray, responding to a baiting tweet from Texas Gov. Greg Abbott, a Republican, that urged Houston to "vote Texas values, not @HillaryClinton values."
Abbott, the Clinton campaign shot back, is "right about one thing: equality is one of Hillary's values."
In recent months, the campaign to undo HERO has become a focal point for the right, which has spent millions and recruited an assortment of local celebrities to their cause, including former Houston Astros star outfielder Lance Berkman.
"My wife and I have four daughters," Berkman says in an ad paid for by the Campaign for Houston PAC, which is seeking to repeal HERO. "Proposition One would allow troubled men to enter women's public bathrooms, showers and locker rooms."
Supporters of the ordinance have bristled at the claim, calling it fear-mongering against transgender men and women.
Ohio: An ex-boy band star tunes up for legalizing pot
Nick Lachey, the onetime lead singer of 98 Degrees, is headlining again --- but the attraction is a little different this time around.
Lachey and a group of investors are behind ResponsibleOhio, a group that is pushing an initiative to legalize marijuana for recreational use in the Buckeye State. The amendment would permit anyone 21 and older to hold up to an ounce of pot for personal use. With a $50 license, they can house eight ounces of harvested pot and four plants. If passed, Ohio would become the most populous state to legalize pot.
"Ohio is my home," Lachey says over some breezy tunes in ad produced by the pro-legalization group, "and I care very deeply about the people here." He promises jobs, a "reinvigorated economy" and a safer state.
Also on the pot front, Colorado voters are deciding what they want to do with the millions in revenue raised from its sale -- return the funds to taxpayers or use it to pay for school construction and other things.
Seattle: Trying to make elections more "honest"
How would you like a coupon to spend on your favorite candidate?
That's what's on the table in Seattle with the "Honest Elections" referendum to diminish the influence of money in politics.
Backers of "Initiative 122" are seeking to radically remake how local campaigns are financed. Under the measure, voters would each be given $100 in "democracy vouchers" --- four each, at $25 per --- to be shelled out to the candidates of their choice.
It would also lower donation caps, ban contributions from corporations with significant city business interests, increase transparency and increase fines for electoral wrongdoing. Officials who leave office would also be required spend three years on the sidelines before becoming eligible to register as lobbyists.
Washington: A push to save endangered animals
This one's for Cecil the Lion, the big Zimbabwean cat killed in July by a dentist on safari from Minnesota.
This statewide ballot measure would criminalize "selling, purchasing, trading, or distributing certain animal species threatened with extinction," raising the bar beyond where laws already on the books in New York, New Jersey and California have previously gone to protect Big Game.
The measure is the brainchild of billionaire Paul Allen, a Microsoft co-founder, who has sunk millions of dollars of his own money into the campaign.
Opponents, including the "Legal Ivory Rights Coalition," say the proposal goes too far. "It's Not What They Say It Is!" blares the group's website, which warns that grandmas looking to pass along their "antique" ivory will be made into criminals.
Not complaining: Elephants and rhinoceroses -- often hunted for the ivory in their tusks and horns -- along with lions, tigers, leopards, cheetahs, marine turtles, and sharks that are among the threatened species that supporters say would be helped by the referendum.
Texas: The NRA is on the hunt
On the other hand, Texans with a taste for "hunting, fishing and harvesting" could get a constitutional boost on Tuesday, as the state goes to the polls to weigh in on its Proposition 6.
The amendment would make it more difficult for activist groups to push through new legislation or regulations aimed at expanding protections for animals or delicate ecosystems. The NRA is leading the way in lobbying for its passage with groups like the "Dallas Safari Club" also boosting the cause.
If the measure passes, Texas would become the 19th state to guarantee its residents a constitutional right to hunt and kill almost all manner of wildlife and the freedom catch and "bag" as many fish as they can haul back home.
San Francisco: Airbnb could get the bootWill Airbnb be kicked out of its hometown?
The vanguard of the so-called "sharing economy" is locking horns with the left again, as affordable housing activists in increasingly unaffordable San Francisco are angling to deal a blow to Airbnb.
This measure would impose a citywide ban on what's known as "short-term rentals." If approved, it would effectively cripple Airbnb, the profitable hub for homeowners and renters who profit from leasing out rooms or houses to travelers for, in most cases, below market rates.
The problem: Rent and home sale prices in San Francisco are skyrocketing, along with evictions, and critics say the fault lies, at least in part, with wealthy buyers who purchase housing for the express purpose of leasing it out for a quick profit.

The opposition group, which argues that its standing up for "women's privacy," has also aired ads featuring former Houston Astros baseball player Lance Berkman, who is urging local voters to reject the measure.
Meanwhile, national LGBT groups like the Human Rights Campaign have dispatched employees to the city to fight for passage. The White House has offered verbal support, as have Democratic presidential candidates Hillary Rodham Clinton and Bernie Sanders.

Headline Text: Abbott, Clinton, celebrities join Twitter fight over Houston gay rights ordinance
Article Text:
AUSTIN ‚ÄìTexas Gov. Greg Abbott and Democratic presidential contender Hillary Clinton clashed on Twitter over whether Houston voters on Tuesday should reject or uphold a city ordinance that bans discrimination in jobs, housing and public accommodations that is based on, among other things, sexual orientation and gender identity.
The so-called Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, or HERO, has attracted national attention and a dollar-fueled TV ad blitz.
HOUSTON: Vote Texas values, not @HillaryClinton values. Vote NO on City of Houston Proposition 1. No men in women's bathrooms.
- Greg Abbott (@GregAbbott_TX) November 2, 2015
Social conservatives such as Abbott, Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick and Family Research Council president Tony Perkins call it the ‚Äúbathroom ordinance.‚Äù They say transgender people could cause problems ‚Äî especially if someone born a man who has a sex change uses the women‚Äôs restroom.
But it‚Äôs about more than potty security, Perkins blogged. He called it a ‚Äúradical measure, which punishes people who refuse to celebrate transgenderism and homosexuality with massive fines.‚Äù Perkins called the ordinance part of a ‚Äúnationwide march to silence religious liberty in America.‚Äù
Clinton, her opponent Bernie Sanders and Houston Mayor Annise Parker have endorsed retention of HERO, which has been the subject of a protracted legal and political battle. They say it simply would bring long-overdue, equal treatment to gays, lesbians, bisexuals and transgender people. Supporters have deplored opponents‚Äô many TV commercials about bathrooms as attempts to scare Houstonians and exploit many people‚Äôs lack of familiarity with transgender people and their struggles.
.@GregAbbott_TX is right about one thing: equality is one of Hillary's values. Houston‚Äîvote #YesOnProp1 today. https://t.co/AI0IWnqhB7
- Hillary Clinton (@HillaryClinton) November 3, 2015
Famous athletes and movie stars have lent their names to the opposing sides.
Weighing in against the ordinance was former Houston Astro and Texas Ranger slugger Lance Berkman. Once known as ‚ÄúThe Big Puma,‚Äù he said he‚Äôs now speaking as the concerned father of four daughters. Berkman taped a TV ad urging rejection of the ordinance, and social conservative activist Jonathan Saenz of Texas Values tweeted about it:
#Houston baseball #HERO Lance Berkman says vote "no" on Houston bathroom ordinance local prop 1, https://t.co/Klm1YZW4wK #txlege #tcot
- Jonathan Saenz (@jonathansaenzTX) November 3, 2015
On the opposing side, Oscar-winning actress Sally Field appeared with supporters of the ordinance at a press conference in Houston late last week. Here‚Äôs a photo shared on Twitter by gay rights activist Chuck Smith of Equality Texas, who regularly does battle with Saenz‚Äô group at the Texas Capitol:
Sally Field: "A vote for #HERO is a vote to treat everyone fairly and equally under the law." #YesOnProp1 pic.twitter.com/oGD4NI9G3p - Houston Unites (@Houston_Unites) October 29, 2015
Big corporations with a presence in Houston, such as Apple, Hewlett Packard, General Electric and Dow Chemical have urged support for the ordinance. They warn that a ‚Äúno‚Äù vote would take down protections for racial and religious minorities as well as for LGBT residents. Also, Houston would be the nation‚Äôs largest city without an anti-discrimination ordinance protecting all of those subcategories of the population.
In a statement, Apple said voting ‚Äúyes‚Äù would send ‚Äúa clear message that Houston is focused on a future of inclusion, diversity and continued prosperity.‚Äù
As my colleague Bobby Blanchard noted here Monday, participation in early voting in Harris County topped all other urban counties. Experts said as many as 250,000 Houston residents might cast ballots in an election that includes not just the culture war battle but a hotly contested mayor‚Äôs race. In Houston‚Äôs last open-seat mayor‚Äôs race six years ago, only about 178,000 people voted.
Political scientists don‚Äôt know whether the choice of starkly different mayoral candidates ‚Äî different in race and ideology ‚Äî or the hubbub about gay rights and bathrooms drove the bigger turnout in Houston. You can read about the experts clashing in this story by Houston Chronicle reporters Rebecca Elliott and Mike Morris.

Headline Text: Election 2015 - HERO the big draw in today's vote - Crowded race for new mayor is overshadowed by emotional fight over equal rights ordinance
Article Text:
Here's what you need to know ...
WHEN Polls are open from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m.
WHERE To find sample ballots, your precinct and poll location, visit the website of your local county clerk's office. Find the links here: Chron.com/ballots
BEFORE YOU HEAD TO THE POLLS
Check out the Houston Chronicle's election page for
candidate profiles, questionnaires and stories about items
on the ballot. HoustonChronicle.com/Election2015
PROBLEMS
For more information or to report a voting problem in Houston or Harris County, call the Harris County Clerk's Elections Division at 713-755-6965.
RESULTS
Visit Chron.com for up-to-the-minute election results.
Despite more than $10 million invested in the Houston mayor's race, it is the city's polarizing equal rights ordinance that appears to be driving voters to the polls, a pattern that is expected to continue today as residents cast ballots for city and school races, county bonds and state constitutional amendments.
Approximately 130,000 city voters cast early ballots, more than doubling pre-Election Day turnout in Houston's last open-seat mayor's race six years ago.
Political observers largely attributed that uptick to interest in the law known as HERO, which has attracted national endorsements and a series of six-figure checks.
"The mayor's race never really took off," local Democratic strategist Keir Murray said. "That leads me to conclude that it's HERO that's been doing it."
A broad field of experienced candidates awash in early money brought expectations of a high-profile fight to succeed term-limited Mayor Annise Parker.
Polls consistently have placed state Rep. Sylvester Turner in an expected December runoff. Former Kemah mayor and businessman Bill King and former Harris County sheriff Adrian Garcia are expected to fight it out for the second runoff spot. Other top-tier candidates in the 13-person field include City Councilman Steve Costello, former Congressman Chris Bell and former city attorney Ben Hall.
During their budding campaigns, the half-dozen major candidates focused on fundraising as they appeared at a series of special- interest forums, collectively harping on the need for infrastructure improvements, pension reform and investment in public safety.
Just as the race was ramping up, however, the Texas Supreme Court in late July ordered the city to repeal the nondiscrimination ordinance or put it to voters on the November ballot. City Council voted to place it on Tuesday's ballot two weeks later.
Proposition 1 asks voters if they favor an ordinance that "prohibits discrimination in city employment and city services, city contracts, public accommodations, private employment, and housing based on an individual's sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, familial status, marital status, military status, religion, disability, sexual orientation, genetic information, gender identity, or pregnancy."
Opponents have seized on the ordinance's protections for gay and transgender residents, alleging it would allow men, including sexual predators, into women's restrooms. Supporters call that preposterous and an attempt to capitalize on public ignorance about transgender residents.
While Election Day voters and early voters typically hail from different sections of the electorate, this fall's early tallies show a clear trend of robust turnout in conservative strongholds and solid numbers in black neighborhoods.
Kingwood, in particular, has posted high vote totals, as have Clear Lake and the conservative west side corridor south of Interstate 10 and north of Westheimer, which is council District G.
These GOP bastions are followed by largely African-American areas in the south and southwest, near Fort Bend County, and in the northwest, near mayoral front-runner Turner's native neighborhood of Acres Homes.
"HERO would seem to be the most likely explanation for the increase in turnout, followed by the larger number of viable candidates and the greater amount of money spent on advertising and voter outreach," Rice University political scientist Mark Jones said.
Ideological diversity
Texas Southern University political scientist Michael Adams offered a different view, suggesting the racial and ideological diversity of this year's mayoral pool also could explain the uptick in turnout.
"This is the first time since 2003 that we've seen this type of split based upon what I call politics and race," Adams said. "What seems to be driving the turnout seems to be that you have these choices that are based on race and also ... ideology."
In light of higher-than-expected early voting, political scientists are now projecting as many as 250,000 city voters will cast ballots. More than 985,000 Houston residents are registered.
Groups on both sides of the HERO fight said they will be working until the polls close to keep up the momentum of early voting.
Jared Woodfill, spokesman for the anti-HERO Campaign for Houston, said Election Day will see his forces working the phones to encourage voters to head to the polls and deploy teams at poling locations with signs and push cards, in addition to ongoing TV and radio ads.
A supportive group called the Black Robe Regiment out of San Antonio distributed packets of information to at least 400 local churches Sunday in the hopes of encouraging the pastors to preach against the ordinance. That effort was bolstered on Monday by high-profile statements against the ordinance from Gov. Greg Abbott and Attorney General Ken Paxton.
"We've had a high turnout for early voting, but we want to finish strong and make sure there's no voter left behind," Woodfill said. "It's important that we push, push, push all day to 7 p.m. We had to fight to earn the right to vote, and tomorrow we'll finally be crossing the finish line of this marathon we started two years ago." Richard Carlbom, spokesman for the pro- HERO group Houston Unites, was equally confident, saying hundreds of volunteers will hit the streets at 6 a.m., going door to door and working phones. Carlbom said the campaign also will staff several dozen precincts with poll watchers, and have a team of volunteers and faith leaders ready to deploy to polling locations should tensions arise.
"We plan on canvassing large parts of the city to turn out every last voter we can find who wants to vote yes on Prop. 1, and really pushing for a very large turnout on Election Day," Carlbom said. "One of the things we've known from the beginning is voters who haven't voted consistently in a municipal election are more likely to be with us. And we know our turnout operation will be stronger than theirs. We're going to be operating on all cylinders tomorrow."
Last week, the ordinance picked up support from Democratic presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, as well as actors and Fortune 500 companies.
Advocacy groups wrote the largest checks on HERO's behalf, which included more than $619,000 from the Human Rights Campaign, more than $562,000 from the ACLU of Texas, more than $346,000 from the Washington, D.C.-based Freedom for All Americans, and $250,000 from both the New York-based American Unity Fund and Colorado's Gill Action.
Texans contribute
Opponents, meanwhile, drew top dollars from individual Texas donors, including more than $206,000 from Houston real estate executive Allen Hartman, more than $146,000 from GOP kingmaker Dr. Steve Hotze, $26,000 from the committee to support Harris County Commissioner Jack Cagle, and $25,000 each from Houston attorney Jack Little, Kingwood executive Paul Sarvadi and Schulenburg's Ralph Schmidt.
The Houston-based Trinity Equity Partners I, LP also chipped in $50,000. These totals include in-kind donations and loans.
"It's a much more emotional and, in some ways, given the ads that have been run, a sensational issue," Murray said of HERO, comparing it to the mayor's race.
rebecca.elliott@chron.com mike.morris@chron.com ...
More about Election Day WHAT'S AT STAKE
Houston voters will cast ballots for mayor, City Council and city controller, as well a charter amendment on term limits and a referendum on the city's anti-discrimination ordinance known as HERO. City voters also will cast ballots for seats on the Houston ISD board and Houston Community College Board of Trustees.
Harris County voters will weigh in on four bond issues, totaling $848 million for roads, parks, flood control and veterinary services.
Voters also will decide seven propositions to amend the Texas Constitution, including one to increase the public school homestead exemption from $15,000 to $25,000. For more information on the propositions, visit: Chron.com/Props
Surrounding counties, suburbs and school districts are seeking approval for a host of bond issues, including a $280 million road bond in Montgomery County and a $487 million bond package for Conroe ISD. Baytown voters will decide 24 propositions.
WHAT YOU NEED TO VOTE Under Texas' voter ID law, residents will need to present one of seven forms of identification to enter the voting booth. Acceptable IDs include:
A Texas driver's license
A Texas Election Identification Certificate
A Texas personal identification card issued by the Department of Public Safety
A Texas concealed handgun license
A U.S. military identification card with photo
A U.S. citizenship certificate with photo
A U.S. passport. With exception of the U.S. citizenship certificate, all forms of photo ID must be valid or expired for less than 60 days.

Headline Text: Marijuana, transgender issue top ballot initiatives in low-key election
Article Text:
An unconventional marijuana legalization question in Ohio and a transgender bathroom measure in Houston are drawing the lion's share of attention in an otherwise low-key election for ballot initiatives.
Ohio's Issue 3 would legalize recreational marijuana for adults 21 and older, but with a twist: the measure would also create a cultivation monopoly for 10 property owners who are also heavy donors to the campaign.
Even some pot aficionados say they are uncomfortable with the preferential treatment embedded in Issue 3, which if passed would make Ohio the fifth state to legalize recreational marijuana, and the only state to do so without first approving a medical market.
Foes of the measure have swung back with Issue 2, a measure placed on the ballot by the state legislature that would nullify Issue 3 and also ban ballot measures that promote monopolies. A legal battle is expected to ensue if both proposed constitutional amendments pass.
With that in mind, the Cincinnati Enquirer advised voters in an Oct. 18 editorial to reject both initiatives, saying that "Ohioans don't need Issue 2 to save ourselves from Issue 3, "while the Cleveland Plain Dealer urged a "no" vote on Issue 3, calling it "weed greed."
"Even pro-legalization groups such as the Green and Libertarian parties of Ohio oppose Issue 3, saying it represents crony capitalism," said the Plain Dealer in an Oct. 29 editorial.
So far neither measure is polling over 50 percent, according to a University of Akron survey released Oct. 21, which found voters in favor of Issue 2 by a margin of 40 to 28 percentage points and split on Issue 3 at 46 to 46 percent.
"One thing is for sure ‚Äî all eyes are on Ohio this week," said Oregon activist Johnny Green on the Weed Blog.
Mason Tvert, spokesman for the Marijuana Policy Project and architect of Colorado's successful 2012 recreational marijuana campaign, said his organization has not taken a position on Issue 3.
"We support the measure to the extent that it would end marijuana prohibition and replace it with a system in which marijuana is regulated similarly to alcohol, but it is up to voters to decide whether the system it proposes is the right one for Ohio," said Mr. Tvert.
In Houston, gay rights groups have pumped millions into passing Proposition 1, an equal rights ordinance that would make it illegal to stop transgender people from using public restrooms that correspond with their gender identity.
The opposition, led by Houston pastors and conservative groups, has scored with alarming ads saying that the ordinance would allow male sex predators to use women's restrooms, showers and locker rooms. One television spot shows a man cornering a little girl in a bathroom stall.
Those in support of Proposition 1 have argued that the measure does nothing to change laws that prohibit indecent exposure, harassment and assaults. Instead, proponents have framed the measure as an anti-discrimination ordinance that would protect a broad class of people, including veterans and pregnant women.
Companies like Apple and Hewlett-Packard "know that Houston needs an equal rights ordinance in order to attract and retain top talent ‚Äî and send a message that the city is truly open for business to everyone," according to the pro-Proposition 1 campaign Houston Unites.
Meanwhile, the Campaign for Houston, which opposes Proposition 1, received a shoutout Monday from Texas Gov. Greg Abbott, who urged Houstonians to vote "no" on the measure.
"No men in women's bathrooms," said Mr. Abbott, a Republican on Twitter.

Headline Text: Houston equal rights measure in hands of voters
Article Text:
HOUSTON (AP) ‚Äî An ordinance that would establish nondiscrimination protections for gay and transgender people in Houston is in the hands of voters after a nearly 18-month battle that spawned rallies, legal fights and accusations of both religious intolerance and demonization of the LGBT community.
Houston residents were voting Tuesday on the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, which supporters say would not only offer increased protections for gay and transgender people, but would also provide a wealth of protections against discrimination based on sex, race, age, religion and other categories.
"I voted yes because I believe (in) opportunity for all individuals and I believe that the people that vote no are going to be on the wrong side of history," Anna Bakken said Tuesday outside a polling site.
Opponents of the ordinance planned to reach out to voters Tuesday at polling locations and through social media, phones calls and emails, said Jared Woodfill, a spokesman for Campaign for Houston.
Those against the ordinance, including a coalition of conservative pastors, have said it infringes on their religious beliefs regarding homosexuality. But in the months leading up to Tuesday's vote, opponents have focused their campaign on highlighting one part of the ordinance related to the use of public bathrooms by transgender men and women that opponents allege would open the door for sexual predators to go into women's restrooms.
"I don't know why anyone would think that men going into a women's bathroom or swimming pool or locker room would be a good idea," Susan Hunter, who voted against the ordinance, said Tuesday. "It's not safe and these people need to find another solution."
Democratic Houston Mayor Annise Parker, who is gay, and other supporters of the ordinance have called this "bathroom ordinance" strategy highly misleading and a scare tactic.
The ordinance was initially approved by the Houston City Council in May 2014 but a lawsuit to have residents vote on the measure eventually made it to the Texas Supreme Court, which in July ordered the city to either repeal the ordinance or put it on the ballot.
Tuesday's referendum has drawn attention from around the nation, with the measure getting high-profile endorsements last week from the White House, high-tech giant Apple and Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton. The ordinance also has received support from other members of Houston's religious community.
Woodfill said opponents of the ordinance have included a diverse group of individuals, including pastors from all denominations and local and state elected officials.
On Monday, Republican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott tweeted his support for opponents, saying, "HOUSTON: Vote Texas values, not @HillaryClinton values. Vote NO on City of Houston Proposition 1. No men in women's bathrooms."
Tuesday's outcome is considered uncertain, with one political expert believing the measure is leaning toward defeat.

Headline Text: What to watch for around the country on Election Day 2015 ‚Äî VIDEO
Article Text:
Even as Americans remain transfixed by Donald Trump and the feisty presidential contest that won't actually be decided for another 12 months, Election Day this year arrived Tuesday with plenty at stake.
Voters across the country are heading to the polls to make their picks in local elections, a couple of governors' races, and on dozens of important ‚Äî and sometimes quirky ‚Äî ballot measures in the off-year election.
In Kentucky, the closely fought battle for governor in one of 2015's most-watched contests pits wealthy tea party favorite Matt Bevin, who unsuccessfully took on Sen. Mitch McConnell, against Democratic Attorney General Jack Conway for the open seat. (McConnell is now backing Bevin.)
In Mississippi, incumbent Republican Gov. Phil Bryant looks set to win another term, although the contest has been pushed to the background by a clash over a constitutional amendment that would allow voters to sue the state to boost funding for public schools. In Virginia, Democrats are seeking to capture the state Senate, which Republicans now hold narrowly. And there are notable elections for mayor in Philadelphia, Houston and Salt Lake City.
Meanwhile, heated debate surrounding an effort to defeat a LGBT rights law in Texas could become hot fodder for the presidential candidates, a billionaire is backing a major effort to protect Big Game, and voters in Seattle are weighing a unique answer to the problem of money in politics.
Here are some of the issues being decided Tuesday and that are sure to be dissected in the aftermath as pols, pundits and the press look for clues to what the results all mean in the 2016 contest for the White House:
Houston: LGBT rights on the line down south
"No Men In Women's Bathrooms" ‚Äî that's the rallying cry from opponents of the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance (HERO), a law passed by the city last year to protect lesbian, gay and transgender people.
On Tuesday afternoon, the Clinton campaign joined the fray, responding to a baiting tweet from Texas Gov. Greg Abbott, a Republican, that urged Houston to "vote Texas values, not @HillaryClinton values."
Abbott, the Clinton campaign shot back, is "right about one thing: equality is one of Hillary's values."
In recent months, the campaign to undo HERO has become a focal point for the right, which has spent millions and recruited an assortment of local celebrities to their cause, including former Houston Astros star outfielder Lance Berkman.
"My wife and I have four daughters," Berkman says in an ad paid for by the Campaign for Houston PAC, which is seeking to repeal HERO. "Proposition One would allow troubled men to enter women's public bathrooms, showers and locker rooms."
Supporters of the ordinance have bristled at the claim, calling it fear-mongering against transgender men and women.
Ohio: An ex-boy band star tunes up for legalizing pot
Nick Lachey, the onetime lead singer of 98 Degrees, is headlining again --- but the attraction is a little different this time around.
Lachey and a group of investors are behind ResponsibleOhio, a group that is pushing an initiative to legalize marijuana for recreational use in the Buckeye State. The amendment would permit anyone 21 and older to hold up to an ounce of pot for personal use. With a $50 license, they can house eight ounces of harvested pot and four plants. If passed, Ohio would become the most populous state to legalize pot.
"Ohio is my home," Lachey says over some breezy tunes in ad produced by the pro-legalization group, "and I care very deeply about the people here." He promises jobs, a "reinvigorated economy" and a safer state.
Also on the pot front, Colorado voters are deciding what they want to do with the millions in revenue raised from its sale -- return the funds to taxpayers or use it to pay for school construction and other things.
Seattle: Trying to make elections more "honest"
How would you like a coupon to spend on your favorite candidate?
That's what's on the table in Seattle with the "Honest Elections" referendum to diminish the influence of money in politics.
Backers of "Initiative 122" are seeking to radically remake how local campaigns are financed. Under the measure, voters would each be given $100 in "democracy vouchers" --- four each, at $25 per --- to be shelled out to the candidates of their choice.
It would also lower donation caps, ban contributions from corporations with significant city business interests, increase transparency and increase fines for electoral wrongdoing. Officials who leave office would also be required spend three years on the sidelines before becoming eligible to register as lobbyists.
Washington: A push to save endangered animals
This one's for Cecil the Lion, the big Zimbabwean cat killed in July by a dentist on safari from Minnesota.
This statewide ballot measure would criminalize "selling, purchasing, trading, or distributing certain animal species threatened with extinction," raising the bar beyond where laws already on the books in New York, New Jersey and California have previously gone to protect Big Game.
The measure is the brainchild of billionaire Paul Allen, a Microsoft co-founder, who has sunk millions of dollars of his own money into the campaign.
Opponents, including the "Legal Ivory Rights Coalition," say the proposal goes too far. "It's Not What They Say It Is!" blares the group's website, which warns that grandmas looking to pass along their "antique" ivory will be made into criminals.
Not complaining: Elephants and rhinoceroses -- often hunted for the ivory in their tusks and horns -- along with lions, tigers, leopards, cheetahs, marine turtles, and sharks that are among the threatened species that supporters say would be helped by the referendum.
Texas: The NRA is on the hunt
On the other hand, Texans with a taste for "hunting, fishing and harvesting" could get a constitutional boost on Tuesday, as the state goes to the polls to weigh in on its Proposition 6.
The amendment would make it more difficult for activist groups to push through new legislation or regulations aimed at expanding protections for animals or delicate ecosystems. The NRA is leading the way in lobbying for its passage with groups like the "Dallas Safari Club" also boosting the cause.
If the measure passes, Texas would become the 19th state to guarantee its residents a constitutional right to hunt and kill almost all manner of wildlife and the freedom catch and "bag" as many fish as they can haul back home.
San Francisco: Airbnb could get the boot Will Airbnb be kicked out of its hometown?
The vanguard of the so-called "sharing economy" is locking horns with the left again, as affordable housing activists in increasingly unaffordable San Francisco are angling to deal a blow to Airbnb.
This measure would impose a citywide ban on what's known as "short-term rentals." If approved, it would effectively cripple Airbnb, the profitable hub for homeowners and renters who profit from leasing out rooms or houses to travelers for, in most cases, below market rates.
The problem: Rent and home sale prices in San Francisco are skyrocketing, along with evictions, and critics say the fault lies, at least in part, with wealthy buyers who purchase housing for the express purpose of leasing it out for a quick profit.

Headline Text: Marijuana, transgender issue top ballot initiatives in low-key election
Article Text:
An unconventional marijuana legalization question in Ohio and a transgender bathroom measure in Houston are drawing the lion's share of attention in an otherwise low-key election for ballot initiatives.
Ohio's Issue 3 would legalize recreational marijuana for adults 21 and older, but with a twist: the measure would also create a cultivation monopoly for 10 property owners who are also heavy donors to the campaign.
Even some pot aficionados say they are uncomfortable with the preferential treatment embedded in Issue 3, which if passed would make Ohio the fifth state to legalize recreational marijuana, and the only state to do so without first approving a medical market.
Foes of the measure have swung back with Issue 2, a measure placed on the ballot by the state legislature that would nullify Issue 3 and also ban ballot measures that promote monopolies. A legal battle is expected to ensue if both proposed constitutional amendments pass.
With that in mind, the Cincinnati Enquirer advised voters in an Oct. 18 editorial to reject both initiatives, saying that "Ohioans don't need Issue 2 to save ourselves from Issue 3, "while the Cleveland Plain Dealer urged a "no" vote on Issue 3, calling it "weed greed."
"Even pro-legalization groups such as the Green and Libertarian parties of Ohio oppose Issue 3, saying it represents crony capitalism," said the Plain Dealer in an Oct. 29 editorial.
So far neither measure is polling over 50 percent, according to a University of Akron survey released Oct. 21, which found voters in favor of Issue 2 by a margin of 40 to 28 percentage points and split on Issue 3 at 46 to 46 percent.
"One thing is for sure ‚Äî all eyes are on Ohio this week," said Oregon activist Johnny Green on the Weed Blog.
Mason Tvert, spokesman for the Marijuana Policy Project and architect of Colorado's successful 2012 recreational marijuana campaign, said his organization has not taken a position on Issue 3.
"We support the measure to the extent that it would end marijuana prohibition and replace it with a system in which marijuana is regulated similarly to alcohol, but it is up to voters to decide whether the system it proposes is the right one for Ohio," said Mr. Tvert.
In Houston, gay rights groups have pumped millions into passing Proposition 1, an equal rights ordinance that would make it illegal to stop transgender people from using public restrooms that correspond with their gender identity.
The opposition, led by Houston pastors and conservative groups, has scored with alarming ads saying that the ordinance would allow male sex predators to use women's restrooms, showers and locker rooms. One television spot shows a man cornering a little girl in a bathroom stall.
Those in support of Proposition 1 have argued that the measure does nothing to change laws that prohibit indecent exposure, harassment and assaults. Instead, proponents have framed the measure as an anti-discrimination ordinance that would protect a broad class of people, including veterans and pregnant women.
Companies like Apple and Hewlett-Packard "know that Houston needs an equal rights ordinance in order to attract and retain top talent ‚Äî and send a message that the city is truly open for business to everyone," according to the pro-Proposition 1 campaign Houston Unites.
Meanwhile, the Campaign for Houston, which opposes Proposition 1, received a shoutout Monday from Texas Gov. Greg Abbott, who urged Houstonians to vote "no" on the measure.
"No men in women's bathrooms," said Mr. Abbott, a Republican on Twitter.

Headline Text: Opponents reduce Houston equal rights ordinance to a dirty bathroom myth
Article Text:
It must be something in Houston‚Äôs water ‚Äì specifically running through the public restroom taps ‚Äì that interferes with the brain‚Äôs ability to process simple language.
There‚Äôs just no other explanation for the fact that thousands of voters will swarm the polls there Tuesday not only disagreeing on how they‚Äôll vote, but with a bizarre disconnect on what they‚Äôre even voting about.
Many people grasp that Houston‚Äôs Proposition 1 (Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, or HERO) is really a catch-up measure intended to bring the city into the modern era of basic rights protections. They will be voting on a broad non-discrimination ordinance, similar to the one we have had in Dallas for 13 years now with no ill-effects.
But some of our friends down in the Bayou City seem to earnestly believe that what they are voting on is this: UNISEX BATHROOMS. It‚Äôs a flashing alarm in their heads just like that, a scary red warning sign in all capital letters.
Apparently, when you take a routine civil-protections measure and feed it through the big anti-LGBT scarification machine what you get is the possibility that men might pee in the ladies room.
And not just any men, either. We‚Äôre talking about scary demented sex predator perverts, sharing the very same stalls with sweet little pig-tailed girls in their little plaid schoolgirl uniforms, or with modest elderly grandmas who use their lavender-scented hankies to avoid touching germy toilet handles with bare hands.
If that sounds like a creepy porn video, it‚Äôs because that‚Äôs what this is. It‚Äôs a stupid, sick fantasy cooked up by the same hysteria- mongers who think same-sex marriage is a plot to turn their kids gay, or that gender identity is something you put on like a pair of socks. It is a product of profound ignorance.
Rivals though we historically are, I feel a bit sorry for the large segment of the Houston population that has not lost their collective minds over this issue. All they want is to have the same common-sense protections as Dallas, Fort Worth, El Paso, San Antonio, countless other major American cities and nearly half the states in the U.S.
They want the same basic non-discrimination guidelines that many major employers, tour promoters and relocation consultants expect in the places they do business.
Houston‚Äôs proposed ordinance, which was adopted by the City Council last year ‚Äì but suspended pending Tuesday‚Äôs vote ‚Äì bars discrimination based on more than a dozen categories including race, age, religion, military status, and whether you‚Äôre pregnant. The idea is to make sure people don‚Äôt lose their jobs for being gay, or kept out of nightclubs because they‚Äôre old, or barred from pancake restaurants because they‚Äôre Muslim, or any of the other petty, idiotic slights that people impose against one another based on irrational bias and fear.
Almost all of that has been ignored, however, by HERO opponents. Instead, they homed in like laser-guided tracer bullets on just two of the categories on which discrimination is prohibited ‚Äì sexual orientation and gender identity. Then they took the entire discussion, quite literally, to the toilet.
‚ÄúNo Men In Women‚Äôs Bathrooms‚Äù! is the overwrought rallying cry around which opponents have gathered, like frightened cavemen huddled around the safety of the campfire. It‚Äôs funny, but it‚Äôs even more stupid. And stupid as it is, it‚Äôs yet more offensive.
An unpleasantly prurient anti-Prop 1 television ad takes these revolting fears considerably further than that. The black-and-white ad shows a menacing public restroom with leaky faucets and fizzing fluorescent lights. In comes a sweet little girl in ankle socks and patent-leather mary janes. Before she can modestly go about her business, a large male body looms into the frame, crowding the terrified child into the grimy stall.
How the basic American business of ensuring everybody receives a fair shake gets perverted into an image of a man crowding a little girl into a toilet stall is beyond my powers of invention, but it has clearly resonated with somebody. Astoundingly, some pollsters now believe this routine ordinance (which has been on the books in Dallas ‚Äì remember? ‚Äì for 13 years without an outbreak of public bathroom assaults) may fail, due to this graphic campaign of shock-and-lies.
I have said this before, because I love Texas (I have a soft spot for Houston, too) and I hate it when we look like we‚Äôre out of our gourds. This isn‚Äôt about liberal-versus-conservative; it‚Äôs about candor versus a pack of ugly, dirty-minded lies.
To date, nobody ‚Äì not a single single police official or rape-crisis counselor in any Texas or U.S. city with a similar ordinance ‚Äì has described a rash of sex predators claiming transgender status in order to gain access to women‚Äôs bathrooms. The ‚Äúbathroom predator‚Äù is an ugly, made-up myth.
We‚Äôre better than that. On Tuesday, it‚Äôs up to Houston to prove it.
James Douglas, president of the NAACP Houston branch, on Sunday urges the public to vote "yes" for Proposition 1 to protect the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance at a news conference.
Still waiting for anyone who's read the HERO ordinance to show me where it allows men in women's bathrooms. Lies.-A

Headline Text: Actors, politicians speak up as HERO vote nears - Nationally known figures, from Capitol Hill to Silicon Valley, are expressing their support
Article Text:
Democratic presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders. Actors Matt Bomer and Eva Longoria. Fortune 500 companies Apple and Hewlett-Packard.
From Capitol Hill to Hollywood to Silicon Valley, a number of nationally known figures are expressing support for the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, known as HERO. Their voices emerged last week as early voting drew to an end, and a close battle over the proposition was still predicted ahead of Tuesday's vote.
Proponents have hailed the proposition as an overdue ban on discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, as well as sex, race and other classifications. Opponents have characterized it as a dangerous move that would allow men dressed in women's clothing to enter women's restrooms and commit sexual assaults - actions that are banned by existing laws.
Locally, the fight has played out on living room television screens and front doorsteps, as dramatic ads aired and volunteers made calls and went knocking door to door. Mayoral candidates have debated the issue, brought forward by and passed under Mayor Annise Parker - the first openly lesbian mayor of a major American city - before a state Supreme Court decision landed it on the November ballot. Notable Texas figures such as Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, former Astros player Lance Berkman and Texans owner Bob McNair (who ultimately rescinded his financial support) already had aligned themselves against the ordinance. Last week, celebrities took to Twitter in support of the measure, using the hashtags #HERO and #YesOnProp1. The social media messages were widely shared.
"No one should face discrimination for who they are or who they love - I support efforts for equality in Houston & beyond," Clinton tweeted Thursday, signing off with "-H" said to indicate she wrote it personally.
White House spokesman Jeff Tiller on Thursday said President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden, though not formally endorsing the Houston measure, were "confident that the citizens of Houston will vote in favor of fairness and equality," according to an article by BuzzFeed. (The @VP and @POTUS accounts, however, were silent on the matter.)
A tweet from Sanders' account followed on Friday.
"In many states, it is legal to fire someone for being gay or to deny someone housing for being transgender," read the Sanders tweet. "That must change."
'Values I try to teach'
It wasn't just politicians who spoke up. On Tuesday, a tweet from Longoria said the actress was "proud" to support HERO. She included a link to a donation page for the Human Rights Campaign's Houston Equal Rights political action committee, which notes that actor Jesse Tyler Ferguson, of "Modern Family," and his husband would match every dollar donated up to $20,000.
"Join me in the fight," Longoria's tweet urged.
Actress Sally Field spoke in support of the ordinance at a news conference in Houston on Thursday. An athlete and another actor also appeared in two videos posted Friday to the Human Rights Campaign YouTube channel. "Work hard, play hard. Football in Texas raised me with these values," says Michael Sam, the first openly gay NFL draftee, who grew up near Galveston. "As part of a team, it didn't matter if you were black or white, gay or straight, we were all equals in football and in life."
Actor Matt Bomer, a Spring native, posed an ethical argument: "I was raised with the belief that everyone deserves to be treated equally. These are the same values I grew up with in Houston and they're the same values that I try to teach my kids."
In addition to Apple and Hewlett-Packard, corporate support for HERO came from General Electric, BASF and EMC Corp. They joined around 60 local businesses, including Dow Chemical, backing the proposition, according to a statement posted Friday by Houston Unites, the main campaign backing the proposition's passage.
"Our stores and our company are open to everyone, regardless of where they come from, what they look like, how they worship or who they love," read a statement from Apple posted by the coalition.
BASF said in the coalition's post: "Our ability to continue to invest and grow (in Houston and the surrounding area) depends on our ability to fully leverage the advantages of a multicultural city that offers equal rights for all."
'Every vote will count'
The dispute in America's fourth-largest city drew Friday headlines from Vice ("How Houston is Being Duped by Bigoted Zealots") and People Magazine ("Hillary Clinton, Sally Field, Matt Bomer and More Stars Rally to Fight Anti-Transgender Discrimination") as well as online commentary from LGBT advocacy groups.
On the ground, the local campaign described the support as a validation of its efforts.
"We've known from the very beginning that this was going to be a very close race," said Richard Carlbom, campaign manager for Houston Unites, the local group supporting the ordinance. "Every vote will count. That kind of attention and making sure people know this is coming up and on the ballot is really helpful."
But opponents said the support, arriving in the "last minute," spoke to the nature of the pro-HERO campaign.
"It's a desperate campaign resorting to desperate tactics," said Jared Woodfill, spokesman for Campaign for Houston. He said the celebrities were from outside the Houston area, whereas those opposing the ordinance were "people that would have to live under the law."

Headline Text: Why so down? Reasons abound for 2-5 Texans - QB circus, porous 'D' contribute to tailspin as midseason arrives
Article Text:
Texans
vs. Titans
When/where: Noon today; NRG Stadium.
TV/radio: CBS; 610 AM; 100.3 FM, 1180 AM (Spanish).
A Texans season once brimming with promise reaches the halfway mark Sunday roiling in chaos.
The hard knocks have kept coming long after HBO's "Hard Knocks" cameras left town. When much of America was watching in prime time, the team was only a manufactured soap opera. Now, it's the real deal.
In just the last eight days, a quarterback missed the team flight to Miami; the coach and general manager were at odds over how fast to get rid of the irresponsible QB; the team looked so bad in falling behind 41-0 to the Miami Dolphins that a national broadcaster called the players out for "loafing"; and the best offensive player was lost to a season-ending injury.
Even the Texans' mild-mannered owner, Bob McNair, got himself caught up in a civic controversy when he awkwardly rescinded a $10,000 donation to opponents of the proposed Houston Equal Rights Ordinance.
If it could go wrong, it has.
"I'm astonished the wheels have come off so completely so fast," said Spencer Tillman, a former Houston Oiler who serves as a television analyst for Texans preseason games and keeps close tabs on the team.
Loss of Foster stings
Despite the troubles, the Texans haven't played themselves out of postseason contention after five losses in seven games. A team that has fallen into 42-0 and 41-0 chasms over the last four weeks - almost unheard-of deficits in the parity-driven NFL - finds itself a single victory out of first place in the woebegone AFC South.
So hope still springs eternal in the collective heart of a beaten-down but doggedly loyal fan base that has gobbled up every ticket the 14-year-old NFL franchise has printed.
Should it?
"There's no replacing Arian Foster; that's the story everybody should be talking about," said Chris Myers, the recently retired Texans center. And normally, the loss of the team's star running back and most pivotal offensive player (Foster tore his Achilles tendon late in the already-lost Miami game) would be the topic du jour.
Instead, the recent focus has been on the relationship between coach Bill O'Brien and general manager Rick Smith and how they handled petulant quarterback Ryan Mallett, whose latest transgression was missing the Texans' charter flight to Florida.
O'Brien wanted Mallett cut immediately, but Smith overruled the second-year coach because the team wouldn't have had a backup for starter Brian Hoyer in last week's game. Mallett was released Tuesday, and O'Brien said his relationship with Smith remains a solid working "partnership."
As early as last season, when the team was doing well, O'Brien has pushed for more control in shaping the roster. But Smith, in his 10th year as GM, retains control of the draft and the support of McNair when conflicts arise.
The O'Brien-Smith tension followed McNair's own issues a few days earlier when he canceled his donation to opponents of the HERO ballot proposition.
In a written statement that quoted Robert F. Kennedy, McNair said he doesn't "believe in or tolerate personal or professional discrimination of any kind."
It was a sidebar distraction McNair didn't need with the Texans in such a bad state that he saw the need to make a rare locker-room visit following the debacle against the Dolphins.
While there, he was seen huddling with veteran nose tackle Vince Wilfork, who had been brought to Houston from New England to help the Texans reach a Super Bowl but has become a symbol of this season's shortcomings.
Wilfork was expected to be the glue for an emergent, J.J. Watt-led defense that, combined with Foster's running, would cancel out the Texans' apparent deficiencies at quarterback, where the repackaged journeyman Hoyer was being asked to take the reins.
Now, Foster's out of the picture, and Wilfork ...
"Vince Wilfork, (I) love him to death, but he's not the same player (he was as a Patriot)," said Rodney Harrison, a longtime NFL strong safety, two-time All-Pro and current NBC football analyst. "He absolutely has (had) no impact."
Mallett 'a train wreck'
Wilfork doesn't deserve to be singled out as the culprit for the Texans' flawed techniques and listless play on defense, but he's high on the short list.
At the top of the list could be O'Brien's handling of the team's quarterback situation, both this season and last. After not being satisfied with Ryan Fitzpatrick following a 9-7 season, the Texans dropped him and signed Hoyer.
O'Brien named Hoyer the starter before the team's third preseason game, but by the fourth quarter of the opener, he had been replaced by Mallett, who would start the next four games. Mallett was benched during the Colts game Oct. 8 and was caught on national TV sulking on the sidelines.
Mallett had become a growing tumor in the locker room through his irresponsible behavior - he also missed a training-camp practice because, ostensibly, he overslept - before being released last week.
"Mallett was a train wreck from the onset," Tillman said. "Even as an outsider, you could see that he was a threat to the team, the classic entitled millennial who acted like he deserved something he hadn't earned. Fixing problems on the field and off the field is about identifying threats. I can't understand how that problem was allowed to go on like it did."
But if getting rid of Mallett solves the off-field dynamics, there's still the question of whether this team will respond to O'Brien and play well enough to win in the second half of the season. Players haven't tuned the coach out, several team members say, and Wilfork was supportive of O'Brien in his talk with McNair. However, several said privately they were surprised by the coach's quick change at quarterback from Hoyer to Mallett and back to Hoyer in the first five games.
Essential for a Texans revival will be much greater week-to-week, series-to-series consistency from Hoyer, a measure of personnel continuity in the injury-wracked offensive line (only once has the entire starting lineup remained the same in consecutive games), and night-and-day improvement in tackling and pass coverage by the linebackers and secondary. Both groups seemed disinclined to lay a firm hand on anybody last Sunday, allowing the Dolphins to score touchdowns on four plays of 50 yards or longer.
"The tackling was awful in Miami," said Tillman, who works college football games weekly for Fox Sports. "Terrible angles, too, just fundamental stuff. ... I saw a clear lack of desire to go knock anybody on his watch pocket."
Bad impression
Harrison, who played 15 years in the NFL, concurred with Tillman's assessment. He, too, noticed something more troubling than subpar foot speed and/or flawed techniques when he watched, with "displeasure," the Miami game. He said the Texans looked "completely discouraged" to him, and that manifested itself in "some of their key players not even hustling. One guy who I particularly love, Brian Cushing, I saw him loaf on a couple of plays. And it was surprising to me (to see) that from a guy who (is known for) his work ethic."
Although Cushing explained away one play Harrison referred to by saying he pulled up because he thought the Dolphin he was targeting, receiver Jarvis Landry, had gone out of bounds, one wonders if the two season-wrecking knee injuries Cushing suffered in 2012 and 2013 have cost him that extra step he needs to be an elite NFL linebacker. Only Cushing or Wilfork or another badly underperforming free-agent acquisition, safety Rahim Moore, really knows what's going on inside their heads or how their bodies feel.
Tillman predicts the situation will become even more dire if the Texans veterans "don't step up immediately and take some leadership as a point of pride."
"They have to question their heart and their will," Tillman said. "Everybody in that locker room has to look at themselves hard. I'm calling out J.J. Watt. I'm calling out Cushing. And I'm calling out the coaches. I'm calling out (defensive coordinator) Romeo Crennel. They're either coaching (badly) or they're tolerating (mistakes). Either way, it's not acceptable."
There's still time
The Texans are fixable, insists Chester Pitts, a retired offensive lineman and an original Texan.
"It's tackling," Pitts said. "They know how to tackle. What happened in Miami should never happen to an NFL team. It's on (Crennel's) shoulders to get the defense where it needs to be."
Pitts suggested calling a "come to Jesus" players-only meeting or two, "which sometimes help." Big-picture changes aren't an option, Myers said. The Texans are far too deep into the season.
You can't throw out your offensive and defensive schemes, and you can't practice harder or longer. If anything, you have to back off. Every player is dealing with aches and pains to varying degrees.
"They've been down by 40 points twice in four weeks," Myers said, shaking his head. "That's probably never happened in NFL history. So you have to be asking yourself, as a player, where are we? What's going on? There's enough talent in the room. That was a team that won nine games last year. Somehow, they've got to go back to the basics and get their heads straight."

Headline Text: Actors, politicians speak up as HERO vote nears - Nationally known figures, from Capitol Hill to Silicon Valley, are expressing their support
Article Text:
Democratic presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders. Actors Matt Bomer and Eva Longoria. Fortune 500 companies Apple and Hewlett-Packard.
From Capitol Hill to Hollywood to Silicon Valley, a number of nationally known figures are expressing support for the Houston Equal Rights Ordinance, known as HERO. Their voices emerged last week as early voting drew to an end, and a close battle over the proposition was still predicted ahead of Tuesday's vote.
Proponents have hailed the proposition as an overdue ban on discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity, as well as sex, race and other classifications. Opponents have characterized it as a dangerous move that would allow men dressed in women's clothing to enter women's restrooms and commit sexual assaults - actions that are banned by existing laws.
Locally, the fight has played out on living room television screens and front doorsteps, as dramatic ads aired and volunteers made calls and went knocking door to door. Mayoral candidates have debated the issue, brought forward by and passed under Mayor Annise Parker - the first openly lesbian mayor of a major American city - before a state Supreme Court decision landed it on the November ballot. Notable Texas figures such as Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, former Astros player Lance Berkman and Texans owner Bob McNair (who ultimately rescinded his financial support) already had aligned themselves against the ordinance. Last week, celebrities took to Twitter in support of the measure, using the hashtags #HERO and #YesOnProp1. The social media messages were widely shared.
"No one should face discrimination for who they are or who they love - I support efforts for equality in Houston & beyond," Clinton tweeted Thursday, signing off with "-H" said to indicate she wrote it personally.
White House spokesman Jeff Tiller on Thursday said President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden, though not formally endorsing the Houston measure, were "confident that the citizens of Houston will vote in favor of fairness and equality," according to an article by BuzzFeed. (The @VP and @POTUS accounts, however, were silent on the matter.)
A tweet from Sanders' account followed on Friday.
"In many states, it is legal to fire someone for being gay or to deny someone housing for being transgender," read the Sanders tweet. "That must change."
'Values I try to teach'
It wasn't just politicians who spoke up. On Tuesday, a tweet from Longoria said the actress was "proud" to support HERO. She included a link to a donation page for the Human Rights Campaign's Houston Equal Rights political action committee, which notes that actor Jesse Tyler Ferguson, of "Modern Family," and his husband would match every dollar donated up to $20,000.
"Join me in the fight," Longoria's tweet urged.
Actress Sally Field spoke in support of the ordinance at a news conference in Houston on Thursday. An athlete and another actor also appeared in two videos posted Friday to the Human Rights Campaign YouTube channel. "Work hard, play hard. Football in Texas raised me with these values," says Michael Sam, the first openly gay NFL draftee, who grew up near Galveston. "As part of a team, it didn't matter if you were black or white, gay or straight, we were all equals in football and in life."
Actor Matt Bomer, a Spring native, posed an ethical argument: "I was raised with the belief that everyone deserves to be treated equally. These are the same values I grew up with in Houston and they're the same values that I try to teach my kids."
In addition to Apple and Hewlett-Packard, corporate support for HERO came from General Electric, BASF and EMC Corp. They joined around 60 local businesses, including Dow Chemical, backing the proposition, according to a statement posted Friday by Houston Unites, the main campaign backing the proposition's passage.
"Our stores and our company are open to everyone, regardless of where they come from, what they look like, how they worship or who they love," read a statement from Apple posted by the coalition.
BASF said in the coalition's post: "Our ability to continue to invest and grow (in Houston and the surrounding area) depends on our ability to fully leverage the advantages of a multicultural city that offers equal rights for all."
'Every vote will count'
The dispute in America's fourth-largest city drew Friday headlines from Vice ("How Houston is Being Duped by Bigoted Zealots") and People Magazine ("Hillary Clinton, Sally Field, Matt Bomer and More Stars Rally to Fight Anti-Transgender Discrimination") as well as online commentary from LGBT advocacy groups.
On the ground, the local campaign described the support as a validation of its efforts.
"We've known from the very beginning that this was going to be a very close race," said Richard Carlbom, campaign manager for Houston Unites, the local group supporting the ordinance. "Every vote will count. That kind of attention and making sure people know this is coming up and on the ballot is really helpful."
But opponents said the support, arriving in the "last minute," spoke to the nature of the pro-HERO campaign.
"It's a desperate campaign resorting to desperate tactics," said Jared Woodfill, spokesman for Campaign for Houston. He said the celebrities were from outside the Houston area, whereas those opposing the ordinance were "people that would have to live under the law."
